TO STOP THE 'ANARCHY' IN U.S. IMMIGRATION

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 414 words


To the Editor:

Joaquin Avila, president of Maldef, the Mexican American Legal Defense Fund
(Op-Ed Dec. 17), is in a better position than most to know that the failure of
state employer-sanction laws to deter illegal immigration, rather than being an
argument against the nowfailed Simpson-Mazzoli bill, is a confirmation of the
ever more urgent need for strong Federal leadership in immigration enforcement.

he states' unfamiliarity with immigration and nationality practice, the
deficiencies of most current ID documents and our courts' uncertainties about
the proper state role in immigration have all worked to undermine the
effectiveness of state laws. In at least one state, California, litigation
supported by special-interest groups, such as Maldef, helped stall enforcement.

The experience clearly shows that strong Federal leadership, based on a
comprehensive, tamperproof, nondiscriminatory ID system, is a must. Mr. Avila's
misgivings notwithstanding, the remarkably low percentage of error and fraud in
the astronomical volume of credit card transactions shows that it is technically
attainable.

And after reading his arguments, I wondered why Maldef opposed the bill at all,
since employers' greed, the porosity of any ID system, the exception planned for
small enterprises and the expanded temporary-workers program would add up to
just as many or more immigrants as ever.

Perhaps Maldef's greatest fear was not that the bill would not have worked but
that it just might have begun to end the current anarchy, in which so many have
a stake, and to channel long-established flows of undocumented immigration into
legal channels.

Mr. Avila mischaracterizes the objectives of immigration reform as ''to stop the
flow of immigrants and to save, for citizens, jobs now held by undocumented
workers.'' More accurately, the bill would have reasserted control over our
borders, once again making the composition and volume of our annual immigration
flow a matter of national choice rather than a process of immigrant
self-selection.

It may well be that we will accept as much or more immigration once we have
reasserted control, but at least we as a society will be able to say it was not
left entirely to chance.  DAVID E. SIMCOX Washington, Dec. 20, 1982

NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

BYLINE: By Robin Herman and Laurie Johnston

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 213 words


Between Two Lands

F or the last year, America has been the drab and barren rooms of a Brooklyn
detention center for 32 Afghans who say they fled their native land last winter
because of Communism and political persecution.

The new year holds no brighter prospects for the refugees in the Flushing Avenue
center as they await deportation hearings and appeals before the Immigration and
Naturalization Service. The Lawyers' Committee for International Human Rights
has been working on their behalf.

''We are 32,'' the Afghans wrote in a letter last week to the American Civil
Liberties Union, asking for its help. ''Most of us been since January '82 in the
detention. All don't know our foult and guilt, but from homelessness away from
our parents and other dears, we have come here and have sought asylum. We are
writing our miserable condition from behind the jail bars to you, and do hope
from your high dignity to pay our attention for our release for the sake of HOLY
CHRISTMAS and NEW YEAR.''

The two-page letter concluded, ''We have nothing to offer, but tearful eyes and
broken hearts and all the time to pray to God, 'God Bless America.' ''

WHAT THE HOUSE SAID IN NOT VOTING AN IMMIGRATION BILL;
News Analysis

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 12, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1246 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 26


In refusing to pass a comprehensive immigration bill, Congress made a statement
about immigration policy as profound as any that could have been made through
legislation.

In the House of Representatives, the debate was diffuse but passionate, and most
of it took place between 11 P.M. and 1 A.M. on two nights, so the questions it
raised may be lost on those who renew the campaign for thorough revision of the
immigration law next year. But the questions are important.

The House, living up to its name, represented the diverse regional, political
and economic interests that have a stake in immigration.  Three hundred
amendments were proposd for the House version, and only a few had been dealt
with when the House abandoned work on the bill on the afternoon of Dec. 18.
There was a sharp contrast in the more patrician Senate, which, by a vote of 80
to 19, approved a similar bill sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican
of Wyoming.

Fears Found Behind Tactics

The chief sponsor of the House bill, Representative Romano L.  Mazzoli, Democrat
of Kentucky, initially accused his opponents of using ''dilatory tactics.'' It
soon became clear that those tactics were motivated by deep fears that his
proposal might lead to racial and ethnic discrimination, yet might not be
effective in curtailing illegal immigration. The bill would have required
employers to check documents on all job applicants to determine whether they
were citizens or aliens authorized to work in the United States.

The premise of the bill was that illegal aliens were attracted by job
opportunities, and that employers must therefore be forbidden to hire them. To
enforce that prohibition, the bill would have established fines and prison terms
for employers who knowingly hired illegal aliens. As an offset, the bill offered
legal status to several million illegal aliens who entered the country before
1980.

Supporters of the bill had to make a leap of faith. No one element of the bill,
was very popular, especially not employer sanctions or amnesty for illegal
aliens. But somehow, it was said, the whole would be more popular and effective
than the sum of its parts. In the end, the House of Representatives could not
accept that logic.

Representative Jerry M. Patterson, a California Democrat, asked: ''If we in the
House of Representatives are at odds over so many provisions, what does this
mean? I would like to suggest that our disenchantment with this legislation
mirrors the position of our constituencies.''

Witnesses Were Opposed

Virtually every argument made by opponents of the bill on the floor of the House
had been made, in hearings, by spokesmen for Hispanic American groups, blacks,
labor unions, agricultural producers and other business interests. Somehow the
arguments had more force when they were made by Representatives who are members
of minority groups such as E. (Kika) de la Garza and Mickey Leland of Texas,
Robert Garcia of the Bronx, Edward R. Roybal of California and John Conyers Jr.
of Michigan.

Their speeches were full of emotion, ignited by the knowledge that many members
of Congress wanted to eliminate the amnesty from the bill.

On the House side, there were many more people who knew something about
immigration and they actively participated in the floor debate even if they had
not been exposed to the bill in the Judiciary Committee. They wanted to know
precisely how the bill would affect their districts, which in some cases include
large numbers of Mexican-Americans, and they were not satisfied with the
answers.

Some surprise was expressed that the bill was torpedoed at the last hour after
so much progress. Among people who followed it closely, there was less surprise.
Members of Congress had been much more critical of the bill in their private
comments than in their public statements.

Topic Vulnerable to Politics

As Mr. Mazzoli said, the Democratic leadership of the House gave his bill a low
priority. But Mr. Mazzoli himself perhaps underestimated the partisan political
signifiance of the issue. The experience of the last two weeks suggests that
immigration is a subject highly vulnerable to partisan politics.

''This was not clearly a bipartisan issue, as many people thought it was,'' said
Dale Frederick Swartz, president of the National Immigration, Refugee and
Citizenship Forum, a private nonprofit group. ''The Democrats may have more to
lose. The major elements of the Democratic Party coalition, including blacks,
Hispanics, organized labor and liberal religious groups, have had serious
differences of opinion, but may be in the process of resolving them.''

Mr. Mazzoli worked well with Mr. Simpson and other Republicans, in Congress and
in the Reagan Administration, but he failed to develop the necessary support for
the bill at the top of his own party. The bill sent to the floor of the House
did not satisfy the Democratic floor leader, Representative Jim Wright of Texas.
The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said that it was not a
Democratic bill, that he was not ''enamored'' of it and that he brought it up
only as a ''courtesy'' to President Reagan.

Opponents Cared More

Ultimately, the bill failed because the opponents cared more deeply about it
than the proponents. The opponents included the people most directly affected:
Texans, Californians and Hispanic Americans. ''I can't find anyone in the State
of Texas who is for this bill,'' said Representative Martin Frost, a Texas
Democrat. Representative Tony Coelho, a Democrat, said, ''There's almost no
support for it in California,'' his home state.

By contrast, the people who are harmed by illegal immigration, the people who
lose jobs to illegal aliens willing to work for lower wages, do not always know
it. In a recession with high unemployment, the economic effects of illegal
immigration cannot easily be separated from the effects of overall fiscal and
monetary policies.

The challenge to the opponents of the Simpson-Mazzoli bill is to propose an
alternative, and they say they intend to do so next year.  Future debate on the
issue is likely to give more weight to foreign policy considerations, including
the economic and political factors that impel people to leave home. Some
supporters of the Simpson-Mazzoli bill, including several State Department
officials, were surprised when the Senate of Mexico adopted a resolution this
month expressing grave concern about the bill's effects on ''the labor and human
rights of migrant workers in the United States.''

A State Department official said: ''I don't think we are prepared to regard the
Mexican Senate resolution as necessarily the viewpoint of the Government of
Mexico on this issue.'' But it certainly buttressed the case for greater
consultation between the two countries.

With high unemployment and economic uncertainty, some members of Congress such
as Representative Dan Lungren, Republican of California, expressed a fear that
there would be growing resentment of immigrants and refugees. Most participants
in the debate said they felt a duty to prevent such a backlash.

JOBLESSNESS TAKES TOLL ON CANADA'S POPULATION

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1459 words

DATELINE: PORT ALBERNI, British Columbia


Canada, which has always needed a constant flow of settlers to harvest its
plentiful resources, is sharply reducing its immigration quotas and radically
revising demographic projections in the face of high and, in some cases, chronic
unemployment.

Fifteen years ago, a Government study projected that this vast land, the
second-largest in the world, would continue to grow in population until it held
50 million people, double today's 24 million. Now, as scores of one-industry
regions are becoming noindustry regions, such visions have been greatly trimmed.

Lloyd Axworthy, Minister of Employment and Immigration, acknowledged in an
interview earlier this month that current expectations were that Canada's
economic development could sustain only limited population growth and that the
total would level off at around 28 million by the turn of the century.

Internal Migration

At the same time, Mr. Axworthy said that Canada faces a period of internal
migration as people moved in search of jobs.

''A major part of our economic problem is that we have the wrong people in the
wrong places doing the wrong jobs, and we need to get things back into
synchronization,'' Mr. Axworthy, a Princeton-trained urban planner from
Winnipeg, said in his Ottawa office.

Just last month, Mr. Axworthy cut back the annual immigration quota to 105,000
from 140,000. Since refugee programs were not cut, the reduction affected
skilled immigrants, the people that Canada had sought, particularly in the
postwar period, for work in primary industries related to mining, forestry,
energy, agriculture and fishing.

But these once labor-intensive industries have in recent years become
overwhelmingly capital-absorbing. The huge mechanized farms of the prairies are
run essentially by families using several million dollars' worth of equipment.

Mining is only rarely a pick-and-shovel operation, relying more and more on
giant earthmovers. And even the ax-wielding lumberjack who symbolized frontier
employment is being replaced by diesel machines that uproot giant trees.

Jobless Rate at 12.4%

Such transformations in work forces are taking place all over the world, but
nowhere are they more sweeping and dramatic than in Canada, where
single-industry cities and towns stretch from the Atlantic to the Pacific, and
where the overall unemployment rate stands at 12.4 percent.

There are localities such as this beautifully situated lumber town of 20,000
people, which three years ago had the second-highest percapita income of any
city in the nation, nearly $22,000 (Canadian). Today, 6,000 people are
collecting full or partial unemployment benefits, while another 2,000 have
exhausted these yearlong payments and are on provincial welfare programs.

At the offices of the International Woodworkers of America, the predominant
union in the region, officers sharply criticized the Government for permitting
the export of untrimmed logs to the Orient and for maintaining immigration at
too high a level. They also expressed concern that even with an economic
recovery, employment for mill hands and lumbermen would not reach levels of the
past.

''None of us now thinks our kids will easily find jobs in the industry,'' said
Nick Bos, a union vice president.  But at the moment, forestry is all there is,
except for fishing, and a recent Government report made it clear that the major
problem of the Port Alberni fishing fleet was that there were too many fishermen
and not enough fish.

Government Appraisal

That report is apparently being echoed in a still confidential Government
appraisal of the 33,000-worker Newfoundland fishery.  According to Government
officials, it suggests that in terms of efficient competition with foreign
factory ships, the inshore fishermen, who have been setting out in their boats
for generations, could be replaced by a few modern ocean trawlers.

Stories of similar dislocations recur every few days and form a regular feature
of Canadian newspapers. And while it is not always clear which layoffs are the
temporary result of market fluctuations and which reflect long-term reduction of
labor forces, the two are closely linked.

''A lot of companies are using the recession as a time to get lean,'' Mr.
Axworthy said. ''In the 70's we had a growth of employment rate of close to 5
percent a year, the highest in the world.'' Some of that growth and the high
salaries that accompanied it were, he suggested, undisciplined, reducing
productivity levels.  Loss of productivity in turn eroded Canada's advantage in
international trade, on which this relatively underpopulated national market
must depend.

Widely fluctuating fortunes are common in the boom-and-bust cycles that plague
all commodity exporting economies, and Canada has been through this experience
before. What makes it different this time, and worse, economists and
demographers say, is the knowledge that a return to prosperous sales is not
likely to restore high employment.  In an economy that may need additional
consumers more than it needs additional producers, this translates into a social
and political challenge.

Social Planning Urged

Howard Pawley, the Prime Minister of Manitoba whose New Democratic Party heads
what he describes as the only social democratic Government in North America,
said in a recent interview that the country needed planning for a society where
more and more people would be employed in the service sector.

Mr. Axworthy, for his part, said he was proud of job-sharing programs under
which workers in retrenching industries share jobs and receive partial
unemployment insurance. He said he hoped that such payments would increasingly
enable the partly idled workers to take advantage of retraining programs.

He also mentioned a need for diversified secondary industries.  Traditionally,
he said, ''Canadians have looked to the huge megaprojects to help them, but now
we see that these approaches have failed, and what we want is to encourage the
formation of hundreds of smaller, locally based activities.''

Mr. Axworthy has also emphasized another traditional Canadian economic strategy
- Government financing of transportation as a means of priming the pump for
industrial suppliers. He said that a $3 billion program for modernizing the
railroads had already led to the formation of a number of companies that are
developing internationally competitive products and techniques.

Jobless Are Moving

But he acknowledged that a great many Canadians would have to leave their homes
as traditional employment patterns continued to change.  Recent visits to dozens
of small and large Canadian settlements suggest that internal movements have
already begun. Towns such as Asbestos, Quebec, and Uranium City, Saskatchewan,
have lost jobs and are losing people as demand for the ores they were named
after has dropped sharply.

Some of the 9l,829 people who came to Sudbury, Ontario, because the city lies
atop the world's richest nickel deposit are drifting away now that unemployment
has hovered above 30 percent for seven months.  Spokesmen for the Toronto-based
Inco Ltd., the town's major employer, said that even after its idled mine and
smelter return to full operation, ''We will still have between a half and a
third of the staff we had a few years back and people can no longer expect jobs
with us just because their fathers and uncles worked here.''

For the first time in nearly 100 years, there is no mining activity in the
Yukon. With the closing of the huge Cyprus Anvil lead and zinc mine, the
territory's rail service has stopped and 5,000 of the 26,000 people in the
region have already left. Schefferville, Quebec, a community of 4,000, is facing
extinction next spring when the mine operated by the Iron Ore Company of Canada,
the isolated town's only reason for existence, shuts down.

And earlier this month, the Bowater newsprint mill that was by far the largest
employer in Corner Brook, Newfoundland's second-largest city, announced it would
dismiss 750 workers because of a sharp decline in European demand for newsprint.

Mayor George Hutchings called the loss catastrophic for the community of 33,000,
and said it was equal to the loss of 20,000 jobs in a city such as Toronto.

AROUND THE NATION;
U.S. Will Permit Entry Of Rumanian Girl, 16

SECTION: Section A; Page 8, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 133 words


The Immigration and Naturalization Service reversed its earlier decision and
granted permission yesterday for a 16-year-old Rumanian girl to join her family
in the United States.

The girl, Ildiko Zudor, is expected to leave Bucharest next week for a reunion
with her parents in Philadelphia, according to H.  Ronald Klasko, an attorney
for the Zudor family.

Rumanian officials granted the girl an exit passport last January, the family
said. But United States immigration officials denied her application for entry
because the girl's parents, Alexandru and Edith Zudor, who had come to the
United States seeking medical aid for their 12-year-old son, were denied
political asylum. They said they planned to reapply for asylum at a deportation
hearing next week.

Oregon Guru Rebuffed in Bid On Permanent U.S. Residency

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section B; Page 4, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 152 words

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 23


Immigration officials have refused to grant permanent residence status to
Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh, a guru whose disciples took political control of the
Oregon town of Antelope.

Followers of the mystic said they would appeal the decision, which was made
known Wednesday.  Immigration and Naturalization Service officials rejected two
applications for the 51-year-old guru, who lives on a commune called
Rajneeshpuram.

The guru, who is Indian, sought residence as a religious leader and because he
needed medical treatment available only in the United States.

Carl Houseman of the immigration service in Portland said the mystic did not
qualify as a religious leader and ''false and misleading statements were made
concerning his dire need for medical treatment.''

AN AFRICAN POET AT NORTHWESTERN LOSES A STEP IN DEPORTATION FIGHT

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL SHEPPARD Jr., Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 9, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 631 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 21


In a letter to Immigration and Naturalization authorities here, the State
Department has said it knows of no reason why Dennis Brutus, a black poet in
exile for 10 years from southern Africa, should not be deported.

Mr. Brutus, a 58-year-old professor of African and English literature at
Northwestern University, has for a year been fighting deportation.

Mr. Brutus contends that if he is deported he would be a target for assasination
by the South African secret police because of his criticism of the apartheid
policies in southern Africa.

As evidence Mr. Brutus and his supporters say that he has been imprisoned in
South Africa and shot by the secret police.

Official Concurs on Fears

In his advisory opinion to immigration authorities, Lawrence Arthur, chief of
the asylum division, Bureau of Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, said his
agency concurred with Mr. Brutus that he had ''well-founded fear of persecution
in South Africa.'' He added, however, that Mr. Brutus had not demonstrated that
he faced such persecution in his home country, Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe, now a black
governed nation, was Rhodesia, a white-governed British territory, when Mr.
Brutus was born there.

''He claims fear of persecution by agents of the South African Government should
he return to Zimbabwe and believes that the Zimbabwean authorities will prove
unable to offer effective protection to him,'' Mr. Arthur's opinion said. ''He
cites the assassination of a prominent African National Congress official in
Zimbabwe to support this belief.'' The citation was to Joe Gqabi, who was
machine-gunned last summer.

''We would point out,'' the Arthur letter continued, ''that it has never been
proven that this assassination was committed by South African agents. In this
connection, we note that an adult son of Mr.  Brutus lives in Zimbabwe,
apparently without threat to his safety.

''Nevertheless, given Mr. Brutus's expressed fear of return to Zimbabwe we would
not recommend that he be returned there.'' Mr. Arthur said Mr. Brutus had lived
and worked in Britain after he left Africa in 1966 and entered the United States
from there many times, using no@nimmigrant visas.

Said He Would Return to Britain

To obtain such visas, he said, Mr. Brutus listed a home abroad to which he
intended to return. He listed Britain, Mr. Arthur said.  Mr. Arthur said it is
his agency's opinion that Mr. Brutus could return to Britain, where his wife
lives, upon application for reentry.

Mr. Brutus said he was not sure that he could get a permanent visa in Britain.
But in any case, he said, the human rights aspect of his case in the United
States was more important.

''The reasons for excluding me from the United States are not good ones,'' he
said. ''The U.S. claims to take a position in support of human rights and
democracy but often does not.

Mr. Brutus's problems began not as a result of any wrongdoing on his part. When
he made periodic application for extension of the temporary United States visa,
which allowed him to work, he was using his British passport.

His Passport Was Replaced

But when Rhodesia separated from Britain and then became independent as Zimbabwe
in 1980, Mr. Brutus's British passport was revoked. Zimbabwe issued a new one,
but he was late in applying for an extension here. Then for six months, an
immigration office here could not find his file.

By continuing to teach at Northwestern, he was placed in violation of a law that
forbids employment by an alien with an expired visa.  A deportion hearing here
is scheduled for Jan. 10.

Shows Holiday Spirit;
Spirit

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 26, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 124 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18


Saturday sessions of the Senate and the House of Representatives are none too
popular with lawmakers who have other things to do with their time one week
before Christmas.

There were only a few dozen members on the floor of the House when
Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, a Kentucky Democrat who is the chief sponsor
of an immigration bill being considered by the House, moved to take up the bill
today.

There was a roar of laughter when the results of a vote on Mr.  Mazzoli's
request were announced: 244 to 7, according to the House Speaker, Thomas P.
O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts.

However, subsequent quorum calls and roll-call votes showed that more than 300
of the 435 House members were on Capitol Hill.

DISCUSSION ENDED ON ALIENS MEASURE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 29, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 890 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18


A comprehensive bill to revise the nation's immigration laws seemed to be dead
today, barring an unexpected extension of this post-election session of
Congress.

The House of Representatives finished eight and a half hours of deliberations on
the bill with nearly 300 proposed amendments still awaiting consideration.

Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, the chief sponsor of the bill, looked downcast
and disappointed as he left the floor of the House and told reporters this
afternoon, ''Unless there is some kind of divine intervention, I guess probably
this is it.''

Mr. Mazzoli, a Kentucky Democrat, said that ''the search for perfection, the
futile, quixotic search for perfection,'' had made it impossible for the House
to complete action on the bill. Last August the Senate passed a comprehensive
immigration bill generally similar to the one debated on the floor of the House
for the last three days.

A Combination of Opponents

An unusual combination of Hispanic-American organizations, blacks, labor unions,
business interests and agricultural producers worked against key provisions of
the bill, especially the section establishing fines and prison terms for
employers who knowingly hire illegal aliens.

Mr. Mazzoli said he still hoped that this Congress would pass the immigration
bill that he introduced with Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming. But
the Representative conceded that such action was highly unlikely in the final
days of a session focusing almost exclusively on appropriations bills.

''We could beat any of those amendments,'' he said, referring to proposed
changes sought by critics of the bill, ''but I don't know if we could beat them
all.''

In the course of debate, it became clear that the amendments were not merely a
delaying tactic, but a true reflection of deep concerns shared by many members
of the House.

Critics Dominate Proceedings

Opponents of the bill dominated today's proceedings as they offered one proposal
after another to reduce what they said was the bill's potential for
discrimination against Hispanic Americans and members of other ethnic or racial
minority groups.

The bill would require all job applicants to offer identification documents to
demonstrate to employers that they were either citizens or aliens authorized to
work in the United States.

It would also establish civil and criminal penalties for employers who knowingly
hired illegal aliens. But it would offer legal status to several million illegal
aliens who entered the United States before 1980.

Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza, a Texas Democrat who is chairman of the
House Agriculture Committee, said that even though his family had been in the
Southwest for 250 years ''anyone who looks like me is going to have to identify
himself every time he asks for a job.''

'Imposition on Individual Liberty'

Mr. de la Garza said the identification provision was ''an imposition on
individual liberty,'' and for this reason he opposed the bill. ''People have
trouble pronouncing my name in the realms of Capitol Hill,'' he said. ''Can you
imagine what happens if I show up looking for a job in Alabama or west Texas or
Kentucky, maybe?''

Supporters of the bill contend that employers could not discriminate because
they would have to examine documents for citizens as well as aliens. But
Representative Tony Coelho, a California Democrat, said that employers would be
much more likely to suspect the authenticity of the documents offered by Mexican
Americans, and maintained that serious discrimination might result.

Representative Dan Lungren, a California Republican who supports the bill, said
the problem of illegal immigration would not go away.  If the bill is not passed
the legislative process can start over again next year, he said, but it was
considered unlikely that the next Congress would establish a comprehensive set
of immigration controls just before a Presidential election.

Thus, Congress will probably not give serious consideration to the subject again
for five or six years, Mr. Lungren said, warning that at that time ''we will be
tempted to pass a bill that is Draconian in its sweep and detail.''

Democratic Leaders Criticized

Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., Republican of Florida, complained of what he
said was the ''shabby way in which the leadership has treated this particular
bill.'' The general debate began after 10 P.M. Thursday and Friday.

In his remarks to reporters this afternoon Mr. Mazzoli also expressed some
irritation at the way in which the bill had been handled by the Democratic
leaders of the House. ''All we needed was time,'' he said, ''and the leadership
felt that other things were somehow more important. I would dispute that
seriously.''

The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, said the
Democratic leaders had agreed to bring up the bill ''as a courtesy'' to
President Reagan.

The Administration, especially the Department of Justice, has strongly supported
the measure, saying it would permit the United States to re-establish control of
its borders.

THE WORLD;
Thatcher Loses But Stays On

BYLINE: By Henry Giniger, Milt Freudenheim and Carlyle C. Douglas

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 2; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 202 words


The vote last week didn't bring down the Government but it did point up economic
and racial tensions now besetting Britain. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's
cabinet suffered its first major defeat in the House of Commons on a bill to
relax immigration rules in some instances and tighten them in others.

Citing Mrs. Thatcher's promise to curb immigration from Asia, 20 right-wing
Conservatives deserted and joined with opposition Laborites and Liberals to
defeat the bill, 290 to 272. The opposition objected to provisions that sought
to discourage immigrant men from entering Britain through bogus marriages to
naturalized female citizens. Labor and Liberal members saw this provision as
sexist and racist while Conservative dissidents took a dim view of provisions
that would ease immigration for some categories. High unemployment and violence
in minority-dominated areas of British cities have made immigration one of the
country's most hotly debated problems.

Henry Giniger, Milt Frdeudenheim and Carlyle C. Douglas

AROUND THE NATION;
26 on Coast Indicted In Alien Smuggling Ring

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Page 12, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 164 words

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 17


Twenty-six people have been indicted on charges growing out of what the Federal
authorities described as a major ring smuggling Mexicans into the United States.

The 144-count indictment charged the 26 with conspiracy, bribery of a Federal
immigration official and transportation of illegal aliens, United States
Attorney Peter Nunez said.

According to the indictment on Thursday, a Border Patrol investigator, Hector
Encinas, was paid about $40,000 in bribes for information about immigration
checkpoints around the Salton Sea, which is 150 miles southeast of Los Angeles.

Mr. Encinas, however, was pretending to be corrupt and eventually became so
trusted he was made bookkeeper for the alleged ring, Mr. Nunez said. Another
investigator, Ron Cooper, posed as a former convict and was hired as a driver
for one of the ring's members, Mr. Nunez said.

Edward O'Connor, a regional immigration director, said the ring frequently
abused, raped and robbed the aliens it smuggled.

DEBATE IS HEATED OVER IMMIGRATION

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 13, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 799 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17


The House of Representatives continued debate today on a comprehensive
immigration bill, and supporters of the measure said its fate depended on the
length of the current postelection session of Congress.

From 10:25 Thursday night to 12:25 this morning, the House debated the bill,
which, according to a Senate report, ''represents the first comprehensive
immigration reform effort in the United States in 30 years.''

Representative Edward R. Roybal, Democrat of California, complained, ''We took
time during the day to debate a bill that deals only with dirt and wild animals
and the wilderness of this nation, but late at night we debate a bill that
affects millions of individuals.''

The House bill, like one passed by the Senate in August, tries to halt the
influx of illegal aliens by forbidding employers to hire them. The bills would
establish civil and criminal penalties for knowingly hiring illegal aliens, but
they would also offer legal status to several million illegal aliens who entered
the United States before 1980.

More Than 3.5 Million Aliens

The number of people who would qualify for the amnesty is not known. The Census
Bureau has estimated that there were 3.5 million to 6 million illegal aliens in
the country in 1978. Many experts say the number has probably increased since
then.

Congress is expected to adjourn in the next few days. Supporters of the
immigration bill said a parliamentary tangle in the Senate over a stopgap
spending bill and a proposal to increase the Federal gasoline tax, might give
the House time to finish work on immigration.

Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky, the chief sponsor of the
immigration bill, said, ''The only thing we have going for us is gridlock in the
Senate.'' He added that supporters of the bill were confident they could answer
any opponents' arguments if they had sufficient time.

Groups in Opposition

The eagerness of lawmakers to return home was thus a major obstacle to passage
of the bill. In addition, Hispanic groups, the American Civil Liberties Union,
the Chamber of Commerce of the United States and many growers of fruit and
vegetables oppose the bill, especially the section establishing employer
sanctions.

When the majority leader, Representative Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, said
that the bill would probably be debated again Saturday, there was hissing from
members who believe that the legislation should not be taken up.

The Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said, ''I'm not enamored of the bill myself,
to be perfectly truthful.'' But he said he had allowed the bill to come up
because he had received numerous requests from Attorney General William French
Smith and from Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the Judiciary
Committee.

Mr. Rodino, Democrat of New Jersey, said he had been urging his colleagues to
deal with the problem of illegal aliens for 10 years.  Since then, ''the problem
has grown much worse,'' he said, adding, ''I do not believe this Government and
the Congress should tolerate further delay.''

''Further delays,'' he said, ''will, in effect, regularize the current situation
of an underground and exploitable segment of our population, beyond the
protection of our laws.''

He defended the bill's amnesty provision, saying there was no way to ''round up
millions of people and deport them without considering each individual's
circumstances.''

Representative Don Edwards, Democrat of California, who has spent much of his
House career working on the civil rights of racial and ethnic minority groups,
opposed the immigration bill. He said it ''accelerates the potential for
increased violations of civil and constitutional rights.''

The possibility of racial discrimination is inherent in the employer sanctions,
he said, and ''employer sanctions are the heart of the bill.''

Representative Dan Lungren, a California Republican, said discrimination was
already a fact of life for illegal aliens living here as ''second-class
citizens.'' He supported the bill and lamented the inability of the United
States to control the movement of aliens across its borders. ''When a law is not
enforced year after year after year, what does that do to our credibility?'' he
asked.

Mr. Lungren, Mr. Rodino and Mr. Mazzoli all denied that the bill would encourage
discrimination against Hispanic workers or members of other minority groups. But
Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said virtually no
Hispanic groups supported the bill.  ''Don't they know anything about their own
problems?'' he asked.

THATCHER CABINET LOSES VOTE ON BILL

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 391 words

DATELINE: LONDON, Dec. 16


Right-wing Conservatives joined forces with opposition members today to hand
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher her first major parliamentary defeat by voting
down a bill intended to relax immigration.

Twenty members of Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party voted against her
Government, helping to produce the 290-to-272 defeat in the Commons.

The rebellious Tories voted against the bill on the ground that it did not keep
a 1979 election promise to curb Asian immigration.  Opposition Labor and Liberal
members denounced the proposal as racially and sexually discriminatory. The
defeat of the bill was not considered important enough to bring down the
Government.

It was not immediately clear which side would benefit by a rewriting of the
bill, which was intended to relax immigration rules as applied to naturalized
female citizens and to put an end to the practice of immigrants entering by the
arrangement of bogus marriages. The law had been prepared by Home Secretary
William Whitelaw, who had come under fire from elements in his party for taking
too liberal a stance on the immigration question.

Prompt Action Urged

Mrs. Thatcher later told the House of Commons that her Government would not be
pressed into a quick revision of the bill, which must be presented again within
40 days.

''If the Home Secretary is properly to consider the effect of the debate last
night and the views expressed,'' she said, ''we must have time to do so.''

David Steel, leader of the Liberals, called for prompt action on the measure
that ''will take account of the view of the great majority of members.''

The bill was the Government's attempt to set rules under which immigrant women
with British citizenship could send for non-British spouses or fiances, a right
already held by all male citizens and by women born in Britain.

In an attempt to discourage a growing practice of bogus marriages, arranged for
the sole purpose of gaining a man's admission to Britain, the legislation
provided for the deportation of immigrant men whose marriages failed in less
than two years. And male fiances were to be permitted entry only if the marriage
took place within six months.

HOUSE BEGINS ITS DEBATE ON IMMIGRATION BILL AS ADJOURNMENT NEARS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 860 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16


The House of Representatives began an impassioned debate on a comprehensive
immigration bill today, with opponents complaining that Congress had too little
time left to finish work on the legislation.

By a vote of 257 to 137, the House agreed to bring the bill to the floor under a
rule permitting five hours of general debate. It set no limit on the number of
amendments that could be offered.

Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky, the chief sponsor of the
legislation, said it had been studied and ''worked over more carefully than
perhaps any other piece of legislation'' in this Congress. He said 300 witnesses
testified on the bill in 100 hours of hearings over 14 days.

In August the Senate voted, 80 to 19, to approve a somewhat similar bill,
sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming. Both measures are
designed to stem the flow of illegal aliens by establishing a system of fines
and prison terms for employers who knowingly hire them.

Would Offer Amnesty

The bills would also offer an amnesty to several million illegal aliens who
entered the United States before 1980. In addition, they would require employers
to examine passports, Social Security cards, birth certificates or other
documents to verify that job applicants were either United States citizens or
aliens authorized to work in this country.

Opponents of the bill urged that their colleagues not even take it up.
Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, said: ''This
is a complicated bill. It is not something that should be taken up at a time
when most members are absent in the waning days of a Congressional session.''

He said the amnesty would have a ''tremendous'' ripple effect, permitting aliens
to bring in their children, brothers and sisters from abroad.

The bill is known as the Immigration Reform and Control Act, but Representative
Edward R. Roybal, Democrat of California, said it would provide ''neither
control nor reform.'' The complexity and importance of the bill, he said, were
reflected in the fact that members have filed nearly 300 amendments for possible
consideration.

The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, said
earlier this week that even if the House passed some version of the bill, there
would not be enough time for a conference committee to reconcile differences
with the Senate. But Mr. Mazzoli and other supporters of the bill have kept
pushing for it. If it is not passed before final adjournment, the legislation
dies, and the next Congress would have to start work on the issue anew in
January. Congress is expected to adjourn over the weekend or early next week.

Administration Backs Bill

Mr. O'Neill said today that he had told aides to President Reagan that ''we are
bringing up his immigration bill and his Caribbean Basin bill - these are not
basically Democratic bills - because of Congressional courtesy to the President
of the United States,'' so Congress could ''act its will on them.''

The Reagan Administration has strongly supported the immigration bill, saying it
would permit the United States to re-establish control of its borders. But 72
Republicans joined 65 Democrats in voting against the resolution to bring the
bill to the floor today.

Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., Republican of Florida, spoke in favor of the
bill, saying, ''The problems of unemployment are absolutely aggravated by the
fact that we do not have control of our borders.'' The bill, he said, will solve
''many of the social problems of this country.''

But Representative Robert Garcia, Democrat of the Bronx, who is chairman of the
Congressional Hispanic Caucus, said, ''Blaming undocumented immigrants for
America's unemployment problems is scapegoating.''

Employers 'as Judge and Jury'

The bill ''on the surface, on paper, looks good,'' Mr. Garcia said, ''but it
will allow employers to act as judge and jury with respect to prospective
employees who speak with an accent or look different.'' There should be
''targeted enforcement of the existing labor law'' rather than a new system of
''employer sanctions,'' he added.

Mr. Garcia said he saw the bill as a first step toward a national identification
card, which would be not only an expensive project but also ''an infringement on
civil liberties.'' The House bill, like its Senate counterpart, gives the
President three years to develop a ''secure system to determine employment
eligibility'' for citizens as well as aliens, but the bills do not specify what
techniques should be used.

Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican of upstate New York, said ''the
genius of the Simpson-Mazzoli bill is reflected in its balance of competing
interests:'' tougher enforcement of immigration controls, a legalization program
for illegal aliens and a new system for adjudicating claims for asylum.

              December 16, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

Immigration and Purity

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 479 words


What do good conservatives think about immigration? The same thing, chances are,
that good liberals do. Probably no issue lends itself less to partisan ideology
- or attracts more centrist agreement. Yet paradoxically, that very quality
explains the peril hovering over the immigration bill to come up in the House
today.

The Senate overwhelmingly approved the bill last fall, and by every sign the
House would do the same if only there is a vote today. But that may not happen;
this painfully achieved proposal is not pure enough for extremists on both ends.
If they succeed in drowning the bill with dozens of perfectionist amendments,
the opportunity of a generation will sink with it.

Unlimited immigration was a need, and a glory, of the undeveloped American past.
Yet no one believes America can still support it. We must choose how many people
to admit, and which ones. That can be done only if we can control the borders.
Otherwise, a population troubled by hard times will slam the Golden Door. As the
Senate debate demonstrated, there's a rising, ugly nativist sentiment to keep
out not only the illegal gate-crashers but also legitimate entrants like the
sister from Italy, the refugee from the Soviet Union, the physician from
Nigeria, the grocer from South Korea.

To do that would defile America's historic image; worse, it would do practical
harm. All Americans prize the vitamin shots of energy, ambition and skills that
legal immigrants keep injecting into our society. But illegal aliens take jobs
and social welfare funds that might otherwise go to poor Americans - and extract
a price in public tolerance.

The surest way to avert the rising exclusionist sentiment is to pass the
carefully balanced Simpson-Mazzoli bill. On the one side, it meets a humane
need: amnesty for illegal aliens who have been here for years. That is
essential, if only to free them from a cloud of exploitation and fear. But
without tougher enforcement, amnesty would only encourage more illegal
immigration.

That's why the bill would also create a practical form of enforcement: through
employment. At present, if an employer hires illegals only they are subject to
prosecution. The Simpson-Mazzoli bill would make the employer culpable too. In
time, that would turn off a powerful magnet.

Could the bill be improved, by liberal or conservative lights?  Obviously, and
that's exactly the point. To have gotten this far, any immigration bill would
have to be a compromise - and this is an honorable one. Yet at five minutes till
midnight, purists still insist on making the best the enemy of the good.
Simpson-Mazzoli deserves to be called a reform bill. The next immigration bill,
if there is one at all, could warrant a much uglier adjective.

AROUND THE WORLD;
Australia Promises To Curb Immigration

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section A; Page 7, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 119 words

DATELINE: CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 13


Australia will tighten immigration rules after demands for curbs by unions and
employers because of rising unemployment, the Government said today.

A spokesman for Immigration Minister John Hodges said new guidelines would be
enforced to prevent Australians from losing jobs to new immigrants.

He said an immigration department check had shown widespread abuse of a plan
allowing employers to bring in immigrants if suitably skilled workers were not
available in Australia.

Figures made public last week showed unemployment had risen to 8.6 percent from
8.2 percent, and officials have said they expect it to rise to about 10 percent
early next year.

SCHOLAR FACING OUSTER BY U.S. GETS HOPE

BYLINE: By JOHN HERBERS, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 3, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 515 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11


The President of Colombia, Belisario Betancur, has asked President Reagan to
halt deportation proceedings against a Latin American scholar at the University
of Maryland, the White House said today.

In addition, people close to the scholar, Angel Rama, said that, after Mr.
Betancur's request, immigration officials indicated for the first time a
willingness to tell Mr. Rama of the charges against him.

The deputy White House press secretary, Larry Speakes, said Mr.  Betancur had
''raised the name'' of Mr. Rama during Mr. Reagan's recent trip to Central
America and South America.

Mr. Rama's case has been widely publicized in Latin America.  He has been in the
United States under temporary visas but has been denied permanent residence
under the McCarran Act, which bans Communists and subversives. Mr. Rama contends
he is neither.

Mr. Rama, 56 years old, received tenure as a professor of Spanish literature at
the University of Maryland last year, but his position has been jeopardized by
the Government's action.

''I am a socialist who writes about socialist beliefs,'' he said.

'A Crazy Story'

Mr. Rama, a native of Uruguay, said last month that the Government had refused
to grant him permanent residence in the United States under subsection 212 (a)
(28) of the McCarran-Walter Act of 1952 but refused to inform him what evidence
it had gathered against him.

''This is a crazy story,'' he said. ''I call it my Catch-28. It's absurd. It's
impossible to move on this case.'' (United Press International reported that Mr.
Rama had said of President Betancur's action: ''The President of Colombia knows
my wife and me. He is a cultivated man who knows the writers of Latin America.
He mentioned my name and the name of my wife. He was worried about our situation
in the United States and asked President Reagan to review my case.'')

John Toll, president of the University of Maryland, said that although he had no
direct knowledge of Mr. Betancur's intervention in the matter, he was encouraged
by indications that the Immigration and Naturalization Service may soon grant
Mr. Rama his request for information on the charges against him.

Mr. Rama, Mr. Toll and a lawyer for the state of Maryland, who is representing
the university in the case, met this week with Richard Spurlock, district
director of the immigration service, to renew the request for information needed
to make a case for lifting the charge.

''I was very encouraged,'' said Mr. Toll, whose campus is in the Washington
suburb of College Park. ''The university is very desirous that he get all the
information he can so far as can be done without compromising sources.''

He described Mr. Rama as an excellent scholar and said the university was
''eager for him to stay.'' Mr. Rama could not be reached for comment today, but
colleagues said Mr. Betancur called him a few days ago and told him he had
raised his case with President Reagan when the two had lunch in Bogota on Dec.
3.

A U.S. COURT RULING MAY HELP HAITIANS

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 63, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 997 words


Lawyers for some of the Haitian ''boat people'' fighting to remain in the United
States say that a recent decision by a Federal judge in Brooklyn could aid the
efforts of hundreds of the refugees scattered across the country.

The ruling, by Judge Eugene H. Nickerson of Federal District Court, involved
just one of the Haitians. It dealt with narrow legal issues related to the kind
of hearing she was entitled to from the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

But if the decision stands, the lawyers said last week, it could help hundreds
of the Haitians receive a category of hearing that would afford them greater
rights than the category the service has been providing them with, and give
thema much better chance of resisting the Government's efforts to send them back
to Haiti.

''It's a very technical decision, but it will have a significant impact,'' said
Arthur Helton of the Lawyers Committee for International Human Rights. The group
is coordinating the legal representation of many of the Haitian boat people.

U.S. Disagrees on Impact

Paul Schmidt, deputy general counsel of the Immigration and Naturalization
Service, agreed that if Judge Nickerson's ruling was not reversed, ''it will
have an impact.'' But he maintained that the effect would lie ''probably more in
delaying the process'' of ousting the affected Haitians from the United States
than in influencing the outcome of their cases.

He said that ''people without documentation to enter'' this country would
ultimately have to leave no matter which type of hearing they have.

Mr. Schmidt said it was ''pretty likely'' that his agency would recommend an
appeal of the ruling. But he said the final decision would be made by the
Solicitor General, who, like the Immigration Service, is part of the Justice
Department.

Judge Nickerson ruled on Nov. 24 in the case of Imane Phelisna, one of the
approximately 1,800 Haitians who fled their country last year, many of them in
small boats, and were caught trying to enter this country illegally. They were
placed in detention centers around the country under a 1981 Reagan
Administration policy designed to stem the illicit seaborne immigration from
Haiti.

The 1,800 have since been paroled from detention and are now involved in legal
proceedings that will determine whether they may remain in the United States.
They contend they qualify to remain as political refugees seeking political
asylum. The Government says they are economic refugees and thus not eligible for
admission.

Arrested in Miami

Miss Phelisna's application for asylum has already been denied by an immigration
judge, whose ruling has been upheld by the Board of Immigration Appeals. The
woman, who is in her 20's and temporarily living in Brooklyn, was arrested
shortly after she and a boatload of some 200 other Haitians disembarked on a
beach near Miami in July 1981.

She spent more than a year in the Immigration Service's Brooklyn detention
center. She and nearly 50 of the other Haitians being held there were recently
paroled.

In further appealing her case in Federal court in Brooklyn, her attorney, S.
Bernard Schwarz, argued that instead of having given her an exclusion hearing -
the type of hearing being given to all the Haitian aliens caught in the Reagan
Administration's crackdown - the Immigration Service should have given her a
deportation hearing.

Exclusion hearings are given to aliens who are deemed not to have ''made an
entry'' into the United States, even if they have physically arrived on American
soil, as in the case of an illegal alien intercepted by immigration authorities
at an airport, explained Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration Service.

Deportation hearings are given to those who have made an entry, said Mr. Austin.


'Entry' a Murky Issue

''The question of when an alien is deemed to have 'entered' the United States is
a very complicated, technical and murky issue,'' Mr. Helton said. But he added
that the distinction can be significant to an alien fighting ouster from this
country.

Among other things, he said, in a deportation hearing the burden of proof on key
matters is on the Government, whereas in an exclusion hearing it is on the
alien. A deportation proceeding also has ''addition provisions for judicial
review,'' he said.

In his ruling, Judge Nickerson rejected the Government's argument that Miss
Phelisna's arrival on United States soil did not fit the legal concept of an
''entry,'' entitling her to the more advantageous deportation hearing. He
directed the Immigration Service to reconsider its position on the issue.

Mr. Schwarz said the reconsideration ordered by the judge would result in ''the
onset of a deportation hearing'' for his client.

Favorable Hearings Expected

Mr. Helton said the ruling could be cited as ''persuasive authority'' by lawyers
seeking the more favorable deportation hearings for the ''hundreds'' of Haitian
boat people elsewhere in the United States who, like Miss Phelisna, were caught
after they ''made it'' to United States soil. Those taken into custody at sea
are probably not affected by the ruling, he said.

Mr. Austin, the Immigration Service spokesman, said the ''large preponderance''
of the Haitians ''were apprehended after having hit the beach.''

Mr. Helton said that the 1,800 Haitians paroled from detention, virtually all of
whom had been caught while heading for or after having landed in Florida, are
now scattered across the country, with the largest concentrations in Florida and
New York State.

They are living with or supported by families who have agreed to sponsor them
while their efforts to remain in the United States continue.

U.S. DENIES ENTRANCE TO RUMANIAN GIRL

SECTION: Section 1; Part 3; Page 92, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 761 words


The Federal Government has refused entry to a Rumanian girl whose family is
seeking political asylum in the United States, prompting expressions of concern
from Rumanian human rights activists in this country and from the office of the
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

In the past, Rumania has been criticized in the West for restricting emigration.
But early this year the Rumanian authorities granted the girl, 16-year-old
Ildiko Zudor, permission to leave, and since then her case has been cited as a
rare instance of American immigration policy keeping someone from leaving
Eastern Europe.

Renewed efforts to reverse the ruling come at a time when, according to State
Department officials, several events have contributed to a confused situation
for Rumanian citizens seeking to immigrate to the United States.

According to State Department officials, administrative delays in the American
immigration process, combined with an unexpected surge of departure approvals by
Bucharest, left hundreds of Rumanians with exit visas unable to depart for a
two-month period beginning in mid-September.

Pursuing Quiet Diplomacy

The issue became more clouded a month ago when Rumania announced that citizens
seeking to emigrate would be required to repay the Rumanian Government for their
education. After sharp initial criticism, including a warning that the action
jeopardized Rumania's most-favored-nation trading status, the State Department
said it was pursuing quiet diplomacy in an effort to relax the new strictures.

Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said
the agency refused two months ago to grant Ildiko Zudor permission to join her
parents in Philadelphia because it had previously denied her parents' claim to
political asylum.

The girl's parents, Alexandru Zudor, 44, and his wife, Edith, 38, left Rumania
to enroll their brain-damaged 12-year-old son, Sandor, in a special medical
program at the Institutes for the Achievement of Human Potential in
Philadelphia.

The Zudors, who are of Hungarian ancestry, applied for asylum in September 1981,
citing political and religious persecution at home against Rumania's Hungarian
ethnic minority. The immigration service rejected the claim last April, noting
that the Rumanian authorities had allowed Mr. and Mrs. Zudor to make several
round trips to the United States in 1980 and 1981.

Ruling to Be Contested

The Zudors, who are now facing deportation, say they plan to contest the ruling.
Their attorney, H. Ronald Klasko, said last week that that process could take
many months.

''All we are saying is to let the child suffer the same fate as the family,''
Mr. Klasko said. ''To grant them asylum is shallow relief if they never get to
see their daughter again.''

''Family reunification is the basis of immigration policy, but that's not the
issue here,'' Mr. Austin replied. ''You do not permit dependents of people in
deportation proceedings to enter the country. In our view, the parents have
elected to be separated. If they had won the asylum claim there would be no
problem.''

Susan Reid, an assistant legal adviser in the office of the United Nations High
Commissioner for Refugees, urged the immigration service last week to reverse
the denial of Ildiko Zudor's visa application.

Likely to Face Persecution

In a letter Dec. 2 to John L. Rebsamen, director of the Refugee and Parole
Staff, she cited ''compelling humanitarian reasons'' and the ''likelihood'' that
the Zudors would face persecution if they returned to Rumania.

Lazlo Hamosh of the New York-based Committee for Human Rights in Rumania said
that persecution of ethnic minorities in Rumania included arrests, job
discrimination and the destruction of churches and schools.

Three Congressmen have also spoken to Government officials in behalf of the
Zudors, Mr. Klasko said. He identified them as Representatives Lawrence Coughlin
and Richard T. Schulze, both Pennsylvania Republicans, and Tom Lantos, a
California Democrat.

Speaking through a translator, Mrs. Zudor said the situation was ''desperate''
because her daughter had indicated, in letters and weekly phone calls, that the
Rumanian authorities had threatened to revoke her passport at the end of this
month and make her a ''ward of the state.''

              December 9, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

IMMIGRATION BILL IS CLEARED FOR HOUSE DEBATE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 23, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 698 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8


A comprehensive immigration bill, broadly similar to one passed by the Senate,
was cleared today for debate on the floor of the House of Representatives as
Congress moved toward a scheduled adjournment at the end of next week.

The House Rules Committee approved a resolution permitting five hours of general
debate and setting no limit on the number of amendments that could be offered.
But the panel said that all amendments must be printed in the Congressional
Record by Thursday.

Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, said he planned to call up the
measure before the final adjournment of the House, tentatively scheduled for
Dec. 17. However, Mr. O'Neill, a Massachusetts Democrat, said that ''all of a
sudden there has surfaced an awful lot of organized opposition'' to the bill,
especially among members of racial and ethnic minority groups.

The main purpose of the bill, which is strongly supported by the Reagan
Administration, is to control illegal immigration. It would establish a system
of fines and prison terms for employers who hire illegal aliens. The penalties
are supposed to eliminate the ''magnet'' that draws illegal aliens to this
country. The bill would also offer legal status to certain illegal aliens who
entered the United States before 1980. In addition, it would revise the
administrative and judicial process for handling asylum and deportation cases.

Jobs for Americans

Concern over unemployment dominated two days of testimony before the Rules
Committee. Supporters of the bill said the measure would remove illegal aliens
from the labor force, opening jobs for Americans. Opponents said that some
provisions, such as the liberalized terms for admission of farm workers from
Mexico, would intensify competition for jobs.

Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, the chairman of the
Judiciary Committee, said the bill would enhance job opportunities and job
security for American workers. Americans, he said, ''will no longer have to
compete for jobs with a docile and exploitable undocumented work force.''

Only two of the 16 lawmakers on the Rules Committee voted against sending the
bill to the floor. Representative Martin Frost, Democrat of Texas, said, ''I
can't find anyone in the state of Texas who is for this bill.'' Representative
Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of Brooklyn, complained of a ''rush to judgment'' on
the bill, and she predicted that the system of employer sanctions would lead to
discrimination against people who ''look Hispanic.''

Representative Edward R. Roybal, Democrat of California, said that members of
the Congressional Hispanic Caucus were prepared to offer 75 amendments and to
demand a roll-call vote on each one. ''This is definitely not a jobs bill,'' he
said, adding that Americans would not take the low-paying jobs vacated by
illegal aliens.

Representative Jim Wright, Democrat of Texas, the House majority leader, said
the bill needed significant changes. ''With the limited time available to us,''
he said, ''I'm not sure we can work out the types of changes that would make it
broadly acceptable.'' However, he said debate on the bill ''may serve a useful
purpose, even if it's not enacted, by focusing attention on the complexity of
the problem so next year we could perfect a more generally acceptable
approach.''

Mr. Wright said he had been meeting with Representative Romano L.  Mazzoli,
Democrat of Kentucky, the chief sponsor of the House bill, to see if it was
possible to set stricter conditions for granting amnesty to illegal aliens.

The Congressional Black Caucus has taken the position that the bill should not
be brought to the floor this year. In a letter to Mr.  O'Neill, 14 black members
of the House warned that ''Congress will be racked with discord if this measure
is brought to the floor for a vote.''

Much of the floor debate is expected to focus on proposed changes in the program
for admission of temporary foreign workers.

              December 9, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

IMMIGRATION: DON'T IMPEDE NEEDED SPECIALISTS

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 480 words


To the Editor:

In a number of recent editorials, you have urged Congress to pass the
Simpson-Mazzoli Immigration Reform Bill. In general, I support the concepts of
this bill. It is high time that we had a comprehensive immigration law, and it
is important to make sure that American workers are not put out of work by
foreign labor. In particular, I support the sanctions contained in the
bill.§till, as originally written, a number of provisions of the bill would make
it extremely difficult for American universities and industry to hire foreign
faculty and workers in areas where there is a serious shortage of qualified
American personnel.

The very serious shortage in computer science and engineering has been well
documented, in The Times and elsewhere. Dr. William Perry, former Under
Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering, has stated that ''the lack of
electronic and computer science engineers may be the single most important fact
limiting the growth and continued vitality of the electronics industry.''

One provision in the immigration bill would require that all foreign students
return home for at least two years following graduation. Another would make it
very difficult for American employers to hire skilled foreign nationals.
Individuals with Ph.D.- level skills in short supply, whether local, regional or
national, should be allowed to work here.

Last July, the heads of computer science and computer engineering departments,
meeting at Snowbird, Utah, unanimously adopted a resolution which recommended
that the proposed legislation be amended to retain or ease provisions of current
immigration law in such critical fields as computer science and computer
engineering.

Different versions of the original bill have passed the Senate as well as the
House Judiciary Committee. It is not yet clear, therefore, what bill might
finally arrive before a conference committee.

One version, which passed the House committee, sets a seven-year limit on
waivers for doctoral students in critical areas. The danger of such a provision
is that it typically takes some five years to get a doctorate in an experimental
subject, so we could expect to see foreign applications to our engineering
schools start to dry up within a couple of years.

With the current sad state of American education in engineering and science, we
can use all the help we can get. This help should be obtained from abroad if
necessary.  (Prof.) J. F. TRAUB New York, Dec. 1, 1982

The writer is chairman of the Computer Science Department at Columbia
University.

PEKING IS TROUBLED BY RISE IN DEFECTIONS TO WEST

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 22, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 958 words


China's policy of sending students, scholars and others to the United States for
extended visits has created tensions between the two Governments because of the
large number of defections, according to American officials.

Peking officials are also reported to be troubled by what appears to them to be
the beginning of dissident activities in the United States by some Chinese
students.

As of the end of October, there were 1,030 pending applications for political
asylum filed by Chinese in this country, a figure equal to roughly 10 percent of
the estimated 10,000 to 11,000 Chinese who are on extended visits here,
according to figures provided by the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Eight applicants for political asylum have been approved so far this year and 87
rejected.

The Chinese Embassy in Washington has made protests ''at the highest level''
over what it views as American receptivity to Chinese requests for asylum,
according to the American officials.  China has charged that ''unscrupulous
individuals'' and American intelligence agencies have lured some of its citizens
into requesting asylum, these officials say.

Motivated by Life-Style Concerns

Similarly, Chinese officials have warned Americans visiting China that the
defections of Chinese to the United States threaten the cultural exchange
program between the two countries. One such visitor quoted a ranking Chinese
leader as saying recently that such ''unpleasant directions'' as defections have
made some parts of the Chinese bureaucracy ''hesitant'' to continue with
cultural exchanges.

The problem is ''pretty serious,'' said an American official. ''It injects
itself into the overall atmosphere.'' ''We try to explain to them,'' he went on,
''that there are risks in an exchange program. Some people fall out, but most do
go back home and we think they are enriched by their experience here.''

China embarked on a policy about three years ago of sending students and
scholars to the United States to learn skills that would be useful in the
country's modernization program.

A State Department specialist, Richard Howarth, said that some of the Chinese
seeking asylum were motivated more by life-style concerns than any real worry
about political persecution back in China.

''The few cases that I've seen were pretty weak,'' Mr. Howarth said in a
telephone interview. ''They weren't involved in political life at all. They just
wanted to stay here with their children or grandchildren.''

Screening Procedures

Still, China presumably carefully screens those students, performers and
athletes that come to this country and the Peking Government has evidently been
shocked that defectors and dissidents have emerged from these selected groups.

A notable case arose recently when a Chinese physician studying on a Chinese
Government scholarship in Canada announced that he would defect to the West to
publish a new dissident magazine, ''China Spring.'' The physician, Dr. Wang
Bingzhang, said he would not return to China but instead would devote himself
full time to a new organization, based in North America, that would work for
democratic change in his homeland.

Mr. Wang's defection caused a stir among many Chinese students and scholars
here. He said he had received hundreds of letters of support, many from Chinese
students. His magazine has received private donations amounting to tens of
thousands of dollars, and companies owned by overseas Chinese have pledged even
larger donations, he said in an interview.

Mr. Wang's defection followed that of several others that Government officials
say were protested by China. Among those who defected were a tennis player, Hu
Na, in California in late July, and a ballet dancer, Lin Jianwei, who announced
during a tour here in June that he did not want to go back. There have been
several other defections, including those of another ballet dancer, a cellist
studying at the University of Minnesota and a diplomat.

To be granted political asylum, a person must show a reasonable fear that he
will be persecuted in his home country because of his beliefs.

Reasons for Staying Are Unclear

It is impossible to determine what percentage of Chinese in the United States
request asylum out of sympathy with dissident ideas and how many do so because
they want to stay for economic or personal reasons.

Mr. Wang said that while he was still in China he sympathized with dissidents
active in 1978 and 1979, many of whom have since been jailed. He said that when
he left China for his studies in Canada he had already decided that he would try
to form a dissident group in North America. Other Chinese students contend that
his ideas have struck a sympathetic cord with many intellectuals in this
country.

''I'm excited by what Dr. Wang did, but I'm not surprised,'' said Liang Heng, a
Chinese student at Columbia University. ''In China and among lots of Chinese
students here I've met lots who have the same ideas as Dr. Wang.''

Some American experts on China believe that as a result of defections, the
Chinese Government has already tightened its selection procedures for students
who want to study abroad. Some Chinese students already at schools in this
country reportedly decided against returning to China during the last summer
vacation out of fear that once back home they would not be allowed to leave
again.

Why Break the Immigration Clock?

SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 391 words


There's a bargain built into the immigration reform bill inching through the
House. On the one hand, the bill would make it much harder for illegal workers
to enter the country. On the other, it would provide limited amnesty for those
already here, living with a fear of discovery that subjects them to
exploitation. It's a humane bargain - and also a practical one. The
Simpson-Mazzoli reform bill, as delicately balanced as a clock, could never have
gotten so far without it.

But now, within sight of triumph, the bargain and thus the bill are suddenly in
jeopardy. Speaker O'Neill, to his credit, has promised to bring up the bill
during this lame-duck session. Meanwhile, some House members, by wanting things
both ways, threaten to break the clock. Though happy to have tougher
enforcement, they want to strip amnesty out of the bill. The effort dishonors
the implicit immigration bargain and misunderstands what amnesty would
accomplish.

Hundreds of thousands of illegal workers would probably seek amnesty. To some
nervous members, amnesty sounds like blanket legalization for a flood of
''crooks, Commies and welfare cheats,'' as one House staff member says
ironically. But the reform bill would provide no blanket legalization; it
requires case-by-case treatment.  Aliens have to have been here for three years
to win temporary status, six for permanent status. Undesirables are excluded.
Eligibility for welfare is denied or delayed.

More important than exaggerated fears are the benefits, which is why the Reagan
Administration vigorously supports the entire package. Amnesty for old aliens
would enable the Immigration Service to focus its threadbare enforcement efforts
on keeping out new ones. And it would eliminate a fearful, servile underclass.

How can it be good for a democratic society when employers or landlords or
merchants prey on illegal aliens' fear of deportation?  How can it be good for
illegal aliens to shrink from ever going to the police, or to be taxed unfairly?
Tolerating such an underclass is cruel to them and unhealthy for the rest of us.
The immigration reform bargain - tough enforcement coupled with sensible amnesty
- deserves to be honored.
