DRIVE TO REVAMP IMMIGRATION LAW IS GAINING

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 28, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 702 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1


Members of Congress appear increasingly eager to pass a comprehensive
immigration bill this year, but there is growing support for efforts to delete a
proposed amnesty for illegal aliens.

Since Congress reconvened Monday, supporters of the bill have been telling
colleagues that it would help reduce unemployment by making it unlawful for
anyone to employ an illegal alien. Thus, they say, the bill would open hundreds
of thousands of jobs to United States citizens. Discussions of the bill on
Capitol Hill have increasingly emphasized its restrictionist features.

The Reagan Administration still supports legalization as a component of the
bill. But Justice Department officials said today, for the first time, that they
would be willing to consider deferring legalization until the Government's
enforcement capabilities had been strengthened.

House Democrats said the bill could come to the floor for debate as early as
next week. Eliminating the amnesty provisions would profoundly alter the nature
of the bill, which, its supporters say, represents a delicate balance between
tougher enforcement and humanitarian changes.

Proposals in Congress

The Senate and the House Judiciary Committee have approved comprehensive
immigration bills that would offer permanent resident status to several million
illegal aliens who entered this country before Jan. 1, 1977, and lived here
continuously since then. The precise number of people who would qualify is
unknown. The bills would offer provisional amnesty to illegal aliens who arrived
from Jan. 1, 1977, to Jan. 1, 1980. They could become permanent residents after
a three-year waiting period. Permanent residents, in turn, can become citizens
after five years.

David D. Hiller, a Justice Department official, said: ''We were an early
proponent of a realistic, properly limited legalization program. That is an
appropriate part of an overall bill. However, there is a great deal of sentiment
out there for deferring legalization until such time as we are convinced that
enforcement measures are in place and effective.''

If there was a strong push to delete the amnesty provisions, he said, ''the
enforcement parts of the bill should go ahead and the issue of legalization
could be revisited later, when Congress felt more comfortable with it.''

Deletion of the amnesty would cause great concern to Hispanic Americans, who see
aggressive enforcement as a possible threat to their civil rights. But with more
than 11.5 million Americans out of work, even some liberals in Congress have
expressed reservations about granting amnesty.

Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, intends to
offer an amendment to delete the amnesty provisions, which he described as ''the
most objectionable features'' of the bill. ''It seems ludicrous to be granting
amnesty to millions of illegal aliens at a time when our country is suffering
from such high unemployment,'' he said.

'Reward' for Breaking Law

In a statement filed with the Judiciary Committee report, Mr.  Sensenbrenner
said that amnesty would set ''a bad precedent'' and encourage further illegal
immigration. In addition, he said, it was ''unfair to the hundreds of thousands
of immigrant applicants, some of whom have been waiting as long as 10 years to
come to this country legally.'' The amnesty, he said, would be a ''reward'' for
illegal conduct.

Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of New Jersey, said that Congress
should not approve a ''mass amnesty program'' until it gave the Immigration and
Naturalization Service more resources to enforce the law.

In September the House Judiciary Committee rejected, 16 to 12, a bid to delete
the amnesty section of the bill.  Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of
Kentucky, and Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, the sponsor of the
Senate bill, have repeatedly said that the legislation was ''not nativist, not
racist and not mean.''

NEW JERSEY JOURNAL

BYLINE: By Albert J Parisi

SECTION: Section 11; New Jersey; Page 3, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1567 words


A raid by Federal agents on a Passaic clothing factory earlier this month may
force the deportation of 40 illegal Polish aliens, all of them women who worked
as sewing-machine operators. The raid, which was conducted by 50 agents of the
Internal Revenue and Immigration and Naturalization Services, centered on
Fashion Associates Inc.

The company's financial records were also seized under warrants issued by United
States Magistrate G. Donald Haneke in Newark for what officials are calling
probable violations of Federal income tax, labor and immigration laws.

Of the 52 persons arrested, all but one were released within hours of being
interviewed at the Immigration Service office in Newark.  ''One woman, a
Filipino national, is still being held,'' said Diane Armenakis, an assistant
United States Attorney. The 40 women, she said, are considered illegal aliens
and face deportation proceedings, but no criminal charges. However, because of
political unrest in Poland, officials stress that deportation is unlikely.

''From what I understand, for these women to remain in the country legally, they
must be classified as 'political exiles' by the State Department in
Washington,'' Mrs. Armenakis said. ''That's where the issue stands right now.''

The women are believed to live in the Wallington and Passaic areas, which have
large Polish-American communities.  Mass arrests of illegal aliens in New Jersey
are not unusual. In April, several hundred Colombian and Salvadoran nationals
were seized in one week throughout the state and eventually deported.

A special program originating from Overlook Hospital in Summit is getting across
the message that keeping calm and avoiding panic are just as important in saving
lives as cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, as it is commonly known.

''Emergency: The First Five Minutes!'' is a two-hour course taught by certified
members of the hospital's CPR Unit on how to cope and what to do in a medical
emergency. The program has just been completed by 150 employees of
Bloomingdale's at the Short Hills Mall, and additional classes are expected to
resume after the holidays.

''There's such a helpless feeling in people who witness someone who collapses,''
said Connie Anderson, the hospital's CPR coordinator, adding that training
focuses on what to do in the interim. ''For the most part, when there's an
accident or someone is stricken, there isn't a doctor in the house.''

Mrs. Anderson said that immediate help could be offered by trained co-workers or
employees. Action in those few minutes between the time someone is hurt and an
emergency medical unit arrives can often save lives.

''Mainly, we're teaching people to keep their heads and call for immediate
assistance,'' Mrs. Anderson said. ''A medical unit that's properly informed on
the situation by a caller who calmly describes the emergency has a better chance
to do its job.''

The program, which took a year to plan and organize, is serving businesses and
industry in parts of Union, Morris, Essex and Somerset Counties. Hospital
officials contend that demand for the training will increase once the course is
better known.

''The employees in Bloomingdale's were enthusiastic over the course and quick to
pick up on it,'' Mrs. Anderson said.  The course costs $40 per instructor for
each 10 students.

Dr. William Pecoraro of Demarest has won a legal battle, and its effect is not
so much on his wallet as on his eardrums. For the last 12 years, Dr. Pecoraro, a
dentist, has objected to a high-pitch fire siren that is bolted to a utility
pole just outside his home and office on Hardenburgh Avenue.

His pleas to local officials for its removal, Dr. Pecoraro contends, have fallen
on deaf ears. But the State Superior Court has ruled that the siren is a public
nuisance and has asked the Demarest Mayor and Council to seek a solution.

The siren, like its counterpart across town, is the only practical way to alert
the volunteer firefighters, emergency officials say.  They will not remove the
sirens, but have curtailed a testing schedule and lowered the sound level.

''The problem is that the siren goes off at all hours of the night - and not
just in emergencies,'' Dr. Pecoraro said, adding that residents in 180 towns
throughout the state have similar problems.  Local and state health officials
have documented that the siren, which blares for nearly three minutes, exceeds
Federal standards in terms of noise level.

''Sometimes, it goes off a few times in the middle of the night, and sometimes
in the day, when I'm working on a patient,'' Dr.  Pecoraro said. ''You learn to
make do.''

If town officials continue dragging their heels over the issue, Dr. Pecoraro
said, he and several neighbors will continue legal action.  ''This is more than
a little peace of mind for me,'' he said. ''I'm trying to protect my family and
our hearing.''

Of the nearly 10,000 vehicles pulled over and examined in October by roving
inspection teams of the state's Division of Motor Vehicles, more than half
failed because of one or more safety defects.

Clifford W. Snedeker, the division's director, said that the drivers of 31
percent of those vehicles were given tickets for extremely serious safety
violations. The tickets were written by local police officers aiding the
inspection teams.

Also, 165 cars were impounded because they were ''too unsafe for continued
highway operation,'' were unregistered or were being driven by motorists with
suspended licenses.

Since September, when the roadside spot inspections began, nearly 15,000 private
and commercial vehicles have been stopped. The inspections are limited to
off-peak hours so as not to cause motorists delays in their work schedules.

The average inspection is said to take about five minutes.

Psyching out the opponent is the name of the game these days for Dr. Selwyn
Mirkin, a Teaneck psychologist with a doctorate in human relations. He treats
athletes, mostly tennis players and the like, who have a problem in common: They
can't win.

Dr. Mirkin described his technique, which he calls ''See-Feel-Win,'' this way:
''I determine if the person is susceptible to being put in a trance state first.
If he is, I hypnotize him and let him regress to a time in a previous match when
he felt comfortable and played well.

''Then we run through a match that may be upcoming and which he's nervous about.
I have him imagine making excellent strokes and trouncing his opponent.
Actually, I'm desensitizing my client to think positive.''

The patient, he said, must meet two criteria if treatment is to be worthwhile:
He must have had successful experiences in the past and he must be susceptible
to hypnosis.

Dr. Mirkin said that he could, for example, bring an ex-Ping Pong player who had
not competed in 10 years up to 80 percent of his former capacity.

One of the psychologist's patients is 12-year-old Henry Mandeville of Montvale,
who is ranked 15th in his division by the Eastern Tennis Association. Henry has
been undergoing treatment for five weeks.

''It's unbelievable,'' his mother said. ''Henry played a 17-yearold top Bergen
County teen-ager -I mean he shaves already - and he made a good showing. Last
weekend, a kid who Henry had never beaten before just folded under my son.''

A 94 percent increase in burglaries in Morris County between 1975 and 1980
prompted County Prosecutor investigators there to come up with an educational
crime-prevention program and resource center financed by a $36,000 Federal
grant.

Since January 1981, more than 125 municipal police personnel and thousands of
citizens have cooperated to reduce residential and commercial burglaries, which
went from 3,315 in 1981 to 2,202 in the first eight months of this year, a
decrease of 33.6 percent.

The Society of Crime Prevention Practictioners - a national organization of
law-enforcement professionals - sent its president, Brooks Russell of Seattle,
to Morristown earlier this month to give the county the society's Outstanding
Unit award for ''contributions, accomplishments and achievements in this
exciting new field of public safety.''

John T. Dempsey, Morris County's crime-prevention coordinator, attributed much
of the success to citizens trained by the police in neighborhood seminars. He
noted that 60 percent of the burglaries occurred in the daytime, and that
residents' new awareness and new precautions had helped neighborhoods to make
themselves less vulnerable to intruders.

''Municipal Police Departments with manpower shortages were willing to risk
taking a man off patrol duty to institute crimeprevention programs, and now they
can see the benefits,'' Mr.  Dempsey said. ''Citizens in 38 municipalities have
become the eyes and ears of the police to direct them to places where crimes may
be about to occur.''

AN EMBARRASSING U.S. QUARREL WITH A LATIN AMERICAN SCHOLAR

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 235 words


To the Editor:

The story of Prof. Angel Rama's unequal fight for permanent residence in the
United States (news article Nov. 14) is a disquieting reminder of how
McCarran-Walter Act provisions are habitually stretched in order to exclude
Latin Americans and other foreigners whose political stance happens to be
somewhere to the left of the State Department's.

Even unstretched, these overly restrictive immigration clauses are an
embarrassment to our democratic reputation. They should be amended. Meantime,
the free-wheeling and disingenuous characterization of so many foreigners
seeking entry or permanent residence here as ''Communists'' is a tactic the
State Department should, in recognition that democracy thrives on honest debate
and free expression, abandon once and for all.

Your article rightly suggests the undemocratic absurdity of Mr.  Rama's having
to face charges based on ''classified'' evidence to which he and his lawyer have
no access, and the illogic of State Department objections to Mr. Rama's articles
in the 1960's on C.I.A.  intervention in Latin America, which were largely based
on reports that had appeared in The Times.

The ill-founded charges against Mr. Rama amount not only to a personal attack
but to an assault on academic freedom.
JOHN F. DEREDITA, New London, Conn., Nov. 15, 1982 The writer is associate
professor of Hispanic studies at Connecticut College.

U.S. IS URGED TO LET STRANDED POLES STAY

BYLINE: By DAVID SHRIBMAN, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 3, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 630 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24


Polish-American groups have called on the Reagan Administration to grant another
extension to Polish citizens who arrived in the United States before the
imposition of martial law in Poland and face an expiration of their visas.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service said the more than 5,000 Poles who
are in the United States on student, business and visitor visas would face
deportation unless the voluntary date of departure was extended beyond Dec. 31.

''These people don't want to return to Poland,'' said Myra Lenard, executive
director of the Washington office of the Polish-American Congress. ''For many of
them the situation is bad. They have been away so long that things have changed,
and they don't know what will meet them when they return.''

The deadline has been extended twice before - the first time until March 31 -and
could be extended again. State Department officials said the Polish domestic
situation was ''under continuous review'' and they declined to speculate whether
the date would be extended or whether the department's recommendation would be
affected if Poland were to end martial law, which was imposed Dec. 13, 1981.

4,800 Applications for Asylum

Those Poles whose visas have not expired are not affected. Nor are the 4,800
other Poles whose applications for political asylum are being considered.

Many Poles whose visas have expired have received notices warning that they are
in danger of being deported.  ''We would like this settled as soon as
possible,'' said Aloysius Mazewski, president of the Polish National Alliance,
in a telephone interview from Chicago. ''Why should people live from day to day?
They should know their fate. The holidays are coming up and everybody wants to
make plans. You just cannot live with that threat hanging over your head.''

Mr. Mazewski said many Poles would be eager to return once the Polish situation
stabilized. He added, however, that he believed it was premature to ask them to
return now.

''The situation has not changed there,'' he said. ''It is just as bad, or worse.
A lot of these people would go back - would love to go back - if they thought
things had improved.''

First Anniversary Approaching

The approach of the first anniversary of the Dec. 13 imposition of martial law
has prompted speculation that changes may be in the offing. A State Department
official said that the nature of any such change would be examined carefully.

The official said that, if the Poles were to move from martial law to what they
call a state of emergency, ''nothing may really change.'' But if they go from
''martial law to nothing,'' the official added, ''then we'll have to look at
what that means.''

Senator Charles H. Percy, the Illinois Republican who heads the Senate Foreign
Relations Committee, has urged the Administration to extend the voluntary date
of departure even if the period of martial law ends.

''The lifting of martial law would not end the problems that the Poles would
face if they returned,'' he said in letters to Attorney General William French
Smith and Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

Duke Austin, a spokesman for the immigration service, said of those Poles whose
applications for political asylum were being considered, ''Even if they are
turned down, they would not be deported.''

Mr. Austin added that officials in the immigration service were unaware of any
Poles having been convicted of criminal acts in the United States and sent back
to Poland against their will.

''Even if these people are found deportable,'' he said, ''they will not be sent
back to Poland if they don't want to go.''

AROUND THE WORLD;
U.S. Envoy Not Worried About Immigration Bill

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 5, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 209 words

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24


The United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin, said today that he did not
share the ''dire expectations'' of some Mexicans about the repercussions in
Mexico of adoption of a comprehensive immigration bill ending in Congress.

In letters to the sponsors of the bill, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of
Wyoming, and Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, a Kentucky Democrat, Mr. Gavin
also noted that an embassy report quoted by The New York Times last Sunday
sought only to reflect the opinions of key Mexicans. ''I think it important, as
I know you do, that their voices be heard,'' he said.

But he argued that the report overlooked that the unclassified embassy report
had been prepared by two summer interns after many interviews with influential
Mexicans and instead ''would have the reader infer that it is based on a recent
'dispatch' from me.''

The 17-page report reflected the views of many Mexican officials, academic
figures and businessmen that adoption of the bill by Congress next month would
harm United States-Mexican relations and ''would foster political unrest with
potentially explosive consequences.''

Making Jobs - and Saving Them

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 478 words


''Our first priority,'' says House Speaker O'Neill, ''must be to put the
millions of unemployed back to work.'' The Speaker has his social priorities
straight; he's willing to act urgently to make jobs. But is he equally willing
to act urgently to save them? Doing that is within his grasp, and that of the
lame-duck Congress starting next week - by passing the nearly finished
legislation to reform the immigration laws.

One need not be an economic scholar to see the connection between unemployment
and illegal immigration. Undocumented aliens pour across the borders in search
of jobs. True, many of those jobs are so menial that Americans won't take them,
or might be automated if there were no illegals willing to do them for low pay.
Nevertheless, the Labor Department estimates that for every five jobs taken by
illegal immigrants, one American is deprived of a job.

How many jobs are lost that way? The facts are spongy. No one knows how many
illegals come in each year, or how many leave. But the United States Ambassador
to Mexico recently reported that if the immigration laws were strengthened,
''Probably between one and two million Mexicans would be forced to return to
Mexico.'' And Mexico supplies only half the illegal entrants.

It seems reasonable to guess that some 500,000 illegal immigrants a year are
added to the work force, displacing at least 100,000 American workers. That
leads to an obvious question. The Speaker - and the President - want quick
action on a $33 billion infrastructure program that would make 320,000 jobs. Why
not equally quick action on an immensely cheaper immigration bill that could
save 100,000 or more jobs?

Quick does not mean hasty. On the contrary. The Simpson-Mazzoli immigration
reform bill is the painstaking, balanced result of years of study, adjustment
and compromise. It would do much more than save jobs. Without being nativist,
racist or mean, it would put the country back in charge of its own borders,
while bringing humane status to illegal immigrants already here.

The Administration supports the bill enthusiastically; so do leading Democrats,
which explains why it passed the Senate in August by a lopsided 80-to-19 margin.
The bill would probably pass the House, too, if it were brought to the floor
during the lame-duck session starting next week. If not, it will die and have to
run the whole Congressional gantlet again next year.

That's where Speaker O'Neill comes in. Making jobs is on his priority list for
the session; saving jobs is on his ''possible'' list. If Mr. O'Neill is truly
concerned about unemployment, not to mention fairness and humanity, he will give
immigration reform the priority it deserves.

MEXICANS OPPOSE U.S. ENTRY CURBS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 13, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 893 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20


Business and political leaders in Mexico have told the United States that
passage of a comprehensive immigration bill now pending in Congress would
seriously harm relations between the two countries and ''foster political
unrest'' if it was effectively enforced.

In a dispatch to Washington, the United States Ambassador to Mexico, John Gavin,
said it was the unanimous opinion of Mexican leaders interviewed by the embassy
that the consequences of the legislation would be ''highly unfavorable for the
U.S. economy and for U.S.-Mexican relations.''

Illegal aliens sent back to Mexico and would-be migrants unable to cross the
border ''would foster political unrest with potentially explosive consequences,
businessmen here told us,'' Mr. Gavin reported.

With the Mexican economy in distress, the peso in turmoil and a new President
set to take office on Dec. 1, Mr. Gavin said, many Mexicans believe this would
be a particularly inauspicious time for the United States to tighten its
immigration law.

Bill Awaits House Action

The bill, sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and
Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, a Kentucky Democrat, has passed the Senate and
is awaiting possible House floor action in the special session of Congress that
starts Nov. 29.

Supporters of the bill, seizing on concern over unemployment, say it would open
one million to two million jobs for American citizens.  The heart of the bill is
a system of fines and prison terms for employers who knowingly hire illegal
aliens. The bill would also offer legal status to several million illegal aliens
who entered the United States before 1980.

''Probably between one and two million Mexicans would be forced to return to
Mexico at the one moment'' in its history when ''Mexico is least capable of
generating additional employment,'' Mr. Gavin wrote.

The ambassador's 17-page report drew on conversations with Mexican officials,
businessmen, economists, journalists and academics, including ''scholars
affiliated with the Government.''

The State Department's chief spokesman on immigration, Assistant Secretary Diego
C. Asencio, said in an interview Friday that ''we've been talking to the
Mexicans, we've been listening to them and we have attempted to take their
concerns into account as much as we could.'' The Reagan Administration has
strongly supported the bill, saying it would permit the United States to
re-establish control of its borders.

Patrols Would Be Increased

The bill declares the sense of Congress that there should be a carefully
controlled ''increase in border patrol and other enforcement activities of the
Immigration and Naturalization Service.'' But from Mexico, Mr. Gavin reported
that ''effective enforcement of this measure is seen to require authoritarian
measures amounting to a militarization of the border zone.''

If there is a substantial reduction in money sent home by Mexican workers in the
United States, Mr. Gavin said, the standard of living in some agricultural
regions of Mexico could ''plummet to belowsubsistence levels.''

''At the national level,'' he said, ''lower remittance incomes would deplete the
Bank of Mexico's dollar reserves and aggravate mounting debt payment
difficulties.'' By further depressing the value of the peso, he said, ''these
developments would fuel inflation, which in 1982 has risen to the highest
levels'' in 50 years.

Some Mexicans contend that the ''economic dislocations'' would be ''more
damaging to the United States than to Mexico,'' Mr. Gavin said. According to
this view, ''border zone employers, already suffering sizable market losses due
to this summer's devaluations, would be dealt the additional blow of losing
their principal source of low-wage labor.''

'Second-Class Citizenship' Seen

Mr. Simpson and Mr. Mazzoli say that by granting amnesty to illegal aliens, they
would eliminate an illegal subclass of people who have been exploited by
American employers. But Mr. Gavin said this proposal was seen as ratifying
''second-class citizenship for Mexicans,'' because they would have to pay taxes
in the United States while being ineligible for most social welfare benefits.

United States officials said that Mr. Gavin's description of Mexican attitudes
was invaluable because, as the ambassador said, the official Mexican policy on
illegal migration has been a ''policy of silence.''

Mexicans ''see the migration problem as deeply embedded in the structure of an
international labor market that unites the two countries,'' Mr. Gavin said.
''These economic forces, characterized as a 'push' from Mexico and a much
stronger 'pull' from the United States, defy legal attempts to modify them.''

Thus, he said, ''Mexicans are deeply pessimistic that Simpson-Mazzoli can be
enforced.'' They ''commonly assume that the U.S. economy's demand for foreign
labor is ineradicable, even in a recession; and many maintain a Marxist
world-view leading them to believe business interests dominate Congress, and
thus would never allow Congress to pass or enforce stiff employer sanctions.''

THEY LOVED NEW YORK

BYLINE: By Edward Hoagland; Edward Hoagland's ''Notes From the Century Before: A
Journal from Britash Columbia'' has just been reissued in paperback.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1731 words


THE WPA GUIDE TO NEW YORK CITY, The Federal Writers' Project Guide to 1930s New
York.  With a new introduction by William H. Whyte.  Illustrated. 680 pp. New
York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $20. Paper, $8.95.

THE quintessential New Yorker who reads or writes books is, I like to think,
someone who can drop down out of the sky and hit the ground running. Not just
that he is in a hurry when he gets to La-Guardia, but that he plunges into the
subway at Roosevelt Avenue or heads for Manhattan by taxi with equal aplomb and
savvy. In the same way, metropolitan street wisdom mixes with cosmopolitan
democracy in this succulent guide to New York City put together by Works
Progress Administration writers during the 1930's. It differs from most of the
other WPA guides being reissued in that it hasn't been updated, except for
William H. Whyte's brief new introduction.

An updating would have changed the optics of the book -the special, and now
rather precious, givens that obtained nearly 50 years ago and that quite easily
surmounted the difficulties of its miscellaneous authorship. New Deal tolerance
and Depression brotherhood helped strike this note of unity, but we also have
here a compendium of New York history by anonymous but eloquent writers who
frankly loved the city. Not simply the restaurants, celebrities and gossip but
the entire knit of tradition and immigration, from Algonquin Indians to
Rumanians.

This is food in Spanish Harlem: ''Piled high in racks are avocados (sometimes
called alligator pears), mangoes with their strong flavor of turpentine, guavas
from Cuba, and melon-like papayas, the leaves of which the Puerto Rican wraps
around tough meat to make it tender.  Tamarinds are sold to make a lemonade-like
drink called tamarindo; and the long brown roots of the tropical cassava swing
overhead.''

For a cockfight: ''The place and time are carefully guarded; the audience
gathers surreptitiously in a basement or empty room, where a small shallow
wooden 'ring' has been laid with dirt and sand. The cocks' steel-tipped talons
are examined carefully by their sponsors.  The birds are brushed, caressed,
huskily exhorted, and then let loose amid excited betting and low-pitched
cheering. Not till one of the cocks lies dead is the fight finished. Then the
winner is embraced, washed, and hurried into hiding.''

Even then, the Staten Island Zoo was a world-class snake emporium.  At Sailors'
Snug Harbor (the old-age home which is currently being turned into The Staten
Island Children's Museum), a reporter finds that ''to the amusement and disdain
of some of the inmates a ferryboat captain and several towboat men have been
admitted. The old tars wear blue uniforms.''

The use of stone cut by Sing Sing convicts for building New York University
precipitated one of New York's first labor demonstrations, the so-called Stone
Cutters' Riot. It would have been when Tompkins Square Park, not Union Square,
was the accepted forum for mass protests. And at the Battery: ''The sea
dominates this virile neighborhood. Sou'westers, sea boots, pea jackets, and
dungarees are displayed in the shop windows. ... Here were the homes of the
merchant princes, known as the 'Peep-o'-Day Boys,' because they arose at dawn to
peer across the harbor.''

And: ''The Bowery, dividing line between the Jewish Quarter on the east and
Little Italy on the west, was once an Indian trail used by aborigines in their
expeditions against New Amsterdam. ... From 1860 to 1875 the city's theatrical
life centered here. ... At the National Theater (104 Bowery) Frank S. Chanfrau,
actor-manager, appeared with his brother in a long series of plays about Mose,
the Bowery Paul Bunyan, an epic slugger, eye-gouger, and hobnail-stamper in New
York's rowdy history. The legendary Big Mose was eight feet tall, with hands as
big as hams. In his belt was thrust a butcher's cleaver, and in summer a keg of
beer hung there for his refreshment. He loved to lift a streetcar off its track
and carry it on one hand as a waiter carries a tray, the horses dangling from
their harnesses.''

The Manhattan Bridge's ''triumphal arch and curved colonnade are combined in a
vigorous baroque composition, inspired by the Porte St. Denis, a gateway in
Paris, and the Bernini colonnade that forms the Piazza of St. Peter's in Rome.''

''Pizza'' is ''an unsweetened pastry filled with tomatoes and cheese, meat, or
fish.'' At the Salvation Army's ''buttermilk bar,'' beef stew, oatmeal and
coffee sell for 5 cents. ''The United Homing Pigeon Concourse, one of the
largest racing pigeon organizations in the city, meets at Teutonia Restaurant,
Third Avenue near Sixteenth Street. ... A block north is the German-American
Rathskeller, known in riper days as Scheffel Hall and later as Allaire's. Many
noted writers quaffed its foaming pilsener.''

At twilight on Brooklyn Bridge, the beauty of the setting sun ''attains such
intensity that even the wisecracks of up-to-date lovers are sublimated. And in
the wastes of night, so passionate is the contrast between the deserted and
melancholy bridge entrances and the moonlit altitude of the passage itself, that
the solitary pedestrian feels himself drawn into association with all the
extravagances of the poets.''

However, Bellevue Hospital treated more patients in 1938 than the population of
San Francisco. And there are elevated subway lines above Second, Third, Sixth
and Ninth Avenues in Manhattan. IRT entrances are marked by blue lamps, BMT by
green and white, and IND by green. But the subways are drab and noisy. Proposals
that WPA painters and sculptors decorate the walls ''have been considered.
Meanwhile, the romance of the subways of New York may be found in their
trajectories, and in the intricacy of their construction and operation.''

John Cheever helped edit the guide, and Richard Wright helped write it
(presumably while composing ''Native Son,'' which came out only a year later, in
1940). No doubt it was Wright who made the section on black Harlem so plush with
feeling. This domain where ''those aspiring to racial leadership ... may
advocate their theories unmolested'' is explored in dignified, unblinking
fashion - the poverty of the ''lung blocks'' and ''oatmeal flats''; the Negro
actors and actresses waiting for work next to ''the Tree of Hope,'' growing in
front of the Lafayette Theater; the buildings at ''the Golden Edge'' facing
Central Park, where professional people lived.  On ''Strivers' Row'' on 139th
Street, the brick houses with ''terracotta facades enriched with wrought-iron
balconies ... were designed with considerable artistry in the spirit of the
Florentine Renaissance'' by Stanford White.

BACK downtown, ''The Plaza Hotel is patronized by the wellestablished older
groups of society, though to a war generation it was a rendezvous of youth. ...
The Hotel Pierre has become popular with the Park Avenue crowd for coming-out
parties. The Savoy-Plaza and Sherry-Netherland are residential hotels.'' ''The
small area centering around Beekman and Sutton Places offers an extreme example
of New York's flair for making Mrs. O'Grady and the Colonel's Lady close if
uncommunicative neighbors. Here drying winter flannels are within fishpole reach
of a Wall Street tycoon's windows, and the society woman in her boudoir may be
separated only by a wall from the family on relief in a cold-water flat.''

On First Avenue from 42d to 46th Streets is the Abattoir Center: ''To the past
belong such features as dilapidated shacks, runaway livestock, and strong,
unpleasant odors. Still employed, however, is the Judas bellwether, the sheep
that leads a flock to slaughter. ...  On the wall of the Wilson meat-packing
plant ... is a Tablet commemorating the execution of Nathan Hale (September 22,
1776), which is supposed to have occurred near here.''

Although less opulent with startling narratives than, for example, the WPA's
splendid guide to Louisiana, the New York City guide is more stylish. Manhattan
is vouchsafed a Dos Passosesque impressionistic opening. Thomas Wolfe is quoted
on the Gashouse District. Pages of supple prints enliven the book, better than
the photographs - lowlife lithographs by Eli Jacobi, highlifes by Mabel Dwight
and Peggy Bacon, and, in particular, the dramascapes of Louis Lozowick and Adolf
Dehn.

If one goes now to a newsstand to read about the city in New York magazine, The
New Yorker and The Village Voice, nothing like such universal curiosity, such
love for the city and ease with the informal grit and weave of local history is
evident. The young writers pounding the beat, as well as their editors, are a
different breed.

It's true that wars have intervened. LaGuardia, then in the planning stage as
''North Beach Airport,'' and Kennedy have changed our sense of our lives' scale.
The city is more dangerous to walk in, although 400,000 fewer people live here.
Ultimately it has become a vastly riskier place because we know that we would be
the first to go in a nuclear exchange of what military scientists have taken to
calling ''decapitation.'' Yet we love our children - we love baseball - as much
in a nuclear age. Maybe we are turning into miniaturists, unwilling to trust our
affections to anything as unwieldy and broadbacked as a whole city again.

SOME features are looking up. There is, of course, Mr. Reagan's ''safety net''
nowadays, instead of the Salvation Army's 5-cent stew and oatmeal. Crossing
Brooklyn Bridge on foot once cost a penny, instead of being free. South Brother
Island - in the East River opposite Tiffany Street in the extreme South Bronx -
is today an undespoiled, minute wilderness of Virginia creeper, cat brier and
tree-of-heaven trees, where snowy egrets and black-crowned night herons nest.
But it was described in 1939 as ''seven acres of unimproved brush.''

Incidentally, the Tiffany jewelry store used to be situated on Union Square. And
in the 1890's, off Sheridan Square in Greenwich Village, there lived ''a
notorious but colorful gang of thugs known as the Hudson Dusters. A high
percentage of them were cocaine addicts and thus especially vicious and
ferocious.'' Bank Street, close by, is where the counting houses of Wall Street
relocated during the yellow-fever epidemic of 1822. And Leroy Street is named
for ''the oft-found lost Dauphin of France,'' supposedly buried here.
Anything else you'd like to learn?

AROUND THE NATION;
Baby, Deported by U.S., Is Being Returned

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 28, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 92 words

DATELINE: DENVER, Nov. 13


A baby who was deported to Mexico in a raid by Federal immigration agents will
be returned to his family in Colorado, according to the authorities.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service said Friday that the boy,
19-month-old Jaime Lovato, would bebrought back to Colorado by his aunt, who is
caring for him in Mexico.

The child, the son of two illegal aliens fighting to gain American citizenship
in Craig, near Denver, was born in this country and thus is a citizen of the
United States.

LATIN AMERICAN SCHOLAR FIGHTS TO STAY IN U.S.

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 34, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 656 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13


There is only one catch as Angel Rama, a Latin American scholar at the
University of Maryland, sees it, and that is, in his words, Catch-28.

Mr. Rama, who has been in the United States since 1969, lecturing on Latin
American literature, is fighting an apparently losing battle against
deportation. The State Department has invoked subsection 212 (a) (28) of the
1952 McCarran-Walter Act on immigration against the Uruguayan-born scholar. The
subsection bars permanent residence to anyone who has been a member of or
affiliated with a Communist Party, and who been involved with Communist
publications.

Mr. Rama appeared before an Immigration and Naturalization Service officer in
Baltimore on Friday at a hearing called to allow him to defend himself against
the evidence the Government says it has gathered against him. But because the
evidence is classified, and therefore considered vital to the nation's security,
Mr. Rama was not allowed to see it.

''This is a crazy story,'' Mr. Rama said. ''I call it my Catch-28.  It's absurd.
It's impossible to move on this case.'' Russell Manchester, who is handling the
case for the immigration service, said that, legally, ''There is no way for us
to make the evidence available to him,'' adding, ''The burden of proof is
entirely upon the individual seeking to establish his residency.''

Of Mr. Rama's troubles, Mr. Manchester said, ''It is not an unusual case and it
will be handled as others like it have been handled.''

Government Position Unchanged

Louis D. Crocetti, the immigration official who met with Mr. Rama for two hours,
said the hearing did not change the Government's position that the scholar
should not be granted status as a permanent resident. The case will be forwarded
to the immigration service's regional office in Vermont, where a decision will
be made.

Mr. Rama is scheduled to go to Spain on a Guggenheim fellowship in January.
Without status as a permanent resident, Mr. Crocetti said he expected it would
be difficult for Mr. Rama to get back into this country.

Mr. Rama, who is 56 years old, asserts that he is neither a Communist nor a
subversive. ''I was never a Communist,'' he said. ''I am a Socialist who writes
about his Socialist beliefs.''

His lawyer, Michael Maggio, who handles many such cases, said Mr.  Rama's case
was unusual in that he denies any past affiliation with a Communist
organization. In most cases, Mr. Maggio said, individuals admit to having been
members of Communist or subversive groups and subsequently renounce those ties.

Tenured at Maryland U.

Last year, Mr. Rama received tenure as a professor of Spanish literature at the
University of Maryland where Graciela Nemes, a professor in the department of
Spanish and Portuguese, said: ''He's really not the man they say he is. If he
leaves it would be a crushing blow to the university, to the department and to
the students.''

Mr. Rama's ordeal apparently had its genesis in Montevideo, the capital of
Uruguay, in 1969. It was there, he explained, while applying for a United States
visa to teach at the University of Puerto Rico that he was asked about a trip he
made to China in 1962, visits he made to Cuba and about his writings in
Semenario Marcha, a Uruguayan-based magazine that he compared with the liberal
American publication The Nation.

Mr. Rama wrote a series of articles for the magazine in the 1960's about
reported attempts by the United States Central Intelligence Agency to finance
and infiltrate Latin American intelligence organizations. Mr. Rama said that
most of the information he used in the series had been culled from The New York
Times.

He is also the literary editor of Biblioteca Ayacucho, a Venezuelan-based
publishing house, which, like the magazine Semenario Marcha, frequently
publishes the works of Communist writers.

FOREIGN SEAMEN ABANDONED ON DECREPIT SHIP

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 63, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 659 words


Seventeen foreign seamen lived on a rat-infested floating slum on the Brooklyn
waterfront for months and endured a lack of plumbing and electricity on a ship
that had been abandoned by its anonymous owner, according to a seamen's
advocate.

The seamen, Central Americans who speak no English, had been bound to the ship
by immigration laws and by their desire to work. On Wednesday, the Seaman's
Church Institutions placed them at a hotel for seafarers.

''We did it for just plain humanitarian reasons,'' said the advocate, Paul
Chapman, director of the Center for Seafarers' Rights. ''Their lives were just
miserable.''

The seamen had been recruited by a shipping agent in Costa Rica and Nicaragua,
according to Mr. Chapman. The agent had signed them on at $200 a month - plus $1
an hour in overtime -to fix the Sea Lift, a 7,000-ton cargo vessel, and serve as
its crew.

Began Arriving in June

Starting in June, groups of seamen flew from Central America to New York, where
they were met by the agent and taken to the ship. The seamen had paid their own
way, a violation of marine law, Mr. Chapman said.

Once here, they went to work. The lack of running water and toilet facilities
raised a stench. The seamen huddled against the autumn chill in the heatless
ship. Huge holes opened up in the rusty decks.  Rats ran through the ship's
bowels.

Two months ago, Mr.Chapman said, the wages were stopped.  ''Their visas are for
seamen,'' he said, ''so their only legal status is as seamen. They would have to
get approval from immigration officials to leave. Also, they expected to work,
and they were always hopeful that the ship could be fixed and they would put out
for sea.''

At one point, some members of the crew went out for an evening to escape the Sea
Lift. They were attacked and hit with bottles, Mr.  Chapman said.

Accident in the Galley

In September, a chef scalded his legs while cooking in the darkened galley,
which, like the rest of the ship, had no electricity. He stayed aboard for days
while his mates tried to get help from the owner or agent. The chef wound up
paying for his own hospital stay.

Two weeks ago, he placed a lien on the ship to pay those bills.  Other seamen
filed their own claims for unpaid wages, and the Federal Government has
confiscated the ship to pay those claims.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has also filed suit to recover
$95,000 in docking fees the ship had incurred, according to J. A. Selcov, an
authority lawyer.

Mr. Chapman said that finding the ship's owners is nearly impossible. The Sea
Lift has changed owners numerous times - it was once named the Opal -and it is
believed that it is now owned by an American.

But until its registration lapsed recently, the Sea Lift was registered in
Liberia, Mr. Chapman said. Liberian registration is a ''flag of convenience''
that gives the owner anonymity, according to Mr. Chapman.

Attempts Made to Find Owner

Capt. Bill Chadwick, chief of the marine investigations division of Liberian
Services Inc., said his organization was ''urgently investigating'' the
situation.

Mr. Chapman said Odyssey Marine Enterprise was the agent, but calls there were
referred to another company, Excelsior Maritime Ltd. That company's phone has
been temporarily disconnected. Aristotle Voulgaris, who is connected with those
companies, according to Mr.  Chapman, was said to have been on the ship Friday,
but a phone at the ship was not answered.

Mr. Chapman said his group hoped to raise enough money to send the seamen back
to their homes on Tuesday. It is expected that the proceeds from the sale of the
ship will pay for their expenses in the long run, but Mr. Chapman said the Sea
Lift was good only for scrap.

IDEAS & TRENDS;
Visions of a Smaller and Older America

BYLINE: By Margot Slade and Wayne Biddle

SECTION: Section 4; Page 8, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 259 words


Once an ecology slogan of the 1960's, ''zero population growth'' may be the
American reality of the 2050's, according to Census Bureau projections issued
last week. By then, the number of Americans should have peaked at 309 million
and started to decline, as deaths exceed total births and net immigration.

It was the first time the bureau had described zero population growth as its
''most likely assumption'' for the nation's future, said Gregory K. Spencer, a
demographic statistician. Other demographers said the bureau's figures
approximated their own, but the projections could prove wrong. They have been
off-base before because of changes in factors such as birthrate.

If the Census Bureau's projections are borne out, the country will be top-heavy
with elderly people. In 1981, people age 65 and older accounted for 11.4 percent
of the population. The bureau foresaw that the figure would rise to 21.7 percent
in 2050. The ratio of workingage population (18 to 64 years old) to elderly will
continue shifting, the bureau said, from 5.4 to 1 now - that is 54 working-age
people for every 10 elderly people - to 2.6 to 1, or 26 working-age people for
every 10 elderly, in 2050. Moreover, the elderly will include a higher
proportion of the very old - age 85 and over, the bureau said. This ''graying''
of America will have severe implications for Social Security and other programs,
since fewer wage earners will be supporting increasing numbers of the elderly.

STAGE: BRITISH 'TWO FISH IN THE SKY'

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

SECTION: Section C; Page 13, Column 1; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 716 words


THE Phoenix Theater, one of this city's most venerable theatrical institutions,
surely has good reasons for opening its 30thanniversary season with Michael
Hastings's ''Two Fish in the Sky.'' Sad to say, those reasons are not readily
apparent on stage at the Phoenix's new home, the Theater at St. Peter's Church,
where this minuscule British farce was unveiled last night.

''Two Fish in the Sky,'' which was first produced in England four years ago
under the title ''Gloo Joo,'' is about an unemployed Jamaican living in London's
Brixton ghetto and his efforts to outwit a pair of immigration authorities, who
wish to deport him. Its central conflict is bone tired. The Jamaican, Meadowlark
Rachel Warner (Cleavon Little), is an irrepressible free spirit and goodnatured
confidence artist; his anatagonists (Gavin Reed and Christopher Murney) are
petty British bureaucrats, who inevitably must learn that Meadowlark knows more
about the joie de vivre, if not legalistic niceties, than they do.

The play's predictable resolution is endlessly delayed by an illshapen, noisy
and unrewardingly complex plot, much of which also deals with Meadowlark's
flim-flams of the two women in his life (Laura Esterman and Lorraine Toussaint).
The one halfway lively comic payoff occurs early in Act II, when for reasons too
boring to explain, Meadowlark marries one of the women in a Jewish ceremony
conducted by a pixieish rabbi (Michael Tucker) at Gatwick Airport.  While this
isn't the first time that a playwright has tried to get laughs by putting a
black man in a yarmulke, Mr. Hastings does devise a few mildly giggly variations
on the theme.

The other jokes are tiresome. Many of them are racial epithets, which are
supposed to be ironically funny in the manner of Archie Bunker's, but which Mr.
Hastings, short of other comic inspiration, repeats without variation nearly to
the point of offensiveness. They are not redeemed by the play's subsidiary
thematic twist, in which the cruder immigration officer suddenly discovers that
he and Meadowlark share the same proletarian class consciousness. The attempts
to parody bureaucratese are equally lame: the officials repeatedly recite
chapter and verse of the Amended Commonwealth Immigration Act of 1971. When one
thinks of the fun other writers have had with the doublespeak of small-minded
British civil servants - starting with Harold Pinter in ''The Hothouse'' - the
paucity of invention here is astounding.

''Two Fish in the Sky'' would stand a chance only if there were a charismatic,
bubbly actor in the lead, but Mr. Little's Meadowlark never flies: his
performance is as thick and strained as his ersatz accent. Under the direction
of Steven Robman, the supporting cast is often excruciatingly broad, with only
Mr. Tucker and Mr. Reed fighting a losing battle for subtlety. Except for them
and for Wynn P. Thomas's atmospheric scenery, the rest of the production is
ashes from which the Phoenix could not rise a moment too soon.

Uncivil Servants
TWO FISH IN THE SKY, by Michael Hastings; di- rected by Steven Robman; scenery
by Wynn P.  Thomas; costumes by Robert Wojewodski; lighting by Arden Fingerhut;
sound by David Rapkin. Presented by the Phoenix Theater, T.  Edward Hambleton,
managing director; Mr.  Robman, artistic director, and Harold Sogard, general
manager. At the Theater at St. Peter's in the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue

TRIESTE HURT BY YUGOSLAVS' TRAVEL STRICTURES

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 6, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 699 words

DATELINE: TRIESTE, Italy


Until mid-October this was a city of lively traffic between East and West, but
now only an occasional car appears at the border to give immigration and customs
officials something to do.

As a result, this city at the head of the Adriatic Sea, once a great marketplace
where Yugoslavs by the thousands came daily to buy the consumer goods of the
West, bewails a heavy loss of business.  Sadly, Trieste ponders one more blow
from history, which has reduced it from being the only - and flourishing - port
of the vast Austro-Hungarian empire to a backwater of Italy.

The Yugoslavs stopped coming on Oct. 17, ''black Sunday'' for the extensive
retail economy that existed here and in the border town of Gorizia, 26 miles to
the north, to satisfy a large consumer market that had money but a limited
supply of attractive goods on which to spend it. On that day the Yugoslav
Government, owing more than $20 billion to Western creditors, decided to limit
the outflow of private money.

Yugoslavs who want to travel abroad were ordered to deposit 5,000 dinars, or
roughly $80, for the first trip, and to increase that deposit by 2,000 dinars
for each subsequent border crossing. The money, without interest, is to be
returned at the end of a year, when Yugoslavia's inflation will have reduced its
value.

Long Lines of Vehicles Vanish

Because 5,000 dinars represents close to one-half of the average Yugoslav's
monthly earnings, the effect of the measure was immediate. The permanent lines
of cars and buses at the border crossings, which became endless between Friday
afternoons and Sunday evenings, vanished.

So did the customers from the sprawling markets at Piazza Ponterosso and in
front of the railroad station, which sold mainly blue jeans and other low-priced
garments, and from the shops in the large central district that catered to the
border trade.

In addition to textiles they sold groceries, cleaning products, medicines,
household appliances and fixtures, construction tools and materials, electronic
equipment, watches, jewelry and a whole line of notions.

Estimates vary for the value of what Elio Geppi, head of the Trieste union of
entrepreneurs, called ''this new category, retail exports.'' He put the annual
volume at about $32 million. Other estimates range as high as $42 million.

Yugoslav officials have assured Italy that there is no political significance to
the restrictive measures caused by economic strains.

No 'Berlin Wall' Planned

''We will not build a Berlin wall,'' said Franc Setinc, a Yugoslav leader sent
here to reassure the Slovinian minority worried about their families across the
border.

This city of 250,000 inhabitants has the retail structure for a city twice its
size. Until ''black Sunday,'' Italian and foreign residents agree, it was being
suffocated by bus and auto traffic more suited to a city of a million.

''You couldn't see the sea for parked buses along the waterfront,'' said Alberta
Ercolessi, a secretary.  Now the Piazza Ponterosso, along the unusual canal-boat
basin that juts from the Adriatic Sea into the center of the city, is a place of
mourning.

A 47-year-old trader, who said he had dealt here for 25 years, following in his
mother's footsteps, said he would have to close if the Government could not
persuade the Yugoslav Government to ease the restrictions.

Mr. Geppi said the drying up of the ''retail exports'' endangered 2,500 to 3,500
jobs in a city with a labor force of 90,000, with about 5,000 already jobless.

Mounds of coffee beans remain piled in many shops, to the relief of the post
office. Its operations had been clogged and delayed by the multitude of
two-pound coffee packages that Yugoslavs sent by the dozens for resale at home,
where coffee brings five or six times the Italian price.

At Nova Gorica, on the other side of the border, clothing shops, which are also
well stocked although fashion is less high and variety less great, reported far
more active trade.

AROUND THE NATION;
Coast Aliens Defrauded In Sale of False Papers

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 125 words

DATELINE: SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 31


Swindlers posing as immigration experts are bilking thousands of dollars from
illegal aliens by selling them false amnesty papers, Orange County officials
say.

''The undocumented alien thinks he is buying permission to be in this country
when in reality he is not getting anything,'' said Robert Nava of the county
Human Relations Commission. ''I have had at least 10 people in my office in the
last week'' who were fraud victims, he added.

Officials said some aliens have heard of a Reagan Administration proposal to
grant legal status to aliens who came to the country before 1977 and to provide
temporary legal residency to immigrants who arrived before 1980. However, that
bill is still in Congress.

QUICK ACTION VOWED ON AMERASIANS

BYLINE: By COLIN CAMPBELL, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 3, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 562 words

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 28


Attorney General William French Smith said here today that the Reagan
Administration would act ''just as quickly as we can'' to carry out a new law
that permits the Asian children of American fathers to go live in the United
States.

After a visit Wednesday to two of Thailand's camps for Indochinese refugees, Mr.
Smith also said he would speed up and expand the local operations of the
Immigration and Naturalization Service so that it could determine faster which
refugees were eligible for admission to the United States, and could then get
them there sooner.

Thailand's Prime Minister, Gen. Prem Tinsulanonda, and other officials have said
publicly that the United States and other Western governments are falling behind
in their promises to take more refugees off Thailand's hands.

Mr. Smith added, however, that public resistance in America to accepting
countless refugees had grown stronger. And he said he had talked today with
General Prem about making ''a major effort'' to return unsettled refugees to
their countries of origin, ''including Vietnam if possible.''

23-Day Asian Trip

In an interview, the Attorney General also said that ''it is a very nice
question'' what ''repatriation'' means in a place like Cambodia, where thousands
of people have been encouraged to return to insecure border areas under the
control of Cambodian guerrillas opposed both to the regime in Phnom Penh and to
Vietnam's military occupation of most of the country.

Mr. Smith and ranking members of the Justice Department, including the
Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, Alan C. Nelson, are
on a 23-day trip to Japan, Hong Kong, Thailand, Pakistan, Italy and France for
talks on narcotics trafficking as well as refugees.

The main obstacle confronting Amerasian children wanting to leave Vietnam, the
Attorney General said, is likely to be the Hanoi Government. But he said he
hoped the children could now leave by a faster and ''more efficient process''
than many had left through Vietnam's ''orderly departure program.''

The new United States law, signed by President Reagan this month, allows
Amerasian children in South Korea, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia and Thailand to prove
without any accompanying declarations by their fathers that they are half
American and should therefore be eligible for admission to the United States.
The law empowers the Attorney General to make such determinations, and the
Reagan Administration is formulating the law's rules and regulations.

Dealings With Hanoi an Issue

Mr. Smith said he did not know yet just how the United States would deal with
Vietnam, where there are estimated to be from 8,000 to 25,000 or more Amerasian
children. Washington has practically no formal contact with Hanoi.

The new law makes no provision for the admission of a child's mother or
half-siblings. Several American officials who have worked with Vietnamese
Amerasians and their families have expressed private doubts over the willingness
of mothers to sign over their children to voluntary agencies or foster parents
in the United States, as the new law requires. Very few American fathers have
claimed their Vietnamese children and fewer still have asked to take them into
their homes.

              October 20, 1982, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

NEW ASIAN ALIENS CONCERN OFFICIALS

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 590 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Oct. 19


Refugees from the impoverished South Asian country of Bangladesh have begun
making their way illegally into the United States by way of the Bahamas, the
immigration authorities here said today.

Officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service estimate that as many as
400 Bangladesh citizens may have arrived illegally in Florida since June and
then fanned out through the country, and they say thousands more may follow.

Dwayne Peterson, the chief of the antismuggling unit of the Border Patrol in
Miami, said the Bangladesh aliens who had come here so far were from a community
of some 15,000 Bangladeshis who had been living in West Germany. He said they
had also entered West Germany illegally, but after years of legal appeals had
been told they must leave.

Numbers Hard to Estimate

The estimate of 400 illegal aliens from Bangladesh comes from interviews with 57
caught while attempting to enter this country. To immigrate to the United States
legally can be a long and complicated process and relatively few who apply are
accepted.

As an initial step toward ending the influx in the early stages, Mr. Peterson
said, the Federal Government has asked the Bahamian Government to begin
requiring visas of the Bangladeshis.

The Bahamas and Bangladesh, formerly known as East Pakistan, are former British
colonies, and Bangladesh citizens can travel to the Bahamas without obtaining
visas.

Bahamian Island a Staging Point

The Bahamian island of Bimini, about 50 miles southeast of Florida, has been a
''notorious jumping-off point'' for many illegal aliens heading for Florida, Mr.
Peterson said. It is relatively easy, he said, to hire a small boat or airplane
in Bimini that will deliver aliens to Florida.

Mr. Peterson said the Bangladesh refugees have been taking commercial flights
from West Germany to the Bahamas, then taking commuter flights to Bimini, where
they pay about $950 for a clandestine journey to Florida. A regular one-way
seaplane trip from Bimini to Miami costs $45.

In late 1981, Mr. Peterson said, the State Department presented evidence to the
Bahamian Government that Colombians were using the islands as a base for illegal
immigration to the United States. In response, he said, the Bahamian Government
acted within five days to require Colombian tourists to the islands to obtain
visas.

That move significantly slowed the smuggling of Colombians, he said.  He said
that unlike other refugee groups entering South Florida, the Bangladeshis were
generally well educated and ''capable of taking technical jobs away from U.S.
citizens.''

Beverly McFarland, a Miami spokesman for the immigration service, said one group
of six Bangladesh men had made their way to Fort Lauderdale, then offered a taxi
driver $1,500 to take them to New York.

About half of the 57 Bangladeshis under arrest are in the custody of Federal
marshals as material witnesses since they were caught in the company of their
smugglers. The rest are being held in the Krome Detention Center in Miami
awaiting deportation hearings.

were still being held at Krome, said the Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste of the Haitian
Refugee Center Inc.

International-Aid Organization Elects an Executive Director

SECTION: Section 1; Part 2; Page 57, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 157 words


Frank C. Kiehne has been elected the executive director of Private Agencies in
International Development, a new organization that says it will seek to
stimulate private assistance to underdeveloped countries.

Mr. Kiehne had been the interim director of the immigration and refugee program
for the Church World Service of the National Council of Churches in New York
City.

Private Agencies in International Development, based in Washington, coordinates
the work of 78 international voluntary agencies, among them CARE, Goodwill
Industries and the Population Council.

The group's president, Elise F. Smith, explained its mission as follows: ''This
new umbrella group was initiated to tie in with the President's call for
increased private sector initiative. It will greatly improve the ability of
private agencies to cut red tape in helping solve the vast arena of problems in
the third world.''

              October 14, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

AGENDA FOR BONN OUTLINED BY KOHL

BYLINE: By JAMES M. MARKHAM, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 5, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 904 words

DATELINE: BONN, Oct. 13


Setting a new agenda for West Germany at home and abroad, Chancellor Helmut Kohl
declared today that his conservative Government would encourage private
investment, trim welfare spending, restrict foreign immigration and ''reinforce
and stabilize'' its relations with the United States.

Evoking strands of continuity with the Christian Democratic era of Konrad
Adenauer, the 52-year-old Mr. Kohl unveiled before Parliament a Government
program that stressed individual initiative in its domestic policies and put
fresh emphasis on West Germany's central place in the North Atlantic Treaty
Organization.

''The question for the future is not how much more the state can do for its
citizens,'' proclaimed Mr. Kohl, who two weeks ago replaced Chancellor Helmut
Schmidt. ''The question for the future is how can freedom, dynamism and
self-reliance blossom anew. It is upon this idea that this coalition of the
middle is founded.''

Saying his new Government had inherited ''the worst economic crisis'' since the
establishment of the Federal Republic in 1949, Mr. Kohl said his new coalition
had come to power to prevent ''the decline turning into a crash.''

Some Programs Being Cut

The Chancellor said that, with productivity and capital-formation shrinking,
15,000 companies had gone bankrupt this year and 2.5 million West Germans would
be out of work this winter. Without proposed budget cuts of $2.2 billion, he
said, the federal budget deficit in 1983 could have reached $23.8 billion.

Calling for a ''pause to catch our breath'' in the development of the country's
welfare system, Chancellor Kohl said his Government would delay increases in
pensions, cut unemployment benefits, limit subsidized hospital stays and
encourage early retirements ''without further burdening the old-age pension
system.''

''We will preserve the welfare state by strengthening its economic
underpinnings,'' declared the Chancellor.  Giving few details, Mr. Kohl said the
coalition would ease taxes for small businesses, channel spending into
investment in urban renewal, schools and Government housing, and use a special
tax on high-income groups to finance new housing starts. He said the Government
would develop cable television, satellite communications and nuclear energy -
all of which were given low priority by the Schmidt Government.

Control of Immigration

He said he would prevent ''an unlimited and uncontrolled immigration'' of
foreign workers, who now total 4.6 million in West Germany, some 1.5 million of
them Turks. The Chancellor said that the immigration of foreign workers'
children would be restricted, and that ''guest workers'' would have to choose
between integration into German society or returning home.

Mr. Kohl, who is expected to make an official visit to Washington next month,
said he would ''free German-American ties from the unfavorable light in which
they now appear, and reinforce and stabilize the friendship.'' He said his
Government unconditionally supports the NATO decision to deploy medium-range
nuclear missiles in Western Europe next year if there is no breakthrough in
armslimitation negotiations in Geneva.

''Only if the Soviet Union knows that it must definitely reckon with the
stationing of American systems in Europe at the end of 1983 can one count on
their readiness to contribute to the negotiation results,'' said Mr. Kohl, who
said he would defend the disputed deployment in his own country.

The new Chancellor said the banning of the independent union Solidarity ''is not
only a broken promise to the Polish people, not only a violation of the Helsinki
Final Act, but a surprise coup against the Polish people.''

Difference on Madrid Talks

Mr. Kohl, however, put his Government at odds with the Reagan Administration by
urging that the Madrid review conference, which next month resumes its
consideration of compliance with the Helsinki human rights accords, should
strive to reach agreement on a European disarmament conference. The Reagan
Administration maintains that the crackdown in Poland has made ''business as
usual'' in Madrid unthinkable.

The Chancellor avoided any direct mention of the outstanding dispute between the
United States and its Western European allies over the Siberian natural-gas
pipeline, but he said that economic ties to Eastern Europe were ''an important
part of the whole East-West relationship.'' He added that NATO security
interests would of course be kept in mind in developing such ties.

While sounding themes of considerable continuity on many foreign policy
questions, Mr. Kohl and the Christian Democrats are more outspoken on the issue
of eventual German unification. ''We cannot force the unity of the nation,''
said the Chancellor. ''Walls, barbed wire and the order to shoot cannot be the
last word between East and West, in Germany, in Europe and the world. Humanity
and reason refuse to accept this.''

At the same time, Mr. Kohl said his Government would demand that East Germany
lift recent increases in the minimum foreign exchange requirements for West
Germans visiting the East.

THE NATION IN SUMMARY;
WHat He Really Did in The War

BYLINE: By Carlyle Douglas Caroline Rand Herrom and Michael Wright

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2, Column 2; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 263 words


He lied to American immigration officials 32 years ago to win an entry visa. He
lied about his Nazi sympathies during World War II, about his role in bloody
riots in Bucharest in which hundreds of Christians and Jews died. It was enough
to get Valerian Trifa, a Rumanian Orthodox archbishop in Michigan, deported, the
Justice Department announced last week.

Federal authorities said the 68-year-old archbishop would be the first person
forced out of the United States for concealing war crimes from American
immigration officials. He may not be the last.  Allan A. Ryan Jr. of the Justice
Department said his special investigations office was investigating 210 people
living in the United States who are believed to have been fascists. The
Government has begun prosecuting 25, including a 62-year-old Long Island man,
Karl Linnas, who last week lost a bid in United States Supreme Court to retain
his American citizenship. Mr. Linnas, a native Estonian, was said to have
commanded a Nazi concentration camp in which 12,000 East Europeans, including
2,000 Jews, were executed during World War II.

Archbishop Trifa is the spiritual leader of 35,000 members of the Romanian
Orthodox Episcopate, based in Grass Lake, Mich. He agreed to leave the United
States if Federal authorities dropped charges that he incited anti-Semitic
violence. Explaining the Archbishop's concent to leave, his lawyer said he was
''old and sick'' and wanted to end a ''no-win situation,'' and hoped to go to
Switzerland.

               October 9, 1982, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. SEEKS TO DEPORT 10 OTHER NAZIS

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 10, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 925 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8


Government prosecutors said today that they were pressing 10 more deportation
proceedings against suspected Nazi war criminals and had enlarged the search for
additional suspects through the first systematic culling of Nazi rosters by
American investigators.

In the last year alone, a half-dozen new suspects have been identified in this
country through the acquisition and matching of a 50,000-name Nazi SS list
against American immigration records, according to Allan A. Ryan Jr., director
of the Justice Department's special investigations office. Similarly, several
more suspects were identified when the Soviet authorities, who are described as
very cooperative, released to American investigators the roster of a Nazi
''killer'' battalion that had been active in Eastern Europe on genocide
missions.

Mr. Ryan said the activities of the special three-year-old office, created to
prosecute criminal facist refugees from World War II, had been strengthened
greatly Thursday with the deportation agreement signed by Valerian Trifa, the
Rumanian Orthodox Archbishop accused of concealing war crimes when he applied
for United States citizenship.  The Archbishop will be the first naturalized
citizen to be thus deported in the 37 years since the war ended.

Seen as Signal to Others

''In practical terms, it's got to have an effect on every other defendant and
attorney watching the Trifa case,'' Mr. Ryan said, hailing the case as evidence
that the Government has become less passive in seeking to deport suspected war
criminals. ''Just the fact that the first deportation order was finally entered
in this area is enough to make them sit up and take notice.''

Archbishop Trifa, who yielded to the deportation agreement after a seven-year
legal fight in which he lost his citizenship, is accused of having been an
active Nazi sympathizer and of inciting a pogrom in which hundreds of Christians
and Jews were killed in Bucharest in 1941.

He has denied the charges while conceding that he made anti-Semitic speeches and
had supported the Iron Guard organization.  Representative William Lehman, a
Florida Democrat active in the pursuit of war criminals, said through his office
today that the archbishop's agreement showed the strength of the case that had
been assembled by the Justice Department agency.

Soviet Witnesses Testify

Since its inception in 1979, the special investigations office has started a
program of cooperation with Soviet authorities who have allowed more than 100
Soviet witnesses to testify and be crossexamined on television tape in
connection with American citizenship and deportation cases. Mr. Ryan said that
this testimony was crucial in most of the nine recent court victories by the
agency in which suspected facist criminals lost their American citizenship.

The agency, which assumed nine cases from other jurisdictions when the
anti-facist effort was centralized, now has 25 cases in the courts. Twelve are
at the first step, revocation of citizenship, Mr.  Ryan said, and the 13 others
are at the final step, deportation, with three of the defendants too infirm or
aged to face further prosecution.

In addition, 550 suspects have been investigated in the last three years, and of
these, 210 cases are still active. ''A few more'' suspects are discovered each
month, Mr. Ryan said, as the agency's experience and international sources grow.

''It's not cloak and dagger stuff,'' Mr. Ryan said. ''It's more sifting through
paper.''

SS Roster Led to Guard

In a routine clerical effort never tried in the past, he said, Conrad Schelling,
a former guard at the Dachau death camp, had been discovered in Chicago through
cross-matching the SS roster, which was acquired in 1981, and postwar
immigration records. He has since lost his citizenship for concealing his past
and Mr. Ryan's agency is seeking his deportation along with five others tracked
this way. In response to a question, Mr. Ryan said that his investigation had
found no evidence to confirm allegations that the Central Intelligence Agency
had helped Nazi war criminals resettle in the United States. He said that
specific individuals named in charges made on television by a former Justice
Department employee had been investigated. ''We've been unable to find any
evidence to prove they were Nazis,'' he said.

Mr. Ryan said the 50-member agency's role had been bolstered by a 1981 Supreme
Court decision upholding the point that immigrants could lose their citizenship
for concealing criminally facist backgrounds.

''Time is what we need most now,'' Mr. Ryan said. ''The people who did these
things are getting old and this work should have been done 30 years ago.''

---

Trifa Calls Himself Victim

DETROIT, Oct. 8 (AP) - Rumanian Orthodox Archbishop Valerian Trifa denied all
the Government charges against him today and called himself a victim.

''I had to acknowledge it to sign the agreement with the Government,'' he said.
''It was part of a way to come to an end to this. I feel victimized by the fact
that things are picked up and enlarged in such a way as to mean completely
different things.''

His attorney, William Swor of Detroit, said his client would like to relocate in
Switzerland.  However, Heinz Wey, consul at the Swiss Embassy in Washington,
said he could not predict whether the archbishop's request would be granted. He
said that ''Switzerland is not very eager to accept'' ex-Nazis.
