U.S. TO DEPORT ARCHBISHOP ACCUSED AS A NAZI ALLY

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 900 words

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 7


Valerian Trifa, the Rumanian Orthodox archbishop accused of being a Nazi
sympathizer who incited bloody riots during World War II, will be deported from
the United States, the Justice Department said today.

Archbishop Trifa, the spiritual leader of 35,000 members of the Romanian
Orthodox Episcopate, based in Grass Lake, Mich., will be the first person
deported from the United States for concealing war crimes from immigration
officials, according to Neal M. Sher, deputy director of the Office of Special
Investigations in the Justice Department.

Under an agreement with the Federal Government, Archbishop Trifa admitted lying
to immigration authorities to cover up his fascist sympathies when he entered
the United States 32 years ago. He agreed to leave the United States rather than
continue the civil deportation proceeding, which had begun here Monday before
Judge Bellino D'Ambrosio.

The 68-year-old archbishop wanted to avoid ''dragging it on'' in a ''no-win
situation,'' his attorney, William Swor, said. ''He's old and ill.''

Wants to Go to Switzerland

He said the archbishop, who was stripped of his naturalized American citizenship
in September 1980 after a five-year legal battle, wanted to go to Switzerland
and would apply for Swiss travel documents. He must leave the United States
within 60 days after receipt of the documents.

The Government was prepared to show that Archbishop Trifa had been an ardent
supporter of the Nazis and a member of a group called the Iron Guard, and that
he wrote inflammatory newspaper articles and made anti-Jewish speeches, said
Allan A. Ryan Jr., director of the special investigations office.

Federal officials said that a speech by Archbishop Trifa on Jan.  20, 1941,
touched off four days of rioting in Bucharest in which 300 Christians and Jews
were killed.

The charge of inciting riots, and other charges relating to what the Government
said was persecution of enemies of the Nazis, were dropped under Archbishop
Trifa's agreement to be deported.

Archbishop Trifa has repeatedly denied inciting anti-Semitic violence. But he
acknowleged that when he entered the United States he concealed his activities
in the Iron Guard, an anti-Semitic group active before World War II.

Investigations Continuing

''This is the first time in 30 years a person has been ordered deported for
fascist activities, and it won't be the last,'' Mr. Ryan said at a news
conference. He said his office was investigating 210 people living in the United
States who are believed to be fascists.  The Government has begun prosecutions
of 25.

Andrija Artukovic, a cabinet-level officer in the Nazi puppet government of
Croatia, was ordered deported in 1953, but still lives near Los Angeles. Mr.
Ryan explained that Mr. Artukovic was permitted to stay in the United States
because of the possibility that he might be persecuted if he returned to
Yugoslavia.

In 1971, the United States citizenship of Hermine Braunsteiner Ryan of Maspeth,
Queens, was revoked, and in 1973 she was extradited to West Germany, but not
deported. In 1981 she was sentenced to two consecutive life sentences after
being convicted in Bonn of child murder and selecting prisoners for the gas
chamber at the Maidanek concentration camp in Poland in World War II. At least
250,000 Jews are believed to have been killed at the camp.

Admits 3 Charges

When he entered the United States in 1950, Archbishop Trifa said he had been
confined to Nazi concentration camps. In opening arguments Monday, however,
Kathleen Coleman, a lawyer for the Justice Department, said Archbishop Trifa
spent his time after leaving Romania ''much like a tourist in Nazi Germany.'' He
eventually lived in comfortable housing that was separated from concentration
camp barracks, she said.

Archbishop Trifa admitted the truth of three specific accusations: that he was a
member of the Iron Guard, an organization deemed by the United States to be
fascist; that he misrepresented and concealed facts from immigration officials
when he entered the United States, and that he could be classified as an
excludable alien because he had lied to get his entry visa to the United States.


----

'Gratified' by Deportation

Kenneth J. Bialkin, national chairman of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai
B'rith, said Thursday that he was ''gratified'' at the imminent deportation of
Archbishop Trifa. ''We congratulate the Justice Department and offer A.D.L.'s
continued cooperation in ridding this country of Nazi war criminals,'' he said.

Elizabeth Holtzman, the Brooklyn District Attorney and a former United States
Representative, also said she was ''gratified'' by what she called a
''significant victory'' for the Justice Department.

Miss Holtzman, who was the chairman of the House subcommittee on immigration in
the 1970's when it investigated the Government's handling of reputed Nazis, said
of Archbishop Trifa: ''He is one of those I cited in 1974 when I pointed to the
failure of the United States to take action against alleged war criminals.''

''The fact that Trifa consented to deportation is a testament to the strength of
the Government's case against him,'' she said.

MEXICO'S PRESIDENT-ELECT TO MEET WITH REAGAN IN SAN DIEGO TODAY

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 8, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 748 words

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 7


Mexico's incoming President, Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, is expected to suggest
new ways for the United States to help alleviate this country's acute economic
crisis when he meets President Reagan in San Diego on Friday.

Although the informal talks are aimed essentially at allowing the two men to
become acquainted, well-placed Mexican sources said Mr. de la Madrid will argue
that the United States can best help Mexico meet its huge debt obligations and
rebuild its economy by providing new trade and credit opportunities.

The Mexican President-elect is also expected to raise numerous other issues,
including pending United States legislation to control illegal immigration,
although the economic problems he will inherit when he takes office Dec. 1 are
reportedly utmost on his mind.

The Reagan Administration has already provided emergency credit to Mexico and
has paid in advance for 40 million barrels of Mexican oil, although further
assistance is apparently conditioned on Mexico's reaching agreement with the
International Monetary Fund on an austerity program. Officials here said that an
agreement with the fund was close to being initialed.

Relations Now Strained

The talks Friday nevertheless come at a difficult moment since relations between
the Reagan Administration and the outgoing Government of President Jose Lopez
Portillo have deteriorated sharply, with officials here convinced that
Washington has tried to extract unfair advantage from this country's economic
difficulties.

Aware of Mexico's current mood of nationalism, aides of Mr. de la Madrid said
that in his talks with President Reagan he will also stress that the broad lines
of Mexico's foreign policy, including its independent approach to Central
America, will not change. ''There is a tradition of continuity to Mexican
foreign policy,'' a key official said, ''and it will be little different this
time round.''

But the aides insisted that Mr. de la Madrid, who speaks English and studied at
Harvard University, is eager to establish a good working relationship with the
United States during his six-year term so that problems between the two
countries can be dealt with without friction or emotion.

Referring to policy differences over Central America, Mr. de la Madrid said in a
televised interview last week that it was natural for two democracies to have
some disagreements, but he added that it should be a matter of pride for the
United States that a weaker neighbor ''should have the dignity to dissent on
occasions from some of the policies of the American Government.''

The program for Friday has been carefully worked out to avoid the impression
that Mr. de la Madrid is going cap in hand, with local officials pointing out
that incoming Presidents in both countries traditionally meet the President next
door before taking office.

Reagan to Cross Border

Officials here are also anxious to underline the fact that President Reagan will
first meet Mr. de la Madrid in Tijuana, where he will lay a wreath at a statue
of Benito Juarez, the leader of Mexico's 19th-century liberal reforms. This
visit to Mexico, although for only 45 minutes, will enable Mr. de la Madrid to
travel to Washington early next year without disturbing the tradition of
alternating visits by Mexican and United States Presidents. Mr.  Reagan traveled
to the Mexican border town of Ciudad Juarez for talks with President Jose Lopez
Portillo 10 days before his inauguration last year.

After meeting in Tijuana, Mr. Reagan and Mr. de la Madrid will drive together to
the Hotel El Coronado in San Diego for private talks and lunch, which will be
followed by a brief press statement.

No concrete agreements are expected to be announced, although aides to Mr. de la
Madrid are hoping for a promise that a top-level American delegation, headed
perhaps by Vice President Bush, will attend his inauguration.

Mr. Reagan will be accompanied by Secretary of State George P.  Schultz, the
national security assistant, William Clark, and other top White House officials.
Mr. de la Madrid's delegation will include several aides expected to play an
important role in his administration, including Mexico's current Ambassador to
Washington, Bernardo Sepulveda Amor.

PRESIDENT TO SIGN IMMIGRATION BILL

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 837 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7


President Reagan is expected soon to approve a bill making it possible for
thousands of Asian-born children of American servicemen to immigrate to the
United States.

The House and Senate passed the bill last Friday, just hours before they
adjourned.  Eleven Vietnamese-American children arrived in the United States
this week, but they differ from the intended beneficiaries of the bill passed by
Congress. The 11 children, who range in age from 7 to 15 years, have been openly
acknowledged by their American fathers. By contrast, the bill is meant to assist
children abandoned by, or unknown to, their American fathers.

Supporters of the bill said the United States was facing up to its moral
responsibility in helping the children come to ''the land of their fathers.''

Target of Cultural Biases

Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, said that ''these children,
though blameless in the eyes of God, have been forced to bear alone the brunt of
anti-American sentiment and cultural biases'' that stigmatize illegitimate or
mixed-race children.

Representative Stewart B. McKinney, a Connecticut Republican who led a four-year
effort to gain approval of the legislation, said, ''These children come from
nations committed to racial purity, and so they were regarded as nonpeople.''

The Reagan Administration, after some initial hesitation, supported the bill and
recommended several minor amendments that were adopted by Congress.
Administration officials said today that Mr. Reagan intended to sign the
measure.

The bill had 273 co-sponsors in the House. The chief sponsors of the legislation
in the Senate were Jeremiah Denton, Republican of Alabama, and Carl Levin,
Democrat of Michigan.

Guarantee of Financial Support

Under the bill, a child is eligible to immigrate to the United States if he was
fathered by an American citizen and was born in Korea, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia
or Thailand after 1950. He must also have a guarantee of financial support from
an American family or a private charitable agency for at least five years. The
family must have an income equal to at least 125 percent of the official poverty
standard, which for a family of four is about $9,300 a year. Federal officials
expect that the younger children will be formally adopted by American families.

While paternity is often difficult to establish, the bill lists several types of
evidence that the Attorney General may consider. The evidence includes ''the
physical appearance of the alien,'' birth and baptismal certificates, local
government records and photographs of the ''putative father,'' as well as proof
of financial support from the father.

There is no official estimate of the number of Amerasian children.  Mr. McKinney
said that 60,000 to 100,000 Amerasians might be eligible to immigrate under the
bill, but added that there was no way of knowing how many would come to the
United States.

Representative Douglas K. Bereuter, Republican of Nebraska, said the bill would
not increase the number of people entering the United States each year as
immigrants, would not increase the welfare caseload and would not cost taxpayers
anything.

Preferential Treatment

Under the immigration law, aliens who are children of American citizens are
eligible for preferential treatment when they try to immigrate to the United
States. However, an Amerasian youngster is not recognized as the child of an
American citizen unless the father acknowledges him. Under the bill, the Asian
youngsters would be eligible for the same preferential treatment as other
children of American citizens.

Visas are distributed under a system of six preferences. The Amerasian children
could receive visas under the first preference, for unmarried sons and daughters
of United States citizens, or the fourth preference, for married sons and
daughters of citizens.

The bill, according to Senator Denton, does not require that the fathers be
''specifically or individually identified.'' Federal officials said the
Government would make no attempt to track down the fathers.

Under the bill, an alien seeking entry to the United States must file a petition
with the Attorney General. In most cases, according to Congressional aides,
private charitable organizations will file the petitions on behalf of the
aliens.

Despite widespread support for the bill, it faced many difficulties. The
provision for Amerasians was originally part of a much larger immigration bill
sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Representative
Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky. They agreed to have it considered
separately when it became clear that Congress could not complete action on their
bill before adjourning last week.

               October 7, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

'WE SIMPLY CANNOT REMAIN A NATION WITHOUT BORDERS'

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 522 words


To the Editor:

The much-heralded yet widely misunderstood Simpson-Mazzoli Immigration Reform
bill (H.R. 6514, S. 2222) has been endorsed by many as the answer to our
immigration problems. They should know that the House Judiciary Committee, on
which I serve, has gutted the measure and made it one which will only worsen
those problems.

As amended by the committee, the bill has three basic weaknesses:

* It leaves intact the system of ''preferences'' for admitting relatives of
immigrants already here legally, leaving the door open for serious abuses (such
as the petition of one immigrant who sought entry for 69 relatives).

* The bill's sanctions against employers who knowingly hire illegal aliens have
been weakened to the point where the U.S. will continue to be an economic
magnet. The combination of the aliens' desire for jobs and the willingness of
some employers to obtain cheap, often sub-minimum-wage or even ''hidden'' labor
has resulted in thousands of cases of border jumping. Still, employers will have
a terribly large new paperwork burden thrust upon them.

* The bill legalizes the presence of all those who have already entered the
country illegally by granting them amnesty. This merely encourages more aliens
to cross our borders in the hope of beating the deadline for amnesty, while
discouraging those wading patiently through our immigration red tape.

Furthermore, the committee adopted, then rejected, and then adopted again a
limited provision of Federal reimbursement of state and local welfare and social
service costs which could be generated by many of those granted amnesty, so
state and local taxpayers would probably have to foot a substantial part of the
bill for the amnesty.

Frankly, I never was convinced that the measure would correct the immigration
law's weaknesses, which open our borders to an excessive number of legal and
illegal immigrants. The estimate of illegal aliens in the U.S. is already as
high as 12 million, on top of which we have accepted as many as 800,000
immigrants, refugees and other entrants a year, more than all other countries
combined.

These great numbers produce several serious problems, including the displacement
of Americans from their jobs and increases in the taxpayer burden of providing
social services.

I would hope the U.S. could continue as much as possible its ''open door''
tradition toward the displaced, the persecuted and the ambitious of the world.
However, the reality of our economic and resource situation is that we simply
cannot remain a nation without borders. We must limit the influx of aliens and
have an orderly and fair system for admitting those we are able to absorb.

The Simpson-Mazzoli measure, as reported by the House Judiciary Committee,
provides neither, so it cannot be regarded either as a true reform of our
messed-up immigration laws or as the first step toward restoring order to our
immigration system.

If it cannot be amended on the floor of the House to remedy these deficiencies,
it should be defeated.
F. JAMES SENSENBRENNER JR., Member of Congress, 9th Dist., Wis., Washington,
Sept. 28, 1982

L.I. MAN FAILS IN A COURT BID ON NAZI LINK

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON

SECTION: Section B; Page 7, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 401 words


A 62-year-old Long Island man who was said to have commanded a Nazi
concentration camp, in which 12,000 East Europeans, including 2,000 Jews, were
executed during World War II, lost his bid in United States Supreme Court
yesterday to retain his American citizenship.

The Justices let stand a ruling by Judge Jacob Mishler of Federal District Court
in Westbury, L.I., that denaturalized the man, Karl Linnas, a native Estonian
who lives in Greenlawn, L.I.

The next step toward deporting Mr. Linnas will be taken by the Justice
Department, according to Neal M. Sher, deputy director of the department's
special investigations unit, which was created three years ago to pursue the
prosecution of Nazi war criminals.

Deportation Proceedings

''We have already instituted deportation proceedings against him in New York,''
said Mr. Sher. ''Our next step is to get an Immigration Department judge to set
a date for his deportation.''

Judge Mishler found at the end of a nonjury trial in July 1981 that Mr. Linnas,
an engineering draftsman, had hidden his World War II role in Estonia as a
concentration camp official and his participation in the execution of prisoners.

The charges against Mr. Linnas were brought by the United States Government,
which accused him of lying to immigration authorities in 1951, when he entered
the United States as a displaced person from Germany, and again when he became
an American citizen in 1960.

Estonian Trial in Absentia

Federal attorneys said that Mr. Linnas had been an officer in an Estonian
partisan group that collaborated with the German Army and conducted executions
of Jews and Communists at the prison in Tartu, Estonia, in 1941. Mr. Linnas was
tried in absentia in 1962 in Estonia, which is now part of the Soviet Union, and
was sentenced to death.

The charges were denied by Mr. Linnas through his attorney, Ivars Berzins, who
attempted to prove that any testimony or documents provided by the Soviet Union
in the case were not trustworthy.

Mr. Linnas did not appear in court during the proceedings against him. Mr.
Berzins declined to talk with reporters and said he had advised Mr. Linnas not
to comment on the case.

Mr. Linnas's home telephone number in Greenlawn is unlisted at his request. No
one answered the door yesterday at his home.

11 CHILDREN FROM VIETNAM LAND ON THE COAST

BYLINE: By JUDITH CUMMINGS, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 661 words

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3


Eleven Vietnamese-American children who left Vietnam last week to rejoin their
American fathers arrived in the United States today.

They were met at Los Angeles International Airport and assisted through
immigration processing by American relief agency volunteers, who helped prepare
them for the final leg of their journey to new homes in American towns and
cities.

The children, aged 7 to 15, are the largest group of children of American
parentage from the Vietnam War years to leave that country since the war ended
in 1975. Officials of private relief agencies expressed the hope that the exodus
would continue and grow.

Fright Mixes With Joy

The arrival was marked by confusion and fright as well as relief and joy.  The
children emerged from immigration processing to meet a crowd of press and
television people. One little boy in front, apparently confused by the sight of
so many Caucasian men, cried out, ''Daddy, Daddy,'' although his father was not
on hand.

Most of the American parents of the children chose not to come to Los Angeles,
and were waiting at airports in their hometowns. The exception was Gary D.
Tanous of Camas, Wash., who flew to Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, to meet
his 15-year-old daughter, Jean Marie.

None of the children can speak English yet. Mr. Tanous said his daughter was
exhausted ''but exuberant about this whole thing.'' ''We weren't able to discuss
anything at all on the plane because there's a language barrier,'' he said. ''I
told her through an interpreter that I loved her and she said she loved me -
that and small talk.''

Left Loved Ones Behind

Nguyen Quoc Viet, 11 years old, bound for Sacramento, came out of the airplane
with tears in his eyes. Gary Larsen, who had traveled with the children as a
volunteer with Operation California, a relief agency, explained that the boy had
been weeping over leaving behind an aunt who had cared for him.

''In spite of the fact their existence in Saigon is very tough, they're still
leaving people who have been thir only emotional support for seven years,'' Mr.
Larsen said.

The children are being resettled in America under the Orderly Departure program.
The program, after several years of actively resettling children of French,
Australian and other nations' soldiers who were in Vietnam, has begun to make
progress in getting some Vietnamese-American children out, said Richard Walden,
executive director of Operation California, one of six volunteer agencies at the
airport.

20,000 Children Affected

Relief officials estimate that there were 20,000 children of American fathers in
Vietnam and that they suffered discrimination there because of their racial
heritage. Relief officials say the American Government has been reluctant to
accept them, asserting that there was inadquate proof to indicate that the
children were fathered by Americans and not other nationalities.

The few mixed-race offspring who have been released to date represent a small
minority whose parents have claimed paternity and who have sufficient
documentation to prove it to the satisfaction of the United States Government.
The Rev. Larry Hixon, an official of Church World Services, the relief arm of
the National Council of Churches, said he regarded the transfer of the children
as a bid by the Government of Vietnam to ''normalize relations between the two
Governments.''

''Vietnam has been more willing to talk than the U.S.,'' he said.  Last Friday,
as one result of the expanding effort to repatriate the children, Congress
passed a measure that would give the children of Americans first preference
among those seeking to immigrate from Vietnam.

               October 2, 1982, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

SIMPSON-MAZZOLI IMMIGRATION BILL: BACK TO THE BRACERO FIASCO?

SECTION: Section 1; Page 26, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 618 words


To the Editor:

Despite the claims of supporters (including The Times) of the Simpson-Mazzoli
immigration bill, there is one overriding and simple reason why the bill should
not be passed when the House takes it up later this session: It will not
accomplish its major purpose of curbing immigration.

he fever to pass the bill has been whipped up amid nationwide fears of vast
alien hordes sweeping relentlessly across our borders.  We don't know whether
this problem actually exists (the real numbers of undocumented workers coming
into the country has not been determined), but we do know that Simpson-Mazzoli
promises a cure it can't deliver. The version of the bill passed by the Senate
will actually let in more immigrant workers under an expanded and more lenient
H-2 program.

The current H-2 program allows growers in the Northeast and South to bring small
numbers of temporary workers into the country to harvest crops, under very
restricted circumstances and with a long and complex application process. The
Simpson-Mazzoli bill greatly simplifies the process and expands the program to
give employers all over the country wide access to H-2 workers.

Congress has talked about allowing 175,000 to a million workers into the U.S.
under H-2. The experience in this country with the bracero program of the 40's,
50's and 60's, and that of European countries with guest-worker programs,
suggest that a great many of these H-2 workers will stay on after their
temporary status expires, even without documentation.

Since most choose temporary worker situations because they cannot find any work
or work that pays as well at home, they are predictably unwilling to give up the
better life. Barring a change in the economic situation back home, their
newfound prosperity is a much stronger carrot than enforcement measures are a
stick.

The Simpson-Mazzoli H-2 program is really just a replay of the bracero program,
sure to mirror that program in another respect as well: It is certain to repeat
the abuses that marred the bracero program and eventually led to its
discontinuation in 1964. Workers lived in unsanitary hovels, worked for low pay,
faced numberless abuses in the work place and had no alternative to accepting
their situation without question. Braceros, in effect, had no rights.

The abuses of the bracero program were viewed universally as a national
disgrace, and Simpson-Mazzoli supporters assure us that those abuses will not be
repeated. Yet there is no real, effective defense against them in any system
that creates a sub-class of people.

The bracero experience leads back to the first point.  Simpson-Mazzoli will not
work because it will foster immigration.  Despite the shocking abuses of the
bracero program, large numbers of braceros opted to stay in this country. So
will H-2 workers, because the promise of a better life is as attractive to them,
as it has been to generations of immigrants.

Real, positive immigration reform is both necessary and possible.
Simpson-Mazzoli is merely a rehash of old thinking that will create far more
problems than it solves. It should be defeated.  JOAQUIN G. AVILA President and
General Counsel Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund San
Francisco, Sept. 27, 1982

              September 27, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

A SURGE OF IMMIGRANTS ALTERS NEW YORK'S FACE;
A New Melting Pot: The City in the 80's First article of a series appearing
periodically

BYLINE: By DENA KLEIMAN

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1669 words


More so today than at any time since the early part of this century, when
boatloads of Irish, Italians and Eastern Europeans spilled onto the city's
shores, New York is a city of immigrants. Beginning 17 years ago with a
loosening in the Federal immigration law, the latest surge of foreigners from
virtually every nation has reached dimensions not seen since the last great wave
of immigration ended in the 1920's as the heyday of Ellis Island came to a
close, Federal immigration records show. More than a million immigrants now live
in New York City. According to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, there
are more than 650,000 legal immigrants here, and the city estimates that there
are 750,000 illegal aliens as well.

The heaviest influxes are from Central and South America, the Caribbean, Italy,
the Soviet Union, India, China and Korea, a complex mix that includes wealthy
newcomers whose high visibility around the city often obscures the traditional
immigrant force - those who come here with only a dream and a willingness to
struggle.

This new surge is altering the city's ethnic texture, revitalizing many of its
neighborhoods and reaffirming something about the city that many may have
thought long lost - that despite the fiscal crisis, crime statistics and other
drawbacks, the rags-to-riches promise of New York that attracted generations of
immigrants is still very much alive.

''The word has leaked out,'' said Frank Vardy, who analyzes immigration for the
city's Planning Commission. ''You can make a living in this city, and you might
even make it big.''

All over New York, immigrants are making their mark. And nowhere is this
presence more apparent than in the new ethnic outposts that have sprouted in
recent years, taking over where Little Italy, Chinatown, the Lower East Side and
other immigrant nurturing grounds of the past left off.

Of these, perhaps none is more an epitome of the whole city's new ethnic
landscape than Elmhurst, Queens. It is the city's most ethnically diverse
neighborhood, a true melting pot where 20,000 immigrants from more than 110
countries live in the shadow of the elevated No. 7 Flushing subway line, and
where every day a trip to the cleaners, a stop at the post office or a wait for
the bus becomes an important step in that complicated osmosis involved in
becoming an American.

Elmhurst is the kind of place where the local grocer is Korean, the butcher
comes from Argentina and the baker is Colombian - where it is harder to find a
decent hamburger than Pakistani lemon pickle. There are blocks where the fashion
is saris, and others where it is mandarin collars, and still others with
garments that look plucked from the streets of Guatemala.

Ethnic surprises abound in this community of modest row houses and low-rise
apartment buildings that has been transformed over the past decade from an
Archie Bunker-style working class haven to an international metropolis in
miniature. Indian, Greek, Korean, Thai, Chinese, Argentine, Colombian, Italian,
Ecuadorean restaurants dot the commercial terrain. An Indian ashram sits across
from the local high school. The Dutch Reformed Church now conducts services in
Taiwanese.

Unlike many other sectors of the city where people have flocked in distinct
ethnic groups, Elmhurst is a place where Bengalis live alongside Ecuadoreans -
where lending a cup of sugar becomes as much an exercise in double translation
as in neighborliness.

Elmhurst has an Italian-style pizzeria operated by a newcomer from Greece who is
unable to talk to his customers because most are from India. The most faithful
patrons at the local doughnut shop are Chinese, although most have yet to master
the word for cruller.

It is a place, in fact, where the pale-skinned look out of place and unaccented
English sounds odd.

In Search of English

''I came to New York so that I could learn English,'' said Jumoke Rhodes, a
Nigerian whose native language is Yoruba and who complains that neither she nor
her two children can find anyone in Elmhurst to speak English with. ''Here is an
English-speaking country. What I got in my life is something else. I don't know
where I am. Spain?  China?''

In many ways, Elmhurst furnishes an overview of today's immigrant experience -
reflecting many of the contributions and burdens this foreign population has
brought to the city as a whole.

There are 34 different languages spoken by pupils in the local public school,
P.S. 89. Citywide, the Board of Education has hired 2,500 teachers at a yearly
cost of $27 million to work with youngsters unable to speak English.

Elmhurst General Hospital employs its own interpreters, and deals daily with
such situations as having an Indian man refuse an emergency gynecological
examination for his wife because the only doctors on call are men.

There are sweatshops in Elmhurst where workers are paid by the piece - and below
the minimum wage. There are places, too, where forged Social Security cards are
reported to go for $180.

''The city is changing, there's no question about that,'' said Charles B. Keely,
a senior associate at the Population Council, which studies international
population movement and trends. ''Not since the turn of the century have there
been so many foreigners here, and they are as diverse a group as ever.''

''It's amazing,'' said Detective Jerry Campbell of the 110th Precinct, which
includes Elmhurst. ''Anything God put on this earth, we've got at least two of
them here in this precinct.''

Attraction Is Not Apparent

No one quite knows why so many different foreigners flock to Elmhurst, which is
about an 18-minute subway ride from Times Square.  Housing is cheaper than it is
in Manhattan, but no more so than in many other neighborhoods. There is nothing
about the community's layout or services that would naturally attract the
foreign born.  Still, immigrants arrive every day - having been given the green
light by relatives and friends or by friends of friends -often oblivious to how
international a center it really is.

''Please, change, quarters,'' Lev Mines said in uncertain English the other day,
handing over a dollar bill to a woman in a coffee shop in Elmhurst.

''Not enough,'' Maria Fernanda replied with equal linguistic difficulty,
attempting to explain she only had dimes.

There the two of them were. He, who moved to this country two years ago from
Leningrad, and she, who arrived here two years ago from Colombia, reaching out
to one another in a foreign tongue, ultimately arriving at some understanding,
with neither of them quite aware how.

A Shared Deficiency

''No English, no English,'' Mr. Mines exclaimed, as if to apologize to the rest
of the customers in the shop. Unbeknown to him, the shop caters primarily to
Colombians, and few of the customers spoke English either.

Elmhurst - named years ago for its abundance of elm trees - sits in the heart of
Queens, adjoining such other increasings oolong.

Economic Contrasts

Few foreigners find life easy here in Elmhurst. It is a place where families are
often crowded five to a room and work as many as 14 hours a day, seven days a
week. Many in this community hold two or three jobs.

It is a place of extremes: A Yugoslavian handyman and his wife, who cleans
office buildings at night in Manhattan, saved up $90,000 to buy a new home, but
a young Colombian busboy who came to this country last year to seek his fortune
paces the floor at night, torn between subsisting here or swallowing his pride
and going home.

In Elmhurst lives Isabel Aguirre from Argentina, who operates the shish kebob
stand on Vanderbilt Avenue at 43d Street, across from Grand Central Station, and
Nu Trieu Pheu, who escaped by boat from Vietnam. It is home for 25-year-old
Cesar Sierra, an immigrant from Colombia now studying to become a doctor, and
28-year-old Cheng-I Chang, who hopes someday to open his own Chinese restaurant.
And it is now home for Yvonne Chang, a 3-year-old immigrant from Taiwan, who has
been here three months and is already listening to records about the life of
Curious George.

Sophie Chapman was on a float in a Hispanic Day parade when she met the man she
hopes to marry. Tina Wong decided to marry Jimmy, and did, after bumping into
him on a street corner in Brooklyn after not having seen him for years since
their school days in Hong Kong.

An Immigrant Romance

As for Sarita Ocampo, romance was a bit more involved.  Mrs. Ocampo, who now
works in Elmhurst, first came to the United States from Colombia as a maid. She
had never been a maid before, and disliked the job from the start. She
continued, however, because - given her inability to speak the language - there
was nothing else for her to do.

One day Mrs. Ocampo went looking for an apartment and consulted a real estate
agent. This particular agent had more than simply real estate to offer. He asked
whether Mrs. Ocampo was interested in making some extra money. She said she was.
He opened his wallet, and took out a photograph of his brother.

He said his brother, who had no legal way to remain in this country, would pay
her $800 if she would agree to marry him. Mrs.  Ocampo recalls that she was
intrigued by the photograph. She agreed to the deal, and a week later was
married. That, she says, was 10 years ago. They are still married. They are
still in love. He has never paid her the $800.

These days, the Ocampos, who have recently bought a home on Long Island, are
both in the real estate business. They are looking for a maid.

POLES WHO TOOK VESSEL TO JERSEY GRANTED ASYLUM

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Page 29, Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 539 words

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 24


Four members of the Polish labor union Solidarity who sailed into Port
Elizabeth, N.J., in the dark last week were granted political asylum today, and
freed from a detention center to find homes and jobs in the United States.

Tired after their five-month journey in a 38-foot schooner and their six-day
stay in a detention center in Brooklyn, the four men walked out of the Federal
building here shortly before 5 P.M.

''We are all very happy,'' one of the men, Jarek Neczaj-Hruzewicz, said. ''We
didn't think it would be so fast.'' Political asylum was granted by the United
States Department of State at 4 P.M., just hours after Nathan Gordon, an
immigration judge, had ordered a new hearing that would have allowed the
Immigration and Naturalization Service to release the men on bail until
deportation hearings.

The hearings ordered by Judge Gordon were canceled when the State Department
allowed the men to remain in the United States as political refugees.

Concern About Publicity

Their attorney, William McAlvanah, said the men could apply for permanent
residency in a year.  Mr. Neczaj-Hruzewicz, a former chemistry professor at the
University of Lublin and the only one of the four who can speak English, said
the men were concerned about the publicity their case has attracted.

''I have a wife and children in Poland,'' Mr. Neczaj-Hruzewicz said. ''We all
do. That's why we are so worried.'' Two of the other men, Andrzej Bienkowski and
Stanley Kozak, also are from Lublin. The fourth, Andrzej Plewik, is from
Pulaway.  Poland had permitted the men to fly to Athens, where the boat was
moored, for a vacation sail back to Poland, Mr. Neczaj-Hruzewicz said last week.

Instead, he said, the crew had sailed through the Mediterranean Sea and across
the Atlantic to the United States, landing in Africa, France, Spain and Bermuda
on the way.

Coast Guard Avoided

The four men sailed into Port Elizabeth on Sept. 16, avoiding Coast Guard
vessels while they searched for a marina. Once they docked, the men found a bar
where some people spoke Polish and set out to find their friends.

Mr. McAlvanah said the four men had intended to ask their friends for help in
getting visas to stay in the United States, but immigration officials learned of
their arrival and the men were taken into Federal custody.

Membership in Solidarity was one of the reasons, ''among other things,'' that
prompted their flight, Mr. Neczaj-Hruzewicz said today.

The other issues ''touch on political reasons,'' he added, and refused to
elaborate.  The four left the courthouse for Elizabeth to stay with friends
while they search for jobs and homes.  ''We must find some way to support our
families,'' Mr.  Neczaj-Hruzewicz said.  Hearings on whether they should be
allowed to enter the United States had opened Tuesday.

AROUND THE NATION;
10 Indicted for Importing Indonesians for Servitude

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 172 words

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 23


Ten people, eight of them members of one family, were indicted today by a
Federal grand jury on charges of bringing 50 Indonesians into the United States
illegally and selling them to wealthy residents as servants.

Two defendants were arrested today, and the others are expected to surrender to
the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Immigration and Naturalization
Service for arraignment Oct. 4.

Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds, head of the Civil Rights
Division of the Justice Department, said in a statement the indictment had
resulted from a 16-month international investigation by the F.B.I., the
immigration agency and the office of United States Attorney Stephen Trott in Los
Angeles.

Each of the defendants was charged with conspiracy. Some face additional counts
of enticement into slavery; holding in involuntary servitude; holding in
peonage; fraud and misuse of visa, and bringing illegal aliens into the United
States.

Showing ID at the Golden Doors

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 591 words


There are, in truth, two golden doors to the United States. Anyone who wants to
keep the front door open to legal immigration, despite the rising nativist and
racist pressures, should like the Simpson-Mazzoli immigration reform bill. So
should anyone who wants to close the back door against illegal immigration.
That's why the bill, having overwhelmingly passed the Senate, has finally run
the gantlet of the House Judiciary Committee. If the House leadership recognizes
how broad a consensus the bill represents, it could come before the whole House
next week.

But consensus notwithstanding, critics right and left are rushing to launch
torpedoes, notably because they are offended by the bill's key provision:
employer sanctions. That is, employers could no longer innocently hire illegal
aliens. They would have to check the identification of prospective workers, thus
discouraging the illegal flow. To the critics, identification is a dirty word;
they insist that as a cure, it is worse than the disease.

The argument may have appeal to libertarians on the right and to civil
libertarians on the left, but it remains romantic. The Simpson-Mazzoli bill
offers the opportunity of a generation and ought not to be obstructed by such
yearnings for a simpler past.  Identification is a fact of modern American life.
The test is how to use it wisely.

The American Civil Liberties Union opposes use of Social Security or other
Government cards to identify legal immigrants applying for work: that would, in
effect, create an ''employment passport.'' The libertarian right expresses
similar horror. Our colleague, William Safire, writes of ''this generation's
longest step toward totalitarianism.'' What's all the shouting about? The United
States of the 80's is a time of Visa, MasterCard and other forms of
identification. Americans carry it not because of orders from some Big Brother
but because they want and need it.

Applying for a job? You should want to give your Social Security number, so
payroll taxes will be properly credited to your account.  Hate identification in
principle? Probably every one of the critics has a driver's license, and
produces it without qualm when cashing a check. And if not, 41 states already
provide special cards for people without drivers' licenses who want ID.

The only practical right the Simpson-Mazzoli bill would curtail is the right to
use counterfeit identification. In exchange, the nation would greatly strengthen
its capacity to control the borders and let in legal applicants, patiently
waiting in line, instead of gatecrashers. To us, the medicine's side effects are
slight compared with the disease.

Ah, but that's not what we're afraid of, the critics say. Once you create
national identification, like the forgery-resistant Social Security card
announced just yesterday, you invite increasing intrusiveness. The police, for
instance, will want to use it to look for heinous criminals - and then
not-so-heinous criminals. This is one camel's nose that must be kept out from
under the tent.

That is always a danger with a camel, but what a sensible society does with a
camel is ride it. One does not ban telephones because they can be tapped. The
Simpson-Mazzoli bill provides a fair, humane and effective way to control
immigration. If the 97th Congress approves, it will finally have done something
to be remembered for.

              September 24, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

NOTHING TOTALITARIAN ABOUT A WORKER'S ID CARD

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 545 words


To the Editor:

To equate a secure system to determine employment eligibility with
totalitarianism, as William Safire does (''The Computer Tattoo,'' column Sept.
9), is sheer nonsense. Criticisms of adequate immigration controls, based on
civil liberties, have no merit and merely distract attention from the real
issues.

he central immigration issue is whether or not this country will, at long last,
assert its sovereign right (and duty) to control its own borders, as every other
country has long done. Senator Alan Simpson and many others have correctly
judged that to do so, two things are essential: employer sanctions to prevent
the hiring of illegal aliens and a secure system of worker identification, so
that employers can easily determine which applicants are citizens or legal
residents.

The alternative is social and economic chaos, coupled with major changes in the
ethnic composition of our society, and continued rapid population growth.
Because of their proximity, and the ease with which their citizens can enter the
U.S. illegally, perhaps the greatest threat is posed by the countries of Central
America, Latin America and the Caribbean.

Their people are all worthy people, but we cannot solve those countries'
problems, which stem largely from overpopulation and continued population
growth, by allowing millions to enter the U.S., as legal or illegal aliens.

Mexico is a case in point. Its population, at present about 70 million, is
expected to double within the next 25 years or so.  Without adequate immigration
controls, we might reasonably fear that a substantial proportion of the
additional 70 million will be living and working here.

Is our present Social Security card (now too easy to obtain fraudulently and too
easy to forge and tamper with) a threat to civil liberty? Of course not. Would
it somehow be a threat if it were upgraded in order to prevent fraud, so that an
applicant for a card would have to present proof of citizenship or legal
residence to obtain one? The question answers itself.

Congress is at last on the right track in proposing effective immigration
controls. The Senate bill errs, however, by making provision for too many legal
immigrants each year. In our view, our national goal should be zero net
migration; that is, the number of legal immigrants allowed to enter the U.S.
each year should not exceed the number of American citizens and legal residents
leaving the country permanently - a number thought to be in the range of 50,000
to 100,000.

One of our top-priority national goals should be to halt and then reverse U.S.
population growth (now about three million a year).  There is no valid reason
why we should continue to allow immigration - which now accounts for over half
our annual growth in population - to contribute to any further increase in our
numbers.  DONALD MANN President Negative Population Growth, Inc.

New York, Sept. 15, 1982

NOTHING TOTALITARIAN ABOUT WORKER'S ID CARD

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 414 words


To the Editor:

William Safire terms the development of a secure system to determine employee
eligibility for work purposes in the United States ''this generation's longest
step toward totalitarianism.'' I take great exception.

As former chairman of the Civil Rights Commission and more recently chairman of
the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy, I have not been
unmindful of attempts to abridge freedom and curtail civil liberties. Neither
have Senator Alan Simpson and Representative Ron Mazzoli, the architects of the
immigration reform bill being debated in the Congress, or Representative Peter
Rodino, the able chairman of the House Judiciary Committee.

Identification systems to be used upon application for a job and for work
purposes only are no different from other forms of identification required by
our society today and readily accepted by millions of Americans: credit cards
which must be checked by merchants; identification cards other than driver's
licenses used for cashing checks; Social Security numbers to open bank accounts,
register for school or obtain employment.

Sufficient safeguards to prevent the abuse of any worker identification system
must be written into the law. The Simpson-Mazzoli bill, as adopted by the Senate
and as under consideration by the House, contains these safeguards, and we shall
all work to maintain their sanctity.

In my view and in the view of many of my colleagues on the Select Commission, it
is of paramount importance that the United States take control of its own
borders, legalize a substantial number of undocumented persons currently in our
country and bring them out of the shadows, guarantee that in the future American
citizens and permanent resident aliens will have the opportunity to get the jobs
that are available, and demagnetize the U.S. as a source of jobs for
undocumented persons seeking work.

Contrary to what Mr. Safire says, I see a nondiscriminatory worker
identification system, coupled with sanctions against employers who knowingly
hire undocumented aliens, as an effort to increase the rights of American
workers, not to abridge our freedoms.

Raising the specter of ''Big Brotherdom,'' calling a worker identification
system totalitarian or labeling it ''the computer tattoo'' does not further the
debate on U.S. immigration policy; it only poisons it.  (Rev.)
THEODORE M. HESBURGH, Co-Chairperson, Citizens' Committee for Immigration
Reform, Washington, Sept. 14, 1982

HOUSE UNIT BACKS IMMIGRATION BILL

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 926 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22


The House Judiciary Committee today approved a bill containing a comprehensive
revision of the nation's immigration laws. But the bill differs from one passed
by the Senate, and it was not immediately clear whether Congress could complete
action on the legislation before it adjourns in early October.

The House committee's bill contains a ban on the employment of illegal aliens
and would offer an amnesty to several million illegal aliens. No one knows the
precise number of illegal aliens who would qualify.

By a voice vote, the committee recommended passage of the bill by the full
House. But the panel was deeply divided. Voting 15 to 13, it defeated a motion
to send the legislation back to the Subcommittee on Immigration for further
work.

Just before the final vote, Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of
Kentucky, the bill's chief sponsor, told his colleagues: ''This bill is
imperfect. I am the first one to say it is.'' But he added that it was also
''fair, balanced, sensible, humane and workable.''

Called First Such Effort

A co-sponsor, Representative Hamilton Fish Jr., Republican of upstate New York,
said that ''this bill comes to grips for the first time with serious enforcement
of the law'' on illegal aliens.

The Senate last month approved an immigration bill that is generally similar to
the House bill but different in many details. If the legislation is not passed
in precisely the same form by both Houses before adjournment, it dies and the
work of writing an immigration bill would have to start over in both houses in
January.

The bill approved by the Judiciary Committee establishes a graduated system of
penalties for employers who hire illegal aliens.  The penalties range from a
warning on the first offense to a maximum, on the fourth offense, of one year in
prison and a $3,000 fine for each illegal alien worker.

The House bill, like the Senate's, establishes a two-tier system for granting
legal status to illegal aliens. Aliens who entered the country before Jan. 1,
1977 and had resided here continuously since then would be eligible for
permanent resident status. The bill would grant ''temporary resident'' status to
those who entered from Jan. 1, 1977 to Jan. 1, 1980. After three years in that
status, temporary residents could become permanent residents. Aliens can apply
for citizenship after five years as permanent residents.

Administration Lobbying

Aliens who have entered the country since Jan. 1, 1980 would not be eligible for
the amnesty.  Administration officials mounted an intensive lobbying effort
today for Congressional approval of an immigration bill that President Reagan
could sign.

The House Judiciary Committee today approved, then reconsidered and rejected an
amendment that would have guaranteed full Federal reimbursement of state and
local governments for the cost of all welfare and medical assistance provided to
aliens who receive amnesty. The amendment was offered by Representative Don
Edwards, Democrat of California.

Administration officials, including Deputy Attorney General Edward C. Schmults,
persuaded several Republicans to switch their votes on the Edwards amendment,
saying it was so costly it would, in effect, kill the bill. The Administration
wants a comprehensive immigration bill but opposed the original Edwards
amendment.

Revised Amendment Approved

The committee later approved a revised version of the amendment that would
provide reimbursement to state and local governments, ''subject to available
appropriations.''

On the question whether there was time for full House action on the bill, the
Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that the
Judiciary Committee Chairman, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of
New Jersey, had made no request to have the bill considered on the floor. ''It
has not been mentioned to me as a priority,'' the Speaker said.

Mr. Rodino said he intended to make such a request. The bill ''is a priority
with me,'' he said.  The House Majority Leader, Representative Jim Wright,
Democrat of Texas, said the bill would be ''highly controversial'' and would
have ''a difficult time passing.''

But Representative Mazzoli, the bill's sponsor, said ''a lot of people are
feeding the Speaker erroneous information about the bill.'' He said the
information came from lobbyists and members of Congress who opposed the bill.

Propriety Is Debated

Today's action by the House Judiciary Committee followed a lengthy debate on the
propriety of granting amnesty to illegal aliens.  Proponents said amnesty was a
necessary corollary to fines and prison terms for employers hiring illegal
aliens.

But Representative Bill McCollum, Republican of Florida, said amnesty would be
''a reward for lawbreakers,'' an incentive for more illegal immigration and a
burden to state and local governments, which would have to provide welfare and
social services to some of the aliens.

''This act of legalization provides a magnet effect to draw millions of aliens
across the border in the hope that they too may be given amnesty and they too
may be given access to the economic fruits of our country without having to wait
in line,'' Mr. McCollum said.

U.S. MOVES TO PAROLE 49 HAITIANS HELD IN BROOKLYN

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 800 words


The Justice Department said yesterday that it intended to parole 49 illegal
Haitian aliens who had been detained in Brooklyn for from nine to 13 months
while their applications for legal admission into the United States were
pending.

The 49 had not been covered by the ruling of a Federal court in Miami in June
that called for parole of 1,774 other illegal Haitian refugees being held
elsewhere in the United States and in Puerto Rico.

Their continued detention had provoked charges of unfairness by their attorneys
and other critics of the continued detention, but immigration officials had said
that they were enforcing the law and that release of the 49 was not required by
any court ruling.

Yesterday, however, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service,
a branch of the Justice Department, said the service had concluded, ''for
humanitarian reasons and in order to avoid any appearance of unfairness, that
all Haitians in detention on the date of the court order'' issued in Miami by
Judge Eugene Spellman ''should be treated similarly.''

The spokesman, Duke Austin, said he did not think the Reagan Administration had
bowed to public criticism, including criticism in the press, in deciding to
parole the Brooklyn detainees. ''We're saying we're doing it now because we feel
we want to be fair,'' he said.

Asked why the Administration had not felt it would be fair to release the
Brooklyn detainees earlier, he said officials had been focusing on the problems
of releasing the much larger group covered by Judge Spellman's order. Now, he
said, ''we have experience under that program and feel we could probably use
those conditions and experience to parole these people.''

An attorney for the 49, Arthur C. Helton of the Lawyers Committee for
International Human Rights, said of the parole plan announced yesterday: ''I
would consider it the only just, proper and legal outcome. I would give a good
deal of credit for the outcome to a very concerned press as well as interested
politicians.''

Mr. Austin said he could not predict when the first of the 49 will be released
from the Brooklyn detention facility, a former Navy prison at 136 Flushing
Avenue, on the edge of the Fort Greene section. He said that would depend on how
quickly a program could be set up under which sponsors - such as church groups
or individual families - could be found for each person and other conditions
could be arranged ''to insure the appearance of those paroled for later
processing.''

That processing involves a series of hearings and appeals that will end with
each detainee either being permitted to remain in the United States under
political asylum or being sent back to Haiti.

Dispute Over Status

The Haitians contend that they are political refugees and are seeking political
asylum. The Government says they are economic refugees, and thus not eligible
for admission.

They were detained under a policy, adopted by the Reagan Administration 15
months ago, of placing illegal aliens in detention until their status was
determined. Previously, Mr. Austin said, such aliens were paroled pending the
status proceedings.

Supporters of the Haitians detained under the policy charged that it
discriminated against them. In his decision, Judge Spellman ruled that the
policy was not discriminatory, but that 1,774 of the Haitians detained under it
had been jailed illegally because the Government had not given proper notice and
opportunity for public comment before implementing the policy.

However, he said his parole order did not apply to the Haitians being held in
Brooklyn because their separate lawsuit for parole had been lost in the Federal
Court of Appeals in Manhattan.

2 Have Been Given Asylum

The Administration undertook the tougher detention policy to try to stem the
tide of illegal ''boat people'' from Haiti, and Mr. Austin said this had worked.
In 1980, he said yesterday, more than 15,000 Haitians had been caught trying to
enter the country illegally. Thus far in 1982, he said, only 84 had been found.

As of yesterday, he said, more than 1,500 of the detainees covered by Judge
Spellman's order had been paroled, with two having been granted political asylum
and none yet sent back to Haiti. Those who have been denied asylum by
immigration judges are appealing, he said.

The men and women being held in Brooklyn have been kept in conditions that their
lawyers called coercive and highly inadequate.  They said the refugees had not
been provided adequate medical care or recreational and social services.

THE CITY;
4 Poles Remain In U.S. Custody

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 207 words


Four Polish nationals who sailed into Port Elizabeth, N.J., last Thursday after
a four-month voyage from Greece in a 38-foot sailboat remained in custody
yesterday pending action by immigration officials on their request to remain in
the United States.

Mary Mistrette, acting district director of the Newark office of the Immigration
and Naturalization Service, which is handling the case, declined yesterday to
answer any questions about the four. She also refused to amplify on a brief
statement Friday confirming that the four Poles had arrived and were being
detained while their request to stay was being considered.

The immigration service's office was closed over the weekend, and there were no
indications that officials were conferring on the case. The four men were being
held at immigration service facilities at 35 Remsen Street in Brooklyn.

Before being taken into custody, one of the Poles, who spoke English, said in an
interview that all were members of the outlawed Solidarity labor union and had
left families and weathered an Atlantic crossing to escape from Poland, which
has been under martial law since last December.

CHANCES DIM ON PASSING NEW IMMIGRATION LAW

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 11, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 653 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19


Chances for approval of a comprehensive immigration bill in the current session
of Congress seemed to decline last week when the chairman of a second House
committee asserted a right to have the bill reviewed by his panel.

The chairman, Representative Carl D. Perkins, who heads the Committee on
Education and Labor, said his panel had ''clear, unquestionable jurisdiction''
over those sections of the bill relating to the importation of foreign laborers.

Accordingly, Mr. Perkins, a Kentucky Democrat, asked Speaker of the House Thomas
P. O'Neill Jr. to refer the bill to the education panel after the Judiciary
Committee finishes work on it. Mr. Perkins said he wanted to be sure that the
legislation maintained labor standards designed to protect aliens working
temporarily in the United States.

The regulations, he said, are also designed to ''prevent an adverse effect on
the domestic work force.'' The bill, sponsored by Representative Romano L.
Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky, sets fines and prison terms for employers hiring
illegal aliens, but it also offers amnesty to millions of illegal aliens already
in the country. Last month the Senate, by a vote of 80 to 19, passed an
immigration bill sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming.

Opponents Back Perkins

The Senate report on the bill said it was ''the first comprehensive immigration
reform effort'' in 30 years.  Opponents of the House bill, including Hispanic
American groups, had urged Mr. Perkins to assert his right of review in the hope
that it would slow the bill's progress and prevent enactment. A committee aide
said that Mr. Perkins was not trying to ''kill the bill,'' but was genuinely
concerned that it might weaken the labor standards found in existing
regulations.

Mr. Mazzoli has said that the bill would streamline the process for admitting
agricultural workers from Mexico and other countries, but he maintained that it
would not adversely affect American workers.

The Judiciary Committee considered the Mazzoli bill and numerous proposed
amendments for three days last week. It is scheduled to take up the bill again
Tuesday and could vote then to report it favorably to the full House.

Interest of Other Panels

A third panel, the Agriculture Committee, headed by Representative E. (Kika) de
la Garza, Democrat of Texas, may also ask for referral of the bill, committee
aides said. And a fourth, the House Budget Committee, might also want to examine
the bill because it requires ''an increase in Border Patrol and other
enforcement activities of the Immigration and Naturalization Service,'' as well
as a new system for verifying that all job applicants are either citizens or
aliens authorized to work in this country.

Mr. de la Garza has asked staff lawyers to determine whether the Agriculture
Committee has a ''jurisdictional claim'' on the bill.  Committee aides said
there probably was a basis for such a claim because the Agriculture Committee
had authorized a program under which Mexican farm workers were admitted to the
United States from 1942 to 1964.

If Mr. O'Neill decides to refer the immigration bill to another committee, he
could limit the time for its consideration by the committee. The time could be
as short as one day or as long as several months.

The House is scheduled to adjourn Oct. 8. Supporters of the Mazzoli bill said
they were troubled by the prospect of any delays, but they found consolation in
Congress's plan to return for a special session after the elections in November.
President Reagan has asked Congress to hold the session so it could pass
appropriations bills, but once Congress reconvenes, it could also act on other
legislation.

IMMIGRATION AGENCY'S MOVE OPPOSED

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 28, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 894 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 18


Waiting in line on the street for up to 18 hours to deal with the Immigration
and Naturalization Service often makes people unpleasant. Were it not for the
line, which often begins to form by midnight, a proposal to move the Federal
agency's office out of downtown might set off fewer howls.

''Everybody knows that a lot of influential people don't want I.N.S. in downtown
Miami,'' said a resident of the area near 79th Street and Biscayne Boulevard,
where the agency is supposed to move to make room for an expanded United States
Attorney's office. ''But we certainly don't want it here, either.''

The downtown office has been considered convenient because it is served well by
public transportation, and for almost 20 years it created no controversy.

But about a year ago the long lines began to form outside, mainly because the
agency adopted a procedure under which nearly every client of the agency, alien
or citizen, now has to appear personally before an agency official.  Under this
''up-front adjudication'' policy, applications filed by mail are either returned
or not acted upon.

Fights and Heat in the Line

As a result, hundreds of people have started forming lines, often at midnight,
to be able to see an official by 4 P.M. On occasion, fist and knife fights have
broken out, and the police have had to intervene.

Complaints by many clients exhausted by waiting all day in the Florida sun have
not made immigration officials change the policy.  The agency, part of the
Justice Department, has regarded the situation outside its building as a problem
under the city's jurisdiction.

''This might be technically true,'' said Mayor Maurice A. Ferre.  ''But this is
the worst bureaucratic buck-passing I have ever seen.  The I.N.S. has caused a
serious problem, and now they are blaming the city for it. This is absurd. They
are the ones who are to be blamed for a chaotic situation in downtown Miami.''

The city's efforts to deal with the problem have hardly made the line go away.
In May, after several fights broke out in the line and it became known that a
number of people were selling their places in the line, the city manager allowed
occupational licenses to be issued for people holding places.

''For months now, every morning when I come to work I see the same five or six
individuals standing in line,'' an official of the agency said. ''I know that
later they sell their places to lawyers or others for up to $150 each. So they
make at least $500 a week, they pocket the money and might even have a license
to steal. It's really disgraceful.''

Criticism from the Mayor

Mr. Ferre calls the licensing plan an ''asinine measure'' and has urged the City
Commission to rescind it.  People who stand in line have been particularly
bitter.  ''I came from Cuba a couple of years ago thinking that I left 'Fidel
lines' behind,'' said a Cuban refugee who refused to be identified. ''I did not
know that here I would have to stand in a 'Reagan line.' Someone who invented
this system is certainly not a friend of the President.''

''We realize that we are in the middle of a larger problem,'' said Beverly
McFarland, spokesman for the agency's Miami office. ''We did not introduce the
up-front ajudication on our own, nor did we ask to move. And we know that nobody
wants us.''

At a public hearing, those most vocally opposed to the move were merchants and
homeowners from around 79th Street. Grace Rockafellar, president of the
Northeast Miami Improvement Association, to which many 79th Street merchants
belong, said the group would sue the Government if the General Services
Administration proceeded with the relocation.

Crime Problems in the Past

About two and a half years ago, when the immigration agency opened a small
satellite office at 79th Street, Mrs. Rockafellar said, crime increased and
businesses were ruined. The office closed after residents took the Government to
court.

''Now that merchants are just starting to get back on their feet, see what
happens?,'' she said. ''The G.S.A. is returning to the scene of the crime.''

Officials of the immigration agency, who requested anonymity, also expressed
strong feelings about the move and their work.  ''As any human being, I would
like to be liked,'' one official said. ''It's hard to be working for an agency
that tops the list in unpopularity. But the people don't realize the pressure we
are working under, or the abuse we have to suffer from no fault of our own.''

Immigration officials say Haitian refugees would apparently be the prime
beneficiaries of the move, since the new site is within walking distance of a
Haitian neighborhood. Cubans and other Latin refugees, many of whom rely on
public transportation, would not be able to reach 79th Street as easily.

The immigration agency estimates that more than 80 percent of its clients are
Latin and less than 10 percent are Haitian.  A spokesman for the General
Services Administration said the Justice Department would decide whether and
where to move the agency next month.

POLES REACH U.S. AFTER A LONG SAIL AND ASK TO STAY

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

SECTION: Section 1; Page 27, Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 476 words


Four Polish nationals who sailed into New York Harbor after a fourmonth voyage
from Greece in a 38-foot sailboat asked yesterday for permission to remain in
the United States, and immigration officials said their request was being
considered.

The immigration officials, who declined to identify the four or to say whether
they had specifically requested political asylum, issued a brief statement
saying only that they had sailed into Port Elizabeth, N.J., Thursday morning and
that they would be detained pending a decision in their case.

However, a report in The Daily Journal of Elizabeth, based on an interview with
one of the four before they were taken into custody, said that they were members
of Poland's outlawed Solidarity labor union and had left families and braved an
Atlantic crossing to escape from Poland, which has been under martial law since
last Dec. 13.

The man interviewed, Jarek Neczaj-Hruzewics, a 38-year-old chemist from Lublin
who was the only English-speaking member of the group, was quoted as having said
that he wanted political asylum in the United States and that some of his
shipmates also wanted to defect.  He declined to say which ones.

Others Identified

''They have escaped from Poland the way she is now, and if she changes they will
come back,'' he said of his companions. He identified them as Andrzej Plewik,
37, of Pulaway, captain of the boat; Andrzej Bienkowski, 34, the first mate, and
Stanley Kozak, 38, the second mate, both of Lublin.

The newspaper quoted Mr. Neczaj-Hruzewics as saying the group had received
permission four months ago to fly to Athens, where their boat was moored, and to
sail it back to Poland during what was supposed to be a two-month vacation.

Instead, he said, they headed west through the Mediterranean Sea, touching at
ports in Africa, France and Spain. Then, he said, they passed through the
Straits of Gibraltar and crossed the Atlantic, stopping in Bermuda before going
on to the United States.

They chose to land in Elizabeth, Mr. Neczaj-Hruzewics said, because they have
friends there.

Detained One Night on Boat

An anonymous caller notified the Elizabeth police, who ordered the men to stay
on the boat until immigration and customs officials arrived. The men, deeply
tanned and clad in work clothes, were detained aboard their boat Thursday night
by the United States Coast Guard on Governor's Island. They were then taken to
Newark yesterday for daylong interviews.

Mary Mistrette, acting district director of the Newark office of the Immigration
and Naturalization Service, which was in charge of the case, said the four men
were being held at immigration detention facilities in Brooklyn.

HOUSE PANEL PROGRESSING ON IMMIGRATION BILL

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 527 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 16


The House Judiciary Committee made slow but steady progress today in writing a
bill to overhaul the nation's immigration laws.

The panel approved a major amendment guaranteeing access to the courts for
aliens, including those who entered the United States illegally. The Senate last
month passed an immigration bill, strongly supported by the Reagan
Administration, that would have restricted access to the courts for many aliens
seeking asylum or challenging orders for their expulsion from this country.

The chairman of the Judiciary Committee, Representative Peter W.  Rodino Jr.,
Democrat of New Jersey, said that such restrictions were unacceptable, and his
colleagues agreed with him.

Those who come to this country seeking refuge from persecution must have an
opportunity to present their claims to a Federal court if their applications are
rejected by the Justice Department, Mr. Rodino said. Otherwise, he said, ''we
become accomplices to the imprisonment, torture and murder that await them upon
their return to their home country.''

Amendment Wins Praise

The amendment, offered by Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of
Massachusetts, won praise from the American Civil Liberties Union, the American
Immigration Lawyers Association and Hispanic groups, including the Mexican
American Legal Defense and Educational Fund.

Those groups had all been extremely critical of the restrictions contained in
the Senate bill. The civil liberties group and major Hispanic organizations
still object to many other features of the bill.

On another hotly debated issue, the Judiciary Committee, by a vote of 15 to 12,
eliminated sections of the bill that would place a ceiling on legal immigration
and revamp the system for allocating visas.

The Justice Department, meanwhile, intensified its lobbying in support of the
bill. Department officials told members of Congress today that passage of such a
bill was the top legislative priority of Attorney General William French Smith.

Reagan Plans Appeal

Administration officials said that President Reagan would make a public appeal
for passage of the immigration bill when he speaks on Friday, which is
Citizenship Day, at a naturalization ceremony in Whitehouse Station, N.J., north
of Trenton. Mr. Reagan is going to New Jersey to assist the Senate campaign of
Representative Millicent Fenwick, a Republican.

With only three weeks remaining before adjournment, members of Congress said
there was no way to determine whether the immigration bill would be enacted. The
bill seemed to be gaining momentum today as the House Judiciary Committee
considered numerous amendments, dealing with both major issues and minor
details.

The forecast most often given by senior members of Congress was that the bill
would gain approval from the Judiciary Committee, but would not reach the floor
of the House. The new Congress, according to this forecast, could then resume
work on an immigration bill next January.
