HOUSE COMMITTEE BACKS PENALTIES FOR THOSE WHO HIRE ILLEGAL ALIENS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 23, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 499 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15


The House Judiciary Committee, in its first votes on a comprehensive immigration
bill, today endorsed fines and jail terms for employers who hire illegal aliens.

By a voice vote, the committee rejected a proposal by Representative Patricia
Schroeder that would have barred specific sanctions against employers of illegal
aliens. The panel then approved a penalty system recommended by the committee
chairman, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey.

Under his amendment, an employer who hired illegal aliens would receive a
warning from the Justice Department for the first offense.  A second violation
would subject the employer to a $1,000 fine for each illegal alien on the
payroll. The fine for a third offense would rise to $2,000 for each alien
worker. For subsequent violations, the employer would face one year in jail and
a $3,000 fine for each illegal alien worker.

Federal law does not now explicitly prohibit the hiring of illegal aliens.

Fears of Discrimination

Mrs. Schroeder, a Colorado Democrat, said she wanted ''to put the employer
sanctions on ice'' because she was concerned that enforcement of a ban on hiring
illegal aliens might lead to discrimination against Hispanic Americans, who
account for about 19 percent of her district's population.

Her amendment would have made it illegal to hire illegal aliens, but would have
sought enforcement through existing labor laws, such as the minimum-wage
regulations.

Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky, the chief sponsor of the
immigration bill, called the proposed penalties ''the heart and soul of any
effort'' to curb immigration.

It remains uncertain whether Congress can complete action on a comprehensive
immigration bill before adjournment, scheduled for early October. In a letter to
Mr. Rodino, Jim Wright, the House majority leader, warned about rushing a bill
through''without making sure that it has been given the extremely serious
consideration that a matter of this magnitude deserves.''

Mr. Wright, Democrat of Texas, will have a large say in scheduling floor action
on the bill.

Senate Action Completed

The Senate approved a similar bill last month by a vote of 80 to 19. However,
the penalties in the Senate bill range from a $1,000 fine for each alien to a
$2,000 fine for each alien and a possible six-month jail term.

Both the House and Senate measures would require employers to check passports,
Social Security cards or other documents to confirm that job applicants were
American citizens or aliens authorized to work in the United States.

Both bills would also offer amnesty to millions of illegal aliens now living in
the United States and establish new rules for determining preferences in the
allocation of visas for those wishing to enter this country.

WHAT ABOUT LEGAL ALIENS WHO WANT TO STAY

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 561 words


To the Editor:

We are writing this letter to comment on the immigration reform bill recently
approved by the Senate, which would grant amnesty to millions of illegal aliens
in the United States (news story Aug. 18). v.e are a group of foreigners from
various countries who were legally admitted to the United States a number of
years ago (3 to 10). We all have visas, and some of us, having obtained graduate
degrees in various specialized engineering and science fields, were granted
temporary work status (e.g., one-year student practical training status). In the
years we have been here, we have developed a love for this country, and we wish
to stay to put our education to good use.

We feel that the new immigration legislation is of good intent.  However, by
only taking care of illegal aliens, it is unfair to those foreigners who have
legal status and wish to stay. Legal aliens, we believe, should at least be
treated the same as illegal aliens and be given the opportunity to obtain
automatic permanent-residence status or provisional permanent-residence status,
depending on how long they have been here.

Our reasons are as follows:

* The majority of the legal aliens came to this country, as we did, with a true
admiration for its culture and people. We arrived as friends of America, and our
conduct has been in harmony with the law. On the other hand, illegal aliens have
been de-fying the law of the United States ever since they entered the country,
and there is no guarantee that they would not break the law again in the future.

Current immigration procedures require a legal alien who desires to stay here
permanently to go through a great deal of paper work and wait for years for
approval. Under the proposed law, illegal aliens would receive
permanent-residence status immediately and automatically, simply because their
entry and their residence contravened the law.

* A large number of legal aliens are highly educated scientists and engineering
specialists. It is obvious that legal aliens have much more to contribute to
this country than their illegal counterparts. For the same reason, they are also
more accustomed to the American life style and could communicate more
effectively with the American people.

* The number of legal aliens who wish to stay permanently in the U.S. is far
lower than the estimated total of three to six million illegal aliens. We
understand the reasons for granting them amnesty, but we feel that the
relatively small group of foreigners who have abided by the law should not be
neglected.

This letter has been read and endorsed by 27 other legal aliens from various
countries. We believe it reflects the views of all those legal aliens in various
parts of the U.S. who desire to stay in this country. We hope that, in revising
immigration procedures, the Government will take our views into consideration.
RAMAMOORTHI M. BHASKAR DEE KOU LI, EDWARD LOTEEF LARMA H. SINGH Cleveland, Sept.
9, 1982

House Panel Takes Up;
Immigration Measure

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section B; Page 11, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 183 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14


The House Judiciary Committee began work today on a bill that would penalize
employers who knowingly hired illegal aliens and would grant amnesty to millions
of such immigrants already living in the United States.

Faced with an Oct. 8 target date for Congressional adjournment, the committee
plans to complete action on the measure, which would overhaul Federal
immigration laws, in time to allow a House floor vote next week. A similar
measure was passed by the Senate last month by a 80-to-19 vote.

Sponsors hope that differences between the Senate and House versions can be
reconciled by a conference committee and a final bill sent to President Reagan
before Congress quits for the election campaign.

Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., a New Jersey Democrat who is chairman of the
Judiciary Committee, appealed for support of employer sanctions, the heart of
the bill, but he and other committee members said they would introduce several
amendments to satisfy reservations they have about other provisions.

SALVADORANS' BID FOR ASYLUM DENIED BY IMMIGRATION JUDGE

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 472 words

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9


Two refugees from El Salvador have been denied political asylum in a test case
here.  In a decision announced today, Immigration Judge Brian H. Simpson ordered
Luis Escobar, 22 years old, and Luis Sanchez, 30, to return to El Salvador
within 30 days.

At their deportation hearing, which began in April, the two men argued that they
were members of a ''persecuted class'' in El Salvador: young, urban,
working-class males who were not associated with the military. They contended
that such men were suspected of affiliation with guerrillas and were selected
for surveillance, interrogation and death.

Represented By Volunteers

Two volunteer lawyers from the National Lawyers Guild, Marc Van Der Hout and
Carolyn Blum, argued that the two men were eligible for asylum under 1980
changes in immigration law. The law now provides that people who establish ''a
well-founded fear of persecution,'' based on their membership in a particular
religious, political, racial or social group, may be granted asylum.

They had hoped that the case would serve to establish young urban males as a
social group by showing that they were systematically killed by right-wing
''death squads.''

While acknowledging human rights violations in El Salvador, Judge Simpson
rejected their argument and held that such a group was not recognized under the
law. He ruled that Mr. Escobar and Mr. Sanchez must show some individual basis
for their contention.

Judge Simpson had allowed the two to present 12 witnesses regarding conditions
in El Salvador. Typical was Oscar Andino, a refugee who testified about his
experience working to bring food and medical assistence to various barrios and
combat zones.

Tells of Finding Bodies

Mr. Andino, a former assistant director of Cruz Verde Salvadorania, or Green
Cross, which he described as a nonpolitical group comparable to the Red Cross,
told the judge about many instances of finding the mutilated bodies of young men
killed by ''members of various security forces who act in a clandestine manner
to take the law into their own hands.''

Mr. Van Der Hout, who criticized the judge's decision, said that it would be
appealed within 10 days to the Board of Immigration Appeals in Washington. He
said that the ruling was expected to affect many of the approximately 12,000
applications for asylum by El Salvadorans currently pending.

Beverly Phillips, the lawyer who represented the Immigration and Naturalization
Service at the deportation hearings, was not available for comment. She had
argued that Mr. Escobar and Mr. Sanchez had come to the United States to
''better their economic circumstances,'' not to avoid harm.

ESSAY;
THE COMPUTER TATTOO

BYLINE: By William Safire

SECTION: Section A; Page 27, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 867 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8


In a well-meaning effort to curb the employment of illegal aliens, and with the
hearty good wishes of editorialists who ordinarily pride themselves on guarding
against the intrusion of government into the private lives of individual
Americans, Congress is about to take this generation's longest step toward
totalitarianism.

''There is no 'slippery slope' toward loss of liberties,'' insists Senator Alan
Simpson of Wyoming, author of the latest immigration bill, ''only a long
staircase where each step downward must be first tolerated by the American
people and their leaders.''

The first step downward on the Simpson staircase to Big-Brotherdom is the
requirement that within three years the Federal Government come up with a
''secure system to determine employment eligibility in the United States.''

Despite denials, that means a national identity card. Nobody who is pushing this
bill admits that - on the contrary, all sorts of ''safeguards'' and rhetorical
warnings about not having to carry an identity card on one's person at all times
are festooned on the bill. Much is made of the use of passports, Social Security
cards and driver's licenses as ''preferred'' forms of identification, but anyone
who takes the trouble to read this legislation can see that the disclaimers are
intended to help the medicine go down.

Most American citizens are being led to believe that only aliens will be
required to show ''papers.'' But how can a prospective employer tell who is an
alien? If the applicant could say ''I'm an American, I don't have any card,''
the new control system would immediately break down. The very basis of the
proposed law is the notion that individuals must carry verifiable papers - more
likely, a card keyed to ''a new Government data bank'' - to prove eligibility
for work.

No big deal, say those who consider illegal immigration more fearsome than the
coming of an internal passport; if you're legitimate, you shouldn't object. And
shucks, law enforcement officials won't use it for anything else, nosirree - at
least not until the nation is ready for another legislated step down the
staircase.

Most Americans see no danger at all in a national identity card.  Most people
even like the idea of a piece of plastic that tells the world, and themselves,
who they are. ''I'm me,'' says the little card. ''I'm entitled to all the
benefits that go with being provably and demonstrably me.'' Good citizens - the
ones who vote regularly, and who don't get into auto accidents -might get a gold
card.

Once the down staircase is set in place, the temptation to take each next step
will be irresistible. Certainly every business would want to ask customers to
insert their identity cards into the whizbang credit checker. Banks, phone
companies, schools, hotels would all take advantage of the obvious utility of
the document that could not be counterfeited. Law enforcement and tax collection
would surely be easier, because the Federal Government would know at all times
exactly where everybody was and what they were spending.

And then you might as well live in the Soviet Union. One of the great
differences between free and enslaved societies is the right of the individual
to live and work without the government knowing his every move. There can
sometimes be privacy without freedom, as those in solitary confinement know, but
there can be no freedom without privacy.

When Patty Hearst managed to remain a fugitive for 591 days, that did not mean
the F.B.I. was bad at catching fugitives; it meant that America was a free
society. In China or the Soviet Union she would have been captured in days,
because it is impossible for ordinary citizens to move about without permission.
If our values mean anything at all, they mean that it is better to tolerate the
illegal movement of aliens and even criminals than to tolerate the constant
surveillance of the free.

The Attorney General, who evidently has no grasp of libertarian conservative
principles, will not fight this legislation. When an outside adviser, Martin
Anderson - who with his wife, Annelise, at O.M.B. represent what is left of the
conservative conscience of the Reagan Administration - objected in a Cabinet
meeting to this danger of Federal intrusion, William French Smith was forced to
tell Congress of ''a small but serious objection'' to the identity card clause.
He later made his objection meaningless by pretending it was ''inappropriate to
presume'' he would have to do what the bill mandates him to do - come up with a
foolproof identity system.

We are entering the computer age. Combined with a national identity card - an
abuse of power that Peter Rodino professes to oppose in the House, as he makes
it inevitable -government computers and data banks pose a threat to personal
liberty. Though aimed against ''undocumented workers,'' the computer tattoo will
be pressed on you and me.

CONVICTIONS OF 4 IN ABSCAM CASE UPHELD BY COURT

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1343 words


A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld the convictions of four former
Congressmen who took payoffs from undercover agents in the Justice Department's
two-year Abscam investigation.

The unanimous ruling in Manhattan by a three-judge panel of the United States
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit was the first by a Federal appellate
court involving any of the seven former members of Congress convicted in the
investigation into political corruption.

Two previous appeals court rulings upheld the convictions of two Philadelphia
City Council members and a Federal immigration investigator.

'Jumping at Chance to Take Bribe'

In affirming the jury verdicts against the four Congressmen, along with three
co-defendants, the panel declared: ''The evidence shows four Congressmen jumping
at the chance to take a bribe and discussing investments in their districts as a
convenient cover to justify their rendering of purchased legislative services.''

Responding to contentions by the convicted men and other critics that agents in
the Government's ''sting'' operation had improperly instigated crime, the court,
in its 80-page opinion, held:

''The appellants' claim of excessive governmental involvement in the instigation
of criminal conduct is not supported by the facts.  Though the singular 'sting'
was surely elaborate, its essential characteristic was the creation of an
opportunity for the commission of crime by those willing to do so.''

Those whose convictions were affirmed were former Representatives John M. Murphy
of Staten Island, Frank Thompson Jr. of Trenton, Michael J. Myers of
Philadelphia and Raymond F. Lederer of Philadelphia.

The three others whose convictions on bribery and conspiracy charges were upheld
were Angelo J. Errichetti, former Mayor of Camden, N.J.; Louis C. Johanson, a
former Philadelphia City Councilman, and Howard L. Criden, a lawyer from
Philadelphia.

Lawyers representing Mr. Murphy, Mr. Thompson, Mr. Myers and Mr.  Criden said
they planned to appeal to the United States Supreme Court. Henry Furst, attorney
for Mr. Errichetti, said he had not yet read the opinion. Phone calls to the
offices of the attorneys for the other defendants were not returned.

The convictions were ratified on all counts except for a conflictof-interest
count against Mr. Murphy. But his conviction on charges of criminal conspir/acy
and receiving an unlawful gratuity were upheld, and he still faces three years
in prison and a $10,000 fine.

The three other former legislators were all found guilty of bribery and
conspiracy charges. Mr. Myers and Mr. Lederer face threeyear terms and $20,000
in fines. Sentencing of Mr. Thompson has been held up pending studies of his
medical condition that are awaiting the outcome of his appeals.

All of the seven whose convictions were upheld yesterday have remained free
pending the outcome of their appeals.

2 Lawyers to Seek Rehearing

Mr. Johanson has also been sentenced to three years and a $20,000 fine, and Mr.
Errichetti and Mr. Criden were each sentenced to six years and $40,000 in
penalties. The three trials involved in yesterday's decision were held in
Federal District Court in Brooklyn in 1980 and 1981.

Michael E. Tigar, a lawyer for Mr. Murphy, and Neal Rutledge, a lawyer
representing Mr. Thompson, said they would ask the three-judge panel for a
rehearing before appealing to the Supreme Court. Mr.  Tigar added that if his
petition were denied, he would ask for a hearing by the entire Second Circuit
Court.

In the investigation, Government agents posed as a wealthy Arab sheik and his
''front men'' willing to bribe American public officials in return for aid with
immigration and investment matters.

Critics of the operation charged that it had involved misconduct and
constitutional violations by agents who ''entrapped'' people in criminal
activities and enticed them into joining governmentmanufactured criminal
schemes.

Justice Department officials have denied this, holding that the operation was a
legitimate approach to rooting out Government corruption that might otherwise be
impossible to detect. Yesterday's ruling endorsed this view, stating, ''The
conduct of the investigation, though subject to some criticism, affords no basis
for rejecting the convictions.''

3 Others Also Convicted

The three other former members of Congress whom juries convicted of bribery
charges are former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey and former
Representatives John W. Jenrette of South Carolina and Richard Kelly of Florida.
All are Democrats except Mr. Kelly, who is a Republican. Mr. Kelly's conviction
was later dismissed by the trial judge in Washington, William B. Bryant, who
held that the Government's tactics in the investigation were ''outrageous.'' The
Justice Department is appealing his ruling.

Mr. Williams and Mr. Jenrette are seeking to overturn their convictions.  Thomas
P. Puccio, the former Justice Department official who was chief prosecutor in
the investigation, said yesterday's opinion ''strongly affirms the fact that the
Abscam investigation was in all respects properly conducted and that these
convictions were properly obtained.''

The opinion was written by Judge Jon O. Newman and was concurred in by Judges J.
Edward Lumbard and Henry J. Friendly.  The seven men to whom the ruling applied
were convicted of sharing $200,000 in return for help to the supposed sheik and
his aides. The payoffs were videotaped by Government agents.

'Caught on Videotape'

''The four Congressmen were caught on videotape in the very act of committing
Federal crimes,'' the opinion said.  The ruling also addressed the fact that one
of the key Abscam undercover agents was Melvin Weinberg, a convicted swindler
who was well paid for working with agents of the Federal Bureau of
Investigation. The convicted men, the court said, ''voice a chorus of
indignation that the Government would employ the services of such an
untrustworthy person as Weinberg.''

But it added that while ''the use of dishonest and deceitful informants like
Weinberg creates risks to which the attention of juries must be forcefully
called, the Constitution ''does not forbid their employment, detail their
supervision nor specify their compensation.''

Of the charge that Mr. Weinberg had ''coached'' targets of the investigation to
say incriminating things, the court said: ''Whatever the public's expectation,
the record reveals that these Congressmen were not children of Hamelin, seduced
by the piping of Melvin Weinberg.''

The court also rejected the view that ''the size of the inducements offered to
the Congressmen were excessive.'' It said, ''We have considerable difficulty
with the premise of this argument, which is that a Congressman is privileged to
take a $50,000 bribe so long as he simultaneously believes he is bringing the
benefits of investments to his district.''

It called this view ''an affront to all the law-abiding members of Congress.''
The appeals court said that the Government could retry Mr. Murphy on the
conflict-of-interest count if it wished. But Edward A.  McDonald, who succeeded
Mr. Puccio as head of the Federal Organized Crime Strike Force for the Eastern
District of New York, said that such a retrial was ''unlikely'' because Mr.
Murphy faced the same three-year prison term with or without conviction on the
conflict-ofinterest count.

HAITIAN REFUGEES NOT SHOWING UP FOR HEARINGS TO DETERMINE STATUS

BYLINE: By RICHARD J. MEISLIN, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 7, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 735 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Sept. 3


About one-third of the Haitian refugees scheduled for immigration hearings after
being released under a Federal court order last month have been failing to show
up. The hearings are being held to determine whether they will be able to remain
in this country.

The figures were were disclosed today by officials appearing before Federal
District Judge Eugene P. Spellman, who on June 29 ordered the release of 1,794
Haitians held in Federal detention camps around the country and in Puerto Rico.
The releases began July 23, but as of today 691 Haitian refugees were still
awaiting their freedom. So far, 39 of the refugees have been scheduled for
various types of hearings but only 12 have shown up.

The hearing today was held to review concerns about the refugee release program
and included testimony from a state social services official that some
sponsoring agencies might not be providing adequate care for the Haitians in
their charge.

''Their care and maintenance ranges from financial assistance to nothing,'' said
Linda Berkowitz, refugee coordinator for the Florida Health and Rehabilitative
Services Department.

Fears Dependence on State

She said it appeared that many were not receiving sufficient training in job
skills and cultural adjustment and expressed fear that at the end of their
120-day period of assistance from the private agencies the refugees would be
left ''high and dry and will again turn to the State of Florida'' for help.

Miss Berkowitz also said that none of the refugees had yet received
identification cards permitting them to use the health insurance acquired for
them by their sponsoring agencies, making it difficult for them to obtain
medical care. Agency representatives said they had had problems with the
insurance company and would promptly rectify this.

The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service reported that as of
this morning six of the 17 Haitians scheduled for the hearings had missed them.
Twenty-two others had been scheduled for hearings intended to assure they were
represented by legal counsel at the immigration hearings, but six of them also
failed to show up. In addition, 45 of those released have failed to make the
weekly reports of their whereabouts required by the Federal court.

An attorney for the immigration service, Leon B. Kellner, said that 19 of those
refugees had been found, 19 were still being pursued and that ''all leads were
exhausted'' in attempting to find the remaining seven.

One Granted Asylum

Of those who have appeared for their hearings before the immigration service,
only one has been granted political asylum. The rest are expected to appeal to
the Federal courts. The Government has argued that most of the refugees fled
their country for economic rather than political reasons and are not entitled to
asylum.

A spokesman for the immigration service, Beverly McFarland, said she believed
that some Haitians were failing to appear because ''they're afraid they may be
deported'' back to Haiti. But lawyers for the refugee agencies asserted that
poor record-keeping by the immigration service was to blame.

One lawyer, Eileen Campion, said she had ''suffered through three cases'' in
which the immigration service had given wrong addresses for her clients, making
it impossible to reach them to inform them of their hearings.

''It is entirely the fault of the immigration service, not the fault of the
refugee,'' she said. ''They fail to appear, Your Honor, because they did not
know the hearing was taking place.''

Disagrees with Criticism

But Mr. Kellner, the immigration service lawyer, said that the agency was merely
passing along the addresses provided by the refugees or their sponsoring
agencies when they left detention.

The failures of some Haitians to appear for their hearings raised new questions
over what to do with those who violated the terms of the court order.

A lawyer for the Haitian Refugee Center, Ira Kurzban, said that returning them
to detention might be a necessity but added that they should be entitled to
normal legal processes.

''The Government should not have the right to grab that off the street and throw
them in detention,'' he said.

DON'T SHUT COURT DOORS ON ALIENS

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 431 words


To the Editor:

Robert Pear's Aug. 17 news article about the Senate's passage of an immigration
reform bill omitted any reference to substantial opposition to the measure on
civil liberties grounds.

his opposition is based on the fact that the Senate bill would sweep away broad
areas of legal and constitutional protection, such as due process of law and
judicial review, in order to restrict the flow of immigrants and refugees into
this country.

The dangerous technique which is being used with increasing frequency in
Congress to undermine the authority and independence of Federal courts to decide
controversial civil rights issues is applied by the Senate bill to the
immigration area.

In recent months, Federal courts have provided a vital forum for successfully
defending the rights of Haitians, Salvadorans and others seeking political
asylum in the United States. The Senate bill would cut off access to the Federal
judiciary to anyone whose request for asylum is turned down by the Justice
Department.

This transforms the process of asylum decision-making into a political contest
governed by the changing foreign policies of each new administration. Not only
would recourse to the Federal courts be removed, but a hearing by an independent
immigration board would also be denied.

Civil libertarians are also critical of the immigration bill's enforcement
provisions and the failure of the Senate to adopt safeguards against their
discriminatory application. The employersanctions sections of the bill will
encourage employers to play it safe by hiring only persons who are, in their
opinion, obviously citizens, and discriminating against Hispanic people and
other members of the national work force who are ''foreign looking.''

The Senate's rejection of amendments to minimize this discriminatory potential
sends an unfortunate signal that equal protection of the laws is less important
than immigration control.

Now that the Senate has acted, the House should pause, take stock of this
extraordinarily sensitive area of the law and resist the temptation to tread on
domestic human rights in an eagerness to reform our immigration laws.  JOHN
SHATTUCK Director, Washington Office American Civil Liberties Union Washington,
Aug. 23, 1982

Guerrilla War on Immigration

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 522 words


Any doubt about how deeply the subject of immigration cuts across party and
philosophical lines should be erased by a small example of guerrilla warfare in
Washington. The immediate flap is finished, but the larger issue remains in
suspense, waiting for the House to settle in September.

The flap arose out of a startling New York Times interview Tuesday with Annelise
Anderson, associate director of the Office of Management and Budget. The
Administration, she said, vehemently opposes part of the Simpson-Mazzoli
immigration bill, passed by the Senate Aug. 17.

The section in question requires development of an identification system to
screen out illegal aliens looking for work in this country. Any such
requirement, she said, is ''typical of totalitarian societies.'' Government
would be tempted to turn it to other purposes, like enforcing draft registration
and quelling riots.

There's nothing startling about such views. We, and others, believe such a
system can be controlled, but more than one civil libertarian - or just plain
libertarian - fears a tumble down the slippery slope. What was arresting about
Mrs. Anderson's hostility was that it so baldly contradicted official
Administration views.

In May, for instance, Attorney General Smith said the Reagan Administration was
''open to the alternative'' of a national identity card. Just 10 days ago, when
the Senate passed the Simpson-Mazzoli bill, he said, ''The Administration
applauds the his-toric Senate action and urges the House to act swiftly, in the
same spirit of reason and reform.'' The Administration yesterday issued a
welcome statement clearly dissociating itself from Mrs. Anderson's views. Its
position on verification, however, remains complex, reflecting sharp differences
not only within the Administration but in society.

Any sensible immigration reform requires a verification system. The best way to
deter illegal immigrants is to make it harder for them to get the jobs that lure
them. The best way to do that, in turn, is to make it illegal for employers to
hire them. Employers can do that only if they know who is illegal. Verification,
however, is opposed by such divergent bodies as the U.S. Chamber of Commerce,
which fears red tape for employers, and the Mexican-American Legal Defense Fund,
which fears discrimination against Hispanics.

So it's hardly surprising that the Simpson-Mazzoli bill ended up bland on the
subject. It does not require a verification system now but merely directs the
President to install one within three years.  The Administration is even more
timid. It denies, in advance, that anything more than present identification
procedures will ever be needed.

There's no reason for the House to be more timid than the Senate.  Without
effective verification, there can be no effective enforcement of the borders.
Without effective enforcement, there can be no immigration reform worthy of the
name. The choice for the House is clear: legislate or pretend.

I.D. PLAN OPPOSED BY ADMINISTRATION

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 28, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 929 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25


A Federal official said today that the Reagan Administration was vehemently
opposed to a section of the Senate-approved immigration bill that requires the
President to devise a system for verifying the identity of all job applicants,
including United States citizens.

The system would be aimed at permitting employers to distinguish illegal aliens
from citizens and aliens authorized to work in this country. Under the bill, an
employer who knowingly hired illegal aliens would be subject to a civil fine of
up to $2,000 for each illegal alien. If there was a ''pattern or practice'' of
violations, the employer could also be imprisoned for six months.

Annelise G. Anderson, associate director of the Office of Management and Budget,
said that the Administration opposed the Senate bill's provision for an
identification system. The bill says that within three years the President must
''establish a secure system to determine employment eligibility in the United
States.''

''The legislation says the system can be used only for worker identification
purposes,'' Mrs. Anderson said in an interview. ''But the temptations to use it
for other purposes in emergencies are extraordinary.''

Uses by Police Are Feared

Despite the safeguards, she said, officials may be tempted to use the system to
enforce draft registration laws, to combat drug trafficking, to quell a riot or
to investigate airport bombings.

Mrs. Anderson said the establishment of an employment eligibility system and its
misuse were ''typical of totalitarian societies.'' ''One of the things that a
totalitarian society can't abide is not being able to control the movement of
people,'' she said. ''If you want to maintain a free society, you have to
tolerate a little bit of slack in your ability to fully enforce the law. If you
have everybody identified, you can stop people on the street to see if they have
registered for the draft. If you have no I.D., you have no way to find these
people.''

Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming and the chief sponsor of the
Senate bill, tried to take account of such arguments in his bill. He inserted
provisions ''to minimize the risk of undue invasion of privacy and the risk of
Government abuse.''

''There is no 'slippery slope' toward loss of liberties,'' Mr.  Simpson said in
the Senate, ''only a long staircase where each step downward must be first
tolerated by the American people and their leaders.''

House Has Similar Bill

The Senate passed the Simpson bill last week by a vote of 81 to 18. The House
Judiciary Committee plans to take up a similar bill on Sept. 14. Supporters of
the House bill hope to complete floor action before Oct. 8, the target date for
adjournment. The House is not scheduled to convene again before Election Day,
Nov. 2, but there has been talk of a lame-duck session after the Congressional
elections.

The Senate and House bills both provide that for three years employers could
rely on the best existing documents to check the eligibility of job applicants.
The documents include passports, Social Security cards, birth certificates and
drivers' licenses.

The ''secure system'' would be introduced after three years. The Senate bill
says the system must be designed so it ''will reliably determine that a person
with the identity claimed by an employee or prospective employee is eligible to
work, and that the employee or prospective employee is not claiming the identity
of another individual.''

It also says, ''If the system requires an examination by an employer of any
document, such document must be in a form which is resistant to counterfeiting
and tampering.''

Called Too Expensive

Mrs. Anderson said it would be ''extraordinarily expensive'' to devise a system
to meet the rigorous requirements of the Senate bill, which authorizes $10
million to begin developing it.

Mrs. Anderson said the total cost, spread over several years, might exceed $1.5
billion. The basis for that figure, she said, is that there are more than 100
million people in the civilian labor force and the cost of producing each secure
document, such as a passport, is about $15.

Senator Simpson acknowledged that the costs could be substantial, but he said
there were also ''tremendous costs'' to society from inadequate enforcement of
the immigration laws.

Attorney General William French Smith said it was ''inappropriate'' for Congress
to presume that particular changes would have to be made in the existing
documents. Some changes may be necessary, he said, but ''that remains to be
assessed.''

Cards Common in Europe

Identity cards have long been common in parts of Europe. France, West Germany,
Belgium and Italy have such cards. In this country, Federal agencies and
advisory committees have repeatedly studied the idea of a national
identification system, and they have generally discouraged the idea.

The Social Security Administration said this month that in an effort to
frustrate counterfeiters, it would start issuing Social Security cards on
bank-note paper next year. Senate aides said they doubted that such cards could
satisfy the Simpson bill's requirements for a secure system.

The Senate bill does not specify whether the President should use identification
cards, a computerized data bank or some other device.

               August 24, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

TWO DEFECTIVE IMMIGRATION REFORM PROPOSALS

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 631 words


To the Editor:

Your Aug. 19 editorial on the Immigration Reform and Control Act correctly calls
for several essential modifications to the legislation that recently passed the
Senate.

As you note, I have long supported and the House has twice approved legislation
to penalize employers who knowingly hire illegal aliens.  In addition, in 1975 I
sponsored, and the full Judiciary Committee approved as a part of another
employer-sanctions proposal, a provision which would have legalized a
substantial number of undocumented aliens.

Regrettably, none of these proposals were enacted into law, and we are today
suffering from a decade of inaction on this serious national problem.

I certainly do not intend to stand in the way of legislation designed to address
that problem meaningfully. However, I firmly believe that any such legislation
must preserve the historic goals of our immigration law -the reunification of
families and the protection of American labor.

In my judgment, the proposal that was passed by the Senate and the one that is
now pending before my Committee on the Judiciary do not adequately protect these
objectives.

I believe that the process governing legal immigration has worked reasonably
well under the landmark 1965 law, which repealed the discriminatory
national-origin system of immigration. The most urgent problem confronting this
nation is illegal immigration, and that should be the primary subject addressed
by this legislation.

I am opposed to any effort to erode the concept of family reunification -be it
the elimination of the preference accorded to brothers and sisters of U.S.
citizens or the imposition of numerical limits on the spouses and children of
citizens. Political expediency or the short-term desire to restrict immigration
should not obscure the time-tested principles of our immigration laws and
policies.

I commend you for recommending a simple and straightforward legalization
program. I certainly agree that the creation of separate and distinct categories
of legalized aliens will be unworkable and counterproductive. We must design a
fair and understandable program that will encourage the participation of the
vast majority of illegal aliens. The Senate bill does not accomplish this
objective. I intend to recommend a more generous and workable legalization
program and will offer such an amendment when this bill is considered by the
full Judiciary Committee.

Another ''area for improvement,'' not mentioned in your editorial, relates to
the lack of judicial review provided under both proposals to aliens seeking
asylum. This is of deep concern to many civil libertarians and religious
organizations, and I am hopeful that a more reasonable approach to this most
difficult problem can be developed.

Finally, neither bill adequately protects the domestic labor market from the
importation of foreign workers. This is especially important when you consider
that unemployment has reached record levels. I am reviewing these provisions and
will endeavor to assure that the American work force is not adversely affected
by the legislation ultimately reported by the Judiciary Committee.

My deep interest in immigration legislation has spanned my entire career in the
Congress. It is also an issue of great importance to the American people. I
certainly share the view that reform is essential at this time.

However, the current fears and frustrations of the American people stemming from
recent events such as the Cuban boatlift, the largescale admission of
Indochinese refugees and the influx of Haitians claiming asylum should not be
allowed to obscure the need for a fair, generous and balanced immigration
policy.  (Rep.)
PETER W. RODINO JR., Chairman, House Judiciary Committee, Washington, Aug. 19,
1982

               August 24, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

TWO DEFECTIVE IMMIGRATION REFORM PROPOSALS

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 6; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 381 words


To the Editor:

In an earlier editorial on the subject (March 18), The Times characterized the
proposed Immigration Reform and Control Act as ''Not Racist, Not Nativist, Not
Mean.'' Senate action on the bill last week suggests that the intended product
of the majority of the Senate certainly leans in that direction.

In an 84-to-16 vote, for example, the Senate approved an Administration-inspired
compromise on legalization which not only rolls back the cutoff dates from 1982
to 1980 but bars newly legalized aliens from obtaining even emergency medical
attention at public expense.

Little more than a month ago, Msgr. Daniel Hoye, general secretary of the United
States Catholic Conference, expressed reluctant support for the bill on the
basis that, even if it wasn't perfect, it would legalize a large number of
undocumented aliens who had arrived as recently as the end of 1981.

The January 1982 cutoff, presented by Senator Kennedy, was sound in that it
recognized the need to clear the docket and to include recent immigrants from
war-torn Central America. Now, over a million people who arrived in 1980 and
1981 are lost to the flotsam of underground society, fearful of exercising
rights we deem the cornerstone of our democracy.

Equally disturbing is the mean-spiritedness displayed in the legalized program
approved. Notwithstanding the fact that undocumented workers are estimated by
the General Accounting Office to contribute over $5 billion in taxes annually,
the 84 senators who voted for the measure were willing to begrudge the legalized
alien roughly $120 million in public assistance which they might utilize under
the pressure of personal emergencies.

This is to say nothing, of course, of the rejection of Senator Kennedy's pleas
to include unmarried sons and daughters of a legal immigrant among admittable
aliens. Here the contention that the bill is not nativist falls flat on its
face.

For a good number of ethnic groups in the United States, the family network that
sustains values is larger than the nuclear family. The bill in effect refuses to
recognize this.
MARIO J. PAREDES, New York, Aug. 17, 1982

The writer is executive director of Northeast Catholic Center for Hispanics, an
affiliate of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops.

               August 24, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

IMMIGRANTS AND THE NEW BILL

BYLINE: By Gary Hart

SECTION: Section A; Page 19, Column 3; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 803 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The legislation overhauling United States immigration law that the Senate has
approved focuses almost entirely on domestic issues - stricter law-enforcement,
lower quotas, regularizing the status of undocumented workers already in this
country. But the Senate has not fully addressed the problem that brings
thousands of immigrants to our shores each year.

Immigration is not merely a domestic issue. It is also a matter of foreign
policy. So even the strictest enforcement of the various elements of the Senate
bill, which has been sent to the House, would have little long-term effect.
Quite simply, these provisions do nothing to address the root causes of
migration and the flow of refugees: economic underdevelopment, social injustice,
human rights violations, populatign growth. Until our immigration debate
addresses these serious international issues, we will never develop an adequate
immigration policy.

The Haitian refugees detained in United States camps vividly illustrate this
point. Although they cannot possibly think they have entered the ''golden door''
of economic and social opportunity, they continue to come. Life in the camps,
with all its hardships, is obviously preferable to a life where social and
economic opportunity are systematically denied.

There are enormous disparities between rich and poor in Haiti.  Five percent of
the population accumulates 50 percent of the national income. In 1980 (the last
year for which data are available), Haiti's average per capita income was $275,
the lowest in the Western Hemisphere. On the average, the Haitian Government
spends $1 per person per year on education; it spends $18 per person per year on
internal security.

According to the Organization of American States, corruption pervades all levels
of Haitian government. As a result, domestic revenues and foreign aid are
diverted for personal enrichment, rather than being spent on economic
development.

Repression has been a fact of life in Haiti since 1957, when Francois ''Papa
Doc'' Duvalier began his brutal regime. His successor and son, Jean-Claude
''Baby Doc'' Duvalier, has continued the tradition. The result has been a flood
of poor, uneducated ''boat people'' to the United States.

Haiti is by no means alone in contributing immigrants. From March 1979 to March
1981, the number of Central Americans and South Americans in the United States
increased from roughly 840,000 to 1.022 million. In the last 18 months alone,
200,000 Salvadorans have fled to the United States. And in Southeast Asia,
intolerable conditions have brought hundreds of thousands of Indochinese to the
United States.

It is unrealistic to think that these trends will not continue.Unprecedented
population growth has contributed to tension not only in Mexico, the Caribbean
basin and Central America, but also in the Middle East and the Far East.

Entrants into the labor force in the nonindustrialized world are expected to
grow by at least 700 million in the next 20 years.  Moreover, migration from
rural areas to already overburdened cities will increase. Add continuing civil
and regional wars, famine and repression, and migration flow will become a
migration flood.

Limiting our changes in immigration policy to domestic measures will thus have
little impact on migration pressures from troubled areas of the world.
Ultimately, our immigration problems must be managed with the cooperation and
participation of other governments.  The immigration factor must become an
integral part of the formulation of our foreign policy, particularly as it
applies to certain areas of the globe. For example, we need to recognize that
our tacit support of the repressive Duvalier regime will be paid for in an
influx of ''boat people'' to this country.

Policies that favor confrontation and military solutions must be avoided in
dealing with Central American countries since such policies add to emigration
pressures.

Trade and investment incentives for Mexico and the Caribbean basin should take
into account their impact on the creation of jobs and demographic movements. For
example, Washington might consider providing incentives to United States and
Mexican firms willing to locate in northern Mexico in return for Mexican
Government assistance in blocking illegal immigration.

Both bilateral and multilateral assistance can, if properly directed, help
create jobs and slow population growth in various countries around the world.

Regardless of good-faith legislative efforts to reform domestic immigration
procedures, the problems presented by immigration in the 1980's and 1990's will
not be solved without a more democratic, imaginative and far-sighted foreign
policy.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Gary Hart, Democrat, is senior Senator from Colorado.

                August 22, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

The Nation in Summary;
SEnate Passes Immigration Law Changes

BYLINE: By Michael Wright, Carlyle C. Douglas and Caroline Rand Herron

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 3; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 392 words


Amid rising concern over strangers at the gates, the Senate last week approved
one of the most significant revisions of immigration law in 30 years. The
measure would grant amnesty to millions who entered the country illegally before
1980, but was aimed at reducing the number who slip across the border in the
future, largely by punishing those who hire them.

The bill, sponsored by Republican Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, won broad
support in the Senate - the vote was 81 to 18 - and Attorney General William
French Smith urged the House to ''act swiftly in the same spirit of reason and
reform.'' However, there was some question whether the House would have time
this year, barring a post-election session.

Representative Peter W. Rodino, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, is known to
favor penalizing those who knowingly employ illegal aliens - the measure calls
for fines of up to $2,000 per illegal worker and jail sentences for repeat
offenders. However, aides said he would seek to change some other provisions of
the bill when his committee takes it up after Labor Day. At the very least, the
New Jersey Democrat is expected to try to kill a section that would eliminate
the immigration preference now given to the alien siblings of American citizens.

The bill's other main provisions include an annual immigration limit of 425,000,
not counting refugees, with no more than 20,000 coming from any country other
than Canada and Mexico, which would be allowed 40,000 each; a requirement that
all job applicants prove they are either citizens or authorized aliens; and a
requirement that the President establish within three years a ''a secure system
to determine employment eligibiilty.'' The bill did not specify just what the
system must be, but some have interpreted it as a call for national identity
cards.

The chief opponent in the Senate was Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who
argued that in many ways the bill restricted immigration instead of reforming
it. He agreed with some Hispanic groups that opposed the measure on the ground
that its ''employer sanctions'' could result in increased discrimination against
Hispanic Americans.

               August 21, 1982, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

ANSWERS TO QUIZ

SECTION: Section 1; Page 48, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 531 words


Questions appear on page 20.  1. Unlicensed productions of the show around the
country are using costumes and other elements of the New York production instead
of those that had been traditional.

               August 19, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

Immigrants, History and the House

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 554 words


Will the 97th Congress be remembered for historic legislation, or merely
housekeeping? It has spent much of its time so far in heated battle over the
budget, spending cuts and a tax increase, important but largely year-to-year
concerns. Now that the Senate has overwhelmingly passed the big Simpson-Mazzoli
immigration reform bill, the House has a chance to do something worth
remembering years from now. But that means it must act quickly; there are fewer
than 20 legislative days remaining before adjournment.

What's historic about the bill is the principle. As the Rev.  Theodore
Hesburgh's immigration study commission said last year, the way to keep the
front door open is to close the back door. The nation wants and needs to unite
families, to bring in people with valued skills, to infuse the renewing spirit
of immigrant ambition and energy. But meanwhile, a continued flood of illegal
immigration taxes national patience to the point that some people are ready to
slam all the doors shut.

To its lasting credit, the Senate refused to reduce the amount of legal
immigration and endorsed a provision to keep illegal immigrants from coming in
the back door. The best way to do that is to take the pie off the kitchen table
- by eliminating the economic incentive to sneak into the country for jobs that
pay a fortune compared with what it's possible to earn back home.

Thus the Simpson-Mazzoli bill calls for ''employer sanctions,'' forbidding
employers for the first time to hire illegals. While that is a landmark, the
Senate bill is far from perfect. It creates two prob-lems in particular for the
House to address. One is that Hispanic-American organizations fear employer
sanctions. They suspect that many employers will refuse to hire anyone who even
looks Hispanic, legal or not, rather than risk tangling with new law. It is a
reasonable fear, which Senator Kennedy tried to meet without success in the
Senate.

What would be the harm of having an agency like the General Accounting Office or
the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission investigate possible discriminatory
effects and make periodic reports? Some such procedure would not eliminate
Hispanic concerns, but simple respect should make the House glad to allay them.

The second area for improvement is amnesty for illegal aliens who have been here
for years, living under a cloud and vulnerable to exploitation. A one-time
amnesty is the humane way to clear the decks, but the version finally patched
together by the Senate is an administrative monstrosity. It would create three
different categories of illegals, each accorded a different status and each
given different rights to public benefits. The House would serve both clarity
and charity by insisting on something simpler.

With the session draining away so fast, can the House act in time?  The fate of
immigration reform now depends on Peter Rodino, the canny New Jersey Democrat
who heads the House Judiciary Committee. He's the same Peter Rodino who pushed
employer sanctions through the House twice, in 1972 and 1973, only to see them
die in the Senate. This time the Senate is committed first. History waits.

              August 18, 1982, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

SENATE VOTES A SWEEPING REVISION OF THE NATION'S IMMIGRATION LAWS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1289 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17


The Senate today approved a sweeping revision of the nation's immigration laws,
including a new system of fines and prison terms for employers who knowingly
hire illegal aliens.

The vote was 81 to 18, reflecting broad bipartisan support for the measure
despite opposition to some sections by Hispanic and business organizations.

The bill goes now to the House, where a subcommittee of the Judiciary Committee
has approved a similar measure. Aides to Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., the
committee chairman, said that he would not stand in the way of prompt floor
action on the issue but that he wanted substantial changes in the Senate bill.

Attorney General Applauds Vote

Mr. Rodino, a New Jersey Democrat, said that the Judiciary Committee would take
up immigration proposals soon after it returns from the Labor Day recess in
September.

Attorney General William French Smith issued a statement today applauding ''the
historic Senate action'' and urging the House to ''act swiftly in the same
spirit of reason and reform.'' He said the Senate bill would ''enable the
Government at long last to sharply curtail the large number of illegal aliens
coming to this country.''

The bill, sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, would
offer amnesty to millions of illegal aliens who entered the United States before
Jan. 1, 1980. For the first time, all job applicants would be required to show
identification papers to prospective employers to prove that they were either
citizens or aliens authorized to work in the United States.

The Simpson bill, if enacted, would make the most profound change in immigration
law since 1952, when the McCarran-Walter Act established the basic rules for
admitting and excluding aliens. That act abolished race as an overall barrier to
immigration but kept particular forms of national bias that favored European
immigrants.  The act was amended in 1965, abolishing the national origins quota
system.

Senate action on the Simpson bill coincides with growing public concern over
illegal immigration. The Government arrested more than 950,000 illegal aliens
last year. Together, legal and illegal immigration now appear to account for 30
to 50 percent of the nation's annual population growth. In 1980, an exceptional
year, more than 800,000 aliens arrived in the United States, including 135,000
Cubans and Haitians.

The Senate bill sets an annual limit of 425,000 new immigrants, not counting
refugees. That is approximately the current level, although in some years the
total has been higher. Under the bill, no more than 20,000 immigrants could come
from any one country except Mexico and Canada, which would be subject to a
ceiling of 40,000 each. Canada's unusued visa numbers would be available to
Mexico, which could, as a result, send 50,000 to 60,000 immigrants a year,
according to current estimates. Mexico is now limited to 20,000.

The bill would eliminate the fifth visa preference, which permits immigration by
aliens who are brothers or sisters of American citizens. Mr. Rodino opposes this
change; Senator Simpson says he is willing to ''make some adjustment'' in the
Senate provision.

English as the Official Language

Before final passage, the Senate today adopted, 78 to 21, an amendment declaring
''the sense of the Congress that the English language is the official language
of the United States.'' The amendment was offered by Senator S.I. Hayakawa, a
California Republican regarded as one of the world's leading authorities on
semantics, who asserted that the amendment would ''do away with the bilingual
ballot'' now required in some counties by the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

''The fact that we have a common language, one language, is one of the most
important things we have tying us together,'' Senator Hayakawa said.

Asserting that ''we live in a time of unprecedented immigration,'' he said it
was essential that immigrants from different cultures communicate in the same
language, and added: ''Somehow or other, within a generation or two, we have to
get them all together, talking to each other, electing each other to city
councils, doing business with each other, buying and selling from each other,
creating governments, creating societies.''

However, attorneys for the Justice Department and several Congressional
committees disagreed with Senator Hayakawa's contention that the amendment would
abolish the bilingual ballot and said a sense-of-the-Congress declaration was
not sufficient to override existing law.

The six Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut voted for the bill.
The opposition came mainly from conservatives opposed to further Government
burdens on business, liberals concerned about infringement of privacy and
possible discrimination, and senators from states with large Hispanic
populations.

Kennedy Opposes Measure

Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, the chief Democratic strategist on
the immigration bill, voted against it even though he had worked closely with
Senator Simpson on the legislation for 18 months.

''What started out to be immigration reform has become, in too many provisions,
immigration restriction,'' Senator Kennedy said, adding that the bill eroded the
principle of family reunification, long a basic goal of immigration policy, and
created ''employer sanctions'' that could result in more discrimination against
Hispanic Americans.

Under the bill, an employer who hired illegal aliens would be subject to a
penalty of $1,000 for each alien on the first violation and $2,000 for each
alien in subsequent violations. Where there was a ''pattern or practice'' of
violations, the employer could also be imprisoned for six months.

An employer with four or more employees would be required to check the identity
of a job applicant by examining either a United States passport or two other
documents, such as a Social Security card and a driver's license. Newly hired
employees would have to certify, ''under penalty of perjury and on a form
established by the Attorney General,'' that they were either citizens or aliens
authorized to work in this country.

Amnesty for Some Aliens

Employers who failed to comply with these requirements would be subject to a
civil penalty of $500 for each violation.  The bill also says that within three
years the President must ''establish a secure system to determine employment
eligibility.'' It does not specify whether the system should use a new type of
Social Security card, a computerized data bank or some other device.

The amnesty program under the Senate bill would grant permanent resident status
to illegal aliens who entered the United States before Jan. 1, 1977, and had
resided here continuously since then.  It would grant ''temporary resident''
status to those who entered the United States from Jan. 1, 1977, to the end of
1979. Temporary residents, after three years in that status, could become
permanent residents. Aliens can apply for citizenship after five years as
permanent residents.

Aliens who have entered the country since Jan. 1, 1980, would not be eligible
for the amnesty and could be deported if they were caught. Aliens who accepted
the amnesty offer would be ineligible for at least three years to receive
Medicaid, food stamps and other social welfare benefits financed by the Federal
Government.

AROUND THE NATION;
Texas Concern Checked On Hiring of Taiwanese

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 106 words

DATELINE: CARROLLTON, Tex., Aug. 17


Immigration officials say they are investigating charges that a technology
manufacturing concern has illegally employed about 30 Taiwanese workers, mostly
engineers, in high-paying jobs.

''This is a formal investigation,'' said Travis Stewart, assistant director of
investigations in Dallas. ''We feel there is a possibility of some violations''
at the Mostek Corporation in suburban Carrollton.

The investigation is part of an effort by the Immigration and Naturalization
Service to remove aliens ''from good-paying jobs where citizens could be
employed.''

               August 17, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

ILLEGAL IMMIGRANT SOUGHT IN MOTEL SLAYING OF GUARD

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 680 words


An illegal immigrant being held in a motel room near Kennedy International
Airport overnight until he could be put on the next flight home apparently
overpowered and strangled his unarmed private security guard early yesterday
morning and escaped in the guard's car, police and immigration officials said
yesterday.

They identified the immigrant as Ramon Cuevas, a 25-year-old Dominican national
who had been carrying a birth certificate falsely listing him under another name
as a citizen of Puerto Rico.

The guard, 36-year-old Jean Marcpenn of Siro Security Services of Brooklyn, was
discovered dead about 8:30 A.M. yesterday by a housekeeper at the Holiday Inn on
Rockaway Boulevard. He had been strangled with a telephone cord, the police
said.

Responsibility of Airline

The guard had been hired by American Airlines under longstanding Federal
aviation rules that require carriers to retain responsibility for incoming
passengers found ineligible for entry into the United States. The carrier then
sends the passenger home.

''This is the first case of murder,'' said Lieut. Martin Veilson of the 105th
Precinct in Queens. ''Usually they just leave and try to get in again.''

A spokesman for American Airlines in Dallas, David Fraley, said the carrier had
been trying for years to shed the liabilities of guarding illegal entrants.

''We would just as soon not have the responsibility,'' he said.  But the
Government takes the position that carriers are responsible for insuring that
their passengers are legally entitled to enter the country they are flying to,
and that if they are not, the airline must take them back where they came from.

Flew Here From Haiti

In an account later confirmed by James Jasey, New York deputy district director
of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, Lieutenant Veilson said Mr.
Cuevas had arrived about 5:30 P.M. Sunday on a flight from Haiti.

The officials said the arriving passenger had presented a birth certificate in
the name of Miguel Lopez Marquez of Carolina, P.R.  But, according to Lieutenant
Veilson, when an immigration agent asked the visitor how far Carolina was from
San Juan he incorrectly gave the distance as 100 miles when it is actually far
closer. At that point, the lieutenant said, the visitor gave his real name as
Ramon Cuevas of Santo Domingo and said he had obtained the paper from a friend
named Martinez in Haiti.

Mr. Jasey said Mr. Cuevas had been offered the chance to argue his case before a
judge, but had elected instead to leave the country. He was then turned over to
American Airlines for the next flight back, Mr. Jacey said.

Checked Into Motel

Because that was not until 7 A.M. yesterday, officials said, Mr.  Cuevas was put
in the custody of Mr. Marcpenn of the Siro agency, which the airline regularly
uses for security work. The men checked into the Holiday Inn just outside the
airport.

At 5 A.M., the police said, the Siro agency telephoned Mr. Marcpenn to check and
to remind him of the 7 A.M. flight. There was nothing then amiss, they said.

But sometime between then and 8:30 A.M., they said, a struggle broke out and the
guard was strangled. His body, clad in underwear, was found face down near the
door.

People who answered the telephone at the Siro agency refused to discuss the
case. The police had no explanation why Mr. Cuevas's failure to appear for the 7
A.M. flight had not immediately triggered an alarm.

The police described Mr. Cuevas as 5 feet 8 inches tall with medium dark skin, a
slight moustache and goatee. He was said to be wearing jeans and a light blue
polo shirt marked ''Property of Pittsburgh Steelers.''

The guard's missing car was identified as a 1974 light blue Plymouth four-door
with the license 2165 AFP.  The police asked that anyone with information call a
24-hour number - 520-9200 - and appealed for Mr. Cuevas to come forward.

                August 16, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

SOME HARD CHOICES EMERGE IN DEBATE ON ILLEGAL ALIENS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1052 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15


A new mood was evident in the Senate last week as members expressed a strong
desire to crack down on illegal immigration. At the same time, many Senators
expressed frustration as they suggested that there were no easy solutions, only
hard choices.

There seemed to be a consensus that the problem was serious enough to justify
imposing what one Senator called ''a new and controversial legal order.''

Under the bill being discussed, there would be a partial amnesty for some
illegal aliens already in the country, but for the first time, every job
applicant, whether a citizen or an alien, would have to show a prospective
employer documents to prove both his identity and his eligibility to work in the
United States.

Having finished two days of debate, the Senate plans to vote on the bill
Tuesday, and Senators on both sides of the aisle said they expected it to pass.
The House might find time to act on similar legislation this year, especially if
there is a session after the elections.

But aides to Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., the Judiciary Committee
chairman, who has been deeply interested in immigration throughout his 34-year
career in Congress, said the New Jersey Democrat would insist on substantial
changes in the bill.

Pendulum Swings Again

Over the years, American immigration policy has swung between the extremes of
free, unlimited entry and tight restrictions, often based on geographic, racial
or ethnic quotas. In this time of fiscal stringency and political conservatism,
Congressional officials said the pendulum was swinging back toward restrictions,
despite a widespread desire to avoid discrimination.

In the debate, Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, chief sponsor of
the omnibus immigration bill, said that it ''truly is not nativist, not racist,
not mean,'' but he acknowledged that ''any reference to immigration reform or
control turns out, unfortunately, to be a code word for ethnic discrimination.''

At times the Senate debate on the bill was desultory, as many Senators were
distracted by conference committee work on taxes and the budget.

But often, debate was passionate, as a remarkable number of Senators spoke of
their own foreign roots and speculated about the impact of the new proposal. For
example, Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, recalled that his parents
were immigrants and that his mother ''was an illegal alien for a long time and
did not even know that she was.''

'Secure System' of Identification

The bill provides that within three years, the President would have to establish
a ''secure system'' to verify ''employment eligibility.'' After a brief
transition period, there would be civil and criminal penalties for employers who
knowingly hired illegal aliens.

The bill would also permit millions of illegal aliens to become legal permanent
residents. But for at least three years after receiving amnesty, they could not
obtain food stamps, Medicaid or other federally financed benefits.

Immigration, like politics, appears to make strange bedfellows, with no clear
liberal or conservative position. Liberal Democratic Senators, such as Edward M.
Kennedy of Massachusetts and Alan Cranston of California, joined conservative
Republicans, such as John Tower of Texas and James A. McClure of Idaho, in
expressing concern about discrimination that might result from the new system of
employer sanctions, the very core of the Simpson bill.

Those Who 'Look Foreign'

Mr. Simpson replied that Hispanic Americans and those who ''look foreign'' could
suffer worse discrimination without the safeguards in his bill. And he said his
proposal had support from champions of civil rights such as the Rev. Theodore M.
Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, who was chairman of an
advisory commission on immigration in the Carter Administration.

Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, said with some irritation
that his parents could not have come to the United States under the policy
embodied in the Simpson bill. The bill, he said, gives a preference to
immigrants with $250,000 of capital to invest here, but eliminates the
preference for citizens' brothers and sisters. He also said he could not
understand why spouses and children of illegal aliens who receive amnesty under
the bill should be admitted in advance of the many brothers and sisters of
citizens who wanted to enter legally.

Senator Kennedy saw that issue as typical of the ''hard and difficult choices''
to be made, adding, ''That is a fine how-do-youdo for this nation.''

Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, said that the bill ''presents a real
dilemma,'' a ''conflict between our normal commitment to human rights, our
humanitarian instincts'' and ''our commitment to the first law of nature, which
is self-preservation.''

For the moment, the Senate seems willing to subordinate its humanitarian
instincts so the country can exercise what Mr. Simpson called ''the first and
most important duty of a sovereign nation,'' control over its borders.

Senator Simpson called his bill ''a very small step forward,'' but, according to
experts in the field, it represents the most profound change in immigration law
in the 30 years since the passage of the McCarran-Walter Immigration and
Nationality Act.

Some Unanswered Questions

As with any such departure from past practice, there are many unanswered
questions: How many illegal aliens would take advantage of the amnesty? How much
money would the Federal Government have to pay state governments to offset costs
attributable to the amnesty? What type of foolproof identification system would
the Government devise?  How many additional aliens would come into the United
States to harvest crops under the liberalized rules for foreign workers?

With legal and illegal immigration together accounting for perhaps 30 to 50
percent of the nation's annual population growth, the Senate seemed to be
inclined not to wait for answers.

                August 16, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

Countdown for the Caribbean

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 419 words


There are sound reasons why Congress should approve the Caribbean Basin
Initiative, and they are not quite so obvious as one might think.

Nearly half of America's imports and exports pass through Caribbean waters,
including three-fourths of our oil. The region itself has become a $7 billion
market, and legal immigration to the United States has increased dramatically -
one of five Barbadians and one of six Jamaicans are now living here. And when
there are political upheavals and economic slumps in the Caribbean, illegal
immigration jumps just as dramatically.

The Senate was evidently listening when Secretary Shultz ticked off these
practical points. It has voted the $355 million in direct aid requested by the
Administration. It also seems ready to support the plan's more imaginative
components: duty-free entry for most products from the basin and tax credits of
up to 10 percent for American investments there. But the funds could be lost in
a budget fight with Congress, and the other concessions may not even come up for
a final vote.

Opponents hope to scupper the Caribbean initiative in the House, where the Ways
and Means Committee is taking its sweet time. The Administration has already
gone pretty far to placate domestic interests. Textiles and apparel have been
excluded from duty-free treatment, sugar growers are being paid off with import
quotas and a promise of price supports and there would be relief for any
industry seriously injured by Caribbean imports.

To some industries, like leather goods, that doesn't seem enough.  Their
lobbyist can exploit a potent misgiving, expressed by Senator Leahy: ''I feel
awfully nervous about going back to Vermont and saying I voted for a
half-billion dollars in foreign aid and not knowing what it is I voted for.''

If the President is sincere about his Caribbean initiative, it is his job to
explain to Vermont voters why Pat Leahy, a Democrat, was wrong to oppose the
initiative. Mr. Reagan also has to weigh the risks of losing $355 million in
direct aid if he should decide to veto the $14 billion supplemental money bill
now before House-Senate conferees.

Defending foreign aid and promoting development are not tasks that come easily
to the Reagan team. But if it galvanizes support in the House, it may yet be
able to claim one clear foreign affairs achievement on the Administration's
largely empty slate.
