'OVERKILL' IN AN IMMIGRATION REFORM BILL

SECTION: Section 4; Page 20, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 461 words


To the Editor:

Senator Alan Simpson's Aug. 10 Op-Ed article, ''Illegal Aliens,''
mischaracterizes the position of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.v.
e understand the need for reform of our immigration laws and for a solution to
the illegal alien problem. We do not condone the hiring of illegal aliens, nor
do we in any way associate ourselves with those who do; we encourage employers
to continue their own efforts to avoid hiring illegal aliens.

However, we are strongly opposed to legislation that would be an undue burden on
citizens seeking jobs or on employers seeking to hire them. Section 101 of the
Simpson-Mazzoli immigration bill does just that - and the burden would fall most
heavily on smaller businesses.

Section 101 would regulate the hiring practices of virtually all employers and
require them to insist that every job applicant show proof of U.S. citizenship
or legal residency. Otherwise, the employer would face a $500 fine - even if the
person hired turned out to be a U.S. citizen.

One of our chief objections to Section 101 is that it does not specify what type
of ''secure system'' the President is to develop within three years: the
business community is asked to comply with, the American public is asked to
accept and the Congress is asked to approve an unknown universal identification
system that will have to be used every time there is a new hire.

What if the President opted for a worker I.D. card/telephone callin system, as
has been suggested? An employer would then have to call the Federal Government
before hiring anyone. Since, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics,
there are 70 million job changes in the United States every year, Uncle Sam
would get two and a half phone calls from employers every second. Anyone who has
ever tried to call the Federal Government for anything must have a pretty good
idea of how such a system would work.

In a July 11 letter to the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, the
Attorney General stated that the cost for implementing the ''secure system'' in
Section 101 would be $2 billion (the General Accounting Office, watchdog agency
of the Congress, came up with the same figure in 1980).

The U.S. Chamber is simply saying that the proposed employer sanctions in the
immigration bill are overkill. We think that on close examination most citizens
would agree.  CHRISTOPHER LUIS Washington, Aug. 12, 1982

The writer is a labor law attorney for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce.

                August 13, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

SENATE OPENS DEBATE ON IMMIGRATION

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 889 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12


The Senate today began debating legislation that, if adopted, would make the
most profound changes in the nation's immigration laws since 1952.

The debate opened with warnings that a continued uncontrolled influx of illegal
aliens could threaten the political stability of the country, especially if
newcomers followed the path of cultural separatism.

Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, said that under his bill,
''illegal immigration should be substantially reduced.'' ''If immigration is
continued at a high level and yet a substantial portion of these new persons and
their descendants do not follow the historical patterns of earlier immigrant
groups in becoming full participants in American society and public culture,''
he warned, ''then they have the potential to create here a measure of the same
political, social and economic anguish which exist in the countries from which
they have chosen to depart.''

Provisions of Bill

Mr. Simpson, outlining the main features of his bill, said employers who
knowingly hired illegal aliens would be subject to a civil penalty of $1,000 for
each alien. The Government would create a worker identification system, and
employers would have to verify that all job applicants were either citizens or
aliens authorized to work in this country. The bill would also establish a
legalization or amnesty procedure under which illegal aliens who had lived
continuously in the United States since January 1978 would qualify for permanent
resident status. Five years after becoming permanent residents they could apply
for citizenship.

The bill would also tighten the deportation and asylum adjudication procedures,
limiting the appeals that seem now to stretch out almost indefinitely in some
cases.

By a vote of 82 to 17, the Senate today rejected a proposal that would have
eliminated the amnesty provisions of the bill. But the Senate also, by a vote of
84 to 16, adopted an amendment making the legalization procedure significantly
more restrictive.

The amendment, sponsored by Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa,
moves back the eligibility date to January 1977, and it would prevent illegal
aliens given permanent resident status from receiving food stamps, Medicaid,
welfare and other types of Federal assistance for three years.

Amendment Is Rejected

By a vote of 63 to 35, the Senate also rejected an amendment that would have
counted refugees against the annual total of 425,000 admissions allowed for all
legal immigration. In effect, the amendment, offered by Senator Walter D.
Huddleston, Democrat of Kentucky, would have reduced the total number of visas
available for legal immigrants this year by 140,000, the authorized number of
refugees. The level of refugee admissions is now set each year by the President,
in consultation with Congress, under a procedure establised by the Refugee Act
of 1980.

Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, the Senate majority leader, said
he hoped the Senate could take a final vote on the measure Friday.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, strongly criticized
several features of the bill. He said it would undermine the ideal of family
reunification, which has long been a factor in the selection of aliens to be
admitted to this country. ''For the first time,'' he said, ''this bill places
the admission of the immediate relatives of United States citizens - spouses,
children and parents - under a rigid annual ceiling.''

Mr. Kennedy also asserted that the proposed system of enforcement, by employer
sanctions and identification papers, was likely to lead to discrimination
against Hispanic Americans and other minority groups.

Conservatives opposed the portion of the bill providing an amnesty for illegal
aliens. Senators Jesse Helms and John P. East, both North Carolina Republicans,
sought to delete that section of the bill. Mr. East said the amnesty proposal
was inappropriate and illconceived because it carried with it ''the idea of
forgiveness.''

'A Mockery of American Law'

Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, said that amnesty was a
short-sighted way to deal with the problem of illegal immigration and would
encourage aliens to keep coming to this country. ''Amnesty rewards
law-breaking,'' she said. ''It makes a mockery of American law. It will
perpetuate the very immorality and lack of ethics that it seeks to end.''

The Senate Judiciary Committee report on the bill describes the plan as ''the
first comprehensive immigration reform effort in the United States in 30
years.'' The last major legislation enacted in this area was the Immigration and
Nationality Act of 1952.

A measure similar to the Simpson bill is now pending before the House Judiciary
Committee.  The Senate rejected three amendments offered by Mr. Kennedy that
would have promoted reunification of families through immigration.  One of the
proposals sought to retain the preference now accorded by the immigration law to
unmarried brothers and sisters of citizens.

              August 11, 1982, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

IMMIGRATION BILL HAS PERSONAL ROOTS

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 958 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Back in World War II, when he was a teen-ager in Cody, Wyo., Alan K. Simpson
would visit a Japanese-American internment camp and play with children his age
who were living behind barbed wire.

''There I was, 13 years old, and the third largest city in Wyoming sprang up on
the sagebrush between Cody and Powell,'' he recalled.  ''I would go to the scout
meetings. Here were boys with the same scout uniforms, the same merit badges,
the same comic books, the same raunchy stories that all 13-year-old boys tell,
and they were behind barbed wire. I would talk with their parents and
grandparents, who were living in tarpaper shacks.''

Today Mr. Simpson, now 50 years old, is a Republican Senator from Wyoming. He is
the co-author of a bill that has drawn mixed reactions from both conservatives
and liberals because it proposes the first major revision in 30 years in Federal
laws governing aliens and immigration. (The bill is to be considered by the
Senate within days.)

Mr. Simpson says that his legislative approach was significantly affected by his
experience with the Japanese-Americans who, for no reason other than their
ancestry, were summarily interned during the fear-filled days immediately after
Pearl Harbor.

National Identification Card

The immigration proposal would give legal status to aliens who arrived in this
country before 1982, would provide for a national identification card for them
and would penalize employers who hired illegal aliens.

The co-author of the bill with Mr. Simpson is Representative Romano L. Mazzoli,
a 49-year-old Kentucky Democrat. He says he became involved in immigration law
as a result of his exposure to the Rev.  Theodore M. Hesburgh, the president of
Notre Dame University who was chairman of the Select Commission on Immigration
and Refugee Policy that was established a few years ago by Congress. A number of
the commission's conclusions are incorporated in the Simpson-Mazzoli bill.

For Senator Simpson, whose easygoing humor has made him one of the best-liked
men in the Senate, the teen-age experience gave him a lifelong distaste for
internment situations. ''You'd go downtown and you'd see a Japanese-American
trustee for the camp who had two sons fighting with the 91st division in Italy,
and next door there would be a sign, 'No Japs Allowed,' '' the Senator recalled.

Mr. Simpson, whose lanky frame towers above that of Mr. Mazzoli and almost
everyone else in Congress, is the tall part of what Mr.  Mazzoli calls ''The
Mutt and Jeff Sideshow.''

''We've taken it to the Borscht Belt of Immigration,'' Mr. Mazzoli says,
referring to San Diego, San Antonio, El Paso, Houston, New York, Florida and
other immigration and refugee centers.

''People are surprised that a Republican from Wyoming and a Democrat from
Kentucky can be completely compatible,'' Mr. Simpson said. ''There's not a shred
of partisanship.''

For those surprised that a Wyoming Senator became involved in immigration law,
even considering his World War II experience, Mr.  Simpson notes that his state
has four times as many Hispanics as American Indians and points out that
Wyoming's Park County ''was one of the largest users and abusers of the Bracero
program in the United States.'' He recalls how Mexicans brought here to pick
sugar beets, were ''skewered by the car dealers'' and other merchants.

Labor Day Assurance

The Senate leadership has promised Mr. Simpson, who has made special visits to
Cuban and Hatian refugee camps, that his immigration measure will be on the
floor before Labor Day. However, Mr. Mazzoli has received no such assurances
from the House leadership.

The Simpson-Mazzoli bill has evoked considerable controversy because of its
provisions for sanctions against employers who hire illegal aliens and its
provision for a national identity card so that prospective employees might
''prove'' that they are citizens or permanent residents. ''We want to end the
magnet that draws people to this country,'' Mr. Mazzoli said.

The measure also is controversial because it would grant permanent resident
status to aliens who entered this country by Jan. 1, l982, and would provide a
temporary employment program for aliens who come to work in specific jobs.
Further, it would permit summary exclusion of an alien entering the United
States without the necessary documents, unless the person asserted some
''reasonable basis''for being admitted or claimed asylum.

Annual Immigration Limited

Finally, the measure calls for a limit of 425,000 immigrants a year, the current
level. No nation could send more than 20,000 immigrants, with the exception of
Mexico and Canada, which could send 40,000 each.

The proposed hiring sanctions in the bill have been vigorously opposed by an
unusual alliance that includes the United States Chamber of Commerce, the
American Civil Liberties Union and various Hispanic groups. On the other hand,
some other Hispanic groups, a number of editorial writers and the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
have strongly praised the bill.

Some Hispanic groups fear that the sanctions on employers will undermine the
job-hunting efforts of Hispanic Americans because employers will not want to
risk hiring illegal aliens. Some civil rights groups fear the precedent of a
national identity card as a first step toward a police state. Other groups
consider the bill to be racist.

''The toughest part of our job is the education process,'' Mr.  Simpson said.
''This is an issue that just can cut you to ribbons.''

               August 10, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

ILLEGAL ALIENS

BYLINE: By Alan K. Simpson

SECTION: Section A; Page 19, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 906 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


All objective, comprehensive studies of the problem of illegal immigration,
including those by the Ford, Carter and Reagan Administrations, and by the
Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy, have concluded that
adequate enforcement of immigration laws cannot be achieved without greatly
reducing the incentive represented by the temptation of employment in the United
States.

For this reason, section 101 of the proposed Immigration Reform and Control Act
of 1982 is the single provision most urgently needed to assist in reducing
illegal immigration. This section would make unlawful the knowing hiring of
illegal aliens and would provide a system that enables employers to verify that
job applicants are American citizens or legal aliens. Section 101 and the bill's
other provisions are strongly supported by the Administration, by an imposing
array of newspapers and special-interest groups and by the Senate Judiciary
Committee.

Yet, the United States Chamber of Commerce has spiritedly lobbied against this
provision. The most startling feature of its opposition is that it appears to be
based solely on a selfish perception of employers' short-term, purely economic
interest: profitability. That is not the right perspective.

To properly assess the economic impact of illegal immigration, we must consider
long-term effects. Moreover, even a totally selfish person does not act solely
to achieve economic goals; adverse noneconomic impacts can often make an
economic benefit unpalatable.  Thus, consideration of the effects of illegal
immigration on our population, of potential social and political changes and of
historical immigration objectives must be part of the decision-making process.

The Chamber argues that any secure verification system would be ''too
expensive.'' As evidence, it has published some extraordinarily high cost
estimates. More objective sources present less-alarming figures: $100 million to
$300 million per year. Certainly, these are not small numbers, but inadequate
enforcement also involves major costs. The number of illegal aliens in this
country in 1978 has been estimated at 3.5 million to six million. Even if those
estimates are used and it is assumed that only 2 percent hold jobs that
unemployed Americans would take, then the cost in public assistance and
unemployment benefits to the jobless is $490 million to $840 million. The actual
number of people displaced from jobs is probably substantially higher. The
number of illegal aliens is estimated to have increased by 500,000 per year.
This calculation does not even consider the other, less easily quantifiable
costs of illegal immigration.

The Chamber states that the verification procedure would be ''too burdensome''
for employers. Actually, the procedure would be optional for those with three or
fewer employees. Larger employers would be required simply to examine in good
faith a United States passport or two other documents - say, a driver's license,
birth certificate, Social Security card - complete and sign a short form and
have that form signed by the employee. The employer would not be responsible for
the authenticity of the documents, only for their reasonably appearing genuine.
Without this system, the two key goals of section 101 could not both be
achieved: screening illegal aliens out of the workforce and avoiding
discrimination against citizens and legal aliens who look or sound ''foreign''
to employers.

The most disappointing part of the Chamber's argument is the assertion that
individuals, including businessmen, have no obligation to assist the Government
in enforcing our laws. That view is certainly not consistent with our tradition
of responsible citizenship and limited government.

Does the Chamber feel that businesses' legal obligation to withhold income and
Social Security taxes is also unreasonable?  There no practical alternative.
Moreover, a legitimate businessman ought not knowingly hire illegal aliens and
thereby provide the major incentive for violating one of the most fundamental
laws of a sovereign nation - the one controlling its borders.

Fortunately, most businessmen do not share the Chamber's view.  Other business
groups support the bill - the National Association of Manufacturers, for
example. Many local Chambers of Commerce, including those in Texas and
California, where there are great numbers of illegal immigrants, have
acknowledged the need for such reform.

The sponsors are attempting to protect America from uncontrolled immigration for
the sake of their children and grandchildren, while keeping at bay the specter
of meanness, nativism and racism.  Fortunately, a sizeable majority of Americans
are willing hark to an appeal to rise above any special interest they may have
in order to obtain workable immigration reform. It is puzzling why the United
States Chamber of Commerce is not.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Alan K. Simpson, Republican Senator from Wyoming, is chairman of the Senate
Judiciary Committee's immigration and refugee reform subcommittee.

                               The New York Times

                August 9, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

Turning Mean on Immigration

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 712 words


Today or tomorrow, the Senate will have a rare, fleeting moment to put the
United States back in charge of its own borders - but it may blow the chance.

Controlling immigration has become an important goal of conservatives and
liberals alike. Now, finally, they have a way to get from here to there: the
broad and balanced immigration reform bill sponsored by Senator Alan Simpson,
Wyoming Republican, and Representative Romano Mazzoli, Kentucky Democrat, which
is about to come up for debate in the Senate.

The underlying idea is simple: reduce illegal immigration sharply while holding
legal immigration at the present level. But both halves of that proposition are
threatened by harsh amendments to be offered in the Senate. Unless they are
beaten, the opportunity of a generation will be lost.

The idea of clamping down on illegal immigration may sound like pure virtue, but
it arouses employers and civil libertarians. In response, the Simpson-Mazzoli
bill is adjusted as delicately as a clock. The best way to discourage illegal
immigrants is to make it harder for them to get jobs - and the practical way to
do that is to make it against the law for employers to hire them. For that to
work, in turn, means some kind of identification system, so employers can tell
who is illegal.

Employer sanctions and an identification system are the heart of the bill;
without them, it is not worth having. But civil libertarians fear invasions of
privacy and Hispanic groups fear discrimination. Unless offset, such fears would
trigger powerful, perhaps fatal opposition to the bill.

That's one reason it also contains an amnesty provision. Over the years,
thousands of illegal entrants have created new lives here, but lives shadowed by
fear of discovery and exploitation by unscrupulous employers. The
Simpson-Mazzoli bill would provide a onetime amnesty for most of them, offering
enough humane benefit to induce some opponents of sanctions to go along.

But that's not good enough for Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina
Republican. He insists that amnesty must be deleted altogether - even though
that would jeopardize the whole bill. He would rather break the clock than see
an amnesty provision succeed.

Senator Charles Grassley, the Iowa Republican, proposes, more sensibly, to delay
amnesty for three years, the same three years in which the Government is
supposed to work out an effective identification system. Both sides of the
bargain would remain hostage to each other, not a bad idea considering how much
the bill's identification provisions have been watered down.

There is a harsh spirit alive also over legal immigration. Senator Walter
Huddleston, a Kentucky Democrat, proposes limiting all immigration to 425,000 a
year. That's roughly the present amount -but there's a big catch. He would
include refugees within his limit. That would reduce total admissions by 100,000
or more people a year.

The Huddleston cap illogically lumps together two wholly different kinds of
people. Refugees are desperate to escape persecution; immigrants are eager to
rejoin their families or find new opportunity. The probable effect would be to
cut deeply into the number of parents, wives and children of U.S. residents who
could come in legally.

At a time of 9.8 percent unemployment, there's a glib appeal to the Huddleston
notion. It's not the first time someone has blamed economic distress on
foreigners. It's not the first time legislators have turned exclusionary or
nativist. But if people like Senator Huddleston are sincere about losing jobs to
foreigners, it's illegal migrants they should be worried about.

The 97th Congress is winding down fast, but the chances are that if the Senate
can pass the Simpson-Mazzoli bill without these ugly amendments, the House will
act quickly. The public, to judge by polls, overwhelmingly supports controlling
the borders. This bill provides a way to do so in ways that are effective
without being ugly. Congress should jump at the chance.

                August 8, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

150 HAITIANS, 46 AFGHANS WAIT IN NEW YORK CENTERS FOR ASYLUM

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 30, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 838 words


About 150 Haitians and 46 Afghans are being held in two Immigration and
Naturalization Service centers in New York State, six weeks after a Federal
judge in Florida ordered the release of 1,900 Haitians he said had been detained
illegally there.

Officials reported they were making arrangements to free most of the Haitians
here. But they added that they did not believe the order, by Judge Eugene P.
Spellman, applied to the Afghans or Haitians who entered the United States
illegally at New York and were detained.

Some of the aliens have been held seven months, under a new policy requiring
preventive detention pending immigration hearings.  Formerly, these aliens were
allowed to stay with community sponsors pending the hearings.

Procedural Violations Charged

The judge said that the agency had not followed proper procedures in announcing
the new policy, but he did not rule on its constitutionality.

The agency's policy change has prompted several challenges to preventive
detention and the way it has been carried out. Lawyers for the detained aliens
argue that the recent court order releasing the Haitians to community sponsors
applied to all nationalities.

Officials contend that only Haitians are affected and defend the new policy as a
deterrent to illegal immigration.  James A. Jaysey, deputy district director of
the Immigration Service's regional office, said he was striving to identify
aliens affected by the court order so he could arrange their release.

So far, he said, five of the 60 Haitians at the Brooklyn detention center, at
136 Flushing Avenue, and 90 Haitians at an Otisville, N.Y., detention center
would be affected.

Wider Application Is Urged

A lawsuit filed Thursday by the Lawyers Committee for International Human Rights
contends that the court order affects not only Haitians. The suit says that a
decision on June 18 also applies to an Afghan and three Iranians held at the
Brooklyn center, according to Arthur C. Helton, director of the committee's
Political Asylum Project.

Judge Spellman ruled that the immigration agency's new policy was ''null and
void'' because the agency had not announced the change in The Federal Register
and had not asked for public comment, as required by the Administrative
Procedure Act.

On June 29, the judge ordered the release of 1,900 Haitians to the care of
sponsors in the community. The agency is appealing.

Rush by Others Was Feared

The judge allowed the agency to continue to detain illegal immigrants, however,
to avoid a rush by others to enter the United States before the new regulations
were published July 9, according to Duane Austin, an agency spokesman.

Mr. Austin said the agency believed the judge's decision applied only to
Haitians so it had no plans to release others unless they were under the age of
16, had close relatives in the United States or were pregnant or ill.

Mr. Helton said he believed the Brooklyn center had not provided adequate
medical care or recreational and social services for the detainees.

The conditions at the facility, he said, ''tend to coerce people to give up
their claims and return to their country to face persecution.'' Mr. Helton said
that the lawyers' committee had not decided whether to challenge the
constitutionality of the detention policy.

Legal Process Prolongs Stay

Mr. Austin said that even though the agency's facilities were not designed for
long-term detention, ''it is the individual's choice to lengthen his stay by
lengthening the legal process.''

''The agency would love to see these cases adjudicated,'' he said.  ''But they
came here realizing that they were foreigners, and they came here undocumented.
What do you say to the 1.2 million people waiting eight or nine years to get
into the United States if you let people arrive here and turn them loose?''

Mr. Austin said preventive detention discouraged illegal immigration. Before the
new policy, he said, as many as 1,700 Haitians a month were entering the United
States illegally. Last month, he said, the known total was four.

In May, 34 Afghans were being held in the Brooklyn center. As of yesterday there
were 46 Afghans, along with eight Iraqis and three Iranians, according to Kevin
Doyle, director of the center. The Afghans are seeking political asylum,
contending they suffered political persecution in their homeland. The State
Department has denied many of the petitions.

1,146 Afghans Awaiting Asylum

At the end of May, 1,146 Afghans across the nation were waiting for decisions on
their asylum requests, Mr. Austin said.  From October 1981 to May, 232 Afghans
were granted asylum and 110 were denied it, compared with 208 approvals and 26
denials the year before.

                August 8, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

HAITIANS FREED BY U.S. JUDGE ARE IN LEGAL AND SOCIAL LIMBO

BYLINE: By RICHARD J. MEISLIN, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 30, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 948 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Aug. 7


More than a month after their release was ordered by a Federal judge, Haitian
refugees are leaving Federal detention facilities at a trickle. And those at
liberty are finding themselves in a legal and social limbo.

As of today, 151 refugees had been released under the court order, all but eight
of them from the Krome Avenue detention center at the edge of the Everglades
just west of here.

A few dozen other refugees have been paroled for what the Immigration and
Naturalization Service called ''humanitarian'' reasons. But that still left more
than 1,600 Haitians in detention in the United States and Puerto Rico.

Representatives of voluntary agencies aiding the Haitians said the next group,
those held at Fort Allen in Puerto Rico, could begin leaving detention sometime
next week. More than 700 Haitians are now being held there.

Long Legal Procedure Likely

''We haven't hit any big snags,'' said Beverly McFarland, a spokesman for the
immigration agency, ''but it's not moving quite as rapidly as people
anticipated.''

Those who have been released will have to appear 30 days later to begin hearings
on whether they will be allowed to remain here, giving their liberty a cast of
uncertainty. The first of those hearings is to begin Aug. 26, but the procedure
could be a long one.

Meanwhile, life for those who have been freed has already become a struggle.
Many of them speak only their native Creole, making their situation more
difficult than that of the Cubans who arrived in 1980 and joined Miami's large
Spanish-speaking community.

In addition, many of the Haitians lack job skills to make them self-supporting.
And since the question of whether they will be able to stay in the United States
remains open, they are less attractive to potential employers.

''The Haitians will work - they'll take almost anything,'' said Gerry Wynne,
director of program development for the United States Catholic Conference, the
largest voluntary agency involved in resettling the Haitians. ''But it's a great
deal to ask, finding jobs in this economy.''

Some of the newly released refugees have already caused a stir by applying for
welfare benefits, a move that appears to run counter to the intent expressed in
the court order by Federal District Judge Eugene P. Spellman that they were not
''to be the continued concern of the state or the community'' in which they were
located.

Linda Berkowitz, refugee coordinator for Miami's Health and Rehabilitative
Services Department, said that at least 22 of the recently released refugees had
applied for benefits and 15 of the applications had been approved.

''By law, we can't deny it,'' she said. ''This is a point that Judge Spellman
made in court the other day when he said that if it's their legal right, there's
nothing even he can do.''

The voluntary agencies have received a Federal grant allowing them to provide
health insurance for the Haitians through a private insurance carrier. Mr. Wynne
said the agencies were supposed to provide for the refugees' needs for at least
the first 120 days, making welfare unnecessary. He estimated that the cost per
refugee would range from $1,300 to $1,800.

Worried About Day 121

Welfare officials have complained that they have no way of determining who a
welfare applicant's sponsor is. The voluntary agencies have now agreed to
provide lists of the refugees they are assisting, to prevent them from receiving
welfare benefits as well, at least for the first 120 days.

''What worries me is what will happen on Day 121,'' Mr. Wynne said. ''The I.N.S.
may think they'll have their hearings and be deported by then, but it's not
going to happen that way.''

As the Haitians begin to leave detention for the community, the legal battle
that brought their release continued.  Judge Spellman's order was based only on
the procedural methods the immigration agency used to change its policy from one
of liberty while awaiting hearings to one of detention. He ruled that the
refugees' main charge, that they were being discriminated against as a group,
was not valid.

The immigration agency has appealed the ruling against its procedure, and
refugee groups have appealed the ruling that the detention policy was not
discriminatory. Arguments in that case are to begin in the Unites States Court
of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in Atlanta next month.

Tough Enforcement Continues

Meanwhile, the immigration agency gave evidence this week that it had no
intention of allowing Judge Spellman's order to permit a renewed flow of
Haitians entering this country illegally.

Four Haitians who stowed away on the Bahamian ship Yeocomico II with the help of
a Haitian crew member were found this week, dehydrated and hungry after a
three-day trip without food or water, when it docked in Dania, Fla., just south
of Fort Lauderdale. The refugees had paid a total of $1,000 to the crew member,
who jumped ship and was still at large.

The immigration agency immediately ordered the Haitians detained, an order that
the captain fulfilled by tying them to the deck railing.

The refugees were deported to the Bahamas the next day, where they were arrested
and jailed. Truman Carr, deputy chief of the border patrol in Miami, said this
type of tough enforcement had discouraged the influx of Haitians to the point
that it had ''dropped down to half a dozen a month from where we were getting
hundreds a night.''

Integration And Idealism

SECTION: Section 11; Long Island; Page 16, Column 4; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 163 words


Michael Kirwan, director of the Human Relations Commission of the Village of
Freeport, admits (''Redistricting and Segregation: Repeating a Pattern,''
Opinion Page) that black immigration into Nassau reproduces the urban ghettos in
suburbia. Yet he insists that integration will take place because its time has
come and because ''it is the American way.''

I disagree on both points. He confuses the American myth, summed up in ''one
nation indivisible, with liberty and justice for all,'' with the American way,
best characterized by Rap Brown's ''Violence is as American as Cherry pie.''
That the time is not ripe is amply reflected by the brutal mob murder of a black
transit worker in Sheepshead Bay on June 22.

Still I am glad that Mr. Kirwan is an idealist. Although idealism always
contains a large measure of self-delusion, it is only through an optimistic
refusal to regard the status quo as permanent that social progress is made.
STANLEY W. PAGE, Lido Beach

                 July 30, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

OUT OF MIAMI DETENTION, HAITIAN TESTS FREEDOM

BYLINE: By REGINALD STUART, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 8, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1105 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 27


Shortly before Joseph Denis was released from the Krome Avenue detention center
here, a Federal immigration official gave him a slip of paper. On it were Mr.
Denis's name, his country of birth, Haiti, and the date on which his temporary
release could be extended or revoked, Nov. 23, 1982.

''This is my freedom,'' Mr. Denis said of the slip of paper a few days after he
left the makeshift prison to settle in a tiny apartment in the Little Haiti
section of this city. Of his new life, still less than a week old, he said,
''They gave me my papers and I hope it's for good.''

Mr. Denis, 24 years old, was among the first of 1,900 Haitian refugees who are
to be released from the seven Federal detention facilities where they have been
held since they entered the country, some more than a year ago. On June 29 their
detention was ruled illegal by Federal District Judge Eugene P. Spellman in
Miami, who found that the Government, in dealing with the Haitians, had changed
its immigration rules without following proper rule-making procedures.

Formerly They Got Parole at Once

Since the 1950's, most refugees, people who say they have fled their country for
political reasons, have been allowed to enter this country and immediately
receive parole pending a determination of their right to asylum.

In the case of the Haitians, however, there is a dispute between the Government
and the refugees. The Government holds that the Haitians have entered the
country illegally, without documents and with no valid claim to asylum, but
simply for economic reasons. The Haitians say they are political refugees
because they would face persecution if they were returned home.

Since August 1981, with a huge flow of Haitians following a huge flow of Cubans,
the Immigration and Naturalization Service has been detaining the Haitians,
planning to exclude them, meaning send them back home. The Government also hoped
that the policy would discourage others from coming here. The move evoked
national controversy, with sharp criticism from many religious and human rights
groups. In September a Federal judge enjoined the Government from holding
exclusion hearings for any refugee not represented by a lawyer. Then in June,
the Haitians were ordered released.

The release signals the end of a series of ordeals for each of them, if the
experiences of Mr. Denis are any example. And although the smell of freedom is
more a reality now than a hope, he and the Haitians who have lived in this
country longer carry a heavy burden.

In an interview, translated into English from his French patois through an
interpreter and family members, Mr. Denis spoke of his concern for others still
detained and of those who died at sea while fleeing. He said he was worried
about possible Haitian Government reprisals against his parents and four
brothers and three sisters.

''I'm scared for them because the authorities could go and abuse them,'' Mr.
Denis said.  As was the case for most of the refugees, Mr. Denis said that he
fled Haiti under less than ideal circumstances. He said he feared for his safety
after an encounter with an officer of Haiti's Volunteers for National Security,
who are as feared as their predecessors, the Tonton Macoutes.

Mr. Denis said the officer had wanted to graze his cattle on Mr.  Denis's small
plot despite Mr. Denis's objections. Mr. Denis was arrested and, as is said to
be commonplace in Haiti, was never charged with anything and was then released.
A few days later, Mr.  Denis said, his new home burned. He blames the officer
for his troubles.

'I Could Not Stay in Haiti'

''It was threatening for me,'' said Mr. Denis. ''So I sold some oxen, put the
money away and paid for my trip here, $85. I was scared to leave because I was
told it was a long dangerous trip, but I could not stay in Haiti anymore.''

On Sept. 22, 1981, he said, he and 61 others boarded a 30-foot boat on Haiti's
southern shore for a journey that would not end until Oct. 14 at Miami Beach.
The only food aboard was rice, a staple in Haiti.  The only stop was in Cuba,
where their food was replenished and their deteriorating boat was pointed toward
the Florida Keys.

On reaching the United States, Mr. Denis did not find the open arms that
Dieuseul Charles said that he remembered when he fled here in May 1970. Mr.
Charles, a neighbor in Miami, was a naval officer in Haiti before being deported
after he participated in bombing the royal palace in Port-au-Prince, the
capital.

''The American immigration people welcomed us like brothers,'' Mr.  Charles
declared, as Mr. Denis gathered his thoughts for a moment.  ''The first time I
came here I was happy.''

Mr. Denis said of his arrival: ''I didn't think I would be imprisoned.'' In the
months that passed, he said, suicide often crossed his mind. ''What I saw was
misery,'' he declared, not the ''life and liberty'' he and the other refugees
talked about in their scary time at sea. ''The only good time I remember at
Krome was when they said they were going to release us,'' he said.

Mr. Denis was released to his relatives here, including Sauveur LaCouture, his
38-year-old brother, who came to this country in 1977. ''I will learn a job,
study,'' he said, as his brother nodded. ''And by this time next year, I will be
looking for something I can do.''

'Our People Help Each Other'

As a practical matter, much adjustment must be made, the more experienced
Haitians said. Most of the refugees, including Mr. Denis, will have to learn
English quickly. So far, Mr. Denis says with a smile, he knows only the word
''dollar.'' Learning to drive an automobile may be imperative to get work
outside Little Haiti.

There is support within the community for all of these things, said Mr. Charles
and Mr. Denis's older brother. ''Our people help each other,'' said Mr. Charles.

Some new Haitians feel they probably face a more hostile public.  The plight of
the Haitian refugees has been embraced in recent months by much of the Miami
area. But hate mail posted on the wall of an activist, the Rev. Gerard
Jean-Juste of the Haitian Refugee Center, attests hostility as well.

''I have heard there are Americans who resent my coming here,'' said Mr. Denis,
when asked about the uneasy environment. ''But to them I say, I cannot go back
to Haiti. Don't send me back to Haiti.''

SPORTS PEOPLE;
Athlete Asks Asylum

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 164 words


Hu Na, the Chinese tennis star who disappeared from her hotel last week, asked
for political asylum yesterday at the San Francisco office of the Immigration
and Naturalization Service. ''It's now up to the State Department whether she
gets asylum or not,'' said David Ilchert, the I.N.S. district director. Miss Hu
appeared with her lawyer, Edward C.Y. Lau of San Francisco, who said his client
had informed Chinese officials last week of her intentions. ''She has been safe
and comfortable in seclusion, where she will remain until the State Department
decides on her petition,'' the attorney said.  Chinese officials said they were
confused by Miss Hu's actions and believed she may have been talked into leaving
her team by an outside source. Miss Hu, who is from the Szechuan Province, won a
tournament last year in Mexico and was considered potentially good enough to be
among the world's top 20 women players.

                July 24, 1982, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

HAITIANS LEAVING DETENTION IN MIAMI

BYLINE: By RICHARD J. MEISLIN, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 971 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 23


With songs and chants from supporters, the first of 1,807 Haitian refugees
ordered freed by a Federal judge were released today from a Federal detention
camp near the Everglades.

The action followed an agreement Thursday night between the Government, refugee
groups and voluntary assistance agencies that set aside the final obstacles to
the release of the refugees, some of whom have been held for more than a year.

Immigration officials released 17 refugees in the first group. They said others
would be freed as voluntary agencies came forward with the names of sponsors, in
a process likely to take several days.

This afternoon at the Immigration and Naturalization Service's Krome Avenue
detention center, west of here, expectation and jubilation began to replace the
frustration among the refugees who, for nearly a month after the judge's order,
had been able to smell their freedom but not taste it.

The frustration welled up earlier this week into a battle when two refugees at
Krome, said to be angry over lack of drinking water, destroyed some furniture at
the center.

There were 407 refugees at the Krome camp today, and 1,400 more at camps in New
York, Kentucky, Texas, West Virginia and Puerto Rico.  All are covered by the
Federal court order, issued June 29 by Judge Eugene P. Spellman, except 53 held
in Brooklyn. Their release had been ordered by a Federal judge in Brooklyn, but
that order was overturned on appeal.

''They've been pretty cheered up,'' Beverly McFarland, a spokesman for the
immigration service, said of the Krome refugees. ''Now they're just waiting for
whose name gets called.''

The first name to be called was that of Etienne Francois, a 42-year-old Haitian
who had been held behind the chain-link fence at Krome, on the edge of the
Everglades, since August.

He left the center shortly after 3 P.M., driven through the gates past a line of
immigration officers by a representative of the Church World Service's Episcopal
Bishops Fund.

As a small group of Haitians outside the gates chanted ''Liberty!  Liberty!''
and sang a Haitian hymn that included the line, ''Thanks to God, the misery is
over for us,'' Mr. Francois, surrounded by dozens of reporters, emerged from his
car. He looked with bewilderment at the crowd and raised his arms over his head
in a sign of victory.

Praying for All to Be Free

The Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste, head of the Haitian Refugee Center here, translated
as Mr. Francois said that he was ''praying to God that everyone else will be
free someday.''

''I don't feel too bad,'' Mr. Francois added, with a sheepish smile. He edged
back into the car and went to stay with a cousin in the Miami area.

His release was followed minutes later by that of Raoul Felix, a 41-year-old
carpenter with a broad grin and a scrubby beard, whose sister Olga had come with
agency workers to retrieve him after almost a year of detention.

''I feel good for him - I'm glad, I'm glad,'' said Miss Felix, who runs a dress
shop in Miami. ''Eleven months I've been waiting - now I'm happy today. Big
party.''

The parole of the Haitians was ordered last month by Judge Spellman, who ruled
that the Government had violated administratative procedures in deciding last
year to detain Haitians who sought refuge in this country. Until that time, the
Government had allowed the immigrants to be free on parole while conducting
hearings and other inquiries on their fate.

Still Face Court Hearings

The freedom gained by the Haitians today is tenuous. Under the Federal court
order, those released will have to return to court in 30 days for exclusionary
hearings to determine whether they will be able to remain here.

The agreement on at least temporary freedom came Thursday night, when the
Government agreed to a shorter release form to be signed by the refugees and
their sponsors. The voluntary agencies, meanwhile, agreed to put aside a battle
with the Government over money for refugee resettlement.

Mr. Jean-Juste said that all but ''10 or 15 percent'' of those being released
from the Krome center would be staying with relatives in the area, making the
issue of resettlement costs less important than that of rapid release.

Under the agreement signed by the voluntary agencies and the sponsors, a sponsor
will have to be in contact with the refugee he is responsible for at least once
a week. Sponsors will have to make a weekly report to a voluntary agency on the
refugeee's whereabouts and to disclose any arrests.

An issue underlying the controversy is whether the Haitians were fleeing
political repression or escaping their country's ravaged economy.

The Government has attempted to place most of the refugees in the latter
category, that of economic refugees, which would mean they are not entitled to
remain in this country. Until last summer, however, it treated them as other
refugees, granting parole until cases were decided.

The change in policy, which resulted in the detention of several hundred
Haitians in Federal centers for more than a year, was intended to stem a sharp
increase in illegal immigration.

----

Interviewing Schedules Set

MIAMI, July 23 (AP) - Haitians detained in Otisville, N.@Y., and Ray Brook,
N.Y., were to be interviewed next week by representatives of the religious
agencies sponsoring them. Officials said plans call for all of them to be
released within two months.

On Tuesday representatives of the United States Catholic Conference are to begin
interviewing the 157 Haitian men at the Federal prison in Ray Brook, in the
Adirondacks, the Rev. Stephen Gratto of Plattsburgh said today.

Representatives of World Relief Services are to begin orientation meetings
Monday with the 93 Haitian men at the Federal Correctional Institute at
Otisville in the Catskills, Warden J. Michael Quinlan said.

AROUND THE NATION;
Some Haitian Refugees Could Be Freed Friday

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section A; Page 8, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 137 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 22


The release of more than 1,800 Haitian refugees held across the country could
begin Friday, attorneys for the Government and the refugees said tonight.

Representatives of the Haitians, volunteer resettlement agencies and the
Immigration and Naturalization Service resolved the wording of a document that
sponsors of refugees would have to sign. It was apparently the last barrier to
the Haitians' release.

The compromise is still subject to approval by the American Council of Voluntary
Action, which is coordinating the resettlement of the 410 Haitians held in a
Miami detention center.

The agreement tonight would have no immediate impact on about 1,400 other
Haitian refugees held in camps in five other states and Puerto Rico, who are
also awaiting their release.

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, July 19


John Demjanjuk, a Ukrainian-born immigrant who was stripped of his United States

STUDY SEES SHIFT IN U.S. POPULATION

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 574 words

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 18


The proportion of Americans who are white and of European ancestry, the nation's
basic ethnic stock since Colonial days, will decline at an accelerating rate in
the next two decades, according to an analysis of population trends by a
California research organization.

Based on computer projections of immigration patterns and fertility rates, the
study concluded that Americans who are white and non-Hispanic will make up 77
percent of the population in 1990 and 75 percent by 2000, compared with
approximately 80 percent in 1980.

The analysis, done by the Center for Continuing Study of the California Economy,
predicts explosive population growth for people of Asian and Hispanic ancestry.
The number of Asians will rise at least 90.7 percent to 10.6 million in the next
two decades, while the number of Hispanics will increase at least 58 percent to
23 million, according to the study.

If the forecast is accurate, the trend would continue a pattern observed in the
1980 census. In the 1970's, the proportion of non-Hispanic whites in the
population declined to about 80 percent from 86 percent.

Growth in Minority Groups

''More than half of the U.S. population growth in the next two decades will come
from minority groups,'' said Stephen Levy, a coauthor of the report.

People of Hispanic origin are expected to account for about 25 percent of the
population growth, largely because of a higher birth rate among Hispanic
families, the relative youth of childbearing Hispanic women and continuing
emigration from Mexico and other Latin countries.

Robert Arnold, director of the research group in Palo Alto, which specializes in
studies of the California economy, said the projections were derived from a
computer model of demographic trends based on current fertility and death rates,
immigration patterns and projections. These projections include an assumption
that the birth rate for Hispanic women, now 30 to 50 percent higher than the
national average, will decline as the women adopt values more common to the
national norm.

The researchers for the study forecast that the nation's population, which was
226.5 million in 1980, would rise to at least 248 million by 1990 and 267
million by 2000, a total increase of 18 percent.

Slight Rise in Black Population

The report said that blacks, who made up 11.5 percent of the population in 1980,
would make up 12.4 percent in 2000, or about 33.5 million. Hispanic residents,
who made up 6.4 percent of the population in 1980, are expected to make up at
least 8.6 percent in 2000, about 23 million. In addition, the study forecasts
that Asians and those in smaller ethnic categories, who made up 2.5 percent of
the population in 1980, will account for 4 percent in 2000, about 10.6 million.

Mr. Levy said the analysts found it hard to estimate future illegal emigration
from Mexico and Central and South America. He said the projections were based on
an estimate of 35,000 to 132,000 illegal Hispanic immigrants annually, but he
indicated that the figure might be overly conservative.

''If this assumption were more than tripled, to 500,000 annually,'' Mr. Levy
said, ''the Hispanic population would total 35 million in a nation of 280
million by the turn of the century.''

AFGHANS IN 'IMMIGRATION GULAG' DESERVE MERCY

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 400 words


To the Editor:

You are to be commended for editorializing (June 17) in favor of mercy for the
Haitian 53 being held in indefinite detention by the Immigration and
Naturalization Service at its jail in Brooklyn. Not mentioned, but just as
deserving, is the group of Afghan refugees also being detained.

here is no legitimate reason for the Immigration Service to keep the Afghans in
detention without provision for release on bond while they await action on their
requests for political asylum. These people, who fled from Russian domination
and persecution, have relatives here capable of supporting them while their
cases are pending and who are willing to post bond to guarantee their
appearance.

The Afghan refugees have been imprisoned for months at considerable expense to
the Government while the Immigration Service dawdles. One, Mohamad Walai, was
denied political asylum on May 14, 1982. On May 19 he petitioned the Board of
Immigration Appeals in Washington.

For the appeal to be heard, a transcript of the exclusion hearing is necessary.
It took the Immigration Service seven weeks to prepare the transcript. Upon
complaint to the service, the response was, ''Sorry, we have only one
transcriber for the Brooklyn detained cases.''

Upon complaint to the United States District Court, habeas corpus was denied and
the judge refused to order the service to quickly provide the transcript. He did
not want to interfere with the way the service processes its cases.

Also jailed are three brothers, one a teen-ager. On May 25, 1982, the Department
of State was requested to evaluate their applications for asylum. Fifty-five
days later there is still no response. The brothers wait, numbed, in jail for
proceedings that may take months or years to complete.

Refugees who are not charged with any crime are jailed indefinitely in Brooklyn.
The Federal courts provide no relief. It is time the public raised its voice
against the immigration gulag.  CHARLES ARONOWITZ New York, July 16, 1982

The writer is counsel for several of the Afghan refugees.

RAIDS ON ALIENS RULED ILLEGAL

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section A; Page 8, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 254 words

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15


A Federal appeals court ruled today that raids by agents of the Immigration and
Naturalization Service in attempts to apprehend illegal aliens at factories
violated constitutional protections against unreasonable searches.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled in favor of the
International Ladies Garment Workers Union, which charged in a suit that the
raids constituted an illegal ''detention of the entire work force.''

The immigration agents must be able to ''articulate a reasonable suspicion that
the questioned person is an alien illegally in this country'' before the worker
can be detained and questioned, the court said.

To rule otherwise, the court said, would allow immigration agents to stop and
interrogate suspected illegal aliens ''at whim'' and erode the privacy rights of
citizens and aliens legally in the country.

The decision invalidates a normal practice of the immigration agrency, which
sends agents into factories where illegal aliens are suspected of working.

The union brought the issue to the court after two garment factories in southern
California were raided by immigration agents in 1977 and 162 aliens were
arrested.

The three-member panel of the court of appeals rejected arguments by the
immigration agency that any intrusion was ''so slight'' that constitutional
protections against unreasonable search and seizures were not violated.

U.S. SEEKS CHANGE IN CHECKS ON VISAS

BYLINE: By DUDLEY CLENDINEN, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 845 words

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 12


The Immigration and Naturalization Service is proposing to do one of its jobs
more effectively by giving the chore to private agencies, but the plan is
running into stiff opposition from some of the service's line officers and from
Congressmen and immigration lawyers who fear its implications.

The problem is keeping up with foreigners who have come to the United States on
student visas. There might be 10,000 such persons enrolled in the colleges and
universities clustered in Boston, or the number might be 15,000. Immigration
officers like Joel Dorfman cannot say for sure.

There may be 300,000 foreign students in the whole nation, or that number might
be 350,000. Or higher. Or lower. Washington officials of the service say they
aren't sure.

''That's a figure that's really unknown,'' said Janet Graham, a spokesman for
the service. ''They're constantly coming in and out.'' Tracking the movements of
the foreign students is tedious and difficult, in part because the job is not
being well done and in part because the officials think overworked officers like
Mr. Dorfman have more to do.

Shifting Duty to Schools

Under the immigration agency's proposed change, the schools would be given the
task of seeing whether foreigners with student visas are properly enrolled and
where they should be, and reporting to immigration officials.

The opposition of frustrated immigration officers is based on a worry that the
proposal would cede Federal authority to institutions, the schools, with a
vested interest in catering to the students they would be asked to oversee.

Largely unnoticed until it drew the attention of immigration officers here, the
proposal was published in the May 28 Federal Register, in 10 pages of small type
saying that the revisions ''would eliminate much burdensome paper work and
maintain control over the students by more effective use of institutional
sponsorship of the students by the schools.''

The student program ''benefits the American economy and those academic and
vocational schools which depend on foreign student enrollments as a major source
of tuition income,'' the service said.  ''This source becomes increasingly
important to those institutions as the domestic student population shrinks.''

Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, on receiving complaints from
immigration lawyers and the American Federation of Government Employees about
the plan, wrote two weeks ago to Alan C.  Nelson, Commissioner of the
immigration agency.

''While I can appreciate the position of many schools throughout the United
States in wanting to administer their foreign student programs efficiently and
effectively,'' Mr. Tsongas wrote, ''I cannot, however, understand the underlying
purpose in taking away the auhority bestowed to a Federal agency and passing the
enforcement of the Immigration and Nationality Act'' to the private
institutions.

'Conflict of Interest' Debated

The Federation for American Immigration Reform, a public interest group in
Washington, wrote that it was, ''frankly, most baffled that the rules were
developed despite the acknowledged conflict of interest.''

Mr. Dorfman and officers of the government employee local have challenged what
they said was an assumption ''that neither school officials nor foreign students
require the discipline imposed by present regulations.''

''Working-level I.N.S. officers and line supervisors.'' they said, ''have much
experience suggesting that foreign students and schools are significant
violators of our immigration laws and that redoubled enforcement efforts, rather
than abrogation of responsibility by I.N.S., are in order.''

Such advisers to foreign students as Jennifer Stephens, whose office supervises
3,000 foreign students at Harvard University, regard as an insult the suggestion
that they would have a financial interest in allowing foreigners to abuse the
rules.

''I know most of my colleagues nationwide, and I certainly wouldn't agree,'' she
said with surprise Friday.  Thus joined is a dispute with practical and
philosophic sides.Immigration officials like Mr. Dorfman say that many
foreigners use student visas as a means of entering the country, working part
time in competition with American youths and lingering in search of some way to
stay on permanently. He sees the proposal as just another sign of the collapse
of enforcement.

The solution, said Eugene H. Smith, the foreign student adviser at the
University of Colorado, is to let the schools report whether students are in
complance with the rules or not, and let the immigration agency enforce the laws
against the students or against schools that do not report on their students.

''I think it's easier for them to monitor 5,000 schools than it is to monitor
500,000 students,'' said Mr. Smith.

MEXICAN HELD AS LEADER OF ALIEN SMUGGLING RING IS ARRAIGNED

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 955 words

DATELINE: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 11


Wearing a white embroidered Mexican shirt, Salvador Pineda-Vergara listened to a
reading in Spanish of a long indictment charging him with masterminding what the
Immigration and Naturalization Service says is the largest illegal alien
smuggling ring it has broken.

The reading took two hours as Mr. Pineda sat here Thursday before a Federal
magistrate, Robert McCoy, in the second round of arraignments of 38 persons
charged with conspiracy to transport illegal aliens and transporting illegal
aliens.

The immigration agency charges that Mr. Pineda, a Mexican national who is 56
years old and the father of 10, headed an operation for four years that grossed
$24 million annually and brought an estimated 24,000 illegal aliens into the
United States each year. His indictment was among several announced June 23.

Mr. Pineda is being held here under $1 million bond, which the immigration
agency says is the highest bail ever set in an illegal aliens smuggling case.
The 48 counts against him carry total fines of more than $100,000 and prison
sentences of up to 240 years.

Not Guilty Plea Entered

Mr. Pineda stood mute, and Judge McCoy entered a plea of not guilty for him. The
defendant also filed an affidavit of indigency, and the judge named a lawyer to
defend him. Trials in the case will begin in the fall.

''Getting Pineda will shut down this entire operation,'' said H.C.  Murphy, a
criminal investigator in the immigration agency's Albuquerque office. ''There
are people with the skills to take it over, but no one has Pineda's skills. He
could have made money legally.''

Mr. Pineda has never commented publicly on the charges.  The smuggling
operation, which the officials said made a profit of $12 million to $15 million
a year, was broken when undercover immigration agents posing as drivers
infiltrated the ring after the Illinois Highway Patrol intercepted a car full of
illegal aliens on the way to Chicago last July. Mr. Pineda was arrested in El
Paso when he went to a Western Union office to pick up payments for transporting
some of the aliens, the immigration agency said.

According to immigration officials, the operation was called the ''Villasana''
or ''safe way,'' after the small hotel in Ciudad Juarez where the aliens were
kept before crossing into El Paso with the normal daily traffic. From there they
were moved by teams of drivers into a network of safe houses, motels and trains
in New Mexico and on to Middle Western cities, particularly Chicago.

$650 to $1,700 Fee Charged

The operation charged Mexican nationals $650 and Central and South American
residents $1,600 to $1,700, according to the immigration agency.

New Mexico was the distribution area for the network because highways and Amtrak
service are good, Mr. Murphy said. In addition, the border patrol is more active
in Texas, leaving New Mexico relatively unattended, and law enforcement there
tends to be scattered because of the rugged country.

Mr. Murphy said his agency hoped to indict many more participants in the ring,
although he would not estimate the number.  He said two routes, overland and by
Amtrak, were used in the operation. In the overland route, he said, aliens were
driven circuitously, to avoid border patrol checkpoints, from El Paso to Silver
City, a remote mining town on the edge of the Gila National Forest in
southwestern New Mexico. There, they were transferred to other cars and the
drivers headed north.

In the Amtrak route, aliens were driven north from El Paso on Interstate 25 to
the farming and commuting town of Belen, 30 miles south of Albuquerque. There
they were transferred to other cars and taken to the Amtrak station at Lamy, a
hamlet of 100 people near Santa Fe, to board the daily train to Chicago.

''It's a long way for us to go,'' Mr. Murphy said, alluding to Lamy. ''It's
impossible to put surveillance on the damned place.''

Slipped Easily Through Towns

Along both routes, runners accompanied the aliens and spotters kept watch for
law-enforcement officials. The groups of aliens slipped easily through the
towns, many of which are predominantly Hispanic American.

Danny J. Gabaldon, assistant police chief of Belen, said that the townspeople's
attitude toward illegal aliens was a mixture of hostility and sympathy. Many
just looked the other way as the aliens passed through. The immigration agency
noted that that was not a violation of any law.

Donald Sandoval, a reporter with The Valencia County News-Bulletin in Belen,
said he knew illegal aliens had worked on local ranches for years, doing jobs
that he said Americans would not do. ''People here accept them,'' he said.

Helen Welkenback, manager of the nine-room Rancho Verde Motel, one of two where
Mr. Murphy said aliens were sheltered, said she suspected it was used for such
purposes. But, she said: ''I'm here to rent rooms. I can't refuse anybody.
They're very quiet people; no trouble with them at all.''

William Rodriguez, the ticket agent at Lamy, paid scant attention to the illegal
aliens boarding trains to Chicago at his station. ''To me, it's all the same,''
he said. ''I just sell tickets. They got money, I'll give them a ticket.''

Robin Doughman, a local contractor, said, ''The whole town's been aware for
years of shady dealings.'' He said residents never notified the authorities
because ''people mind their own business and don't pay attention.''

                 July 11, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

ARGENTINA'S 'SEVERELY DILUTED NATIONAL CHARACTER'

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 307 words


To the Editor:

It appears that Argentina's malaise (''Argentina Ungoverned Again,'' editorial
June 19) could be deeply rooted in a severely diluted national character.

In the 50 years prior to World War I, there was a massive immigration of 2.5
million Europeans; over half of these people were Italian. The Argentine
population in 1869 was 1.8 million.

Although this heavy inflow has continued in recent decades, a large number of
resident aliens never applied for citizenship and have tended to regard
themselves as something else first and Argentine second. This pattern has been
noted by the writer, Jorge Luis Borges, and many non-Argentine observers as
well.

Lord Bryce came to the conclusion in 1912 that the Argentine people ''have
ceased to be Spaniards without becoming something new of their own. They seem to
be a nation in the making, not yet made.''

John Gunther observantly noted during the 1960's that Argentina ''for all of its
basic wealth, prestige, intense national pride and degree of civilization ...
gives a sense not merely of lack of direction but of outright lostness. National
purpose, faith and a sense of mission seem to have disappeared.''

When the Peronists returned to power in Argentina in 1973, they called on all
sectors of the populace to join in a social pact (Acta del Compromiso Nacional)
to make the sacrifices required for the commonweal.

But by mid-1974, greedy self-interest had prevailed over the common good and the
pact was in a shambles due to these ''sacrifices.'' Businessmen resorted to
widespread black-market activities and used double bookkeeping systems to
circumvent the price freeze and the tax collectors. And the powerful trade
unions obtained large periodic wage increases amid a deep recession and soaring
inflation.
ELLIOT A. MARCUS, Lawrence, Mass., June 22, 1982

AROUND THE NATION;
Decline Is Suspected In Illegal Immigration

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 157 words

DATELINE: SAN YSIDRO, Calif., July 7


United States immigration officials, puzzled by an apparent drop in illegal
immigration from Mexico, speculated today that devaluation of the peso might be
partly responsible.

Gene Wood, chief of the Chula Vista

National news is on pages

A12-14, B8-15 and B17.
Sector of the Federal Border Patrol, said, ''Smugglers traditionally insist upon
payment in dollars. It now takes more pesos to buy dollars. That may be a
factor.''

Through June, 171,559 aliens have been arrested in the Chula Vista Sector, which
includes San Diego. The arrests are down by 28,212, or 14 percent, from the same
period last year, and officials said it could mean fewer illegal aliens were
trying to sneak into the United States. A comparable decline has been noted
along the Texas border.

But Mr. Wood cautioned the figures might not reflect a trend.''The decline is
fairly recent, and may be a fluke,'' he said.

Around the Nation;
Judge Gives U.S. 90 Days To Alter Haitian Policy

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 154 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 2


A Federal district judge ruled today that the Government could detain newly
arriving illegal aliens in the next 90 days because there was a ''meaningful
concern'' that thousands of Haitians might flood into Florida if there was no
deterrent.

Judge Eugene Spellman agreed to the three-month grace period to give the
Government time to write a new immigration policy. On June 18 he struck down the
policy of detaining Haitians while they awaited hearings on political asylum.

Judge Spellman said that an affidavit by Gov. Bob Graham, asserting that 20,000
to 40,000 Haitians were in the Bahamas, showed a ''meaningful concern of
irreparable harm'' to Florida if there was a massive influx.

Judge Spellman's decision will not affect the 1,900 Haitians he ordered released
11 days after his ruling on the policy. That decision is expected to be appealed
by the Government.

FLEEING BEIRUT CHAOS TO SAFETY AT SEA

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 966 words

DATELINE: JUNIEH, Lebanon, June 24


Hundreds of Americans, Western Europeans and Lebanese with American immigration
papers were evacuated by a transport ship of the Sixth Fleet today, just hours
after the American Embassy in western Beirut closed down.

Two large American Navy landing craft ferried the evacuees from the docks of the
port of this Christian-controlled harbor 15 miles north of Beirut. The craft
took them out to sea, where the Navy transport Nashville waited in the
Mediterranean haze to sail them to Cyprus. (In a separate operation, according
to The Associated Press, the British merchant vessel Royal Prince also docked at
Junieh to pick up evacuees.)

An American vice consul, Lisa Piascik, said 154 American citizens and their
dependents originally had been granted places on the American transport ship,
along with 144 Lebanese citizens holding green cards that allow them to work in
the United States and 90 other Lebanese who were ''of interest'' to the embassy.

At the last minute, however, scores of other Lebanese, Western Europeans and
Americans showed up at the docks and were permitted to board the landing craft.

650 Board U.S. Vessel

About 650 people were eventually taken to the American shipt, but it was
impossible to determine all their nationalities.  (The State Department said
embassy operations had been transferred to Ambassador Robert Dillon's residence
in Yarze, five miles southeast of Beirut, near the presidential palace in
Baabda. The department said the evacuation was voluntary.)

The scene on the pier was one of controlled chaos. An understaffed American
Embassy crew, short on both information and tempers, shouted instructions
through a bullhorn to the jittery throng waiting to board the vessels. Mothers
clutched their babies, teen-agers lounged on bulging suitcases, old women fanned
themselves with newspapers and everyone complained about everything in a
cacophony of languages.

Evidence of War Nearby

While the evacuees registered for passage, Israeli jets were busy blasting
Syrian gun positions in the hills a few miles to the southeast and Israeli
warships were bombarding western Beirut, from where most of the people here had
fled only hours earlier.

A few hundred yards away, a water skier zipped through the harbor and on the
beach bikini-clad Lebanese Christian women, glistening with suntan oil, took in
the whole tableau with disinterest.

The stories told by the departing Americans painted a vivid picture of the
anarchy that has gripped western Beirut and the bitterness felt by many of them
over what they see as Washington's unwillingness to restrain Israel.

''I was shocked and disgusted at how ruthless the Israelis have behaved,'' said
Carolyn Aliah, a 40-year-old Maryland native who is married to a Lebanese
engineer. ''The Israelis obviously have a goal in mind and don't care what is
between them and that goal. I just want to get out of their path.''

But just getting out of the way has become difficult. To get across the Green
Line dividing predominantly Moslem western Beirut, where some 2,000 Americans
once lived, from the Christian eastern section of the city, travelers have to
pass through four checkpoints of armed men in a space of two hundred yards.

One checkpoint is manned by the remnants of the Syrian army in Beirut, another
by Moslem leftists, a third by the Lebanese army and the last by the Christian
Phalangist militia.

''When we passed through the Syrian checkpoint coming here,'' said Tasha
Loufland, 19, of Los Angeles, ''the Syrians gave my dad a hard time about his
ID. They thought he was an Israeli spy.'' Her father teaches courses in theater
arts at Beirut Arab University.

Most of those heading for the Nashville, anchored about three miles off the
coast, were American women who had left their Lebanese husbands behind to
protect their property in western Beirut. They have had to make the choice of
staying in a city where car bombings and artillery bursts are common or fleeing,
with the risk that their homes may be occupied by the thousands of refugees
roaming the streets.

Woman Was Evacuated Twice Before

''My husband just wouldn't leave the house,'' said Eleyan Rifai, 37, an English
teacher at the American Community School, who is married to a Lebanese. ''My son
has not been able to go outside for two weeks. If it wasn't the Israeli planes,
it was the car bombs.''

Mrs. Rifai is no stranger to such evacuations, having been rescued by the
American Navy from Beirut in the 1975 civil war and from Teheran by the Air
Force in 1979. ''My family in Philadelphia asked me to tell them where I was
going next so they could be sure not to be there,'' she quipped.

Also familiar with evacuations was Mildred Hijazi, 62, of Niagara Falls, N.Y.
She left Cairo in 1956 with the help of the American Government and fled Beirut
in 1967, 1975 and today.

''They're all pretty much the same, Mrs. Hijazi said of the evacuations,
''crying babies and confusion.'' Myrna Mugrdichian, a 25-year-old dental student
whose father is a doctor at the American University Hospital, has been working
as a volunteer with the Lebanese Red Cross, pulling people out of the rubble of
collapsed buildings.

''We would listen for people's moans and that is where we would start digging,''
she said, explaining the rescuers' technique. ''I saw a lot of people in pieces
in the last few weeks.''

Teen-agers among the evacuees talked of the fighting with the aplomb of battle
veterans.  ''You get used to it,'' said Nina Ibrahim, a 15-year-old whose father
works at the American University Hospital. ''What bothered my dad was the
sniping around the university, but what bothered me most was that our school
year ended just like that. All my friends just scattered. No prom, no graduation
ceremony. No nothing.''
