                 June 25, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

'DECEITFUL NEW GAMBIT' IN HAITIAN REFUGEE POLICY

SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 3; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 729 words


To the Editor:

A deceitful new gambit has been played in the Government's Haitian refugee
strategy. On June 14, the one-year anniversary of the Immigration and
Naturalization Service's Haitian refugee detention policy, the Justice
Department announced its readiness to release on parole some of the 2,000
Haitian political asylum applicants languishing in Federal prisons and I.N.S.
jails around the country.v.ithin hours, the news had spread even to those jails,
and the months of lawsuits, legislative initiatives and just simple begging and
pleading seemed happily ended.

The plan, announced to the press in Washington and in the courtroom of a Federal
judge in Miami, offered freedom to those Haitians who (1) were represented by
attorneys; (2) had responsible sponsors; (3) gave assurances of appearances at
future proceedings in their cases.

For most of the detained Haitian boat people, because they have no lawyers, the
offer of parole was, at best, a distant hope. For at least the 53 Haitians who
have been ill-kept at the I.N.S.'s Brooklyn Navy Yard since last summer, all of
whom met the announced criteria, it seemed only a matter of days until freedom
could be arranged.

It was, instead, a cruel and indecent joke. No Government spokesman announced,
on June 14 in Washington or Miami, the Catch-22 in the plan: Persons who
otherwise meet the release criteria but whose asylum cases have already been
presented to an immigration judge are not eligible for parole. While their
legitimate appeals are awaiting decision by immigration authorities, those
Haitians will continue in jail.

This situation is nearly a replay of an earlier litigation in which a Fed-eral
court found that I.N.S. had systematically tried Haitian cases in a fashion
intended ''to achieve expedited mass deportations of Haitian nationals,
irrespective of the merits of an individual Haitian asylum application and
without regard to the ...  rights'' of those aliens. Indeed, any Haitian freed
under the plan whose case is hereafter heard and, as is inevitable, not won at
the trial level, will be swept up and put behind barbed wire again while his or
her appeal is being considered. This determination prospectively to deny the
liberty of persons whose cases are on appeal is specific only to Haitians as a
national-origin group and represents a radical departure from the norm.

It has become clear that virtually none among the Haitians are eligible to take
advantage of the release offer. Those without attorneys do not satisfy the basic
requirement of representation in the plan. Those few with attorneys have already
presented their cases and have filed appeals.

The Haitian parole plan is as senseless as it is cruel and discriminatory. For a
year the Government has decried the lack of lawyers available to represent the
Haitian boat people and I.N.S.'s inability to move the cases to hearing and
toward a conclusion. Only in New York City was it possible, by the end of August
of 1981, to find lawyers for 100 percent of the Haitians jailed in that
community. For our efforts, though, because we moved our clients' cases along to
hearings, as we have equally responsibly taken those cases up on appeal, our
clients will remain cut off from the community they know and which stands eager
to receive them.

The lesson the Attorney General has given to the lawyers will not soon be
forgotten: our professional, responsible behavior has cost our clients their
liberty. Had we simply allowed I.N.S. to foot the detention bill, had we done
nothing for a year to offer our services in representation of our clients, we
could now come forward and secure their freedom. We have learned the lesson at
great cost to the Haitian refugees we represent who remain imprisoned by the
senseless and discriminatory Haitian policy that one year ago greeted them on
their arrival in the United States.  HARRIET RABB New York, June 16, 1982

The writer is director of the Immigration Law Clinic at Columbia Law School and
represents six detained Haitians.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

International
The P.L.O. is finished in Lebanon, according to a faction leader who has been
the main leftist ally of the Palestinian guerrillas in Beirut. Walid Jumblat, a
leader of the Druse, told reporters that the guerrilla group ''is outdated - it
is over.'' In the fighting, Israeli jets continued attacking the positions of
the Palestinian guerrillas trapped in Beirut. (Page A1, Col. 6.)
The evacuation of hundreds of Americans and Lebanese with American immigration
papers was carried out by a transport ship of the Sixth Fleet hours after the
American Embassy in Beirut closed. At the 11th hour, scores of other Americans,
Lebanese and Western Europeans arrived at the docks in the Mediterranean port of
Junieh and were also taken aboard. (A1:3-5.)
Israel's strategy in Lebanon was reported by a senior official. He said that the
Government had decided to hold to its decision not to enter west Beirut but to
review the decision today. The special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, is
expected to arrive in Jerusalem today with a plan for the formation of a strong
Lebanese Government that could cope with the Palestinian guerrillas. (A7:4-6.)
Soviet leaders seek an arms accord and a reduction in tensions with the West, in
the view of Edward L. Rowny, the chief American negotiator to the talks on
curbing strategic arms that open next week. (A3:4-6.)
The first French astronaut to fly in space is Jean-Loup Chretien, a 43-year-old
Russian-speaking colonel. Soviet television relayed live his liftoff into earth
orbit with two Soviet astronauts aboard a spacecraft from the space center in
Kazakhstan. (A9:1-4.)
Discrimination against U.S. troops in West Germany has caused rising concern at
Seventh Army headquarters, which acknowledges that bias has been increasing in
bars, clubs and discotheques. Many soldiers have reacted indignantly to a report
that a Pentagon official said some allies wanted fewer black soldiers stationed
in Europe.  (A2:3-6.)
National
''Absolute Presidential immunity'' from damage suits for any official action
taken while in office was upheld by the Supreme Court. The 5-to-4 decision
overturned a lower court ruling in a suit against former President Richard M.
Nixon. In a companion 8-to-1 ruling, the Justices broadened the ''qualified
immunity'' that applies to most Federal and state officials, making it
substantially more likely that courts would dismiss suits against them before
trial. (A1:1.)
Organized labor was upheld in another decision by the Supreme Court.  The
Justices ruled, 6 to 3, that Federal courts may not prohibit politically
motivated work stoppages. (A13:2-4.)
Three of the Hinckley trial jurors who found the defendant not guilty by reason
of insanity said in Senate testimony that they would have found him both guilty
and mentally ill if they had been given that option. The three were among five
jurors who indicated they had not fully understood the judge's instructions on
the crucial issue of whether John W. Hinckley Jr. was insane at the time he shot
President Reagan and three other men. (A10:1.)
The planned equal rights amendment has no chance of being ratified by the
required three additional states by next Wednesday's deadline, leading
proponents of the proposal conceded. However, they vowed to continue the
struggle against sexual discrimination by electing equal rights backers to state
legislatures and by suing large corporations that practice such discrimination.
(A1:1-3.)
A key money bill was vetoed by President Reagan. He critized as inflationary and
preferential the $8.9 billion urgent supplemental appropriation that contained
$3 billion for housing subsidies. The veto was easily upheld in the
Democratic-controlled House by a vote of 253 to 151. (B14:1-3.)
Increasing desert fissures in Arizona are alarming residents, officials and
geologists. The jagged cracks, often several miles long and very deep, are a
direct consequence of the state's rapid growth in recent decades. They are
caused by widespread pumping of water from underground aquifers to irrigate arid
farmland or to meet the rising demands of urban users for a reliable water
supply. (A1:5-6.)
Metropolitan
A redistricting plan drawn by the State Legislature and rejected by the Justice
Department generated new controversy. Leaders of black and Hispanic groups said
that parts of the Federal order designed to increase minority members'
representation in Congress and the Legislature might have the opposite effect.
(A1:2.)
610 pounds of cocaine were seized by Federal agents on Long Island after more
than 100 law-enforcement officers staked out at Brookhaven Airport witnessed the
drug being delivered by a plane from Colombia.  Four men were arrested on
charges of drug trafficking. The pure cocaine was estimated by officials to have
a street value of $200 million. (A1:2.)
The largest Police Academy class in New York City's history graduated in an
emotional ceremony at Madison Square Garden. The class totals nearly 2,500 men
and women, but much of their feeling was directed toward a classmate who was
seriously wounded by a gunman on June 1 and has spent most of the time since in
a hospital. The rookie, Ronald Simpson, sat among the spectators. (B3:3-6.)

BIG RING SMUGGLING ALIENS REPORTED BROKEN

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 421 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23


Undercover immigration agents have smashed a smuggling ring that was responsible
for bringing 24,000 aliens a year into the United States from Mexico and seven
other countries, Federal officials said today.

Alan C. Nelson, commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said
the ring had been operating for four and a half years and was the largest ever
broken by the service. He said it grossed $24 million a year and had a profit of
$12 million to $15 million.

A Federal grand jury in Albuquerque, N.M., today indicted 38 people who were
said to be members of the ring. They were charged with conspiracy to transport
illegal aliens and 47 counts of actually transporting aliens.

As of tonight, the authorities said, 18 of the defendants had been arrested,
including Salvador Pineda Vergara, described as the ringleader, a Mexican
citizen and operator of the Hotel Villasana in Juarez, Mexico. The Villasana was
one of six hotels in Mexico used as staging points for the smuggling operations,
Mr. Nelson said.

Immigration officials said Mr. Pineda was arrested on Monday in El Paso at a
Western Union station where he had gone to pick up payment for transporting a
group of illegal aliens. The officials said Mr.  Pineda had a card allowing
across the border at will.

The conspiracy count carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a
$10,000 fine. The smuggling count carries a maximum penalty of five years in
prison and a $2,000 fine.

The undercover immigration agents worked as drivers for the Pineda organization
in an investigation begun in July 1981 after the Illinois state police
intercepted a group of aliens on their way to Chicago, according to Mr. Nelson.
Immigration officials said that some 16,000 aliens a year were taken to Chicago
by the group.

Immigration officials said 5,500 additional Mexicans a year and 3,400 other
aliens were shipped to other points, including sites in California, Michigan,
New York, New Jersey, Wisconsin, Illinois, Colorado, Kansas, Missouri, Wyoming
and Indiana.

Joseph Salgado, Assistant Commissioner for enforcement in the immigration
service, declined to say how the aliens had been brought across the United
States border or exactly where.

Mr. Nelson said the other countries from which aliens were brought were
Colombia, Peru, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador and the Dominican
Republic.

The Nation in Summary;
A Step Out Of Detention

BYLINE: By Caroline Rand Herron, Michael Wright and William C. Rhoden

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5, Column 5; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 231 words


In a decison that could significantly affect the Administration's immigration
policy, a Federal judge ruled last week that procedures under which Haitian
refugees have been detained violated the law. The judge, Eugene Spellman of
Federal District Court in Miami, stopped short of declaring the detention itself
illegal and discriminatory, but ordered a meeting for Wednesday, presumably to
determine release procedures.

Until May 1981, Haitians illegally entering the United States were screened for
medical problems into the custody of sponsors in the community. Then, the
Administration, saying the United States was ''losing control of its borders,''
began placing some Haitians in detention camps and stopping others at sea; 2,000
are now being held at camps in five states and Puerto Rico.

Judge Spellman ruled that ''when the Government changed its longstanding policy
of freely paroling Haitians to a policy of incarcerating them it did so in a
procedurally improper way'' because it did not give interested parties notice of
its anticipated action.  Two days before the ruling, the Administration
announced it would parole certain Haitians, provided they were represented by
individual counsel, had secured a sponsor in the community and could reasonably
assure the court that they would show up for scheduled hearings.

Judge Ends Immigration Rule

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section B; Page 8, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 161 words

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 17


Judge Robert Aguilar of Federal District Court here today rejected immigration
rules barring foreign homosexuals from entering the United States. Judge Aguilar
said the rules violated the constitutional rights of free speech and association
for homosexuals.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service ''has asserted no legitimate
governmental or public interest in its policy of excluding homosexual aliens on
the sole grounds that they are homosexuals,'' the judge said. ''Homosexuals pose
no threat to national security merely because they are homosexuals. Nor do they
pose a threat to the health, safety and welfare of the American public.''

Judge Aguilar ruled in the case of the Lesbian-Gay Freedom Day Committee, which
challenged an Immigration and Naturalization Service policy excluding
homosexuals as ''sexual deviants'' once they were certified to be homosexual.

BOGUS SOCIAL SECURITY CARDS WERE TOO NEAT, SENATORS TOLD

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 387 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16


Federal investigators told a Senate committee today that they had cracked a ring
of swindlers trafficking in fraudulent Social Security cards because the
applications for the documents were too neat to pass for Government work.

Daniel F. Lane and Walter T. Hempel 2d testified before the Senate Permanent
Subcommittee on Investigations, which estimates that false personal
identification cards may be costing the American public $24 billion a year.

Mr. Lane is an investigator with the Department of Health and Human Services and
Mr. Hempel works for the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

They described an illegal operation in Los Angeles that they said was run by
Frank and Maria Richards. They said the couple bilked illegal aliens out of $1.5
million by selling them bogus Social Security cards at $20 apiece and other
fraudulent documents.

The investigators said the couple obtained 10,000 to 40,000 Social Security
cards from the Government with the help of Gwendolyn Gay, a Social Security
Administration employee who has been sentenced to 30 days in jail for her part
in the scheme.

Bypassed Local Offices

Mr. Lane said that each week the Richardses would send coded Social Security
card applications in Government envelopes to a Federal computer center,
bypassing the local Social Security offices. The object was to make it appear
that the applications had been approved by a regional office. When the Richards
received the cards, they sold them to the illegal aliens.

The plan worked for years until the applications began to appear too neat and
raised suspicions, Mr. Lane said. ''Sloppy applications are more acceptable
because they're more like the normal ones,'' he said.

The Richardses are fugitives. In addition to Miss Gay, three other persons
convicted in the scheme were sentenced to prison terms ranging from five months
to two and a half years.

In a related development, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the
ranking Democrat on the Senate's Social Security Subcommittee, said today that
he planned to reintroduce legislation that would require the Social Security
Administration to issue new or replacement Social Secuirty cards on
counterfeit-proof paper.

A Little Mercy for the Haitians

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 462 words


When it comes to the Haitians, the quality of Attorney General Smith's mercy is
strained, but it is mercy nonetheless and much to be welcomed. Almost 2,000 of
them are still detained behind the high wire fences; many have been there for a
year or more. Mr. Smith now would permit those with lawyers and sponsors to get
out, pending hearings on whether they are admissible as refugees. Though
grudging, this new policy may mean the beginning of the end of a sordid little
chapter in American immigration history.

There was logic to Mr. Smith's initial policy of detaining Haitian migrants who
made it to this country and of sending the Coast Guard out on patrol to keep
others from trying. The United States should control its borders. However
pitiful the Haitian boat people may be, why should they be allowed to crowd in
ahead of Salvadoran or Somali refugees?

As a matter of cold fact, the Smith policy has so far succeeded; in recent
months the number of illegal Haitians found entering this country has dropped
sharply.

The price, however, has gone up. As the months have dragged on, the deterrent
value of detention has been vastly offset by a growing, noxious awareness.
People whose only crime was trying to escape Haiti are being treated like
convicts. Their hearings delayed by a legal logjam, they have been subjected to
callous, cruel treatment.  Children have been separated from parents. Numbing
boredom has been followed by dozens of mental breakdowns. It all produced a
stern order from Federal District Judge Robert Carter calling for the release of
53 Haitians held in Brooklyn. A broader Florida case may be decided this week.

Nevertheless, the Administration has not budged, until now. And even now there
is less to the Attorney General's new ''experimental'' policy than meets the
eye. It is four times grudging:

(1) None of the 1,910 Haitians will be released for two or three weeks until
procedures are worked out. (2) Even then, only those with lawyers and sponsors
will be let out; there are not now enough sponsors for all. (3) When releases do
come, they will be temporary; anyone found excludable will be put back in the
camps pending appeal. None of the Brooklyn 53 are to be let out. (4) And
detention won't peter out; according to the letter of the policy, all new
migrants will be held indefinitely.

Still, we would like to think that it is the spirit of the policy, more than its
letter, that conveys the Attorney General's intent. It is not easy for proud,
stubborn officials to relent. Indeed, for a cabinet officer to do so is a mark
of strength. And for the Haitians, that may at last be a beginning.

TORONTO MAYOR QUERIED ON ENTRY

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 481 words


The Mayor of Toronto said yesterday that before being admitted to the United
States last Saturday for a conference on urban affairs in New York City he was
questioned by a United States Immigration officer about what he planned to say
at the conference.

''It was more questioning than I've ever been through,'' said the Mayor, Art
Eggleton, a frequent visitor to the United States, ''and I've never been asked
what I was going to talk about before.''

The questioning took place at a United States Customs and Immigration station at
the Toronto Airport on Saturday afternoon, according to the Mayor. That was at
the same time as the rally that drew more than half a million people to Central
Park to demand an end to the nuclear arms race.

A spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service said that border
guards had been under special orders at the time to question foreign visitors
headed for New York. But she said the questions directed at Mayor Eggleton had
probably been meant as friendly conversation.

Mayor Describes Questioning

Mr. Eggleton said, however, that ''there was no doubt in my mind it was
deliberate questioning.'' He said the immigration officer, whom he could not
name, asked why he was coming to New York.  When he replied that he was going to
a conference of mayors, he said, she then asked, ''Are you making any
presentation?'' When he said yes, he recalled, she then asked, ''What will you
be talking about?'' He said he had replied, ''Toronto,'' and was then admitted.
Toronto was one of nine foreign cities represented at the International Urban
Symposium, sponsored by the Citizens Budget Commission.

Discussed Urban Issues

While most of Mr. Eggleton's comments at the symposium, which concluded
yesterday, dealt with urban issues, he did insert in a speech Tuesday a call for
nuclear disarmament, an issue that has been placed on Toronto's election ballot
in November.

Ira Glasser, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, said he
believed the questioning of Mayor Eggleton was unconstitutional.

Janet R. Graham, the immigration spokesman, said she had not been able to locate
the officer who questioned the Mayor. But she suggested that the officer had
probably just been chatting and that the questions had been ''a comment with no
purpose or intent.''

Miss Graham did say that immigration officers had been under special
instructions at the time because of the large numbers of foreigners seeking
admission to the United States to attend the antinuclear rally.

                June 17, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

COURT'S RULING ON ILLEGAL ALIENS: A DOUBTFUL PRECEDENT;
News Analysis

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 18, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1061 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16


In ruling Tuesday that the Constitution entitles illegal alien children to a
free public education, the Supreme Court inevitably invited further tests of
aliens' rights to other government services.

Illegal aliens are now ineligible for most of the basic Federal benefit programs
and their state counterparts, including Medicare, Medicaid, food stamps, Aid to
Families with Dependent Children, Supplemental Security Income and unemployment
compensation. They are excluded from some Federal higher education programs and
from some state colleges.

The Court's declaration that the constitutional guarantee of equal protection of
the laws ''extends to anyone, citizen or stranger,'' regardless of immigration
status, at least suggested that these inequalities are about to be swept away by
the Justices' newly expansive reading of the 14th Amendment.

But, given the framework on which Associate Justice William J.  Brennan Jr.
constructed his 5-to-4 majority opinion, any conclusion that such a result is
imminent is premature. Both Justice Brennan's opinion and the concurring
opinions of two other Justices emphasized the ''unique'' importance of basic
education, both to individuals and to society as a whole, as well as the
particular unfairness of making children bear the burden of their parents'
illegal status.

Medicare Ruling Seems Safe

The opinions contained no hint that the Court was prepared to reevaluate a
unanimous 1976 ruling that held Congress had the right to make citizenship or
permanent residency a requirement for Medicare eligibility.

The language of that decision, Mathews v. Diaz, without doubt still commands a
majority of the Court. ''Neither the overnight visitor,'' the Court said then,
''the unfriendly agent of a hostile foreign power, the resident diplomat, nor
the illegal entrant, can advance even a colorable constitutional claim to a
share in the bounty that a conscientious sovereign makes available to its own
citizens and some of its guests.''

The case before the Court on Tuesday concerned a Texas law that allowed local
school districts to close their doors to illegal aliens. The case thus raised
the specter of innocent children condemned by a punitive and wealthy state to a
life of illiteracy and may have been, quite simply, the most sympathetic case
that advocates for undocumented aliens will ever be able to bring before the
Court. And still the vote was only 5 to 4.

Three aspects of the Texas case were crucial to the Court's decision that the
state's law was unconstitutional, and all three are unlikely to be factors in
future legal challenges on behalf of illegal aliens.

Limits on the States

First, the Texas law represented an effort by a state to enforce its view of
national immigration policy. The Court has long regarded immigration policy as
an area for Federal, not state, action and, as the Mathews v. Diaz decision
indicated, is likely to be much more deferential if an exclusion of illegal
aliens was dictated by Congress rather than by a state legislature.

In fact, in finding the Texas law illegitimate as a way of enforcing immigration
policy, Justice Brennan considered it significant that Congress had never
indicated any desire to deprive illegal alien children of an education. But when
Congress has expressed a policy choice, Justice Brennan indicated, the Court
might well give the states more latitude in taking their own steps to carry out
that policy.

''In other contexts,'' he said, ''undocumented status, coupled with some
articulable Federal policy, might enhance state authority with respect to the
treatment of undocumented aliens.''

In addition, the Texas law concerned education, which the majority treated as a
very special governmental responsibility. Education, Justice Brennan said, is
not ''merely some governmental 'benefit' indistinguishable from other forms of
social welfare legislation.'' The public school, he said, quoting a 1979 opinion
by Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell, is ''the primary vehicle for transmitting
the values on which our society rests,'' and the lack of basic education is both
an ''enduring disability'' to an individual and a deficit to society as a whole.


Brown Decision Recalled

Justice Brennan also reached back to Brown v. Board of Education, the basic
school desegrgation case, for a paragraph on the importance of education. For
the Court, public education has a resonance that is nearly spiritual and that is
shared by few other activities of government. Those few almost surely do not
include cash transfer programs, such as welfare and unemployment compensation,

Finally, the law concerned children, ''innocent children'' in Justice Brennan's
words, who, Justice Powell said, ''should not be left on the streets
uneducated.''

Adult illegal aliens, the majority seemed to say, have created their own
problems and have no particular claim to rescue by the courts. Justice Brennan
said that ''persuasive arguments support the view that a state may withhold its
beneficence from those whose very presence within the United States is the
product of their own unlawful conduct.''

But the Texas law ''directing the onus of a parent's misconduct against his
children does not comport with fundamental conceptions of justice,'' Justice
Brennan said.

It was a point the majority found persuasive, and that might provide the most
fertile ground for future lawsuits on behalf of illegal aliens. Children are
directly affected by, for example, the family's lack of access to medical care.
The case of prenatal care is particularly interesting because the unborn child
whose wellbeing is at stake is automatically an American citizen at birth.

The Mexican-American Legal Defense and Educational Fund, which brought the Texas
case, is now litigating a broad health care case on behalf of illegal aliens in
California, arguing that the state has a duty under the state and Federal
constitutions to provide medical care to all indigent residents.

TEXAS GOVERNOR SAYS COMPLIANCE WITH COURT RULING IS NO PROBLEM

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section D; Page 22, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 859 words

DATELINE: HOUSTON, June 15


Gov. William Clements said today that Texas could easily provide court-mandated
education of illegal aliens in its public schools, but he predicted that doing
so would make illegal immigration more attractive, particularly from Mexico.

The Governor offered no opinion on whether the Supreme Court ruling that had the
effect of mandating free public education for illegal aliens would be
interpreted to include social programs, such as welfare.

Lawyers for the National Center for Immigration Rights in Los Angeles who
prepared the legal arguments in the case differed somewhat in their assessment
of the ruling's probable effect, but they suggested it would be minimal.

Raymond Bynum, the Texas Commissioner of Education, echoed the Governor's belief
that the fiscal impact on Texas schools would be minimal, but he said he feared
that an existing shortage of bilingual teachers would worsen.

Houston Charged Fees

Texas has, in fact, been providing free public education to illegal alien
children since July 1980, when a Federal District Court first struck down as
unconstitutional a 1975 state law that empowered local school districts to bar
aliens from public schools or to charge them tuition.

Before the ruling, the Dallas Independent School System refused to admit illegal
aliens, and the Houston system charged tuition of $162 a month.

''For two years we've been educating them, and the immediate impact is
minimal,'' Mr. Bynum said. ''But if the question becomes will this bring more
workers and families into this couuntry, it is a ruling that has broader
implications for food stamps, unemployment compensation and so forth.''

''We've got the money, we can appropriate the money,'' he said, ''The problem is
we don't have enough bilingual teachers now and we're not getting any assistance
whatsoever.''

Both Mr. Bynum, interviewed by telephone in Austin, and the Governor, who spoke
at a news conference here, suggested that the Federal Government should bear
some or all of the burden of educating illegal aliens because immigration laws
have not been effective in stemming the tide of aliens entering this country
illegally.

''The Federal Government is requiring it, but on the other hand the Federal
Government is not enforcing the immigration laws,'' Mr.  Bynum said. Governor
Clements said he would continue to press for Federal assistance to educate
illegal aliens, but he said that was not the primary issue.

''I don't think there is any question at all,'' he said, ''that once again we
have created a situation here that makes illegal immigration, primarily from
Mexico, attractive.''

The Governor said that figures compiled by the Texas Education Association
showed 12,000 children who are illegal aliens attended Texas public schools in
the 1980-81 school year and 18,000 in the year just ended.

'It Is an Attraction'

''I think you will see this increase because it is an attraction,'' he said,
''but I would also call it a periphery issue to the entire subject of illegal
immigration and undocumented workers from Mexico.''

The Governor conceded that the state had anticipated ''many, many more'' illegal
aliens to flood into Texas schools after the Federal court decision two years
ago; he and others had predicted up to 100,000 such children would enroll. But
the Governor went on to say he thought the problem ''has been vastly overblown
in the press and various forms of the media.''

He continued: ''I'm sure we'll handle it in Texas in good form.'' Commissioner
Bynum put the number of illegal aliens in public schools at the end of the year
at ''between 20,000 and 30,000'' and said it would cost the state $100 million
to educate them. He added that even the higher figure would amount to only about
1 percent of the more than 2 million students in the total school population.

'Would Have Grown Anyway'

He said he expected some increase in the number of illegal aliens as a result of
the ruling, but added, ''I think it would have grown anyway.''

One imponderable is the number of illegal aliens who do not attend school
because their parents fear their illegal status will be discovered and they will
be deported. Some of these children still attend church-supported and other
private schools set up after the passage of the 1975 law.

Two of the lawyers for the National Center for Immigrants Rights in Los Angeles
who helped to prepare plaintiff briefs in the Supreme Court case differed
somewhat on the probable effect of the court's decision on other areas of public
policy.

One of them, Carlos Holguin, observed that the court did not rule that states
could not deny certain rights or privileges to illegal aliens but instead had
said that the State of Texas had shown no valid fiscal or other reason for
denying such rights.

''The state,'' he said, ''really failed to prove that that kind of
discrimination was justified for fiscal reasons.''

                June 15, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. ANNOUNCES NEW POLICY FOR PAROLE OF SOME HAITIANS

BYLINE: By GREGORY JAYNES, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1013 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, June 14


The Justice Department announced today that it was issuing guidelines for the
release of some Haitians from Federal detention facilities. The Haitians would
be paroled to sponsors while they awaited hearings on whether they would be
deported.

Many of the nearly 2,000 Haitians have been detained as long as a year under a
Reagan Administration policy designed to discourage illegal immigration.

The latest action, essentially a return to the policy of a year ago, was
announced this afternoon in Federal District Court here, where a ruling on a
lawsuit that seeks to free the Haitians is expected any day. Attorneys for the
plaintiffs and other advocates for Haitians in Miami said the timing of the
announcement indicated that the Government expected to lose the case and had
changed its policy to save face.

The new guidelines, set forth in a memorandum from Attorney General William
French Smith to the Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner, Alan
Nelson, allow parole for Haitians who are represented by individual counsel,
have a ''responsible sponsor'' and can offer ''acceptable assurances'' that they
will appear for court hearings.

Forms of Acceptable Assurance

Acceptable assurance, said Robert Bombaugh, a Justice Department trial lawyer,
could be a pledge from relatives or others of longstanding residence in the
community, or could be in the form of ''reasonable bonds.''

The condition of ''reasonable bonds'' raised immediate concern among those
attempting to aid the Haitians. ''It sounds fairly good in theory and easily
manipulated in practice,'' said Ira Kurzban, one of the principal lawyers in the
lawsuit, which was filed in behalf of the Haitians in detention as a class.
''For example,'' he said, ''say they ask $2,000 bond. No one gets out.''

The Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste, executive director of the Haitian Refugee Center
Inc. in Miami, said that if ''it is implemented properly, it is a fair
proposal,'' adding: ''The only thing I'm concerned about is the bonding. If they
ask $500 to $2,000, we're back to Square One again.''

Mr. Bombaugh said that he could not ''get into details'' and that a meeting with
immigration officials had been set for Thursday to ''discuss details of the
implementation.''

He said the move ''does not in any way resolve the issues currently before this
court.'' Judge Eugene Spellman, who is hearing the case, agreed, saying he would
make his decision in the lawsuit before the end of this week. The judge and Mr.
Bombaugh agreed to meet June 23 with the Dade County Bar Association and
voluntary sponsoring groups to work out the procedures for those eligible for
release.

600 Held at Miami Center

About 600 Haitians are being held at the Krome Avenue Detention Facility, a
former missile base 25 miles west of Miami. There are 650 at the Fort Allen
Detention Facility in Puerto Rico, and the rest of the 2,000 are being held at
Federal correction facilities in Kentucky, New York, Texas and West Virginia.
Civil libertarians contend they are political refugees and ought to be released.

The lawsuit seeks to prove that the Government's detention of Haitians is
discriminatory because aliens of other nationalities are routinely released. The
Government contends that the Haitians are treated ''specially,'' though not
discriminatorily, in part because, while they are seeking political asylum, the
Government's position is that they have come here for economic reasons.

Other aliens without proper documents are routinely expelled, Government
witnesses said, while the Haitians have prolonged their incarceration with
petitions for political asylum and class-action lawsuits. The detention policy,
according to testimony, was adopted last summer as a deterrent to further
illegal immigration. It was also put into effect after it was discovered that
more than 20,000 Haitians who were paroled in the custody of sponsors over the
last decade, pending exclusionary hearings on their cases, never appeared for
the hearings.

About 800 of the Haitians are represented by lawyers and apparently would be the
first to be considered for parole. But an agreement between the Government and
the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico stipulates that Haitians cannot be released
there. Judge Spellman asked Mr.  Bombaugh about that today, but he could not say
what would be done with those now held on the island.

'Abuse' of Parole Asserted

Until last summer, the immigration service, after a cursory medical examination,
routinely paroled Haitians who arrived in the United States illegally. Mr.
Bombaugh said that the policy was ''abused'' and that it ''caused more, not
less, illegal immigration.''

The new, much stricter parole policy will be ''monitored closely,'' Mr. Bombaugh
said. The numbers of Haitians who do not show up for hearings will be ''kept
track of,'' he said, adding that if it is found that the paroles are
''encouraging more illegal immigration,'' the program will be rescinded.

Asked in Washington whether the timing of the announcement was connected to the
lawsuit in Miami, Associate Attorney General Rudolph W. Giuliani, one of the
witnesses in the two-month trial, said it was ''not in any way an attempt to
influence'' the judge's decision.

Commissioner Nelson said in an interview, ''We are not in any way backing off or
waivering from the detention policy.'' Mr. Kurzban speculated that the Reagan
Administration had ''gotten a lot of political heat,'' and ''felt they were
going to lose the case.'' He said, ''This was a way of softening the blow and
making it look like they were doing it on their own.''

There was no word of reaction by those being held at the Krome Facility, which
has barred all visitors except for immediate relatives because of ''rising
tension.''

AROUND THE NATION;
U.S. Will Not Prosecute Reporter in Aliens Case

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 86 words

DATELINE: SAN ANTONIO, June 13


A newspaper reporter who posed as an illegal alien and was arrested will not be
prosecuted for transporting real illegal aliens in Texas, a Federal official
said Friday.

David Almaraz, assistant United States Attorney in Laredo, Tex., said he had
dropped the felony smuggling charges against Danny Garcia, a reporter for The
San Antonio Light.

Mr. Garcia, 27 years old, had told the Immigration and Naturalization Service of
his plans to pose as an alien.

U.S. Seeks to Deport an Alien Accused of Nazi Unit Service

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 8, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 215 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 12


The Justice Department has filed a request for deportation of a man who is
accused of concealing his service in a German SS unit in Nazi concentration
camps in World War II.

The request, filed in United States Immigration Court on Tuesday, accused Hans
Lipschis of concealing service in an SS Death's Head unit in the
Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp in Poland between 1941 and 1945.

Mr. Lipschis was ordered to appear in court on July 13 to show why he should not
be deported.  The six-count civil complaint contends that Mr. Lipschis, a native
of Lithuania, left his homeland for Germany in 1941 and enlisted as a private in
the Waffen SS, the combat arm of the elite German corps.  He was later assigned
to a Death's Head battalion at Auschwitz, the complaint says.

Mr. Lipschis, also known as Antanas Lipsys, is a permanent resident alien,
according to Allan A. Ryan, director of the Justice Department's Office of
Special Investigations. Mr. Lipschis is accused of concealing his SS service
when he was granted permanent resident status, Mr. Ryan said.

Mr. Lipschis, who lives on the city's Southwest Side, refused to talk to a
reporter who went to his house.

Aliens Found Challenging U.S.

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 16, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 257 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12


Immigration in the next few years will pose a challenge to American society
similar to that when Europeans flocked here at the turn of the century,
according to a private study.

The report by the Population Reference Bureau, a nonprofit research
organization, projects net annual migration into the United States at 795,000 to
970,000 people in this decade.

About half those immigrants will enter the country illegally, according to the
study, which says they will be coming primarily from Latin America.

''Immigration at these levels promises a change in the makeup of U.S. society
that presents Americans with a challenge similar to that of the large numbers of
European immigrants who entered at the beginning of the 20th century,'' wrote
Leon Bouvier, a bureau demographer.

In the report, ''U.S. Population: Where We Are; Where We're Going,'' the
bureau's panel of experts also predicted that fertility would remain low, with
annual births peaking at about four million and then beginning to decline; the
proportion of the population moving each year, currently 20 percent, would
moderate, and the movement of the population to the South and West would
continue but not accelerate.

''The urge to migrate remains high in the Latin American and Caribbean countries
where most illegals originate,'' Mr. Bouvier reported. ''The young adult
population is growing rapidly and unemployment has not been reduced.''

                 June 11, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

Alien Ideas Need No Quarantine

SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 383 words


What has the United States to fear from 315 foreign disarmament demonstrators,
mostly from Japan, who want to attend the United Nations disarmament conference?

The world's greatest democracy, home of the U.N. and host to Saturday's rally in
Central Park, has denied visas to a handful of foreigners who want to
participate. The reason: they are excludable under the McCarran-Walter
Immigration Act of 1952. According to official explanations, this is no band of
hard-core spies. The 315 merely have some connection with the Communist Party of
Japan, or a Japanese disarmament group, or the World Peace Council - all
described by the Administration as ''Soviet fronts.''

Foreigners have no absolute right to enter this or any other country. That the
Government has the sweeping power to deny these visas was underscored in
yesterday's Federal court decision refusing to overturn the action. But having
power and using it are not the same; in this case, the Administration's barring
the border sends the wrong signal. It suggests a fear of outside ideas and
hostility to people who say they come in search of peace.

Americans are not as hostile or fearful as that signal suggests.  And the
Supreme Court has recognized that their right to receive ideas may be
compromised by the exclusion of foreigners who hold unorthodox ones. Such
exclusion is itself the truly un-American activity.

The McCarran-Walter Act that authorizes it was enacted at a time of paranoia
over Communism. It tried to quarantine Americans against alien ideology. But
even that oppressive law allows exceptions. For 30 years, thousands of waivers
have been granted. Even this time the Administration granted 42 waivers, but
only to persons with official invitations to the U.N. function. Its argument
that each of the 315 rejected applicants must show special merit to deserve
entry is even more offensive than the sway of a hysterical old statute.

America sends the world a proud message about freedom of speech and association.
And it need not apologize for its position on arms negotiations. Yet Government
officials behave as if they are ashamed of both. They should be ashamed only of
themselves.

Fourteen pounds of cocaine with a street value of $4.5 million have been seized

                 June 8, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

ABOVE ALL ELSE, HE IS 'THE PRESIDENT'S LAWYER'

BYLINE: By JO THOMAS, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 24, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1486 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 2


On the fifth floor at the Justice Department, beyond the street noise that
testifies to Government as a growth industry, the sounds in the Attorney
General's office are muted, the walls paneled, the lamp cloisonne, the tennis
trophy small. On the back of the tiger, as some have described this place, there
is a calm not found in schools or prisons or refugee camps, although this office
profoundly affects them all.

William French Smith, the gray-haired Attorney General dressed impeccably in
gray, twirled a paper clip as he spoke of confronting some of the most emotional
issues of the day: racial discrimination, crime, immigration. He seemed mostly
interested in results.  Controversy he has left to others, including his
longtime friend, client and current boss, Ronald Reagan.

When he can, that is. Two small items in a personal portfolio worth $2 million
to $3.5 million recently turned the spotlight on him: a $50,000 corporate
severance payment and $117,600 in potential tax deductions on oil drilling
deals. His spokesman, Thomas P. DeCair, called the most recent spate of columns,
articles and editorials on the matter ''a distraction.''

The Attorney General returned the severance payment and sharply limited his
possible deductions ''to terminate'' the furor, he said, ''just to terminate
it,'' but a preliminary inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation was
already under way to determine whether a special prosecutor should investigate
the payment. Normally, the Attorney General would oversee this inquiry; in this
case the Solicitor General will act in his stead.

'One of Those Things'

''Of all the things which I would have thought would have caused a problem,
these two things would not have been it,'' said Mr. Smith.  ''Matter of fact, I
never really even paid much attention to either one of them. In both cases, in
effect, I relied on people whose judgment you respect. Sometimes those things
turn out differently from the way you expect. It's just one of those things.''

In some ways, the controversy over Mr. Smith's finances mirrors that felt at the
White House over two matters in which the White House relied on Mr. Smith. One
was the decision last fall to fight the House-passed version of the Voting
Rights Act, which would have enabled minority groups to bring suit by showing
discriminatory results without having to prove a discriminatory intent. The
other was the decision in January to reverse an Internal Revenue Service policy
and grant tax-exempt status to Bob Jones University and other racially
discriminatory private schools.

Just as Mr. Smith did not see his finances as an ethical issue, he did not see
either voting rights or the tax-exemption policy as racial issues.

''On the Voting Rights Act,'' he said, ''we had one principal concern, and it
should have been everybody's principal concern, namely, that the House bill
could well produce proportional representation and, in the process, take the
decision-making concerning local government structure out of the hands of the
constituency and put it into the hands of the courts. Most people seemed to be
oblivious to the significance of the change.''

'A Good Principle'

On the question of tax exemptions, said Edward C. Schmults, the Deputy Attorney
General: ''There was a good principle there, but it got blown away. The
principle was not race, but whether Congress should decide or leave it to the
bureaucrats to make the decisions.''

''We didn't anticipate the outcry,'' he conceded. Then, referring to James A.
Baker 3d, the Presidential chief of staff, he added: ''It would have been
better, as Baker says, if the legislation to cure this had been ready at the
same time. I still think the legal analysis is correct, but I'm not sure it
makes any difference. The civil rights issue overshadowed it, and Bob Jones was
a lightning rod that made it difficult to explain other changes.''

Those changes, Mr. Smith said, have come in ''areas where we think the remedies
tried for many years in the past just have not worked.  The most obvious
examples, of course, are busing and the use of quotas. I think some of the to-do
that followed those changes tended to obscure what we are doing overall in the
civil rights area.''

''We've had more criminal civil rights cases brought during this Administration
than during any prior Administration,'' Mr. Smith said. ''The President himself
has always advocated the importance of civil rights and protecting civil rights.
There has not been any incompatibility there.''

The Justice Department's record shows 240 civil rights cases under way, a
quarter of them initiated under the Reagan Administration, and 1,500 other
accusations of civil rights violations under investigation, virtually all of
them started under Mr. Smith.  Prosecutions for racial violence, police
brutality and involuntary servitude are higher than for any single year of other
Administrations.

Two Opinions on Busing

Last month Mr. Smith told Representative Peter W. Rodino, the New Jersey
Democrat who is chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, that the anti-busing
bill sponsored by Senator J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana, and
Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, was constitutional in that it
restricted only the lower Federal courts. On the same day, concerning a bill to
withdraw Federal court jurisdiction over school prayer issues, he said that
Congress could not make restrictions that would intrude on the core functions of
the Supreme Court.

Both opinions were released on the day the President, who has been under
pressure from conservatives to act on items on their agenda, endorsed a
Constitutional amendment to permit prayer in schools.

''I think as a result of the Watergate experience,'' Mr. Smith said, ''the idea
became current that somehow the Department of Justice should be independent of
the Administration. I don't think that is so. There are some areas it should be
independent with the decisions it makes. At the same time, it is part of the
Administration to carry out the Administration's policy, and that is what we
have done.''

Carrying out the Administration's policy has not always been easy.  For example,
aides to Mr. Smith say he could have won a ''pyrotechnics prize'' for memos
protesting budget cutbacks in his department, but that he tried to make sure the
memos did not become public and eventually fell in line, saying he would do more
with less.

Mr. Smith has been lobbying hard, often at breakfast in the luxurious conference
room near his office, for passage of the major immigration reform sponsored by
Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Representative Romano L.
Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky, while at the same time he is locking up Haitian
refugees for months in camps in Florida and Puerto Rico and keeping in prison
Cuban refugees whom he can't send back to Cuba but who he thinks might do great
harm on the street.

Relationship With Reagan

The Attorney General's confidence in the face of controversy, according to those
who know him, is probably the result of his relationship with President Reagan
which, as far as Mr. Smith is concerned, ''has never really changed.''

''He's a remarkable man from that standpoint,'' the Attorney General said of the
President. ''He hasn't changed. He's the same person that he was when I first
knew him. And he is, despite the fact now that he has perhaps the most important
job in the world.''

''I'm the President's lawyer,'' he went on. ''I'm not the President's lawyer in
the sense I used to be, not his personal lawyer any more. But one of the
functions of the Attorney General is to advise the President and other members
of the Cabinet on legal matters. We're in a position here, just by the nature of
our job, where we have to say 'no' to a lot of people. I suppose in one sense,
you could say we're sort of a business that sooner or later we're going to make
everybody mad at least once.''

''Even among the Administration, there are those who think that all the laws
they didn't like were repealed on Election Day and don't understand what to us
is pretty elemental, namely, that our function is to enforce the law as it is,
whether we like it or not. And those who don't like it, of course, have to
change the law. We never can and never would not enforce the law to meet some
philosophical or political position or need.''

Around the World;
Costa Rica to Tighten Immigration Policy

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 5, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 129 words

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 5


Warning that Costa Rica had entered ''the eye of the storm of Central America,''
Costa Rica's Vice President has announced that his Government will seek to
tighten its immigration policy to preserve national security.

Vice President Armando Arauz Aguilar announced that the next Government council
session would consider a proposal to enforce strict immigration laws to preserve
national security.

''Costa Rica has stopped being a country that is small, peaceful and isolated
from events of the zone,'' he said Friday. Mr. Arauz Aguilar said new
immigration laws would strictly control foreigners entering Costa Rica ''because
the country needs peace and quiet to remake itself.''

                 June 4, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

REPRISE ON McCARRAN ACT;
News Analysis

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1264 words


Thirty years ago, in the middle of the McCarthy era, Senator Pat McCarran told
the United States Senate of the urgent need for drastic changes in America's
immigration policies.

''Our present laws are shot through with weaknesses and loopholes,'' he
declared. ''Criminals, Communists and subversives are even now gaining admission
into this country like water through a sieve.''

While the Nevada Democrat's apocalyptic language may sound a bit dated, the
McCarran-Walter Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952 is not. The measure,
which lumped Communists and anarchists with prostitutes, polygamists, paupers,
stowaways and lepers and other categories of aliens previously barred from
entering the United States, remains the law of the land, always within reach of
American Governments seeking to exclude ''undesirables.''

In the past few days, the State Department has invoked the McCarran Act once
more - this time to exclude nearly 500 people, including more than 350 Japanese,
from attending activities in connection with a United Nations session on nuclear
disarmament.

The Power of Congress

The move prompted protests from civil libertarians, who went to Federal Court in
Manhattan yesterday to challenge the visa denials and to face the formidable
obstacles encountered in every previous attack on the McCarran Act. It has long
been axiomatic that aliens have no right to enter the United States, but are,
instead, admitted purely by discretion of Congress. Though often challenged,
that power is one to which the courts have universally deferred.

At the same time, according to civil libertarians like Thomas Emerson of the
Yale University Law School, the Government's application of the McCarran Act in
so unusual and seemingly indiscriminate a fashion highlights the First Amendment
implications of the McCarran Act - and could, as a result, make even the
strictest strict constructionist blanch.

Even were the New York Civil Liberties Union to prevail, however, or the
Attorney General to waive the denials, the victories could prove illusory should
they come after the disarmament conference has ended. It is that potential
situation, critics contend, that gives the McCarran Act powers even more
sweeping than its vague language already allows.

Purpose of First Curbs

When the United States first imposed immigration curbs in 1875, they were
designed to preserve the original racial and ethnic composition of the country
rather than to protect its body politic.

With World War II and the coming of the cold war, however, those seeking to curb
immigration became more concerned with ideological than with ethnic purity.

Their efforts culminated with the McCarran Act, which provides that any alien
who belongs to Communist or anarchist organizations, as well as nonmembers who
propagate their ideas or who are suspected by consular officials or the Attorney
General of seeking to ''engage in activities prejudicial to the public
interest,'' are automatically barred from receiving visas unless the denial is
waived by the Attorney General.

The language of the McCarran Act is broad enough to encompass individuals of
varying political persuasions and was employed last December to bar the militant
Northern Irish Protestant leader, the Rev. Ian Paisley. But both in its language
and its application, the law has been much harder on the political left than on
the right.

Many Intellectuals Banned

Numerous leftist artists and intellectuals - including the authors Gabriel
Garcia Marquez and Regis Debray -have been kept from visiting the United States
over the years. In 1975 an Italian Communist foreign affairs specialist was
denied entry to attend a conference - shortly after the leader of Italy's
neo-Fascist party had been readily admitted.

With the 1977 enactment of the so-called McGovern Amendment, which gives
additional rights of access to members of ''proscribed organizations'' such as
Communist parties throughout the world, the McCarran Act lost some of its steam.
But that amendment, designed to bring the United States into compliance with the
freedom-to-travel provisions of the Helsinki Accords, does not apply to many
individuals barred from the country under the McCarran Act.

It would not, for instance, have been available to Dr. Ernest E.  Mandel, a
Belgian journalist and Marxist theoretician - but not a Communist - who in 1969
sought unsuccessfully to obtain a six-day non-immigrant visa to attend a
conference at Stanford University.

Nearly three years after the conference was held - and after Dr.  Mandel gave
his speech to it by telephone - the United States Supreme Court ruled that the
bar did not violate the rights of American scholars.

Supreme Court's Ruling

Dr. Mandel's failure to observe strict limitations placed upon him during
previous visits to the United States constituted a ''facially legitimate and
bona fide reason'' for the Government's decision to keep him out of the country,
Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote for the majority.

While acknowledging that the right of free speech under the First Amendment
includes the right ''to receive information and ideas,'' Justice Blackmun wrote
that the courts would allow the Attorney General to make immigration decisions
without interference.

He suggested, however, that where the Government can offer no justification at
all for excluding undesirable aliens, the courts could be moved to modify their
customary laissez-faire position on the subject.

The exclusion of the disarmament advocates who, unlike Dr. Mandel, had not
disobeyed orders previously placed on them, presents that very situation, the
New York Civil Liberties Union asserts.

Other Charges Against U.S.

The Government, aside from violating the spirit of the United Nations Charter
and of agreements it undertook when the United Nations was placed in New York -
as well as of spirit of the Helsinki Accords - is accused by the civil liberties
union of violating the minimal procedural protections contained in the McCarran
Act. While Dr. Mandel readily admitted his link to Marxism, the group asserts,
the Government has completely failed to show that any or all of the barred
Japanese actually belong to an organization advocating world Communism - a
showing required to override the First Amendment rights of Americans seeking to
meet with them.

The Government's case, the civil liberties group declares, is based on
assertions that ''most'' of the barred Japanese belong to an organization with
''indirect'' ties to an ''alleged'' Communist organization ''supposedly'' linked
to Communism.

''This guilt by association goes far beyond anything which the McCarran Act
contemplates,'' the union charges.  To some, including Ernest Mandel himself,
political and social maturation seems a better bet than litigation for altering
the McCarran Act or removing it from the books altogether.

''In the 19th century the British ruling class, which was sure of itself,
permitted Karl Marx to live as an exile in England for almost 40 years,'' wrote
Dr. Mandel. By banning him, he said, the American Government demonstrated a
''lack of confidence in the capacity of its supporters to combat Marxism on
battleground of ideas.''

                 June 4, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

50 IN PEACE GROUP TO GET VISAS FOR SESSION AT U.N.

BYLINE: By PETER KIHSS

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 705 words


Fifty members of the World Peace Council who were denied visas to attend United
Nations disarmament sessions starting here Monday have now been approved for
restricted entry, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said yesterday.

The State Department said Wednesday that the council was ''an organization with
strong affiliations'' to the Soviet Communist Party. It did so in reporting the
denial of visas to 348 Japanese as members of a group close to the council.

The department acted under the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1952, but said
later that it was recommending Justice Department waivers to admit most of the
Japanese.

Duke Austin, an immigration spokesman in Washington, said the Peace Council
members were separate from 376 cases being reviewed individually. The council
members were approved, he said, because they had been officially invited by the
United Nations.'' But he said they would be restricted to being within 25 miles
of Columbus Circle.

Leader Was Barred

While Mr. Austin could not immediately name the 50, Michael Myerson, executive
director of the U.S. Peace Council, said the world council's president, Romesh
Chandra of India, had been originally barred along with four other members of
the council's secretariat and more than 20 others.

The others, he said, included Gen. Francisco da Costa Gomes, former President of
Portugal, and James A. Lamond, a member of the British Parliament, both vice
presidents of the peace group, and retired General Nino Pasti, of Italy, a
former deputy commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Italy.

Alan Romberg, a State Department spokesman, said the department had asked for a
waiver for General Pasti, excluded initially because he was elected to the
Italian Parliament on a Communist slate. He said there was no record in
Washington of applications by General Gomes or Mr. Lamond.

In a Federal District Court hearing in Manhattan yesterday, Thomas Belote,
special assistant United States Attorney, said a visa had been authorized
Tuesday for a representative of the South-West Africa People's Organization.

Mr. Myerson said this was Theo Ben Gouriab, the organization's permanent
representative to the United Nations for nine years.

Canadian Stopped at Border

Yesterday morning, Kay MacPherson, past president of the Voice of Women in
Canada, who is scheduled to speak at a June 12 disarmament rally, was barred
from entering by car at Champlain, N.Y. In Ottawa, she said she had been coming
to a meeting of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom, which
started at Barnard College yesterday.

Mr. Austin said her name was on a list of persons subject to exclusion because
of affiliation with certain organizations. Miss MacPherson said Canada's
Ministry of External Affairs was looking into her exclusion.

In Federal Court, Judge Pierre Leval ordered the United States Attorney's office
to provide information at 3 P.M. today in response to a suit by the American and
New York Civil Liberties Unions seeking immediate entry documents for foreign
visitors to the United Nations sessions.

The suit claimed First Amendment constitutional rights for Americans to exchange
ideas with United Nations visitors. It also cited a 1947 agreement between the
United Nations and the United States, in which the United States pledged to
refrain from impeding transit for accredited representatives of accredited
nongovernmental organizations.

Steven R. Shapiro, counsel for the New York Civil Liberties Union, told the
judge: ''What may be the legitimate concern of government in certain instances
is not at issue here because this is a United Nations-sponsored activity.''

For the Government, Mr. Belote said ''every officially invited delegate has been
permitted to come,'' but as to others ''it is the sovereign power of the United
States to determine who may enter.'' Judge Leval noted that any plaintiff claim
could be lost by the rapid ''ticking of the clock.''

                June 2, 1982, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

HAITIANS SINGLED OUT FOR HARSH TREATMENT

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 358 words


To the Editor:

In a recent letter (May 21), Alan C. Nelson, Commissioner of the Immigration and
Naturalization Service, defended the Government's policy of detaining more than
2,000 Haitians in substandard facilities for nearly a year. That defense
deserves a response.

First, the Commissioner alleged that under Federal law the Immigration Service
is required to detain persons seeking admission to the country while their
applications are considered.

This interpretation of the law is an entirely novel one which has never been
adopted by any previous administration. To the contrary, the law has
consistently been read to require detention in only the most serious cases.

As the Supreme Court stated in 1958, only six years after the present
immigration act went into effect: ''Physical detention of aliens is now the
exception, not the rule ... Certainly this policy reflects the humane qualities
of an enlightened civilization.'' The inhumanity involved in jailing the
Haitians cannot, therefore, be blamed on the law.

Second, Commissioner Nelson insisted that the Government ''applies (its)
detention policy evenhandedly to aliens of nationalities who are similarly
situated.'' This is simply not true. According to figures supplied by the
Government in a Federal court challenge to its Haitian program, less than 1
percent of persons coming to New York seeking political asylum in 1981 from
anywhere other than Haiti were kept in jail. By contrast, the only Haitians
released were a few pregnant women.

This can hardly be described as ''evenhanded'' treatment. Indeed, after
reviewing the evidence, Judge Robert L. Carter concluded that the Government's
actions ''were motivated by a desire to discriminate against Haitians.''

At a time when this country's future immigration policies are being considered
in Congress, the public debate is hardly advanced by misrepresenting the
relevant facts.
STEVEN R. SHAPIRO, New York, May 21, 1982

The writer, staff counsel of the New York Civil Liberties Union, is involved in
litigation in the U.S.  Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit challenging the
detention of the Haitians.
