                 May 30, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

CAN THE NUMBERS OF ILLEGAL ALIENS BE CONTROLLED HUMANELY?

SECTION: Section 4; Page 12, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1969 words


The Senate Judiciary Committee, by a vote of 16 to 1, last week approved a bill
that would overhaul the nation's immigration laws.  The sponsor of the bill,
Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Antonia Hernandez, director
of the Washington office of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational
Fund, disagree on many of the underlying issues. In separate interviews, they
discussed their concerns with Robert Pear, a reporter in the Washington bureau
of The New York Times. At the outset, each was asked whether the nation had lost
control of its borders and whether there should be more enforcement of the
immigration laws.

SENATOR SIMPSON: There is a huge flow of undocumented aliens that must be
addressed. We will be best about our duties when we legalize that flow instead
of seeing it remain illegal, and we think that that's very possible with
employer sanctions, an identifier system, an expanded H-2 (temporary worker)
program for agricultural and other areas. The true test in the legislation will
be the gut-wrenching decision whether the United States has really become so
dependent upon the undocumented worker that it cannot get off that particular
opiate, or whether we really do want immigration reform and control of the
borders.

Question. There have been so many immigration reforms proposed in the last five
years. Why do you think yours is better?

Answer. I would like to think it's because we took the hot stuff and put it
right up front and began in our early discussions to deal with the issue of a
cap on legal immigration, a staunching of the flow of illegal immigration. We
wanted a reform which would not have the characteristics of all our past
reforms, which have been racist.  By putting everything on the table early, we
had an interesting response and didn't allow it to slip into the evil, vile,
hidden kind of stuff that accompanies any significant reforms.

Q. Did you have any reservations about proposing a scheme that would require
United States citizens to validate their identity when they apply for a job?

A. Yes, when I first heard that proposed, I rejected it. In fact, much of the
original package just gave me the creeps. Then I said: This is impossible; I
don't see how we can reject everything and get reform. Maybe I'd better start
listening. So I started to listen and I started to research and read, and I
became convinced that you have to have employer sanctions or penalties against
those who knowingly hire (illegal aliens), and you have to have a universal
employment authorization verification. I had a good deal of trepidation, but I
said, what are we trying to do? Are we trying to slip over into 1984 and
Orwellian theories? Are we trying to intrude upon the private lives and civil
liberties of the American people? I would visit with people from the A.C.L.U.
and civil libertarians, and I would say, O.K., if you don't like that, what's
the alternative? Please give me an alternative, but no fair quoting from the
Statue of Liberty. I don't want anybody in the argument to do that.

Q. What are the prospects for this legislation?

A. I think there is a good deal of support for it. I have advised the majority
leader that we will have something to be processed. He knows it is a priority
item.

Q. Is it correct to say that your bill would, for the first time, put immediate
relatives of immigrants under the numerical ceiling for immigration?

A. In setting the 425,000 cap, we are staying with existing levels. We are not
cutting away or going up. We do still cherish and embrace the historical
traditions of immediate family, and they will still come in. The people of the
country are not aware that there has never been any limit on immediate family.
It doesn't matter how many would come. They are not totaled against the quotas,
the country allocations. What we are saying is: Continue to come in, even if it
goes over the quota. But then if it does, then the next year you have a rolling
reassessment of that country's quota. Yes, we do in essence place a cap on
immediate family and family reunification.  But it is not evidenced because it
can go into the second year of the allocation, and there are only one or two or
three countries that are heavily affected there.

Q. Why do you put immediate relatives under the ceiling?

A. That figure has gone up about 7 percent a year. That figure 10 years ago was
70,000, and now it is 155,000. Those are unlimited - no numerical limit on
those. If we are going to have that type of exponential growth, we ought to be
paying attention to it in what is called the Immigration Reform and Control Act
of 1982.

When we finish the legalization process, those people will be entitled to have
their families come here. That's why we must be assured that we watch for that
tremendous increase. Once you have legalization, plus five years, plus 3 to 6
million people who all would then have the right to make application for their
relatives under the preference system, that's a lot of numbers.

Q. Critics say that your bill would require employers to help enforce the
immigration laws. What's the point of that?

A. The idea of employer sanctions draws a quick response: that it's terrible to
make the employers of America the policemen of the world. But that is not what
this legislation does. If people will take the time to read the bill - it's 78
pages and it's all in English - I think they will be attracted to what we really
are trying to do with employer sanctions.

What is expected of the employers is one thing, one tiny small thing: that when
they are hiring people, they just check off on the same form, wherever they are
asking for the Social Security numbers or whatever they do ordinarily, just say,
I asked this person for his identifier or his work authorization, and check the
box. And you do that under penalty of perjury.

We knew that if we ever put a tremendous burden on the employer, we would never
get to first base. That's why the legislation does not put a tremendous burden
on the employer.

MISS HERNANDEZ: We believe that there should be more enforcement, more control
of the borders, but there has to be a humane immigration policy. We agree that
the Immigration and Nationality Act should be updated, that it is archaic. Our
concern is that these people are coming through and are being exploited, and
furthermore that their presence here makes the lives of Hispanics much more
difficult.

Question. What is your reaction to the recent roundup of more than 5,000 illegal
aliens by the Immigration and Naturalization Service?

Answer. It was a public charade that will not in any way affect the overall
economic problems of this country. Any day they want, they can pick up that many
undocumented persons without making a big public fanfare.

Q. How does that relate to what would happen if Congress enacted the proposal
sponsored by Senator Simpson and Representative Romano Mazzoli of Kentucky?

A. The employer sanctions, combined with a multiple identification system, would
create the same type of environment. We had reports from Los Angeles that the
immigration officers would go into companies, surround the premises, look at the
employees, divide them into Latin-looking and Anglo employees, and they wouldn't
harass the Anglo employees. They would put all the Latin employees in one
corner. Then they would interrogate each and every one of them to see whether
they were United States citizens or legal resident aliens.  The added problem is
that a lot of United States citizens who were Hispanic Americans didn't have
documentation with them. They were taken to the central station until they could
prove (their status).  Why should anyone of any heritage in America have to
undergo that humiliation, that harassment or that inconvenience?

Q. Is there any way to aggressively enforce the immigration laws without having
harassment that discriminates against Hispanic Americans?

A. I don't think so. Basically, the problem of harassment, of intimidation is
placed on you because of who you are, your ethnicity, your nationality. I.N.S.
people will tell you that they can smell or determine who is an undocumented
alien and who is not, but that's a bunch of baloney. There's no way they can
tell. People will say, that's why you should have a counterfeit-proof
identification card.  Well, that is unrealistic too. Any I.D. card is going to
be based on the same documents that are so easily counterfeited. You can buy a
birth certificate, you can buy a Social Security card.

Let me give you a very personal example. My father is a United States citizen,
and he looks as Mexican as anyone I've ever seen. He had one of the old cards
that I.N.S. used to issue with his picture, saying that he is a United States
citizen. He carries it with him.  That was never good enough when they used to
raid his company. So now he's thinking of getting an American passport to see if
that will do, since a passport is much more difficult to get.

Q. Where was he born?

A. In Texas.

Q. Would the Simpson-Mazzoli bill halt the flow of undocumented workers from
Mexico?

A. No. It fails to consider the strong economic and social factors, such as
higher wages and family reunification, which bring immigrants to this country.
People don't understand the economic interdependence and interrelationship
between the two countries. I am not saying that we have to have an open border.

Q. Would the Simpson-Mazzoli proposal lead to better enforcement?

A. They don't even enforce the laws they have now. There's nothing in the
proposal that would lead us to believe they are going to enforce it. What's
going to happen is that we are going to have another law on the books that is
not enforced systematically, that will be enforced arbitrarily, in a
discriminatory manner.

The Office of Management and Budget came up with statistics saying that a
picture I.D. would cost close to $2 billion. Without a picture, it would cost $1
billion. They should put one-quarter of the $1 billion into better management of
I.N.S., better border enforcement and try this for a couple of years and see
what happens.

Q. What about penalizing employers?

A. Employer sanctions would inevitably result in discrimination against
Hispanics and other minority citizens and legal residents.  Employers intent on
excluding minorities could conceal their discriminatory practices under the
pretext of compliance with the law. On the other hand, well-meaning employers
might avoid hiring minorities or 'foreign-looking' applicants for fear of being
subjected to employer sanctions.

Q. Have the professionalism and training of I.N.S. agents gotten any better?

A. In all my experiences with the immigration service, and they have been many,
by and large I.N.S. officers have been courteous, respectful and understanding.
We in our family have never had the questioning and the suspicion at the border,
but that to us is part of being Hispanic. It's sort of assumed. At the border we
have had very good relationships. My parents fear, they distrust, but they also,
in all fairness, have had few unpleasant experiences at the border.

You can't put all the fault on I.N.S. officers. They are overworked,
understaffed, given an impossible task, told to enforce the law, but not to
enforce the law.

                May 29, 1982, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

OVERHAUL OF IMMIGRATION LAW GAINS IN SENATE

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Page 7, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 588 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 28


The Senate Judiciary Committee has approved a bill to overhaul the nation's
immigration law in a major step toward resolving a long-term dispute.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, was the lone dissenter
Thursday as the panel voted, 16 to 1, to send the proposal to the Senate.

Just minutes before the final vote, Mr. Kennedy won a concession that would
greatly increase the number of illegal aliens now in the country who would be
eligible for legal status.

The Republican-controlled committee, by an 8-to-7 vote, approved Mr. Kennedy's
proposal to give temporary legal status to illegal aliens who could prove they
had been here since Jan. 1.

Another version had set the date at Jan. 1, 1980, the same as in a similar
immigration bill pending before the House Judiciary Committee.

The difference of two years could mean legal status for five million illegal
immigrants, or 500,000 more aliens than would otherwise be eligible, according
to Reagan Administration and committee figures. It is estimated that there are
six million illegal aliens in the United States.

Temporary legal status would be the first step for an illegal alien to gain
citizenship. However, some illegal aliens say they are fearful of stepping
forward and acknowledging their illegal status.

Administration officials said that if Congress agreed on the 1982 date,
President Reagan would probably accept it. The Administration had recommended
Jan. 1, 1981, as the cut-off date.

The bill also proposed permanent legal residence for any immigrant here before
Jan. 1, 1978.

Penalties Against Employers

The measure would also impose the first civil and criminal penalties against
employers who knowingly hired immigrants who lacked legal status.

Mr. Kennedy objected to that provision. He said he was worried that employers,
out of fear of being fined and sentenced to jail, would automatically reject job
applications from people of Hispanic descent.

Mr. Kennedy had unsuccessfully proposed that such sanctions against employers be
automatically canceled after two years unless the President could certify that
they were not being used to discriminate against members of minority groups.

In recent years attempts to change the immigration law have stalled in Congress
as proposals got caught between opposition from many sides. Hispanic groups,
among others, favored eased restrictions on immigrants, while opponents pushed
for stricter measures to guard the nation's borders.

The committee vote on Thursday suggested that Congress might be ready after
years of stalemate to overhaul the immigration laws.  Bipartisan praise was
showered on Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, the sponsor of the
measure, for working out a painstaking compromise. The House version, which is
close to the Simpson bill but not exactly the same, is sponsored by
Representative Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky.

Both measures contain the proposed sanctions against employers. An employer
would be required to check a job applicant's eligibility by asking him to show
either a birth certificate or passport and a Social Security card or driver's
license.

The legislation envisions that after three years the Government would develop a
means of checking legal status, through an identification card or through a
computerized data bank.

                May 26, 1982, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

PITFALLS IN LEGISLATION TO MODERNIZE AMERICAN IMMIGRATION LAW

SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 629 words


To the Editor:

Under active consideration in Congress is the Simpson-Mazzoli bill, which is a
modified version of the immigration proposals of the Administration. While in
some respects our immigration laws doubtless are antiquated, we believe many of
the proposed changes are unsound and undesirable.

A major aspect of this legislation is the theme that if employers are required,
under threat of sanctions, to become government enforcement agents, the problem
of undocumented aliens will somehow vanish. While we have reservations regarding
the wisdom and effectiveness of this device, we recognize that it has been
thoroughly debated for over 10 years.

Unfortunately many provisions in the bill have not had the benefit of extended
discussion or consideration, including the following:

* In an apparent reaction to unfavorable court decisions, the Administration has
proposed, and the Simpson-Mazzoli bill adopts, limitations on the judicial
review of immigration decisions.

Sound executive and legislative policy, in our view, should welcome the role of
the courts in correcting errors and assuring evenhanded justice, and we deplore
the effort to restrict their traditional role.

* The bill would authorize a single immigrant inspector to reject summarily any
person seeking to enter the United States if he concludes that the applicant
does not have the required documents or that his claimed right of entry (or
citizenship) is unfounded.

This arbitrary power could be exercised without any hearing or representation by
counsel, and without opportunity for administrative or judicial review. The
legislation would thereby abandon, without any sound justification, a right to a
fair hearing before an immigration officer, recognized by our immigration laws
since 1903.

* The bill would impose arbitrary, and in our view unjustified, restrictions to
preclude foreign students from seeking residence in the United States unless
they return to their home countries for two years after they complete their
studies.

A two-year foreign residence requirement is now applied to exchange visitors
whose projects are government-sponsored and -financed, but we can perceive no
reasonable basis for such a requirement in the case of a bona fide foreign
student who pays his own way and eventually qualifies for residence benefits,
e.g., by marriage to an American citizen.

* The bill would deny the privilege of adjustment to permanent residence status
for aliens in the United who have violated their temporary status.

A similar effort to curtail such benefits by overly stringent requirements
proved unsound and was abandoned in 1958. This change will merely require an
alien already eligible for a visa to make a meaningless trip to another country
to obtain the visa, and will unnecessarily overburden U.S. counsuls. Various
factors, including administrative delays, may contribute to an alien's failure
to maintain status. We believe the discretionary features of the present statute
afford ample opportunity to deal with visa abusers.

* The bill would curtail the principle of family unity, now a major aspect of
our law, by removing from the preference categories the adult, unmarried
children of lawful residents and the brothers and sisters of American citizens,
thus virtually denying such aliens the opportunity of joining their relatives in
the United States.

These provisions of the Simpson-Mazzoli bill are significant changes of course
in American immigration policy. We believe they should not be adopted.  CHARLES
GORDON SAM BERNSEN MAURICE A. ROBERTS Washington, May 17, 1982 Messrs. Gordon
and Bernsen are former general counsel to the Immigration and Naturalization
Service; Mr. Roberts is former chairman of the Board of Immigration Appeals.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%);

SUBJECT: IMMIGRATION AND EMIGRATION; LAW AND LEGISLATION  IMMIGRATION (93%);
IMMIGRATION LAW (91%); JUDICIAL REVIEW (90%); LETTERS & COMMENTS (90%);

                May 26, 1982, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

BIRTH RATE HIGHEST FOR LATINS IN U.S.

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section C; Page 4, Column 3; Living Desk

LENGTH: 465 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 25


Hispanic people, the nation's fastestgrowing minority, have a birth rate 75
percent higher than the rest of the population, and Hispanic mothers are younger
and less educated, according to a Government report made public this week.

The report, by the National Center for Health Statistics, lends credence to
census experts who predict that at current rates of birth and immigration people
of Hispanic origin will outnumber American blacks before the end of the century.

The report, ''Births of Hispanic Parentage, 1979,'' by Stephanie Ventura,
includes information from 19 states, with 60 percent of the Hispanic population.

Births to Hispanic mothers accounted for 196,000 of the 1.6 million reported
births in the 19 states. The 1979 Hispanic birth rate was 25.5 births per 1,000
population, nearly 75 percent higher than that of non-Hispanic women, which was
14.7, the report said. The fertility rate was 100.5 births per 1,000 women of
child-bearing ages, 59 percent above the rate for non-Hispanic women, which was
63.2, the report added.

Hispanic peoples tend to have larger families, with more than 8 percent of
babies born to Hispanic mothers being the fifth or later child, compared with
3.5 percent of white and 7.4 percent of black babies, the report said.

''Hispanic mothers tend to be somewhat younger than white non-Hispanic mothers
but considerably older than black non-Hispanic mothers,'' it said. Nineteen
percent of Hispanic mothers were under 20 years of age, compared with 15 percent
of non-Hispanic mothers - 12.1 percent for whites and 27.5 percent for black
non-Hispanics.

''The relatively large proportion of births to teen-agers among Hispanic mothers
is a factor accounting for the lower levels of educational achievement observed
for Hispanic women,'' the report said. In 1979, 47.3 percent of Hispanic mothers
had finished 12 years of school, compared with 82.1 percent of whites and 62
percent of blacks. The median educational level was 11.7 years, compared with
12.7 for whites and 12.3 for blacks.

Hispanic mothers are less likely to see a doctor in their first months of
pregnancy, the report said. About 60 percent did in 1979, as against 81.2
percent of white non-Hispanic mothers but about the same as black mothers.

The 19 states were Arizona, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Florida, Hawaii,
Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Maine, Mississippi, Nebraska, Nevada, New Jersey, New
York, North Dakota, Ohio, Utah and Wyoming. Texas, New Mexico and Georgia will
be added to the 1980 report, bringing the total Hispanic population covered to
more than 85 percent.

THE CITY;
Forger of Papers For Aliens Is Jailed

BYLINE: By United Press International

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 137 words


A 25-year-old Brooklyn College student was sentenced to six months in jail and
fined $5,000 yesterday for providing forged documents to illegal aliens seeking
to remain in the United States.

In sentencing the defendant, Jose Del Castillo of Manhattan, Judge Charles L.
Brieant Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan said he was concerned that
''in times of high unemployment'' the Government was ''unable to or unwilling to
enforce the immigration laws.''

A probation report on the defendant said he had ''provided forged documents for
approximately 300 people, charging $300 to $500 per package.'' The allegation
was disputed by Mr. Del Castillo, a native of the Dominican Republic, who has
been in the United States for 12 years and is a permanent resident.

                 May 21, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

A MANDATE ON ALIENS THAT IMMIGRATION AUTHORITIES MUST OBEY

SECTION: Section A; Page 30, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 563 words


To the Editor:

Your April 19 editorial ''Release the Haitians'' created a misleading impression
of this Administration's efforts to control illegal immigration, and
particularly of its determination that the statutory mandate to detain
excludable aliens must be obeyed.  In June 1981, President Reagan announced a
comprehensive immigration reform package. This package includes a legalization
proposal for large numbers of illegal aliens now in the U.S., and we estimate
that 35,000 Haitians who are here illegally will be eligible to eventually
become citizens.

Concurrent with the legalization proposal, however, new enforcement measures
were proposed or instituted to control significant increases in illegal
immigration and to prevent the legalization program from encouraging new illegal
arrivals. They included sanctions against employers of illegal aliens, increased
enforcement resources, strengthening of laws against alien smuggling, detention
of excludable undocumented aliens as required by law and the interdiction of
illegal arrivals by sea.

Illegal arrivals from Haiti in South Florida is one problem any such
comprehensive package had to address. Such arrivals had steadily increased
through 1980, when more than 15,000 entered. The Administration's efforts,
however, have resulted in a dramatic decrease in that number - 4,500 fewer
Haitians the first quarter of this year than in the first quarter of 1981.

The law mandates, with specified exceptions, that excludable illegal entrants be
detained while their right to enter is determined under the law, rather than
being paroled into the community. The Immigration and Naturalization Service
applies the detention policy evenhandedly to aliens of nationalities who are
similarly situated.

The detainees are not prisoners with indefinite sentences. All are free to
return to their countries of origin at any time.  Unfortunately for those who
have chosen to remain at Krome, lengthy legal maneuvers on their behalf have
delayed the hearings. However, Federal Judge Spellman has now allowed individual
exclusion/asylum hearings to begin. Pro bono attorneys, solicited by the
Attorney General and Judge Spellman to represent the detainees are now beginning
such hearings before immigration judges.

Your characterization of the Krome facility's operation is inaccurate. Liberal
visiting hours are in effect, with an average of 150 members of the press,
family and friends visiting the detainees each Saturday and Sunday. Three
balanced meals, medical and dental services and various classroom and sports
activities are provided.

This is hardly a ''harsh environment.'' In addition, no children are detained at
I.N.S. facilities; unaccompanied minors are placed with voluntary agencies or
relatives. If children are accompanied by parents, the entire family is paroled.

No one can be unmoved by the plight of the Haitians in continued detention. We
are not insensitive but believe that the detention policy should be judged on
law and facts, not speculation.

Detention is required by law, and also serves the welfare of those Haitians and
millions of others waiting in their own country for legal entry. Expedited
hearings - in conjunction with reform of the current outmoded processes - are
the answer.
ALAN C. NELSON, Commissioner, Immigration and Naturalization Service,
Washington, May 5, 1982

                May 19, 1982, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. JUDGE IS ASKED TO UPHOLD HAITIANS' DETENTION

BYLINE: By GREGORY JAYNES, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 706 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, May 18


The Justice Department ended its defense of United States immigration policy in
court here today by imploring the presiding Federal district judge to help the
Reagan Administration regain control of the nation's borders.

In the case of Haitians, about 2,200 of whom have been held in Federal detention
facilities for the better part of a year, Judge Eugene Spellman was told that,
by upholding the detention policy, ''You'll be accused of being a racist. You'll
be accused of being a supporter of black concentration camps. There is no way
around it.''

The trial attorney, Robert Bombaugh of the Justice Department, made the remarks
in his arguments at the end of hearings on a civil suit that seeks to free the
Haitians. Attorneys for the Haitians finished their summations last Friday.
Judge Spellman has said he hopes to have a decision in the case in about two
weeks.

''I can remember coming home with an unannounced friend for dinner,'' Mr.
Bombaugh told the court, ''and my mother, being generous, saying, 'There's
always room for one more.' I do not think she would have said that if I had
brought home the whole football team. There are limits.''

A 'Different' Policy

Attorneys for the Haitians have argued, in the main, that the Government's
policy of detaining all Haitians lacking immigration papers is discriminatory,
and that the Haitians are legitimate political refugees who should be paroled.

The Government has said the policy for Haitians is ''different but favorable''
and not at all discriminatory. Government witnesses have testified that the
regime of Haiti's President, Jean Claude Duvalier, is ''authoritarian'' and that
there are ''reasons for concern for those who actively oppose the regime'' but
that a broad policy of political asylum for all Haitians is not necessary.

Throughout the hearings, the Justice Department has contended that the detention
policy, which went into effect last August, was an essential component of a
strategy designed to regain control of the borders. Exclusionary hearings, in
which immigration magistrates sought to learn whether the Haitians had a ground
for political asylum, were stopped last September when another Federal district
judge here held that the present civil suit should be resolved first. Since
then, the Haitians' lot has been either to stay in detention or to sign a
voluntary withdrawal paper and be sent back. Few have signed.

''Clear policies were adopted in spite of, not because, Haitians concentrations
existed in south Florida,'' Mr. Bombaugh said today.  ''There was no question,
because of the conditions in South Florida, that we would be accused of setting
up black concentration camps.''

Right for Equal Treatment

Mr. Bombaugh said discrimination would have been a valid charge if the detention
policy had been put into effect ''because of'' the Haitian presence here.

One thrust of the Government's argument is that aliens who come to this country
without the necessary papers have no more right to full judicial review here
than ''people who stand in line at American consulate offices,'' Mr. Bombaugh
said. He said it was wrong to put the Haitians ahead of those ''patient'' enough
to go through channels and wait their turn.

Responding to a demand in the suit for ''equal treatment'' for Haitians, the
Justice Department has said the executive branch of the Government must retain
broad discretion in immigration matters and that the Government's flexibility to
deal with a crisis with the proportions of those in Poland or Afghanistan would
be ''hamstrung.''

''There are only three ways we could satisfy the criteria for equal treatment,''
Mr. Bombaugh said. ''One, parole everybody. Two, parole nobody. Three, throw all
the names in a hat and pull them out one at a time. Equal treatment in this
context could be discriminatory.''

His last words to Judge Spellman today were, ''We will not surrender enforcement
of the immigration laws. You will have to stop us.''

CLOSE-UP OF THE ILLEGAL IMMIGRATION ISSUE

SECTION: Section 4; Page 22, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 355 words


To the Editor:

It is easy for you, from your northern vantage point, to take up for the
''pitiful'' Haitians who have come into south Florida illegally, breaking our
immigration laws (editorial April 19). You urge the release of those detained,
so that they can disappear into the community and never show up for their
hearings, as so many others have done.v.hy don't you take up the cause of the
residents and merchants of northeast Miami, whose lives have been so terribly
affected by the massive influx of illegal Haitians, something which the release
of the detainees would begin all over again?

Our neighborhoods are deteriorating; our schools and hospitals are overcrowded;
our residents are exposed to contagious diseases that would bar legal
immigration; our streets are jammed with traffic; our welfare system is
overburdened, and our merchants are losing money.

While all this is going on, people who don't share our problem and don't have to
suffer what we are suffering tell us we shouldn't enforce the immigration laws
so that even more will come here.

As president of the Northeast Miami Improvement Association, which represents a
quarter of the city, with perhaps 70,000 people and several thousand businesses,
and as chairman of Miami's Planning Board, I urge you and your readers to think
about how you would like - not just for your city but for your neighborhood - to
bear the burden of 60,000 to 100,000 illegal aliens, most of them unskilled,
uneducated, unhealthy, illiterate, non-English-speaking and unacquainted with
modern customs, including sanitary practices and traffic laws. Perhaps you would
like to offer to take some of these people into your communities and
neighborhoods.

Immigration is fine, as long as it is orderly, legal and according to certain
standards. We have perfectly good immigration laws. Let's enforce them.  GRACE
A. ROCKAFELLAR Miami, April 20, 1982

JUDGE OVERTURNS ABSCAM CONVICTION OF EX-LEGISLATOR

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 912 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14


A Federal district judge overturned the bribery conviction of former
Representative Richard Kelly today, saying the Government had used
''outrageous'' tactics in the undercover Abscam inquiry.

Judge William B. Bryant said that agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation,
posing as representatives of wealthy Arab sheiks seeking immigration assistance,
should have stopped importuning Mr.  Kelly after he rejected their initial bribe
offers. Instead, the judge said, they persisted in applying pressure on the
Florida Republican until he finally accepted $25,000 and stuffed it into his
pockets.

Judge Bryant's evaluation of the Abscam inquiry differed from those of judges in
New York and Pennsylvania. Lawyers said that the conflicts among the rulings
increased the likelihood that the Supreme Court would review the tactics of the
investigation, including such questions as how the Government selected its
targets and whether the agents offered excessive inducements to commit crimes.

Exceeding the Limits of Fairness

The Government, in effect, was ''testing the virtue'' of Mr. Kelly when there
was no reason to suspect his virtue, Judge Bryant said, adding that the
Government had exceeded the outer limits of ''fundamental fairness.''

''Law enforcement exceeds its bounds when it manufactures crime and creates
criminals,'' the judge said in his 25-page opinion.  Judge Bryant granted Mr.
Kelly's request for a judgment of acquittal, overruling the guilty verdict
returned by a jury on Jan.  26, 1981. Mr. Kelly was convicted of bribery and
conspiracy after a seven-week trial. He was the only Republican among the seven
members of Congress convicted on charges arising from the bureau's effort to
uncover political corruption by offering money in the guise of Arabs seeking
favors.

United Press International quoted Mr. Kelly as saying he was ''not feeling very
happy'' after the judge's ruling because he thought it did not address the
problem of a Federal agency that ''takes advantage of a Congressman in trouble
financially.''

''What the F.B.I. did was political,'' he said at a news conference in St.
Petersburg. ''We still have to deal with an F.B.I. that undertook to explode the
mind of the people with a story that just wasn't true.''

Judge Bryant presided over the Kelly trial and issued his ruling today on
post-trial motions by Mr. Kelly and his co-defendants, who asserted that the
Government had violated their constitutional rights to due process of law. That
argument is similar, but not identical, to the defense of entrapment.

The judge also ordered a new trial for two men who were indicted and convicted
with Mr. Kelly: Eugene Robert Ciuzio, a business consultant from Longwood, Fla.,
and Stanley Weisz, an accountant from Smithtown, L.I. The judge said his
different rulings for Mr. Kelly and the other men were justified by a
''disparity in the amount of evidence'' presented against the various
defendants. A Justice Department spokesman, Thomas M. Stewart, said there was a
''strong presumption'' that the Government would appeal Judge Bryant's rulings
to the United States Court of Appeals here. He said no final decision had been
made.

In November 1980, a Federal district judge in Philadelphia dismissed the Abscam
convictions of two city officials, saying they had been ''entrapped'' by the
Government. But in February the United States Court of Appeals for the Third
Circuit reinstated the convictions, finding that the defendants' rights had not
been violated.

At his trial, Mr. Kelly contended that he had been conducting his own
investigation of ''shady characters.'' Judge Bryant described this as a
''bizarre, nearly farcical defense,'' adding that there was ''not a scintilla of
evidence'' to support it.

He acknowledged that he had had a ''personal sense of revulsion'' and a ''strong
visceral reaction'' against the Government's tactics in the Kelly case.

In a videotape shown at the trial, Mr. Kelly took the $25,000 after promising to
do what he could to help two wealthy Arab sheiks immigrate to the United States.
The ''sheiks'' had been invented by the bureau.

When Federal agents and informers first approached Mr. Kelly, Judge Bryant said,
''No one in the Government had even the remotest suspicion about the existence
of any prior, ongoing or imminent criminal activity of this type.'' In other
words, he said, ''there was nothing to trigger traditional law-enforcement
activities until the Government made its overtures.''

'An Unwholesome Spectacle'

''Government agents, hard about the business of corrupting public officials who
are free of suspicion, essentially subvert our Government; and on its face this
presents an unwholesome spectacle,'' Judge Bryant declared.

''When improper proposals are rejected in these virtue-testing ventures, the
guinea pig should be left alone. In ordinary real-life situations, anyone who
would seek to corrupt a Congressman would certainly not continue to press in the
face of a rejection for fear of being reported and arrested. The F.B.I., of
course, had no such restraints in this case.''

The judge said he had been ''disappointed and chagrined'' to see Mr. Kelly, on
videotape, yielding to temptation and stuffing $100 bills into his pockets.

''But in reality,'' he said, ''the hard fact is that our public servants are not
recruited from the seminaries and monasteries across the land and that they are
plagued by the frailties of human nature.''

                 May 10, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

'OUTCAST' NEEDS CONGRESS AID TO STAY IN U.S.

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 13, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 702 words

DATELINE: BISMARCK, N.@D., May 8


Eight years after he was found near death in the Ecuadorean jungle, Juan Ramirez
is educated, healthy and fighting to keep from being returned to South America,
where he believes he would be an outcast.

But the Immigration and Naturalization Service says that only a special bill in
Congress will allow him to stay, and action on it has been stalled since a House
subcommittee rejected it, saying he must exhaust all administrative remedies
first.

Mr. Ramirez, who is now 22 or 23 years old, will graduate June 6 from the Anne
Carlsen School for the Physically Handicapped in Jamestown, N.D., and wants to
study electronics in a vocational school.

He cannot apply for citizenship, however, because he has no blood relatives here
and no job skill and is neither a refugee nor a ''professional of distinguished
merit or ability,'' said Gerald Coyle, the immigration agency's district
director in St. Paul.

Unwanted and Critically Ill

When missionaries found Juan in 1974, he was wracked by convulsions and his body
was wasted by parasites. He was scorned by his family, unwanted because of his
deformities.

The missionaries who found him said his left foot was twisted nearly upside down
because of polio when he was 3 years old. His right foot protruded at a
90-degree angle.

''He was suffering from malnutrition, four or five kinds of worms and amoebas
and a low hemoglobin count, which brought on the convulsions,'' said Dr. Devota
Nowland, an osteopath in Armada, Mich., who helped bring him to the United
States.

''He was treated as an outcast by people outside of his family and would have
suffered a great deal or died had he not been brought to the United States,''
Dr. Nowland said.

Reportedly Sold to Cafe Operator

Mr. Ramirez, who does not know when he was born, was one of seven illegitimate
children, Miss Nowland said. Missionaries and others told her that he was sold
to a woman who ran a small cafe in Chaco.  Mr. Ramirez said he peeled vegetables
for ''one or two meals a day'' and slept on a straw pallet. At 15, when he had
corrective surgery in a missionary hospital in Quito, he weighed 60 pounds.

His hips and legs remain shriveled, but he gets around slowly with leg braces
and a crutch.  He still does not know where his family is. ''They're sort of
moving around,'' he added. ''They go where my mother can find work, field work,
milking cows.''

He denied that his mother had sold him and said, ''I was her son, and even
though I couldn't help her, I think she still loved me.''

Adoption Efforts Failed

Miss Nowland, who was on vacation in Quito, brought Mr. Ramirez to Michigan. She
tried to adopt him, but Ecuadorean law prohibits a single woman from adopting a
boy.

Through a Fargo, N.D., adoption agency, Mr. Ramirez found his way to a farm
owned by Vic and Olga Karges near Hazen, N.D. They too tried to adopt him, but
he was then past 16 and too old, the immigration agency said.

Miss Nowland started the process of trying to extend his temporary visitor visa,
and the Kargeses are continuing the effort.  ''The only relief is what they are
doing, trying to get a private bill through Congress,'' said Mr. Coyle of the
immigration agency, adding that there would be no deportation action until
Congress acted.

Bill Approved by Senate

The bill was approved by the Senate last Oct. 27, but the House subcommittee
rejected it in February.  Representative Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North
Dakota, said he had the subcommittee to reconsider and planned to tell each
member ''the adversity this boy has overcome and why he deserves a chance to
stay here permanently.''

The alternative is to reopen the deportation hearings, said Betty Hum, the
Kargeses' attorney.  ''I don't know what 'administrative remedy' they're talking
about,'' said Senator Quentin N. Burdick, Democrat of North Dakota.  ''I think
it's a real strong humanitarian case.''

BRIEFING

BYLINE: By Francis, X. Clines and Lynn Rosellini

SECTION: Section 1; Page 11, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 159 words


Alien Roundup: A Backfire

I n the attempt last week by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to round
up illegal aliens, called Operation Jobs, Federal officials questioned legal
residents whom they took for people of Hispanic origin.

When Representive Patricia Schroeder heard that 71 of the 107 people apprehended
in Colorado were legal residents, she wired Attorney General William French
Smith: ''How would you like it if everyone on Wall Street wearing a three-piece
suit was arrested on suspicion of tax evasion?''

The Colorado Democrat also said the announced aim of Operation Jobs, making jobs
held by aliens available to unemployed Americans, was ''a subterfuge to avoid
Administration responsibility for the rotten economic conditions in America.''

A Justice Department spokesman said, ''The results were much better in some
other areas.''

U.S. USING TOUGHER POLICY ON ASYLUM FOR AFGHANS

BYLINE: By PETER KIHSS

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 875 words


The Federal Government has taken a tougher stand to bar Afghan applicants for
political asylum. It is charging some with attempting to ''circumvent our
immigration law,'' even though they might face persecution at home.

A State Department letter that became known yesterday gave attempts to
circumvent the law as the reason for the detainment of 34 Afghans at the
Brooklyn immigration center. The Afghans have been denied parole while awaiting
hearings, some for four months.

They are the only Afghans now in custody. More than 6,000 others have won
refugee status or asylum elswhere in the United States since Soviet troops
rolled into Afghanistan in December 1979.

Thousands More Applying

Refugee applications of 5,000 to 6,000 more Afghans are being processed abroad,
the State Department indicated yesterday, and they are in addition the Afghans
who come to the United States and then apply for asylum. Of that number, 1,096
were awaiting decisions as of Jan. 31, according to the Immigration and
Naturalization Service.

To win asylum, Federal law requires that an applicant establish a well-grounded
fear of persecution in his homeland. The fear must be based on race, religion,
political affiliation, membership within a social group or nationality.

Applications for asylum go first to the State Department's Bureau of Human
Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, which evaluates the application and makes a
recommendation, based on its sources abroad.

Six May Lose Asylum Bid

The State Department has now recommended denial of asylum for six of the 34
Afghans detained in Brooklyn. The Afghans came to this country from Pakistan - a
first stop for many who flee Afghanistan.

A bureau letter said that ''the applicants have established a wellfounded fear
of persecution in Afghanistan,'' but that ''they did not apply for refugee
resettlement in the United States while they were in Pakistan.''

Accordingly, it said, ''We do not believe their application for asylum should be
approved because of the misuse of our immigration laws.'' It quoted President
Reagan as having said last July 17 that neither the United States nor any other
nation could absorb all would-be entrants.

''Asylum in the United States is intended to provide a sanctuary for persons
fleeing persecution,'' the bureau wrote. ''It is not intended to be a substitute
for or an alternative to the immigration laws policy of this country and should
not become a vehicle of convenience for applicants who may wish to circumvent
our immigration law.''

The number of Afghan refugees has been soaring, with perhaps a fifth of
pre-invasion Afghanistan's population now abroad. Pakistan has 2.7 million
Afghans registered currently, according to the office of the United Nations High
Commissioner for Refugees in Washington.  Pakistan plans to accommodate an
average of 2.1 million Afghans this year, up from an average of 1.7 million last
year.

For the fiscal year started last Oct. 1, the Federal Government has allocated
4,000 refugee places for Afghans out of a total of 140,000 refugee places. The
4,000 come from the 5,000 places reserved for refugees from the Near East,
defined as the area from Morocco to India and Bangladesh. That number is up from
3,500 in fiscal 1981.

President Sets Number

The number of refugee places is set by the President after consultation with the
Judiciary Committees of Congress.  Paula Lynch, Near East program officer in the
department's refugee program, said several hundred Afghans were admitted as
refugees in the first year after the Soviet invasion, followed by 2,829 in
fiscal 1981 and 1,500 from last October through last April. Refugee applicants
are interviewed and approved at offices in Pakistan, India, Frankfurt and Rome.

Of those Afghans who arrived without refugee status and then filed an
application, 140 were granted asylum from October through January of this fiscal
year, and 70 were denied it, according to Duane Austin, a spokesman for the
Immigration and Naturalization Service.  In fiscal 1981, 201 were approved and
131 denied.

Waiver Required for Release

Mr. Austin said the 34 Afghans in in Brooklyn were being held under exclusion
provisions that bar them from being released pending hearing unless they get a
waiver from a district director.

Arthur C. Helton, director of the political asylum project for the Lawyers
Committee for International Human Rights, said parole had been granted to all
102 Afghans and 65 other aliens who arrived in New York and asked for asylum
between January 1981 and last November.

This fact, he said, was presented in a hearing in December, in which it was
successfully argued that the Government had discriminated against 86 Haitians
that it had held in Brooklyn since the previous July. Thereafter, said Mr.
Helton, a new guideline said parole in exclusion cases would be granted only to
children under the age of 16, aliens with close family members here or those
pregnant or ill.

                  May 7, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

ALIEN RAIDS OPENED UP JOBS, AIDE SAYS

BYLINE: By JO THOMAS, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 11, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1050 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6


A series of raids by the Immigration and Naturalization Service rounded up 5,440
employed aliens and persuaded 4,071 of them to leave the country, according to
Joseph Salgado, the agency's associate commissioner for enforcement.

The well-publicized ''Project Jobs,'' intended to force illegal aliens out of
decent-paying jobs that could be held by unemployed citizens, produced a clamor
of job-seekers in some places.

The immigration service gave state employment services and community groups the
names of the businesses where aliens lacking the proper documents had been taken
off the payroll. But how many of the jobs will be filled by citizens is unknown.
The agency estimated that the jobs paid a total of $50.3 million a year.

The April raids came on the eve of detailed Congressional scrutiny of a bill,
the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1982, that today was considered line
by line in a Senate subcommittee and sent to the full Judiciary Committee.

'Game Plan' Denied

Alan Nelson, the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, said there was
''no game plan'' linking the arrests to the legislation. He said the raids were
planned in February.

Nonetheless, questions raised about the raids, such as the degree to which
illegal aliens contribute to unemployment among citizens and the degree to which
employers are culpable, are part of the discussion of immigration reform. The
bill under consideration in the Senate subcommittee would introduce penalties
for those employing illegal aliens; the employers face no sanctions at present.

In an interview last week, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Associate Attorney General,
said the raids took place in Chicago, Dallas, Denver, Detroit, Houston, Los
Angeles, Newark, New York and San Francisco. Most of the aliens apprehended
voluntarily agreed to leave the country; the others are facing deportation
hearings.

The top-paying job involved, according to Mr. Salgado, paid $10.08 an hour at
the Burlington Northern Railroad in Chicago. At an automobile parts concern in
Chicago, he said, more than 30 undocumented workers were making $7 to $9 an
hour. The average wages of those arrested nationwide was $4.81, Mr. Salgado
said. In Chicago, more than 1,500 people applied for 161 vacated jobs.

Some May Reduce Workforce

A number of employers whose companies were raided, however, said that they might
not hire any new workers right away. Some said the downturn in the economy would
have forced layoffs in any case. Others said they still did not think they could
find citizens who wanted to do the work. One said he could not rapidly train
replacements.

At the Price Pfister Brass Manufacturing Company in Pacoima, Calif., where 80
workers were arrested, 1,000 applications were accepted, but the concern may not
do any hiring.

''Of those who were taken,'' said Peter Gold, a company spokesman, ''50 have
come back, and we are proceeding on the assumption that they have their
documents and have been released. Ten have said they are involved in
administrative hearings. Under the terms of our union contract, 20 people have
been terminated for being missing for three full days. We don't know whether
we're going to replace them. There is a recession. We've done no hiring for a
year and a half.''

In New Jersey, where raids led to the arrest of 172 illegal aliens in 23
factories, Winifred Brady, the assistant director of the Division of Employment
Services of the State Department of Labor, said six workers had been placed so
far at $3.50 an hour.

Layoffs a Possibility

Walter Gibson, controller of the Carolyn Shoe Company in Monterey Park, Calif.,
said that the raids had caused layoffs at his company, where 80 of 240 workers
were arrested.

''A line of production has to have every position filled,'' he said. ''You take
out one third of the workers, and you have holes. On Monday, we laid off 30.
Yesterday we laid off 10 more. We have ads in the papers for experienced help.
But we have no manpower to train people off the street.''

He said that his company, because of foreign competition, paid only $5 to $6 an
hour after long training.  Mr. Gibson said that although 40 of those arrested
had returned to work, ''It'll be weeks before we can get the thing rolling. But
we're not going to make poor shoes because of it.''

Another employer, Bruce Vaughan, part-owner of the Boulder Valley Poultry Farm,
Boulder, Colo., said: ''We've had an ad in the paper for a long time, but
usually people will not work in a poultry house. Half an hour later, they walk
out. We don't pay less than $3.50 an hour, but they'd rather take welfare.''

Fleeing Worker Killed

Last Friday morning, a worker Mr. Vaughan knew as James Gonzalez, who had papers
identifying him as Jose Morales, fled as immigration agents pulled up at the
farm. In his panic, according to Mr. Vaughan, Mr. Morales ran to the main road
and into the path of a gravel truck which struck and killed him.

The raids, in which 4,908, or 87 percent, of the 5,635 arrested were Mexican,
have come under attack from Hispanic groups. The total of 5,635 included both
employed aliens apprehended at job sites and others arrested at the sites.

''We're appalled at the raids,'' said Joaquin Avila, president and general
counsel of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Educational Fund. ''This will
seriously affect the rights of Hispanics when they seek employment.''

Arnaldo Torres, a spokesman for the League of United Latin American Citizens,
said he felt that the raids would crystallize opposition to the immigration bill
now before the Senate Subcommittee on Immigration and Refugee Policy. The bill,
sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Representative
Romano L.  Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky, contains penalties for employers who
hire illegal aliens.

''Employer sanctions are a key part of the bill and have been since the
beginning,'' Senator Simpson said. ''Now it's illegal for an illegal alien to
work, but not for an employer to hire him.''

                May 5, 1982, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. AUTHORITIES DETAIN AFGHANS AT BROOKLYN SITE

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 489 words


Thirty-four Afghans who said they fled political persecution in Afghanistan are
being held in the Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center in
Brooklyn. Some have been detained for as long as four months pending deportation
hearings.

Although in the past many aliens have been released to sponsors in the community
pending the hearings, the Afghans have been denied permission to leave the
center at 136 Flushing Avenue. They have been detained, said James A. Jaysey,
deputy district director of the service's regional office, because they did not
have proper papers when they entered the United States.

''For four years, not one second was comfortable in Afghanistan and still I am
in the same conditions here,'' said Mansour Osmani, who is 29 years old and has
been held for 45 days. ''I heard that American people will help us.''

2 Worked for U.S. Agency

Mr. Osmani, who said he had been a banker in Afghanistan, was one of nine
Afghans interviewed yesterday at the detention center. Two of those held said
they had worked in Afghanistan for the American Government's Agency for
International Development.

The group included a professor of agriculture, four high-school students and a
70 year-old factory supervisor. Some spoke English and some spoke through an
interpreter, Akunshiram Abnashkumar, who said all 34 had been persecuted in
Afghanistan.

Immigration officials said that because many in the group had come to the United
States from Pakistan, where they did not face political persecution, they might
not be entitled to political asylum. Pakistan is the first stop for people
fleeing Afghanistan.

Immigration officials said that it was policy to detain most aliens until their
cases can be heard.

Discrimination Issue Raised

But human rights advocates and lawyers who specialize in immigration matters
said the Afghans, some of whom said they did have relatives in this country,
were being held to demonstrate that the immigration service did not discriminate
against a group of Haitians that had earlier been refused permission to leave
the center.

On March 5, Judge Robert L. Carter of the Federal District Court in Manhattan
ruled that the agency had discriminated against a group of Haitians that had
been held since July 18 in the Brooklyn center while all other groups who had
requested parole had been released.  The ruling is being appealed.

''The I.N.S. seems to be engaged in a post hoc attempt to justify what they have
been doing to the Haitians,'' said Aryeh Neier, vice chairman of Helsinki Watch,
a human rights group.

Mr. Jaysey said that although aliens had been released to sponsors in the past,
guidelines issued in December 1981 state that parole is granted only to children
under 16 years old, those aliens with close family members or those who are
pregnant or ill.

                 May 4, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

ALIENS SEIZED BY U.S. REPORTED BACK AT WORK

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 919 words


Several companies in the New York metropolitan area where illegal aliens were
rounded up last week reported yesterday that many of them had been released from
custody and were back at their old jobs.

And some companies said that few, if any, unemployed American citizens had
applied for the jobs that were freed by the raids and which the Government said
were rightfully theirs. The companies were major targets of a roundup by the
Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service.

Americans Called Uninterested

''Except for four or five, all of the aliens that were arrested here last week
are back at work this morning,'' said Anthony Spinale, the president of the G &
T Fruit Company at 230 West 230th Street in the Bronx. According to the
Government, 22 illegal aliens were seized at Mr. Spinale's produce-packing
warehouse April 26.

Mr. Spinale and officials of the other raided companies asserted that there was
little demand for their jobs by unemployed American citizens - a view that drew
some support from officials of the New York State Department of Labor.

''It also may be true what the employers are saying,'' said Art Winick, speaking
for the department. ''That these are marginal jobs that most people are not
interested in.'' However, he said he did not know whether people who might want
the jobs were aware of their availablility.

The Immigration Service conducted raids in eight cities besides New York. The
results in terms of job applications were still incomplete yesterday.

At one of the New York companies -Plated Plastic Industries Inc., 381 Troutman
Street in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn - Nick Amish, the company's vice
president, said that 15 or so of the 23 workers seized at the plant last week
were back at work.

At another - the Phalanx Furniture Company in Wantagh, L.I. - Irving Lieberman,
the president, said that about five of the 20 or so employees seized by
immigration agents were back at work yesterday after having been released from
custody.

Mr. Spinale, still fuming at what he called a ''kindergarten raid'' on his
plant, said, ''I can't recall one American coming in here and asking me for a
job.''

According to Mr. Amish, not one American has applied for work at his company
since the raid. ''American citizens don't want to work for the minimum wage,''
he said. ''There's no sense kidding ourselves - they simply can't get by on
$3.35 an hour. Aliens are the only people who will work for the minimum wage.''

''It was true 30 or 40 years ago for Italians and Greeks,'' he added, ''and it's
still true today for Hispanics, and it will be true for someone else 20 years
from now.''

Mr. Lieberman said he could use 10 skilled cabinetmakers for his Long Island
furniture company. ''But my unskilled jobs go begging if aliens don't take
them,'' he said.

''We runs ads for unskilled workers and we don't get any response,'' he added.
''The only ones who want these kind of jobs are aliens.''

At the J. J. Cassone Bakery Inc. in Port Chester, N.Y., where Government agents
seized 25 illegal aliens last week, a company official said that only one of 50
Americans who had applied for work was interested in working at the same pay
scale - and on the same schedule, nights and weekends - as the seized aliens.

'Majority' of Aliens Freed

The apprehension of about 5,500 illegal aliens last week at job sites across the
country was described by immigration officials as an attempt to recapture jobs
paying more than the minimum wage for unemployed American citizens.

According to immigration officials, the ''overwhelming majority'' of those
arrested have been released, pending deportation hearings.  They said most of
them of Hispanic origin. Officials said it was not unlawful to employ an illegal
alien.

William S. Slattery, the chief of special investigations for the Immigration
Service's office in New York, said that 523 illegal aliens were seized at about
50 companies in the New York area.

''We are very satisfied with the results,'' he said. ''We have created 500 jobs
for unemployed Americans, some of them paying $5 an hour or better.''

State Says Few Have Applied

Asked if he knew of any company that had hired any American citizens as a result
of the arrests, Mr. Slattery said that the New York State Department of Labor
had been handling that aspect of the operation.

Joanne Palmieri, an official of the state employment service, said preliminary
reports showed that ''very few applicants have expressed any interest thus far
in the jobs of the aliens that were arrested.''

Mr. Winick, the department spokesman, said that filling the jobs with citizens
would be a ''lengthy process.'' He also said, ''It is highly unlikely that the
jobs that the aliens were pulled off have been referred to us in certified
form.''

Mexico Protests Aliens' Treatment

MEXICO CITY, May 3 (AP) - Mexico has accused the United States of violating the
rights of an undetermined number of the illegal aliens rounded up in last week's
sweep, which involved nine American cities. A story in the official Government
newspaper El Nacional said the Foreign Ministry had accused American immigration
officials of violating diplomatic procedure by denying Mexican consular
officials interviews with Mexicans arrested in the sweep.

U.S. ALLOWS REVIEW OF 2 HAITIAN CAMPS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 670 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 3


The United States has agreed for the first time to let an international body
examine conditions at two camps where Haitians are being detained, in Florida
and in Puerto Rico.

The Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, an arm of the Organization of
American States, asked for permission to inspect Fort Allen, P.R., and the Krome
North camp near Miami after receiving complaints of human rights violations at
the two centers.

The State Department and the Immigration and Naturalization Service denied that
any of the Haitians' rights had been violated but agreed to let the group
examine the conditions in which they were being held.

Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the immigration service, said today that there
were 555 Haitians at Krome North and 771 at Fort Allen, the site of an old Army
base and Navy communications center.

Hearings 'Stymied by Litigation'

''We detain all aliens pending exclusion hearings,'' Mr. Jervis said. ''Hearings
on the Haitians have been stymied by litigation.'' The original complaint was
filed in 1979 by the International Human Rights Law Group, a nonprofit public
interest law firm, on behalf of the National Council of Churches and 8,000
Haitians seeking refuge in the United States.

The basic charge, said Amy Young-Anawaty, executive director of the law group,
is that ''innocent people are being detained in unlawful, inhumane conditions
and should be released.''

The United States initially opposed any investigation by the O.A.S. commission,
on the ground that the Haitians were litigating the same issues in Federal
courts and had not exhausted the remedies there. However, when the commission
decided to visit the camps, United States authorities said last week that they
would do all they could to help the official observers.

Formal Report May Follow

Normally after such a visit, the commission prepares a formal report with
recommendations and submits it to the General Assembly of the O.A.S., which can
then pass a resolution urging a country to improve human rights conditions.

Immigration officials said physical conditions at the Krome center, which has
permanent buildings, were somewhat better than at Fort Allen, where the Haitians
live in tents set up on a wooden platform.

David Carliner, an immigration lawyer who is chairman of the International Human
Rights Law Group, said he hoped that the O.A.S.  investigation would ''sensitize
the United States Government to the international implications'' of detaining
the Haitians. Federal authorities are holding a total of 2,025 Haitians at 14
sites.

Reagan Administration officials said that the detention of Haitians arriving in
Florida and the interception of boats suspected of carrying illegal immigrants
had sharply decreased the flow of Haitians in the last year. The officials said
President Reagan's policy was designed to prevent a mass migration of aliens
like the one in 1980, when 125,000 Cubans fled to the United States.

Extension Sought for Fort Allen

The Government's agreement with Puerto Rico to use Fort Allen as a detention
center expires in August. Michael J. Henke, a Washington attorney for the
Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, said the United States was negotiating to extend
the agreement for a year.

An extension would require approval from the United States Court of Appeals for
the First Circuit, in Boston, which issued an order limiting the use of Fort
Allen in certain ways designed to protect public health and the environment. The
First Circuit includes Puerto Rico.

Although the O.A.S. commission asked the United States to refrain from deporting
Haitians while it studied their complaint, the Government has proceeded with
deportation hearings and some deportations.

''The Haitians are being detained because they choose to stay,'' Mr. Jervis
said. ''They are free to return to Haiti at any time.''

CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION ASSAILS RAIDS FOR MAKING 'SCAPEGOATS' OF;
ALIENS

BYLINE: By PETER KIHSS

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 440 words


A nationwide Federal roundup that led to the arrests last week of 5,500 workers
suspected as illegal aliens was assailed yesterday by the American Civil
Liberties Union as ''playing with people's rights to score a public relations
victory.''

The raids, conducted from Monday to Friday by the United States Immigration and
Naturalization Service, will not significantly free jobs for legal American
residents, which was their stated purpose, but instead have cast basic
due-process rights ''by the wayside,'' the civil liberties group protested in
letters to President Reagan, Attorney General William French Smith and the
immigration agency.

About 500 people were arrested in the New York metropolitan area, according to
Stanley McKinley, the immigration service's regional director for the Eastrern
seaboard.

''The effort was distinctly to get at higher than minimum-wage conditions to
open up jobs,'' Mr. McKinley said.

'Street Sweeps' in Chinatown

Steven Shapiro, staff counsel for the New York Civil Liberties Union, reported
complaints of ''street sweeps'' in Chinatown and of gypsy cabs being halted in
the largely Hispanic Washington Heights section of upper Manhattan, going beyond
the searches of particular factories for which warrants had been obtained.

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, in a statement in Spanish, said it
had been told that the raids concentrated on factories that largely employ
''cheap hand labor,'' despite the immigration service's assertions that the aim
of the raids was to turn up illegal workers in the construction and computer
industries.

The New York area arrests forced the service to open an extra floor of its
detention facility in Brooklyn temporarily. But Verne Jervis, a spokesman for
the agency in Washington, said he believed that ''very few'' persons remained in
custody around the country after ''quite a few hundred'' voluntary deportations,
mostly to Mexico, and the release of others on bond or their own recognizance
pending hearings.

Charge of 'Scapegoating'

The A.C.L.U. letters by Ira Glasser, national director, and John Shattuck,
legislative director, charged that the Federal Government was ''scapegoating
undocumented workers in an effort to shift the blame for the Administration's
dismal failure to cope with increasing unemployment.''

They asserted that ''only 'foreign-looking workers' '' were being required to
prove legal status and cited reports of ''widespread denial of the right to
counsel and to timely bond hearing.''

The Nation in Summary;
U.S. Job Squads Arrest Aliens by the Hundreds

BYLINE: By Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 340 words


The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service last week did what it
could to free up jobs for bona fide Americans, though not everyone appreciated
its efforts.

Altogether, 3,500 illegal aliens, many of them Mexican, were taken into custody
in raids staged in nine cities during a week-long ''Operation Jobs.'' Ted. L.
Giorgetti, an immigration service spokesman in Chicago, where more than 100 were
arrested, said the agency had received ''hundreds of calls'' from prospective
workers about the availability of jobs that had thus been opened.

Elsewhere, the results seemed rather more mixed. Officials in Detroit had to
release 71 of the 107 picked up there because they were able to produce proper
papers. Some employers, who aren't subject to penalties for hiring illegal
aliens, complained that the jobs being freed were not the sort to be snapped up,
as one put it, by white middle-class Americans. Said a manager of a California
poultry packing plant north of San Francisco: ''You hang up chickens and cut
their throats. They work in guts and blood and in a cold damp place all the
time. I wouldn't do that kind of work for anything.''

Immigration service spokesmen said that most of the aliens would be released if
they promised to return to their native country. Critics complained about
instances of Government heavy-handedness.

In Los Angeles, after charges that immigrants weren't being allowed to contact
lawyers, were being unfairly questioned and forced to sign voluntary deportation
orders, Federal District Judge William Matthew Byrne temporarily barred the
deportation of 150 of the 425 arrested locally. ''To say I.N.S. is really
interested in the rights of these people is absurd,'' the judge said. In
Boulder, Colo., a poultry farm employee said to be of Mexican extraction was
struck and killed by a gravel truck as he attempted to elude agents. Government
sweeps also took place in New York City, Dallas and Houston.

JUDGE ORDERS IMMIGRATION AGENTS NOT TO ABUSE SALVADORAN REFUGEES

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section 1; Page 14, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 719 words

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 30


A Federal judge today ordered agents of the Immigration and Naturalization
Service to stop threatening and abusing Salvadoran refugees and to advise them
they have the right to seek political asylum in the United States.

United States District Court Judge David Kenyon issued the 41-page preliminary
injunction at the request of the National Center for Immigrants' Rights, which
had asked the judge to prohibit the immigration service from illegal and
unconstitutional practices against refugees from the war in El Salvador.

'Verbal and Physical Abuse'

In the order, the judge held that immigration agents had used ''verbal and
physical abuse'' to try to get Salvadoran refugees to waive their right to apply
for political asylum.

''Salvadorans who resisted were told that their refusal would be of no avail and
eventually they would be deported to El Salvador anyway,'' the judge said.

Judge Kenyon ordered that the refugees be advised in both English and Spanish of
their rights, ''including securing the services of an attorney, having a
deportation hearing and applying for political asylum if they do not want to
return to their strife-torn homeland.'' The order also provided that the
refugees be given written notice of these rights.

'No Power' to Control Employees

David Inman, a lawyer with the immigration service in Washingtion, argued at the
hearing that the agency had no power to control the actions of its employees.

A spokesman for the agency said the ruling would be appealed to the Court of
Appeals for the 9th Circuit.  Judge Kenyon's order, which warns the Federal
agency it should ''not employ threats, misrepresentation, subterfuge or other
forms of coercion,'' follows a hearing held early last week.

The injunction applies to an estimated 25,000 Salvadoran refugees now detained
in the United States.  The judge found that Salvadoran refugees had been
illegally placed in solitary confinement as part of a national campaign to
guarantee their mass deportation, regardless of the merits of their individual
applications.

Prohibited Writing Materials

He said that the immigration service had also illegally prohibited detained
refugees from having pens, paper and other materials to help them prepare asylum
applications.

''An estimated 10,000 refugees have already been coerced into waiving their
rights to apply for asylum and involuntarily deported to El Salvador, where many
have faced death in prison and torture,'' said Peter Shey, the director of the
immigrants' center. ''We presented the judge with irrefutable evidence that
persons deported to El Salvador have been killed shortly after their return.''

Mr. Shey said the judge agreed that the agency's conduct had violated the
Constitution, the Refugee Act of 1980 and United Nations protocol on the status
of refugees.

Judge Kenyon directed the agency to submit a plan to the court within 10 days
for ''a national system'' to give the center 24 hours' notice prior to the
deportation of any Salvadoran refugee.

Mr. Shey described the injunction as ''a major victory for the Salvadoran
community'' in the United Sates.  ''We believe it will send a message to this
administration,'' he said, ''that it can no longer decide refugee policy on the
basis of foreign policy considerations, namely rejecting applications made by
those seeking safe haven in the United States after fleeing rightwing
governments supported by Washington.''

----

Alien Is Killed While Fleeing

BOULDER, Colo., April 30 (AP) - A man fleeing from a roundup of illegal aliens
today was killed by a gravel truck. The victim's identity was not immediately
known. Officials said he was of Mexican extraction and apparently worked for the
Boulder Valley Poultry Farm.

Witnesses said the man was standing in the farm parking lot and ran when agents
of the Immigration and Naturalization Service arrived.  Robert Hester of the
immigration service said agents were not aware of the incident until later.
''Nobody was in pursuit,'' he said. ''No one saw him.''

The raid was part of a nationwide crackdown on illegal aliens that has resulted
in the arrests of more than 5,000 people, according to Government officials. The
raids are aimed at apprehending people who have jobs that could be held by legal
United States residents.
