AMERICA'S 'INVISIBLE' CHINESE

BYLINE: By Diana Fong

SECTION: Section 1; Page 27, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 859 words


We've been called the model minority, the silent minority. Sometimes we're too
insignificant in numbers to even count as a minority. Although the Chinese
population in the United States has surged in recent decades, we are still only
four-tenths of 1 percent of the entire population.

Who are we, and why are we so few in number?  Part of the answer dates back to
restrictive immigration legislation enacted in May 1882. Immigrant laborers,
welcome when the frontiers were expanding in the West, became targets of
anti-Chinese agitation, which led to passage of the Chinese Exclusion Act, the
United States' first statutory proscription of a group based on race. The act
was finally repealed by Congress in 1943.

Today, the Chinese in America are caught in a strange paradox of being both
noticed and ignored. Between the Hudson River and the Golden Gate, in San
Francisco, we are such a tiny, conspicuous group that we pique the friendly
curiosity and once in a while the hostility of people. Since large numbers of us
are also foreign-born, we're often treated like guests in this country - more
hospitably, but then we don't belong to the ''family.'' Chinese citizens are
sometimes viewed as aliens - even the ABC's (American-born Chinese).

At times, we don't count as a minority either. When the word ''minority''
appears in newspapers, only blacks and Hispanics are usually mentioned. Three
years ago, when I was a college intern for a television series about minorities,
a stunned white student remarked, ''Funny, I always thought you were white.''

We straddle an awkward middle ground - the buffer between whites and blacks.
We're accepted and we're not accepted - ''better'' than other minorities but not
good enough. Though we're included in affirmative-action programs, we're not
perceived as a ''disadvantaged'' group. Most often, we're viewed in a positive
light - as law-abiding citizens, math whizzes, and as so successful that we've
been dubbed the ''model minority.'' As a group, we ''out-white the whites'' in
scholastic achievement, occupational status, and median-income levels.

Though we've ''made it,'' discrimination still exists - it's just
better-disguised now. Once in a few years, I'll come across a blatant remark
such as: ''Why don't you go back to your own country?'' Most of the time,
prejudice doesn't rise to the surface, but we can sense it. I think minorities
develop special feelers that detect hostile undercurrents - like antennae that
pick up radio waves.

We've been called a ''silent minority'' because we tend to cope with prejudice
in quiet - ''inscrutable'' ways, others say, sometimes legitimately. During the
exclusion period, there were still Chinese who entered illegally by jumping ship
and others who trickled in because of immigration loopholes. Now, illegal
immigrants are scattered throughout the lowly paid sweatshops of this country's
Chinatowns.

Today, we're excluded in another sense - we're ignored. In schools, study is
almost exclusively centered on Western civilization.  Partly it's our own fault
that we're ignored. We keep a ''low profile.'' Chinese do not generally see
politics as a means of achieving group goals or to fight discrimination here in
the United States.

We don't even identify ourselves as a unified group. Since we speak different
dialects, we can't always communicate in Chinese. A majority is Cantonese. In
the 1940's and 1950's, a small but significant intellectual elite settled here,
virtually all displaced by the Communist revolution; the big wave from Hong Kong
and Taiwan started in the middle and late 1960's; in the 1970's, Southeast
Asians of Chinese descent arrived; most recently, a handful from the People's
Republic of China has come. And then, there are the American-born Chinese,
largely young, many Chinese in physical appearance only.

For many Chinese, the road to economic success, to acceptance and power, is
scholarship and commerce. A disproportionate number of us are entrepreneurs,
physicians, research scientists, engineers, and accountants. We also tend to
choose self-employment, partly because of discrimination in private industry.
There and elsewhere, while equal opportunity makes it easier to enter, it's
still harder for minorities to move up the institutional ladder. Thus,
discrimination limits occupational choice.

The rate of intermarriage between Caucasians and Chinese-Americans is relatively
high, an indication of increasing acceptance, but we're still not fully
integrated into the mainstream because of our yellow skin and almond eyes. Much
has changed in 100 years, but still we cannot escape the distinction of race.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Diana Fong, who was born in the United States and who spent many years in Hong
Kong, conducts tours to the Orient and Soviet Union.

THE CITY;
Decision Deferred On Jailed Haitians

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 125 words


A Federal appeals court reserved decision yesterday on whether to overturn a
lower court's order to release 53 Haitians held in an immigration detention
center in Brooklyn.

Their release had been ordered by District Judge Robert L. Carter, who said the
Immigration Service had discriminated against the Haitians by refusing to parole
them. His order was stayed pending a decision by the United States Court of
Appeals for the Second Circuit.

After the appeal was argued, about 20 supporters of the Haitians demonstrated in
front of the Foley Square Court House. The Rev.  Jesse Jackson said 2,700
Haitian refugees had been held in ''concentration camps'' in this country for
almost a year.

ROUNDUP OF ALIENS MEETING PROBLEMS

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 558 words


A week-long series of Government raids to remove illegal aliens from jobs that
could be held by unemployed Americans has run into growing criticism and a court
challenge.

About 3,500 people have been arrested by the Immigration and Naturalization
Service in nine cities since Monday, and clergymen, politicians and spokesmen
for minority groups in several of those cities have expressed opposition.

In Denver, the Roman Catholic Archbishop and the Episcopal Bishop signed a
statement protesting the crackdown. One priest said he was willing to harbor
people ''just as the church served as a refuge in the Middle Ages.''

Immigration officials in Detroit said they had to release 71 of the 107 people
picked up there when their families produced papers showing they were working
legally. The 36 others, officials said, ''probably will be deported.''

Duke Austin, a spokesman for the service, said the raids through Wednesday had
found 3,500 illegal aliens, who were earning an average of $4.70 an hour.

Court Order Obtained

In Los Angeles, lawyers for an immigrant rights group won a Federal court order
barring deportation of 150 of 425 Mexicans arrested there. A busload about to
leave was halted after Federal District Judge William Matthew Byrne Jr. ordered
all aboard to be asked whether they wanted a lawyer.

''To say I.N.S. is really interested in the rights of these people is absurd,''
Judge Byrne said.  Lawyers for four rights groups told Judge Byrne that
immigrants were being denied access to counsel and pressured into signing
voluntary deportation orders.

The judge broadened his order yesterday to require that immigration officers
advise those under detention of their rights before asking them how they got
into the country or offering them voluntary deportation forms. A lawyer for the
American Civil Liberties Union, Mark Rosenbaum, said that the case had been
certified as a class action and that Judge Byrne's order should apply
nationwide.

An affidavit quoted two aliens as saying that immigration officials had told
them a lawyer would cost $4,000 and that ''their fingers would be broken if they
refused to provide their fingerprints.''

Spokesman Says It's Routine

A spokesman for the immigration service in California said it was routine to
question suspected illegal aliens before they saw a lawyer.

In Denver, the Rev. Pat Valdez of Our Lady of Guadalupe Roman Catholic Church
said, ''People are hiding in their homes, afraid to leave.'' He said that many
residents in Denver suburbs had offered their homes as hiding places.

As he talked Wednesday night, Father Valdez was answering phone calls for help.
''We have a food bank and that woman just said she's been hiding in her house
since Monday and ran out of food,'' the priest said.

Maria Esther Aguayo, 21 years old, a naturalized citizen who lives in Colorado,
said she and a friend who had permanent resident status were arrested in a raid
Sunday at a nightclub.

She said: ''I kept telling them, 'I'm an American citizen,' but they just
laughed at me and said, 'You're going home. You're a wetback and you're going
home.' ''

AROUND THE NATION;
250 More Are Arrested In Crackdown on Aliens

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 142 words


By The Associated Press
Immigration officers in New York and Houston arrested about 250 suspected
illegal aliens yesterday in the second day of a nationwide crackdown aimed at
aliens who work in well-paying jobs that could be held by United States
citizens.

The raids were started Monday by a group of 400 agents, and Immigration and
Naturalization Service officials said initial reports indicated as many as 1,000
aliens had been picked up in nine cities the first day.

Forty suspects had been picked up in New York City by midday yesterday,
according to William Slattery, supervising investigator for the agency. Agents
in New York and Newark arrested 191 people Monday.

In Houston yesterday, immigration agents arrested 200 people, bringing the
two-day total there to more than 400.

                April 27, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

NEARLY 1,000 ARE SEIZED IN A;
JOB SWEEP OF ALIENS

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 937 words


Swooping in as workers began morning shifts, Federal immigration agents
apprehended nearly a thousand illegal aliens yesterday at job sites around the
nation in what the Government said was an effort to recapture higher-paying jobs
for unemployed American citizens.

In New York and New Jersey, Immigration and Naturalization Service agents raided
at least eight companies and arrested about 175 aliens without the blue-lettered
''resident alien'' cards.

In the operation, called Project Jobs, immigration agents seized hundreds of
other people at work sites in Detroit, Chicago, Denver, Dallas, Houston, Los
Angeles, San Francisco, Utica, N.Y., and other cities in sweeps that are
expected to continue through the week. The service said it expected to apprehend
3,000 to 5,000 illegal aliens holding jobs that it says have been taken away
from unemployed citizens and legal aliens.

'Quite a Success'

In Washington, Verne Jervis, a spokesman for the immigration service, said that
scattered reports from the field showed that the first day of the operation was
''quite a success.'' Immigration officials said preliminary reports showed that
268 illegal aliens were arrested in the Fort Worth area, 230 in Houston, 135 in
Denver and 130 in Los Angeles.

Mr. Jervis said the jobs left open by the arrests would be referred to state
employment agencies, veterans groups and labor unions to be filled.

He said one raid at a landscaping and tree surgery company in Houston found
illegal aliens holding jobs paying $4 to $5 an hour and that aliens arrested in
other areas of the nation had jobs paying as much as $11 an hour.

If the arrests made yesterday in New York and New Jersey are any indication,
most of those caught in the sweep will be illegal aliens from Mexico and other
Latin American countries.

Bronx Company Raided

In one raid, about 100 people, virtually all of them Hispanic workers, had just
started the day shift at the G & T Fruit Company at 220 West 230th Street in the
Kingsbridge section of the Bronx yesterday morning. About a dozen immigration
agents carrying search warrants jumped from their unmarked automobiles and ran
into the company's large warehouse. The workers, who were repacking sacks of
potatoes unloaded from nearby boxcars for supermarkets, were lined up and
ordered to produce their resident cards.

''They came in here like Jesse James, scaring people half to death,'' Anthony
Spinale, owner of the company, said as he watched agents take away 22 employees.
Those who did not have the plastic cards were placed in the immigration cars
outside.

The workers who were not arrested stood silently on the warehouse loading dock,
their eyes darting from one agent to another, until Mr. Spinale told them it was
time to go back to work.

''If they are trying to open up high-paying jobs to citizens, then this raid is
a joke,'' said Mr. Spinale, who went on to accuse the Government of using
''Gestapo-like tactics.''

Workers Said to Get Low Wage

''I pay these people the minimum wage of $3.35 an hour for hard, honest work,''
he said, ''and my books are open to prove it.'' Immigration service officials
said that in the past they had often caught illegal aliens working low-skilled
and minimum-wage jobs. In most cases, the officials said, those jobs were simply
filled again by other illegal aliens.

However, William S. Slattery, chief of special investigations in the immigration
service's New York office, said the objective this time was to remove illegal
workers from better-paying jobs that would then be available for unemployed
citizens in the surrounding community. The agency estimates that there are 3
million to 6 million illegal aliens in the nation and that about half of them
hold jobs illegally.

Immigration officials said the principal targets of their nationwide dragnet
were illegal aliens earning at least $4.50 an hour.

'Who Else Would Do This Work?

But Mr. Spinale ridiculed that idea.  ''Who else would do this work?'' he asked,
pointing at workers lifting heavy sacks of potatoes and sorting fruits and
vegetables.  ''No one else, just these people.

When told of Mr. Spinale's charges that low-paid workers were being taken away,
Mr. Slattery said, ''That's bound to happen.'' Mr. Slattery said agents seized
45 illegal aliens at the Alsy Manufacturing Company in Hicksville, L.I.; 23 at
the Plated Plastics Company at 331 Troutman Street in the Bushwick section of
Brooklyn; four at Paramount Fibers, 348 Manita Street, and four at Capital
Caterers on White Plains Road, both in the Bronx.

Mr. Slattery said 32 persons were arrested in Westchester County.  He said all
of those detained were being questioned at the service's ''processing center''
in the old brig at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

Mr. Slattery said most of those detained would be released if they agreed to
return to their native countries. Otherwise, he said, they would be held for
deportation proceedings.

Those released will be required to sign ''no work'' pledges. Other than the loss
of workers, there are no penalties for companies that hire illegal aliens.

In New Jersey, James Pomeroy, acting director of the immigration service's
district office in Newark, said 44 illegal aliens were apprehended at two
factories, 35 at the Chem Spray Company in Totowa, and nine at Lite Industries
in Paterson.

Key West, in Protest On Aliens, 'Secedes'

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 12, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 175 words

DATELINE: KEY WEST, Fla., April 24


Residents of Key West, angry at the Federal Government for what they called its
cumbersome efforts to control illegal immigration, ''seceded'' from the United
States Friday and briefly established ''The Conch Republic.''

They quickly ended the spoof, but said they wanted to apply for $1 billion in
foreign aid. Residents of the Keys are at odds with the Government over a
roadblock the Border Patrol set up to capture illegal aliens and drug smugglers.
Last weekend, the roadblock backed up traffic for 19 miles, and Key West
officials say it is choking off tourist trade.  The Border Patrol says it is
serving a necessary purpose, and that 25 illegal aliens were intercepted in five
days.

Mayor Dennis Warlow of Key West presided over the mock ceremonies proclaiming
''The Conch Republic.'' He declared war on the United States, fired a ''verbal
shot'' and then surrendered the new republic so that, he said, it would be
eligible for foreign aid.

                April 25, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

CENSUS FINS THAT NEW YORK'S POT IS STILL MELTING

BYLINE: By JOHN HERBERS, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 38, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1519 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24


The New York metropolitan area is home to more foreign-born people than to
people born in other parts of the United States, new figures from the 1980
census show.

This finding, according to authorities, reflects both the large increase
nationally in immigration of foreigners during the 1970's and the slowdown in
the migration of Americans from all regions to New York and other Northern
cities for better economic opportunities.

The figures also show the metropolitan area, as defined by the Federal
Government, to have an exceptionally high poverty rate, an educational level
only slightly above the national average, a median family income at about the
national level and an unusually high percentage of whites over 65 years old.

In almost every economic respect, the New York area, with its large populations
of the poor and minorities, ranked considerably below its predominantly white,
middle-class neighbor, the Nassau-Suffolk metropolitan area on Long Island.

Because the boundaries of some metropolitan statistical areas were changed
during the last decade the figures released by the Census Bureau this week could
not be compared immediately as far as New York was concerned with those of the
1970 census and previous decades.  That information will be available later.

Statistically Accurate Sample

The data that were released were a statistically accurate sample of the long
form that went to one in every five households when the census was taken in
April 1980. The sample contained selected characteristics for the nation, the
states and the 38 metropolitan areas with populations of more than one million.

The New York area is defined by the Government as containing New York City,
Westchester and Rockland Counties and Bergen County in New Jersey. In 1970,
Nassau and Suffolk Counties were part of the New York area but were subsequently
broken off to form a separate area, in part because they had developed their own
economy and identity even though they remained in some ways a satellite of New
York City.  Bergen County was added because of its increased economic dependence
on New York.

New York remains by far the largest metropolitan area in the United States, with
a 1980 population of 9,120,346, even though it experienced the greatest
population decline, 9 percent, of any metropolitan area during the decade. The 9
percent decline does not include the loss of Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
Chicago and Los Angeles-Long Beach are the next largest, both with more than
seven million people.

Nassau-Suffolk ranks ninth with 2,605,813.  The new figures show the New York
area to be distinctive in many ways, not only in comparison to Western and
Southern urban centers but also among those in the Northeast as well.

Income
The median family income - the point at which half the families received more
and half less - was $19,794 in the New York area for 1979, the last full year at
the time the census was taken. That was almost the same as the national figure -
$19,908. But the disparity in incomes among racial and ethnic groups was greater
in the New York area. Whites had a median family income of $23,208, blacks
$12,407, Asians $18,024 and Hispanic people, $10,347. Nationally, Asians ranked
ahead of whites. And New York had a considerably higher proportion of people
with incomes in excess of $50,000. Nationally, only 4.6 percent of all
households received that much. In the New York area 6.1 percent - 214,866
households - did.

A household is defined as the people, whether related or not, living in one
housing unit.  The Nassau-Suffolk area, with its relatively low share of poor
and minorities, offered a sharp contrast to its larger neighbor. There, the
median family income was $26,135, exceeded only by the Washington, D.C., area,
which had $27,515. And in Nassau-Suffolk 10 percent of the households had
incomes in excess of $50,000.

Poverty
Nationally, 12.5 percent of the households in 1979 were judged to be below the
poverty level based on cash income. That threshold varies according to the cost
of living in various areas but is what the Government judges to be the amount on
which a family can barely survive.

In the New York area the poverty rate was 17.4 percent. Of the 38 metropolitan
areas, only San Antonio and New Orleans exceeded the New York figure, with 18.3
percent and 18.7 percent respectively.

Nassau-Suffolk, on the other hand, had a poverty rate of 5.5 percent, and other
areas with large minority populations fared better than New York - Atlanta with
11.9 percent and Detroit with 11.4 percent, for example. Both those cities had a
majority black population. The low income for Hispanic people in New York was an
important factor in the high level for the area.

The Foreign Born
During the 1970's, New York's historic role as a melting pot for immigrants from
around the world took on new importance, while the migration of poor Americans
from other regions - a phenomenon that had occurred during most of this century
- virtually came to a halt.  Many people left the area for jobs in the West and
South as the region's manufacturing base declined.

By 1980, the Census Bureau reported, the New York area had 1,898,765 people who
said they were born (as non-Americans) in another country. That was 20.8 per
cent of the population, compared with a national average of 6.2 per cent. Only
the Miami area, with its many refugees from Latin America, and the Los
Angeles-Long Beach area, the melting pot of the West Coast, had higher figures,
with 35 percent and 21.6 percent respectively. These figures do not include
other categories, such as American citizens born abroad.

For the first time, the Census Bureau asked people whether they spoke a language
other than English at home. Nationally, 10 percent reported they did. In the New
York area, 30 percent said they used a language at home other than English.
Spanish was predominant as the other language both nationally and in New York.

When asked whether they were born in a state other than the one in which they
were living, 1,529,776 persons in the New York area said they were, while
5,185,216 said they were born in New York. Thus only 16.7 percent of the
population came from other states, compared with 29 percent nationally. New York
and other Northeastern cities clearly are no longer major economic lures for
Americans from other regions.  That role has passed to cities in the West and
South.

Education
Thirty-one of the 37 other metropolitan areas ranked higher than New York in
education. Nationally, 66.3 percent of people over 25 had completed four years
of high school. In the New York area the percentage was 63.6. The figure for
Nassau-Suffolk was 75.5 percent.  For Minneapolis-St. Paul, it was 80.1 percent;
for Los Angeles-Long Beach, 70.6 percent; for Atlanta, 69.3 percent; for Boston,
76.1 percent, and for Denver, 81.1 percent.

The New York area registered comparatively better for college graduates.
Nationally 16.3 per cent of people over 25 had completed four or more years of
college. In the New York area the percentage was 20.6. That was almost equal to
Nassau-Suffolk, which had 20.8 percent.

Age and Families
Nationally in 1980 there was an average of 2.75 persons per household and 3.27
per family. Both categories have been declining over the past two decades. In
the New York area the size of the average family was only slightly less than the
national figure, or 3.25 persons per family. But the size of the average
household was considerably below the national average, at 2.55, due partly to
the rise of one-parent and single-person households in the area.

And the New York figures in both categories were considerably smaller than in
most other metropolitan areas. Nassau-Suffolk, for example, had an average of
3.17 persons per household and 3.58 persons per family. The New York area's
tendency toward fewer people per housing unit was in part a function of age, of
older people living alone. The median age in the New York area was 33.1,
compared with a national average of 30.

And it is whites who provide a disproportionate share of the aged.  People older
than 65 make up 16.5 per cent of the white population in the New York area, but
only 12.1 per cent of the white population nationally. In the New York area,
people over 65 make up only 7.2 per cent of the black population, 5.7 per cent
of the Asian population and 4.7 per cent of the Hispanic population, figures
that are close to the national average for all three categories. It is largely
the younger white people, authorities say, who have left for better job
opportunities in other regions.

                April 25, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

MYTHS, HONOR AND MACHISMO AT STAKE IN THE FALKLANDS

BYLINE: By EDWARD SCHUMACHER

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1425 words

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES


Spanish conquistadors named this land Argentina, ''land of silver.'' While they
found little treasure, the name somehow remains apt. The society they founded in
the 16th century is still based more on what a leading Argentine sociologist
called ''myths and magic'' than on law and morality. This is central to the
Argentine national character and helps explain why Argentine forces boldly
seized the Falkland Islands from Britain three weeks ago and now are poised to
defend it against a British battle fleet.

Waves of immigration have made Argentines a people mostly of European stock. The
land is fertile, temperate, as big as the United States east of the Mississippi,
but with only 28 million people.  Before World War II, Argentina was by far the
most developed country in Latin America and as industrialized as Canada. Buenos
Aires is a cosmopolitan capital of smartly dressed people with refined tastes in
art, literature and music. Argentines have won four Nobel prizes.

But with these advantages has come a chauvinism notorious throughout Latin
America. Argentines are often condescending and didactic. Brazilians are
referred to as ''monkeys'' and North Americans as ''uncultured.''

Jose Ortega y Gasset, the Spanish philisopher, wrote that ''recognizing there is
something that you do not know is an attitude not not usually found among
Argentines.''

Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Colombian novelist, is said to have described ego
''as the little Argentine inside each of us.'' In the case of the Falklands, it
is virtually impossible to find an Argentine who concedes even minor validity to
the British claim. This is understandable, given the fact that every national
map shows the islands as Argentine and Argentina's ''right'' to the islands has
been drummed into schoolchildren since the British occupied the Falklands 149
years ago. What is harder to understand is that many Argentines genuinely fail
to see that their use of force provoked the crisis or might actually have been
wrong.

Asked to explain this blind spot, an Argentine psychoanalyst herself failed to
see it. ''It's like lending someone a watch,'' she said. ''It's still yours, and
when you want it, you take it back.'' It appeared not to occur to her that 149
years have passed, a British community of 1,800 people has put down roots on the
islands, the historical claims are debatable and force is no longer an approved
instrument for conducting foreign affairs.

Jose E. Miguens, a leading sociologist who supports Argentina's claim, explained
its actions. ''This is a mythical society and reason is unimportant,'' he said.
''It is an attitude of magic - sovereignty over the islands is ours and so it is
ours.'' The seizure by force, he suggested, was a perfectly natural and
righteous consequence. To Argentines, the islands were not ''invaded'' but
''reconquered.'' Many genuinely seem to blame the British for starting the
trouble by sending a fleet to take the islands back.

The Pull of the Pampas

One irony of the situation is that few Argentines would want to live on the
islands, a desolate and windswept place on the cold fringes of the Antarctic
Ocean. Argentines are not a pioneering people; 40 percent of the population
lives within the confines of Buenos Aires. Vast regions of the outback in the
south, the mountains of the West and the jungles of the north are held in
reserve by owners, but scarcely populated.

Yet land to an Argentine still has a powerful emotional pull.  Although the
conquistadors found no silver, they staked out huge tracts of the empty and
fertile pampas. Almost every Argentine aspires someday to own his ''quinta,''
his small plot of land. In his classic study of the 1930's, ''X-ray of the
Pampa,'' Ezequiel Martinez Estrada could have been referring to the Falklands
when he wrote, ''The old conquistador yet rises in his tomb. He is dead, but
within us looks across his frustrated dreams at this immense and still promising
land, and our eyes moisten with emotion.'' He continued, ''In Europe, to
establish a bond of ownership with the land was to marry into history, to seal a
genealogical link, to enter into the dominion of the past. But in America - in
South America - which has no past and consequently, it is thought, must have a
future, owning land is one part vengeance and another part greed.'' Despite the
vastness of Argentina, the Argentines' interpretation of their history is that
they lost great chunks of territory in the 18th and 19th centuries to their
neighbors, territory which, if they had it today, would make them a world power.

Their neighbors, naturally, hold different interpretations. Three years ago,
Argentina almost went to a war with Chile ago over their conflicting claims to
the Beagle Channel, at the tip of the continent. The Argentine military
continues to prepare for war there even though arbitration by a group of
international jurists 10 years ago and a mediation proposal by Pope John Paul II
five months ago went against Argentina's claim.

Argentina is a country of many lawyers, but not really one of law.  The United
Nations Security Council resolution calling for withdrawal from the Falklands
has been ignored. Mr. Martinez Estrada traces the country's legal tradition to
the conquistadors. They did not come to build a new society, but to exploit.
Laws limited their freedom and so were evaded. ''Argentines are not a moral
people,'' Mr. Miguens, the sociologist, said, ''in the sense that they do not
judge their actions against an unchanging standard.''
Little Regard for Democracy

The most prized value is loyalty to family and friends. In other relations,
expediency is usually followed. Cheating is common in business. A huge black
market exists to move dollars to secret Swiss bank accounts.

Many civilian leaders and ordinary Argentines helped subvert the principle of
democracy, supporting the military overthrow of five governments in the last 30
years. Large parts of the population openly or tacitly supported the
assassinations and ''disappearances'' carried out by the current military
Government to combat terrorists who used similar tactics.

Jorge Luis Borges, the Argentine author, describes his country as a nation
without a national identity. ''We're Europeans'' or ''We're Western Christians''
is a constant refrain in conversations. The upper middle class copies French and
English manners. Working-class Argentines, meanwhile, have built an exaggerated
notion of Argentina's place in the world, a notion that spurs the country to
take on the British and at the same time, conceals a basic sense of national
insecurity, a lack of mature nationhood.

Italians are the largest ethnic group in Argentina and Argentines have inherited
the Italian ambivalence about the need for government. The people swing back and
forth between authoritarianism and anarchy. There are 14 major political parties
today, and many more minor ones. The largest party is the movement that followed
a populist demagogue, Juan Domingo Peron.

Over the last 40 years, power has see-sawed between the military and the
Peronists, a competition that has not helped to move the country forward. After
years of frustrating division, the sudden unity over the Falklands has been a
heady elixir that Argentines are reluctant to give up. ''This is our first
Malvinas,'' said an intellectual, using the Argentine name for the Falklands and
suggesting that the unity over the islands might lead to consensus about
domestic problems, too.

Another reason for Argentines' willingness to take on the British stems from the
Spanish side of their character, a deep sense of honor. Foreign Minister Oscar
Camilion last year and Nicanor Costa Mendez this year bristled at meetings with
Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary forced to resign three weeks ago,
because they felt that he did not not take them seriously. Now the fleet is
bearing down. Honor, backed by a strong sense of machismo, seems not to allow
capitulation. ''The British are treating us like natives,'' Mr. Miguens said.
''Our dignity is up against the wall. We can't back down now.''

               April 24, 1982, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. IS REMAINING ADAMANT AS DETAINED HAITIANS PRESS APPEALS FOR ASYLUM

BYLINE: By GREGORY JAYNES, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6, Column Z; National Desk

LENGTH: 1291 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, April 23


Once in a while a letter of anguish makes its way out of one of the detention
facilities for Haitian refugees, as this one to President Reagan did a few weeks
ago:

''We did not flee our country in search of food and drink, like they say. You
know this as well as we do, and yet you treat us like animals, like old rags
forgotten in some corner. Do you think that in acting that way you dissuade us
from our purpose? Do you think that you are thus morally destroying us? You are
wrong.''

The letter, signed by 38 Haitian women at the Fort Allen detention facility in
Puerto Rico, went on: ''This is a cry of despair, a final call to your
nobleness, to your good judgment, to your title as a great power. We would be
honored by a satisfactory answer from you, an answer to these luckless refugees
who ask only for the charity of liberty.''

This week, at a news conference in Miami, Attorney General William French Smith
gave the answer the Government has been giving and has not changed in the eight
months since the Immigration and Naturalization Service adopted its ''detention
posture'' toward the Haitians. ''There's not a single Haitian who can't walk out
the door and go home,'' the Attorney General said. ''They can leave voluntarily
any time they want to. All they have to do is go home.''

'Go Home and Stand in Line'

''The fact of the matter,'' said Mr. Smith, ''is that an illegal alien can go
home and stand in line with all the other people who want to enter the U.S.
legally.''

The United States is holding about 2,200 Haitians at Federal detention
facilities in five states and Puerto Rico. Most of them have been behind bars or
barbed wire since last summer, when the Reagan Administration answered another
anguished cry, that of the State of Florida, whose officials said it could not
embrace one more refugee. About 125,000 Cubans washed up here in the spring of
1980.  About 40,000 Haitians made it to the beaches in the last decade.

The ''illegal aliens,'' as the Government categorizes them, say that they fled
political repression, but the United States Government holds that they fled
economic deprivation, not a ground for political asylum in this country.

The Government took two actions that have greatly stanched the flow of Haitians
and have also outraged civil libertarians who have succeeded in a court fight in
New York and are in the fourth week of a similar battle over discrimination in a
Federal court here.  Immigration officials have stopped ''sponsoring out'' the
Haitians to families and churches in the region. Before last Aug. 1, the
Haitians had routinely been released in someone's care, pending a hearing to
which few ever came.

Coast Guard on the Watch

The second thing the Government did was place a Coast Guard cutter on patrol in
the Windward Passage, between Haiti and Cuba. Only two Haitian vessels have been
interdicted and only 106 Haitians have been returned to their country by the
Coast Guard, but the presence of the cutter and the word of mouth about long
detentions in this country have profoundly diminished the exodus.

In October 1980, 2,280 Haitians were picked up here. Last October, 306 were
detained. From Jan. 1, through April 23, 1981, 2,036 Haitians were taken into
custody. This year, through today, 78 Haitians have been detained. The numbers
are always lower in winter than in summer, because the winds are wrong and the
sea is boisterous, but the Government views the recent figures as showing that
the deterrent is working.

The remaining question: What to do with the detainees?  Until last September,
immigration officials were holding quick hearings and sending them home. Lawyers
in Miami won a Federal court injunction halting the hearings until a suit in
behalf of the Haitians was resolved. That resolution will come in two weeks from
Federal District Judge Eugene Spellman, who, for the last month, has heard 37
witnesses for the Haitians and half a dozen witnesses for the Government.

Bruce Winick, chief counsel among a battery of lawyers arguing the case for the
Haitians without a fee, says he believes that even if Judge Spellman rules
against letting the refugees go free, as their suit asks, a sound enough record
has been compiled to win the argument on appeal. ''We think we've proved our
case,'' said Steve Forester, another lawyer involved in the suit.

The Government's Position

The Government has contended, according to the testimony of Associate United
States Attorney General Rudolf Guiliani, that the Haitians came here for
''economic betterment.'' Mr. Guiliani has testified that ''the situation of
political repression does not exist, at least in general, in Haiti.''

The plaintiffs contend that the Haitians' requests for political asylum are
legitimate. Stephen Cohen, who was the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for
Human Rights in the Carter Administration, termed Mr. Giuliani's assertion
''laughable.'' He said, ''It would be like someone in our Government getting up
to say that the Soviet Union is a democracy.''

A Justice Department lawyer, Robert Bombaugh, argued in court: ''We turn a
million Mexicans back at the border every year with no judge, no trial attorney.
We tried, because of the complaints about the special and unique problems of
Haitians, to protect their interests.  Then we are accused of discrimination.''

Pierre Silien, who was brought to court from the Krome Detention Facily 25 miles
west of Miami, where about 600 Haitians are held, answered a question with a
question: ''I'd spend eight months in prison and then go back to Haiti? I'd
rather spend eight more months in jail here.''

In an affidavit, Mr. Silien had said that if he was returned, ''They will beat
me, put me in prison, maybe kill me -they consider me an enemy, a traitor.'' He
said he wanted political asylum ''with all my heart.''

Mayor on Haitians' Side

Mayor Maurice Ferre of Miami testified in favor of freeing the Haitians. ''We
absorbed 125,000 Cubans in two months and many of those were criminals,'' he
said. ''Our criminal record for the Haitians is zip. They are a peaceful
people.''

''Will this encourage five million Haitians to move in?'' the Mayor went on.
''There are 1,000 illegal Mexicans that enter the United States each hour. The
Mexicans are just as poor as the Haitians, but we don't put them in jail. We are
talking about human beings and putting them in a camp for eight months without
explanation.''

Only one session of testimony remains before the case goes to Judge Spellman
next week. It will be an analysis of statistics provided by the Government,
statistics that the Haitians' attorneys say they believe will further prove
discrimination. What the statistics show, according to Mr. Winick, is that
''being a Haitian gets you detained, while being a non-Haitian works the other
way, which is all part of a discrimination suit.''

The Haitians at the Krome facility have been following the case closely.
Thirty-three women have been on a hunger strike for a week, protesting for
freedom. Three are being fed intravenously. Physicians there report that the
long incarceration has created widespread depression in the camp.

Immigration officials continue to tell the Haitians that all they have to do is
say they want to go home and they will be given a free $145 airline ticket to
Port-au-Prince.

               April 24, 1982, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

IMMIGRATION OFFFICIALS TO VISIT JOB SITES TO CHECK ON ALIENS

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 10, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 639 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23


Immigration officials said today that investigators would visit 200 to 300 job
sites throughout the country next week in an effort to catch illegal aliens who
hold better-paying jobs.

Joseph F. Salgado, Associate Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization
Service, said in an interview that he was announcing the operation in part to
counter reports that Federal agents would conduct ''raids'' or ''sweeps'' in as
many as 50 cities throughout the country.

Mr. Salgado added that the Government would focus on 200 to 300 places of
employment in ''no more than 10'' target cities. He confirmed that Los Angeles,
San Francisco and Dallas were among those cities, but he would not name the
others.

He said that the operation, if successful, could lead to the apprehension of
3,000 to 5,000 aliens, opening jobs for citizens and legal aliens in
construction and computer-related industries where illegal aliens often earned
$7 to $9 an hour, substantially more than the minimum hourly wage of $3.35.

Rights to Be Respected

Rumors about the enforcement action have been circulating for several weeks in
Hispanic neighborhoods and among immigration lawyers and civil liberty groups.
In the last three days, Mr. Selgado has briefed journalists, Hispanic groups and
members of Congress on the Government's plans, emphasizing that investigators
would respect the aliens' rights.

''We didn't want to seem to focus on any one ethnic group, locality or region,''
said Mr. Salgado, who is in charge of enforcement for the immigration agency.

Hispanic organizations protested the planned operation, saying it would spread
fear through Hispanic communities. Antonia Hernandez of the Mexican American
Legal Defense and Educational Fund said, ''We don't question their authority to
do this; we do question the means they are using.''

Arnoldo S. Torres, executive director of the League of United Latin American
Citizens, said that the operation would spread a false impression that
undocumented workers were responsible for the nation's high unemployment rate.
In addition, he said, they would stir up animosity toward Spanish-speaking
immigrants, whether legal or illegal.

Differs From Previous Actions

The planned operation, known as Project Jobs, differs from previous enforcement
actions in its emphasis on removing aliens from better-paying jobs and in its
effort to involve the Labor Department and state employment agencies.

In the past, immigration officials said, they often caught illegal aliens
performing low-skilled manual labor and agricultural jobs that citizens did not
want. The officials also said there was often no effort to fill the vacated jobs
with citizens or legal aliens, so the people caught were merely replaced by
other illegal aliens. In Project Jobs, Mr. Salgado said, the Government is
trying to line up unemployed citizens to replace illegal aliens.

Mr. Salgado said that 400 immigration service employees, including 80 Border
Patrol officers and 300 investigators, would take part in the enforcement effort
starting Monday.

In some cases, he said, job sites would be searched and employees questioned
with the consent of the employers. In about 40 percent of the cases, he added,
the Government has obtained search warrants.

The Federal authorities may take action to deport aliens who entered the Unites
States without the proper documents, who stayed beyond the time fixed by the
Government or who took employment without proper authorization. However, the
aliens have extensive rights of appeal within the Department of Justice and in
Federal courts.

                April 19, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

Release the Haitians

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 707 words


For months, in some cases a full year, the United States has ''detained''
undocumented Haitian migrants. Imprisoned is more like it; some are in fact
housed in prison cells. But unlike prisoners, the Haitians do not know when
their sentences will end. Once, this detention policy was justifiable. Now,
after so many months, it has started to smell: like the detention of
Japanese-Americans in World War II; like racism; like cruelty.

A former Immigration official reports that last Christmas, a Miami radio station
sent a black Santa to give presents to the Haitian children held behind the
razor wire of the Krome South detention center. He was forbidden to see them and
had to leave the presents in a parking lot.

Another official tells of a Haitian man in the adjacent Krome North camp who was
transferred to a new camp so quickly that he was not allowed to go to the
bathroom to get his false teeth; six months later, his dentures still had not
arrived.

Other observers tell of detainees at Krome and a dozen other locations who have
become psychotic because of ''the awful boredom.'' Husbands are separated from
wives, children from families. Some Haitians have been subjected to indignities,
others to physical mistreatment.

Why? What have these 2,200 pitiful people done to deserve such punishment? Their
offense is that, desperate to escape poverty or persecution, they have tried to
enter the United States. After a year of imprisonment, and with no end in sight,
conscience calls out for relief.

Originally, there was a logic to detention, a logic we were willing to support.
The United States needs to get control of its borders.  Illegal gate-crashers,
however pitiful, should not be allowed to displace legal immigrants who have
waited their turn, often for years. Detaining Haitians pending hearings may
discourage other gatecrashers. But because of a legal logjam, the hearings have
been put off endlessly and detention has turned into indefinite im-prisonment.
The result has been to pile injustice on inequity on inefficiency.

Start with the inefficiency. Hundreds of Border Patrol officers have been
diverted to staff the detention camps. The cost comes out to $22,000 a year for
guarding each Haitian - and that ignores the paradoxical cost in border
enforcement. Apprehensions of illegal aliens have dropped from 1.2 million to
about 750,000 in the last fiscal year.

The inequity relates to other nationalities. Hundreds of thousands of other
illegal entrants are apprehended annually, but only a handful are detained.
Virtually every one of the undocumented Haitians, all black, are detained.

As for the injustice, the Administration is belatedly providing language and
other training, and Attorney General Smith deserves applause for persuading 250
Florida lawyers to volunteer to tackle the backlog of cases. But while the
conditions of detention are improving, the duration of detention is not; the
months pass.

Where can the Haitians turn? Congress could pass an emergency law to unclog the
sclerotic hearing process. But so far it sees only abstract injustice; it is
considering legislation in so deliberate a manner that no relief seems likely
for months. The courts have been receptive. Federal District Judge Robert Carter
last week ordered the release of 53 Haitians being held in Brooklyn. But appeals
in this, and a similar case pending in Florida, will drag on for more months.

There remains one place to turn: Attorney General Smith. He has discretionary
authority to ''parole'' the Haitians into the custody of responsible
organizations pending their hearings. The time has come for him to use it.

To release them may send a signal encouraging more migration. If so, let that
goad Congress to act more promptly. Not to release them etches an ever deeper
stain into the American conscience. ''After 10 months of unlawful confinement in
a harsh environment,'' Judge Carter ruled, ''justice demands swift remedial
action.'' Head and heart, he is right. Let them go.

                April 13, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

INVITATION TO GREATER ILLEGAL IMMIGRATION

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 401 words


To the Editor:

As president of the American Immigration Lawyers Association, I would like to
respond to your editorial on the proposed Immigration Reform and Control Act of
1982, introduced into Congress on March 17. v.e commend Senator Alan Simpson and
Representative Romano Mazzoli for their courage in confronting almost unsolvable
immigration issues but hope that Congress will seriously consider the
consequences of this legislation before adopting it.

After initial review, we have two fundamental reservations:

* The proposed sanctions on U.S. employers and the national identity card
requirement would attempt to control illegal immigration by adding a complex law
to enforce at a time when Congress is unwilling to give the U.S. Immigration and
Naturalization Service enough money to enforce existing laws.

One alternative would be to increase fees for services and fines for violations,
which would more than offset additional enforcement costs. Still, considering
the enormous administrative costs and potential abuse of sanctions and an
identification card, we urge that less drastic alternatives be tried first.

* We are distressed that the proposed legislation attempts to curb illegal
immigration by imposing unnecessary limitations on lawful immigration. While the
bill grants lawful status to those who have entered and have remained in the
U.S. illegally, no special quota provision is made for many qualified persons
who have waited years to immigrate lawfully.

The proposed legislation restricts the present provisions for legal immigration
based on family ties and shortages of skilled U.S.  workers. Skilled workers may
no longer be able to immigrate on the strength of U.S. Labor Department
certification that qualified and willing U.S. workers are unavailable for a
particular position.

All foreign students who are graduated from U.S. colleges would be required to
return to their home country for at least two years, regardless of immediate
needs of U.S. industry for skilled professionals in certain fields.

In short, this bill may cause more illegal immigration by unfairly restricting
legal immigration.  CHARLES C. FOSTER Houston, March 31, 1982

Around the World;
Sikh Separatist Is Barred From Visiting India

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 5, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 97 words

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, April 10


Indian immigration officials refused today to let G.S. Dhillon, a Sikh
separatist leader and United States citizen, enter the country. Mr. Dhillon, who
had been traveling to a world Sikh conference in the northern state of Punjab,
was put on a flight to Hong Kong.

Mr. Dhillon argued with Indian officials at the airport here before he was
escorted back to the Pan American World Airways plane on which he had traveled
to India.

A spokesman for the deported leader later criticized the action as
''interference in Sikh religious affairs.''

               April 7, 1982, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

PROMINENT IMMIGRANTS HONORED AT A LUNCHEON

BYLINE: By LESLIE BENNETTS

SECTION: Section B; Page 2, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 552 words


The 37 distinguished immigrants had all made it to the United States from such
countries as the Soviet Union, Cambodia and Argentina, but more than one-third
did not manage to get to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel for lunch yesterday.

Nevertheless, snow and canceled flights notwithstanding, two dozen prominent
Americans did show up to be honored by the Citizens Committee for Immigration
Reform. Their fields of achievement were diverse, ranging from science to music
to politics to finance, but the honorees all shared the experience of having
immigrated to America.

Among those honored were Felix G. Rohatyn, the Vienna-born investment banker;
Arthur E. Burns, who was born in Austria and is now Ambassador to Germany;
Pamela Harriman, a native of Britain and the wife of former Gov. W. Averell
Harriman; I. M. Pei, the architect, who was born in China; Viveca Lindfors, the
actress, who was born in Sweden, and Wassily Leontief, the Nobel Prize-winning
economist, who was born in the Soviet Union.

Several Guests Stranded

Those stranded in various airports included the keynote speaker, the Rev.
Theodore M. Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, who never made
it out of Chicago; W. Michael Blumenthal, a former Secretary of the Treasury,
who was in Detroit, and Diego Asencio, Assistant Secretary of State for Consular
Affairs, who was still in Washington.

Those in attendance got to hear Father Hesburgh's speech anyway, as delivered by
Dr. Charles Keely of the Population Council.  ''Just look at this room today,
and it is obvious what the benefits of immigration are,'' said Dr. Keely.
''Without immigration, their contributions might have been lost to us. The
lesson is clear: Far from worrying about the short-term cost of permitting legal
immigrants and refugees to come here, we should rather be worrying about the
long-term costs to United States society of a restrictionist immigration
policy.''

Several of the honorees spoke, and all expressed their gratitude to the country
that had adopted them.

Opportunity for Newcomers

''For millions of people, and for me, coming to America to live has brought a
kind of second birth into a land of hope, opportunity and promise,'' said Mrs.
Harriman. ''It is terribly important for our own inner health as a country that
we continue to offer newcomers that opportunity.''

The Citizens Committee was formed a year ago to promote ''a rational, just,
race-free immigration policy,'' explained Nina Solarz, its executive director
and the wife of Representative Stephen J. Solarz.

There was much talk of freedom, and the almost 200 guests rose to sing ''America
the Beautiful'' to music provided on a Roneat Ek, a Cambodian percussion
instrument, by Chinary Ung, a Cambodian musician who is now a professor of music
at Connecticut College. But one speaker sounded a darker note.

''What haunts any refugee who came to this country in the last 50 years is the
notion that if this country loses its confidence and soul, there is probably no
other country in the world worth immigrating to,'' Mr. Rohatyn said.

AROUND THE NATION;
Plane Hijacked to Cuba Returns Safely to Miami

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 185 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, April 5


A Delta Air Lines jet returned here safely today after being forced to Havana by
three men who doused the plane and a stewardess with gasoline.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation said the three were taken into custody by
Cuban immigration authorities. Passengers said that the hijackers, a middle-aged
man and two young men who called him ''Father,'' spoke Spanish and threatened to
set the plane on fire. The reason, one of them told a passenger, was that he did
not like the United States, the F.B.I. said.

None of the seven crew members or 93 other passengers were injured, said a
bureau spokesman, Welton Merry.  Flight 591 left Chicago at 10 P.M. Sunday and
was hijacked at 12:15 A.M. over La Belle, Fla., 22 minutes before it was due to
land in Miami, a Delta spokesman said. It landed at Jose Marti International
Airport in Havana at 1:09 A.M. and returned to Miami at 3:55 A.M.

The F.B.I. said the men were believed to have taken the gasoline aboard in jugs
in carry-on luggage.

IN BRITAIN, THE SPIRIT OF COLONIALISM LINGERS

SECTION: Section A; Page 22, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 438 words


To the Editor:

Your March 23 news story ''Britons Renew Debate on Race Problems'' must not pass
without comment. Aside from the immoral and inflammatory aspects of Scotland
Yard's insensitivity in releasing a racial breakdown of crime statistics, there
remains the more sinister theme expressed in the excerpts from an editorial in
The Daily Telegraph that must be challenged.

he fallacious reasoning behind the idea that Great Britain had somehow erred in
its judgment to allow non-white immigration is not only racist, it is also
difficult to substantiate. To believe that blacks and Asians are responsible for
''polluting'' the purity of white British society only demonstrates the
society's failure to successfully assimilate these people.

It is not a question of their ''not sharing similar values or respect,'' as the
editors of The Daily Telegraph would like to believe, but rather it is an
indication that the essential elements of British colonialism, subjugation and
exploitation, have not ceased with the dissolution of the Empire.

Facing a bleak existence in their homelands, many of these immigrants flocked to
Britain for much the same reasons as those who came to the United States in the
late 19th and early 20th centuries.  Unfortunately, the reality that greeted
them was not a pleasant one.

Quite simply, most non-whites in Britain today are faced with a choice between
governmental relief or taking one of those positions usually reserved for them,
such as cleaning public lavatories in an underground station. And even these
positions are scarce.

As the history of our own country clearly demonstrates, a high unemployment
concentration in an urban area will also result in a corresponding rate of
crime. But such crime is usually directed against those living in that
community. One need only examine the plight of minorities in places like Leeds
or Birmingham to see that the victims of non-white crime in Britain today are
the non-whites themselves.

Sadly, Britain is simply suffering what all colonial powers have suffered, the
payment for the sins of its past. If one studies the plight of minority groups
in this country, the scenario is much the same.  ANTHONY D. CAVALUZZI Glens
Falls, N.Y., March 24, 1982 The writer, assistant professor of English at
Adirondack Community College, has studied and taught in Great Britain.

RACE FOR GOVERNOR OF HAWAII THREATENS DEMOCRATS

BYLINE: By WALLACE TURNER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 17, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 947 words

DATELINE: HONOLULU, April 1


The power of the Democratic coalition that has ruled Hawaii since 1963 appears
to be seriously threatened this year by a three-way battle for the governorship.

The three-way contest reflects factionalism within the Democratic Party. Also,
the heavy immigration here in recent years has been dominated by voters who tend
to be Republican.

Political life is different in the land of sun-baked beaches, cane fields and
swaying palms. Most people who move from state to state on the mainland tend to
be job hunters who would be likely to vote Democratic, but new arrivals in
Hawaii tend to be upper-income whites from the mainland who vote Republican.

Important mainland political issues sometimes have reverse effects here, 2,400
miles from San Francisco. For example, President Reagan's big military budget
will be an asset to the Republican nominee for Governor of Hawaii, where the
military provides $1 billion in state income.

Contrasts With Mainland

Also, the February unemployment rate was 5.5 percent in Hawaii, as against 8.8
percent nationally. While sugar and pineapple, the big agricultural crops,
continue their long-time downward cycle, tourism continues to provide thousands
of low-paying jobs for the unskilled members of this state's work force.

Gov. George Ariyoshi, the first American of Japanese ancestry to be elected
Governor of any state, is expected to be the Democratic nominee for re-election
to what would be his third term.

As the inheritor of the mantle of the late John A. Burns, who organized the
successful Democratic coalition in the territorial days 30 years ago, Mr.
Ariyoshi, 56 years old, leads an organization that may be losing ground because
of immigration from the mainland.  Both Gerald R. Ford in 1976 and Ronald Reagan
in 1980 came close to carrying Hawaii, although both ignored the state in their
Presidential campaigns because of its small electoral vote and its strong
Democratic Party tradition.

Frank F. Fasi, 61, a three-term Mayor of Honolulu who was defeated two years ago
by the incumbent, Eileen Anderson, an Ariyoshi political protegee, intends to
run for governor as an independent candidate although he has been a Democrat
throughout his previous political career.

That strategy will keep Mr. Fasi out of the Democratic primary on Sept. 18,
where he would spend a lot of money, and where he lost to Mr. Ariyoshi in 1974
and 1978.

Likely Republican Candidate

State Senator D.G. Anderson, 52, is expected to be the Republican nominee for
Governor. He has been in the Hawaii Legislature from Honolulu districts for 16
years and was defeated twice for mayor of Honolulu by Mr. Fasi. He owns
businesses including a fashionable restaurant and a camera store.

Filing will close in August and there is no indication of serious opposition for
either the Governor or Senator Anderson.  Before this, Republicans have done
badly in statewide campaigns in Hawaii. Senator Anderson agreed that the
Republican Party's image here has been that it primarily represented business
interests and the ''Haoles,'' the Hawaiian word for Caucasians.

''We've always been described by the Democrats as the Haole party, and to a
large part that has been true,'' said Senator Anderson in an interview in his
Capitol office overlooking the grounds of Iolani Palace, where the Hawaiian
monarchs ruled until 1893.

''But if you look at the changing Hawaii, that's what it's changing to,'' he
said, referring to the upward surge of Caucasian population here.

State statisticians said today that as Hawaii's population grew from 499,769 in
1950 to 964,691 in 1980, the Caucasian population grew from 22.9 percent to 33
percent of the total. From 1970 to 1980, they added, Caucasians increased from
228,913 to 318,770 in Hawaii.

Wide Mixture of Ancestry

A six-footer, with the dark skin of his Hawaiian and Portuguese ancestors, Mr.
Anderson also is a mixture of Norwegian, English, Scottish and Irish, he said.
Governor Ariyoshi, who also was born here, is the son of Japanese immigrants.
Former Mayor Fasi was born in Connecticut and is of Italian descent.

A population study published recently by the Hawaii Department of Planning and
Economic Development put the state's household population at 930,271. The study
found the state's racial composition to be 26.3 percent Caucasian, 23.3 percent
Japanese American, 11.2 percent Filipino, 18.9 percent Hawaiian and
part-Hawaiian, 5.1 percent Chinese and the remainder Korean, black, Puerto
Rican, Samoan and other groups.

Each of the three candidates has hired a Mainland consultant.  Former Mayor Fasi
has hired Joseph R. Cerrell of Los Angeles. Mr.  Fasi said he wanted to have at
least $1 million for the campaign.

As in earlier years, Governor Ariyoshi will use Joe Napolitan of Springfield,
Mass. The Governor reported early this year that he had more than $1 million in
hand. He hopes to raise more.

Senator Anderson said he hoped to have $1.2 million to spend. He has hired
Stuart Spencer, of Los Angeles.  Thus $3 million to $4 million will be raised
and spent in the gubernatorial campaign this year. When asked where it would
come from, Mr. Fasi replied:

''Well, we get it from the same place that every politician gets money from -
those who have done, are doing or hope to do business with government. Those are
the facts of life. I wish the system could be changed. Show me how.''

                March 30, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

ILLEGAL-ENTRY CURBS THAT HURT CITIZENS

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 390 words


To the Editor:

We are disappointed that you endorse employer sanctions as a means of
''controlling our border'' (editorial March 18). In all likelihood, such
sanctions and a worker identification system, proposed last week in a bipartisan
immigration bill, will not decrease undocumented immigration and will lead to an
increase in discrimination against Hispanic-Americans.

At first blush, a law that punishes employers for hiring undocumented aliens
sounds like a reasonable way to curb illegal immigration. If employers won't
hire aliens, aliens won't come here anymore. But it hasn't worked that way in
the approximately 16 states which have employer-sanction laws, and it won't work
that way if it become Federal law.

The beleaguered Immigration and Naturalization Service will have the
responsibility to enforce the law, but unless its resources are increased
dramatically, the agency simply won't be able to - with or without a new
identification system.

The (Simpson-Mazzoli) bill would require the development of a new ID system
within three years, the specifics of which will be worked out by a special
commission. That will probably mean an expansion of the largely thriving black
market in forged documents. Someone who wants a United States birth certificate
badly enough - because it will enable him to get the document that will enable
him to get a job - will find a way to get one.

While the fine points of our new identification system are being ironed out,
Hispanic-American job applicants will bear the brunt of the employer sanctions
law.

We will have the burden of proving that we are American citizens when we apply
for jobs, and if an employer isn't satisfied with the ''proof'' we provide - or
if he just plain doesn't want to hire someone Hispanic - he can turn us away and
throw up the shield of employer sanctions as his excuse.

A government that proposes employer sanctions looks like a government that is
serious about ''controlling'' its borders. But there is little reason to think
that a new law will change an old, tacitly accepted policy: For the most part,
United States officials ignore aliens who are here illegally because their labor
supports so many of our industries.
ANTONIA HERNANDEZ, Associate Counsel, Mexican American Legal Defense and
Education Fund, Washington, March 19, 1982

                March 23, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

PRIEST FIGHTS ON BEHALF OF HALF-AMERICAN CHILDREN

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 21, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 841 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22


They are called the ''dust of life'' children, half-American, half-Asian boys
and girls born of American servicemen.

''These are our children,'' said the Rev. Alfred Keane, a Roman Catholic priest
who has worked with half-American children in Korea for 24 years. ''They endure
scorn and ridicule because they look American, and our legislators here in
Washington have now chosen to ignore their pain.''

What has stirred the anger of Father Keane and others is a new immigration bill,
sponsored by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Representative
Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat of Kentucky, that places sharp restrictions on the
entry of these children into the United States.

''The bill totally misses the point that these are American children,'' said
Representative Stewart B. McKinney, a Connecticut Republican who has sponsored
his own measure. It would allow substantial numbers of children of American
servicemen to receive priority status in seeking permanent immigrant visas.

Immigration Limited to 2,000

The Simpson-Mazzoli bill, which has been widely praised for the way it seeks to
limit large-scale illegal immigration, deals only briefly with half-American, or
Amerasian, children.

It says that, over the next five years, a total of 2,000 young people a year,
from the age of 14 through 21, may be admitted to the United States for
adoption. They must prove that they were fathered by a serviceman in Korea,
Vietnam, Cambodia or Laos, that they are subject to significant discrimination
and that they are orphans.

Under the current Immigration and Naturalization Act, Amerasian children are
given ''nonpreferential'' status, making it nearly impossible for them to be
admitted to the United States. In recent years, only a handful of such children
have entered the country.

Aides to Mr. Mazzoli and Mr. Simpson indicated that there was some disagreement
about how to deal with the Amer-a@sian issue. Senator Simpson wanted nothing in
the bill about it, they said, while Mr.  Mazzoli sought to address the problem
in a limited way.

The aides also said there were concerns about opening the floodgates to the
children. Estimates vary, but there may be as many as 80,000 Amerasian children
in Korea and Southeast Asia, including 25,000 in Vietnam.

Reasonable Age Limit Seen

Although Father Keane and Mr. McKinney say that the measure leaves an increasing
number of Amerasians over 21 with scant hope of emigrating to the United States,
Congressional aides who helped write the bill said that 21 seemed to be a
reasonable age limit.

Critics of the Simpson-Mazzoli bill also said it was unlikely that large numbers
of teen-agers would be adopted by American parents, as the bill stipulates. But
Congressional aides said experience indicated that adoption would be a
relatively minor problem.

''Frankly, we felt that the McKinney bill was too broad and too open-ended,'' an
aide to Mr. Mazzoli said.  The bill sponsored by Mr. McKinney, which has 165
co-sponsors in the House, would give the abandoned children a visa preference as
the offspring of American citizens. Moreover, Mr. McKinney says the bill would
not place the children on the welfare rolls because it requires that a sponsor
be legally and financially responsible for five years.

A similar measure has been sponsored in the Senate by Senator Jeremiah A.
Denton, an Alabama Republican and former Navy pilot who spent more than seven
years as a prisoner of war in North Vietnam.

Father Keane, a Boston-born Maryknoll priest who now spends most of his time on
Capitol Hill seeking support for the McKinney and Denton measures, said that
Amerasian children were shunned, ignored, not allowed education benefits and
treated as nonpersons in such countries as Korea.

''These are our own flesh and blood,'' he said. ''I don't think you can hear the
stories and see the pictures and not become involved.'' Father Keane noted that
France, after withdrawing its troops from Indochina in 1954, opened its doors to
virtually any child of French and Indochinese parents born during the war, and
financially supported up to the age of 18 those who remained with their mothers.

Many Amerasian children had fathers who had long relationships with the mothers,
the priest said, and they often carried pictures of their fathers.

''Asking these children to actually prove that they're objects of
discrimination, as the immigration bill says, is ridiculous,'' he said. ''You
think a country like Vietnam will let them out if they have to prove
discrimination?''

Mr. McKinney said he would seek to amend the immigration bill and use every
parliamentary possibility to give Amerasian children priority as immigrants and
allow them to enter in far higher numbers than allowed by the Simpson-Mazzoli
bill.

                March 21, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

The Nation;
An Immigration Proposal That Gets Somewhere

BYLINE: By Michael Wright and Caroline Rand Herron

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 251 words


President Ford, President Carter and the 96th Congress all studied immigration
policy. So did President Reagan who, like Mr. Carter, issued legislative
proposals. Last week, the 97th Congress went further, producing an actual reform
bill.

The measure, introduced in the Senate by Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming,
and in the House by Romano L. Mazzoli, a Kentucky Democrat, would offer
permanent resident status to those who entered the country illegally before 1978
and temporary status, which could be upgraded after two years, to those who
entered before 1980.  Those arriving after that, Mr. Mazzoli said, ''would have
to go back home.'' The Reagan Administration had proposed a 10-year waiting
period, which critics said would be too long to be effective.

The Simpson-Mazzoli bill would come down harder on employers who knowingly hired
illegal workers than the Administration, subjecting those with even a single
illegal employee to fines of up to $2,000 and six-month prison terms. Mr. Reagan
had sought to limit comparable sanctions to employers with four or more illegal
workers.  The bill would also require the President to develop a ''universal
employment authorization'' system to determine a worker's eligibility, something
Mr. Reagan opposes. Instead of the President's guest-worker program, it would
''streamline'' existing programs admitting laborers from Mexico, Jamaica and
other countries.
