               February 15, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

WHAT AN ETHIOPIAN MUST DO TO PROVE DESERVING OF ASYLUM

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 541 words


To the Editor:

Assistant Secretary of State Chester A. Crocker's letter (Feb. 1) charging
Anthony Lewis with ''gross inaccuracies and distortions'' in his column on the
deportation of Ethiopians (Jan. 4) is devoid of evidence supporting Mr.
Crocker's assertions.

Mr. Lewis's column demonstrates the glaring inconsistency of our U.N.
Ambassador's scathing condemnation of human-rights abuses and political
repression in Ethiopia in light of the Immigration and Naturalization Service's
demand, during the same month, that thousands of Ethiopians depart this country
within 30 days.

Instead of elucidating this paradox, Mr. Crocker's letter served only to
underscore the hypocritical treatment Ethiopians seeking refuge in the United
States will face. He makes this alarming statement:

''Although the human-rights picture in Ethiopia is still very bleak, the level
of chaos and violence in most of the country has declined since the period of
the Red Terror and the other postrevolutionary excesses. It is now possible for
Ethiopians who are not on their Government's 'wanted' list to return without
fear of falling victim to persecution.''

While admitting the bleakness of the ''human-rights picture'' in Ethiopia,
circumstances Ambassador Kirkpatrick more aptly termed ''savagery,'' Mr. Crocker
pronounces that, in order to be granted political asylum, an Ethiopian must
prove that he is on the Government's ''wanted'' list.

It is absurd to maintain that such an identifiable list exists, and ludicrous to
think that any refugee should have had the foresight to have secured a copy of
it. Such a high standard is patently unfair and discriminatory, and it
definitely overshoots Mr. Crocker's stated goal of bringing the status of
Ethiopians ''in line with that of most other nationalities.''

Are Cubans, Russians, Poles or other East Europeans who also flee
Soviet-inspired political repression required to show inclusion on a ''wanted''
list of their government in order to obtain political asylum? Most decidedly
not. Such a standard for determining ''a well-founded fear of persecution'' has
no basis in the law or in the I.N.S. regulations or operating instructions.
Moreover, adherence to such a standard would violate this country's
international commitments under the United Nations Protocol Relating to the
Status of Refugees.

Rather than contradicting Mr. Lewis's article, Mr. Crocker's letter exemplifies
the ''particular political callousness'' of our Government toward Ethiopians
characterized by Mr. Lewis.

It is, to say the least, difficult to explain why unusually high standards are
set for Ethiopians seeking refuge in the United States. It was also difficult to
explain the recent reinstatement of tax-exempt status for racially
discriminatory schools. However, in that case, the President had the courage to
admit and seek to correct his mistake.

The case of the Ethiopians is a terrible mistake yet in the making. We pray this
Government has the strength to undo it before an unspeakable toll is paid in
human suffering.
C. O'NEILL BROWN, VIVIANE EISENBERG, New York, Feb. 9, 1982

The writers are lawyers; Miss Eisenberg heads the New York City Bar
Association's Committee on Immigration and Nationality Law.

               February 14, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

WHO ARE THE TRUE MODERNISTS?

BYLINE: By LEO BERSANI; Leo Bersani is chairman of the French department at the
Univ ersity of California at Berkeley. His most recent bo oks are ''Baudelaire
andFreud'' and ''The Death of Stephane Mallarme.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 9, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1718 words


ALL THAT IS SOLID MELTS INTO AIR Th e Experienc e of Modernity.  By Marshall
Berman.  384 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.50.

MARSHALL BERMAN loves the Bronx. At the end of this occasionally endearing but
intellectually porous book, Berman, professor of political science at the
Graduate Center, City University of New York, proposes if not a solution, at
least a kind of cultural palliative for the urban blight of which the beloved
borough of his birth has become an infamous model. Berman's revenge on that
monstrosity devised by Robert Moses, the Cross-Bronx Expressway, would be a
gigantic mural, ''executed in a number of radically different styles'' and
painted onto eight miles of brick and concrete retaining walls running alongside
the expressway. This community art work would defy the ghastly present with a
portrayal of the Bronx's glorious history back to the great waves of immigration
at the beginning of this century. At the end of the Bronx mural (at ''the
boundary between the Bronx and the world''), there would be an enormous
ceremonial arch, which ''would be circular and inflatable, suggesting both an
automobile tire and a bagel. When fully pumped up, it would look as indigestibly
hard as a bagel, but ideal as a tire for a fast getaway; when soft, it would
appear leaky and dangerous as a tire but, as a bagel, inviting to settle down
and eat.''

Forget the vaguely sickening quality of that soggy bageled arch.  Forget the
threat to traffic safety which such a presumably gripping mural would create.
Forget the fact that this ambitious work would be enjoyed mostly by
non-Bronxites speeding through that borough on their way to communities probably
less afflicted with poverty, ruins and crime. The issue of the mural's audience
gets lost in Berman's excited anticipation of its hugely beneficent cultural
effect. Like Rafael Ferrer's ''Puerto Rican Sun'' (an enormous arch leading to
the Fox Street Community Garden, an arch sculptured in steel and evoking ''a
tropical paradise lost''), the Bronx mural could help people ''who are going
through a crucial, excruciating passage in their history - and in ours - get a
grip on where they are going and who they are.'' ''I hope (Ferrer's gateway) is
helping them,'' Berman adds. ''I know it is helping me. And it seems to me that
this is what modernism is all about.'' And that, I'm afraid, is what Marshall
Berman's book is all about.  The little silliness about a Bronx Expressway mural
comes at the end of a very ambitious argument about modernity, an argument which
is at once simple and incoherent. According to Berman, the modern age ''has lost
touch with the roots of its own modernity.'' Even the work of the most brilliant
contemporary artists and thinkers suggests that '' ... we have missed or broken
the connection between our culture and our lives.'' Compared with 19th-century
modernists, the modernists of today give us ''a radical flattening of
perspective and shrinkage of imaginative range.'' Nineteenth-century writers
''were simultaneously enthusiasts and enemies of modern life, wrestling
inexhaustibly with its ambiguities and contradictions.'' They had more depth
than we have today, more ''empathy with, and faith in, their fellow modern men
and women,'' a greater sense of ''modern man as a subject - as a living being
capable of response, judgment and action in and on the world.'' In the ''bleak
context'' of recent tendencies to isolate modernist culture from the social
techniques and processes of modernization, Berman proposes that we return to
those thinkers of the 19th century who ''experienced modernity as a whole,'' and
who provide the model for a ''dynamic and dialectical modernism'' opposed to the
compartmentalized, dehumanized modernism of today. Thus Berman will offer us
readings of Goethe, Marx, Baudelaire, as well as of several 19th-century Russian
writers, in the faith that '' ... going back can be a way to go forward: that
remembering the modernisms of the nineteenth century can give us the vision and
courage to create the modernisms of the twenty-first.'' It is refreshing to be
reminded of the inescapable ties between the realities of industrial
modernization and a cultural modernism which, as Berman writes, has sometimes
presented itself as untouched, unsullied, by such realities. And it is
enlivening to have a reading of Marx which proposes that, '' ... for all Marx's
invective against the bourgeois economy, he embraces enthusiastically the
personality structure that this economy has produced.'' I should add that Berman
is good at narrative: the accounts of the building of St. Petersburg, and of the
careers of Baron Haussmann in Paris and of Robert Moses in New York make for
enjoyable reading. Finally, there is, suffusing nearly every page of ''All That
Is Solid Melts Into Air'' (the title comes from ''The Communist Mani festo''), a
kind of intense good will, a sincerity, a decency and an enthusiasm for certain
aspects of modernity (es pecially city streets) which cannot but touch us.

Unfortunately, there is much more (or less ) than enthusiasm and good will in
this book. There is, first of all, the quality of thought displayed in such
remarks as: ''Rousseau, as everyone knows, was a deeply troubled man.'' ''Drawn
impatiently toward new realms of thought and action, (Faust) has come to feel
(Gretchen's) needs and fears as more and more of a drag.'' ''If we had to
nominate a first modernist, Baudelaire would surely be the man.'' ''But the
clash and fusion of modernities goes on even in the most fully modernized
sectors of today's world; the Petersburg influenza infuses the air of New York,
of Milan, of Stockholm, of Tokyo, of Tel Aviv, and it blows on and on.''

Furthermore, ''All That Is Solid Melts Into Air'' is not without slipshod
judgments. What can it possibly mean to say of ''structuralism'' (whatever
Berman may mean by that) that it ''simply wipes the question of modernity -
along with all other questions about the self and history - off the map''? And
even the most unconvinced reader of Michel Foucault's efforts to describe how we
can resist the moves of oppressive power in society could not claim that '' ...
Foucault denies the possibility of any sort of freedom, either outside (such
institutions as prisons, hospitals, and asylums) or within their interstices.''

Such unconsidered pronouncements on contemp orary thought seriously weaken
Berman's thesis. The argument for the contemporary relevance of a certain
19th-century modernism depends o n the demonstrated inadequacies of more recent
versions of moder nism to modern life, inadequacies which are asserted but never
ser iously studied. But evenin making this objection, we are perhaps bein g too
indulgent toward Berman's enterprise. If (a big ''if'' I shoul d add)
20th-century modernism is without either a sense of ''dept h'' or a sense of
''modern man as a subject,'' then that is our situation, and no amount of
quoting from Goethe is going to cha nge it. I don't mean that we should
therefore stop reading Goethe and Baudelaire, and I don't mean that our
situation will never be c hanged. I do mean that the modernism which Marshall
Berman deplores is aware of the modernism which he admires. Furthermore a cer
tain repudiation of the humanistic rhetoric of ''depth,'' of ''wholen ess'' and
of ''unity'' in human life cannot be dealt with simply by an admiring or
polemicalrepetition of that rhetoric.

Berman takes that rhetoric as an ahistorical given, and he uses it to judge both
those thinkers who have attempted to remove themselves from the assumptions
underlying such terms, and those who invented, or at least agreed to, those
assumptions. Needless to say, the latter come off best in such a comparison.
History, however, gets lost in this unquestioned promotion of a particular
humanistic ideology to a teleological status in modern history.

The truth is, of course, that Berman simply prefers an optimistic humanism to -
whatever it is that we may have today. That preference probably makes him a more
likeable fellow than many rigidly ''postmodernist theoreticians,'' but it is,
alas, no substitute for a study of those historical conditions which allow, at
different moments, for the emergence of different sorts of human discourse.
Berman gives us a parody of the already parodistic rage for relevance prevalent
in the counterculture of the 60's. The failure to take seriously the particular
conditions of particular discourses leads to that extraordinary statement about
the 19th-century Petersburg ''influenza'' blowing ''on and on'' in all the
capitals of the contemporary world, as well as to the equally astonishing
identification of the construction site of the Bronx Expressway with the
economic development project in ''Faust, Part II'', or of New York City with the
''Baudelairean forest of symbols.''

But Berman moves with great ease between literature and society; he even speaks
of artists as the ''unacknowledged legislators of the world.'' To refute such
cultural pieties might lead us to some rather difficult arguments. It might, for
example, bring us to identify the power of literature with its legislative
impotence, to argue that its critical (and political) force consists not in the
forms of life which it deceptively proposes, but rather in the persistence with
which it demonstrates the problematic nature of meaning in human statements.
Literature may thereby make us wary of the coercive intentions to which all
legislative discourses are perhaps inherently congenial.

But to pursue such lines of thought is of course viewed with great suspicion in
many quarters of our society. The publication of Marshall Berman's book - and,
even more, the serious and generally favorable reviews which it has already
received - are interesting mainly as yet another sign of the current state of
thought in America. One result of the lazy and complacent dismissal of difficult
thinking by certain cultural conservatives in the United States is the attention
which we are expected to give to ''All That Is Solid Melts Into Air.'' And there
is no sign that the Anglo-Saxon intellectual ''influenza'' emanating from this
book will do anything but, in Marshall Berman's entertainingly inelegant
language, ''blow on and on.''

Catholic Migrants

SECTION: Section 7; Page 31, Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 205 words


To the Editor:

This letter is in reference to the review of the book ''American Catholics''
(Nov. 29) by Garry Wills. In the third paragraph Mr.  Wills states that ''Puerto
Ricans, Mexicans and Cubans continue the story of Catholic immigration.''uerto
Rico was ceded by Spain to the United States in 1898, and American citizenship
was granted to Puerto Ricans in 1917. Therefore it is no more accurate to speak
of Puerto Ricans who move to the continental United States as immigrants than it
would be to speak of Americans who move from one state to another as immigrants.
The term that should be used to describe migration by citizens of one country
within the borders of that country is ''migrants.'' Unfortunately, there are
large numbers of people in the United States, many of them well educated, who
believe that Puerto Rico is a foreign country.  Associating Puerto Ricans with
true immigrants only helps to perpetuate that belief.  RAFAEL JUAN IGARTUA Glen
Burnie, Md.

Buffalo Hearing Put Off for 5 Suspected of Helping I. R. A.

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 2; Page 29, Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 149 words

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Feb. 12


A hearing on charges of trying to enter the United States illegally was delayed
today for five men suspected of intending to purchase arms for the Irish
Republican Army.

After the five were arrested at the Canadian border last weekend, Benedict J.
Ferro, who is in charge of the Buffalo office of the Immigration and
Naturalization Service, said there was ''substantial evidence'' that the men
were acting as agents of the I.R.A.

William Truesdale, deputy director of the Buffalo immigration office, said one
of the defendants, previously identified as Michael Weir, 35 years old, of
Belfast in Northern Ireland, actually is Desmond Ellis, 29, of Dublin.

The other four defendants were identified as Edward Howell, 34, of Belfast; and
William O'Neill, 29; James Kelly, 41, and William Gilroy, 36, all of St.
Catharines, Ontario, and formerly of Belfast.

TWO VISA DISPUTES ANNOY AND INTRIGUE INDIA

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 722 words

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Feb. 10


The award of a United States entry visa to an Indian advocate of Sikh separatism
and the denial of a Soviet visa to an Indian Communist who holds the Order of
Lenin have raised indignation and speculation here in the last week.

The Government's anger was aroused by news that Jagjit Singh Chauhan, the chief
spokesman for a movement that advocates a separate homeland for the Sikh
religious minority, had been allowed to enter the United States from Canada.

Foreign Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao summoned the United States Ambassador, Harry
S. Barnes, last weekend to convey the extreme disappointment of the Indian
Government that Mr. Chauhan had been allowed to enter the United States despite
an earlier notification by India that his passport was no longer valid. Mr. Rao
reportedly expressed surprise that in light of the American Civil War support
could be given to an avowed secessionist.

United States officials here and in Washington notified the Indian Government
that although Mr. Chauhan's entry had originally been blocked, the objection to
his entry was waived on humanitarian grounds because he told United States
immigration officials that he was going to Houston for treatment of a heart
problem.

Meeting Termed Stiffly Formal

Mr. Rao reportedly also questioned why the United States had not specifically
barred Mr. Chauhan from taking part in political activity, as has Canada, where
Mr. Chauhan is a resident. The Foreign Minister was told that there was no
provision under United States law for such a limitation.

During the meeting with the United States Ambassador, which was characterized as
stiffly formal by both sides, the Indian Foreign Minister said the decision to
admit Mr. Chauhan was ''a new irritant in the already strained relations between
the two Governments.''

The case of the Soviet visa denial to a staunch pro-Soviet activist has not
drawn any official response, but the action is regarded as a significant
indicator of Soviet attitudes toward the Government of Prime Minister Indira
Gandhi. The man denied the visa is S.A. Dange, an 83-year-old Communist whose
pro-Soviet loyalties go back 60 years. He had intended to attend the Havana
meeting of the World Federation of Trade Unions, of which he is a co-founder and
a vice president. He had hoped to change planes in Moscow but was thwart ed when
the SovietEmbassy refused him a visa.

To some here, this decision appears to signal a retreat from recent Soviet
policies of support for the Indian Government. Last autumn Mr. Dange broke away
from the Communist Party of India to form the All India Communist Party, which
threw its support entirely behind Mrs. Gandhi.

A Visit to Moscow

At that time Indian analysts and Western diplomats thought that Mr. Dange had
Soviet sponsorship for his action because he formed the new party after a long
visit to Moscow and Eastern Europe. The assumption was that while Moscow had
varying degrees of responsibility toward the two established Indian Communist
factions that opposed Mrs.  Gandhi's domestic policies, their foremost
obligation was to her Government, which con sistently supported Soviet positions
on Afghanistan a nd Southeast Asia.

This belief was further strengthened when Soviet dignitaries attended the first
meeting of a group called the Friends of the Soviet Union, which was set up by
Mrs. Gandhi's Congress Party to wean away the flow of patronage from Moscow that
had previously gone to Indo-Soviet Cultural Society, a front organization
dominated by traditional Indian Communists. Mr. Dange supported the creation of
the new group.

Since then, the two major Communist factions appear to have narrowed their
differences, which go back 18 years and which were aggravated in 1975 when one
wing supported Mrs. Gandhi's declaration of emergency and the other opposed her.
Last month both of the factions backed an inconclusive national strike against
Government policies, and in this they appeared to have some lukewarm support
from Moscow.

              February 11, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
ELLIS ISLAND SOUTH

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

SECTION: Section A; Page 35, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 898 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 10


The exodus of desperate Haitians to South Florida has raised hackles, fears and
some decent sympathies. So many gripping issues are entangled that there is a
tendency for outrage to narrow into lines that never meet. That can't ease
matters, let alone produce solutions.

There is, in fact, a dilemma that neither the Coast Guard, the Immigration
Service, liberal indignation, xenophobia nor economic and social resentment can
handle on their own.

Here is a glaring case where the idea of ''new federalism'' directly confronts
basic national interests in many ways, including foreign policy, protection of
constitutional rights, humane values and the under standable irritation of a
relatively small community forced to bea r the burden of a problem stemming from
America's role in the world.

In Haiti, the New York Times correspondent Jo Thomas has reported, ''Miami''
means the U.S., land of opportunity. It isn't really America's fault that things
are so bad in the hemisphere's second oldest republic. But the U.S. cannot and
does not want to change the fact that it is the best-off country and thus an
inevitable magnet for miserable neighbors.

There is no way to move out of the North American neighborhood, as there was a
way, however painful, to move out of Southeast Asia. So the fact of attraction
has to be faced, along with the Republic's historic pride in accepting ''your
tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free.''

The Administration has seized on the test of political asylum as a way of
sorting out who can stay and who must be deported. Given American tradition, it
is an arbitrary filter to provide an excuse for limiting the numbers of Haitians
accepted and selecting the better educated.

The attempts to apply the test have led not only to anomalies but to procedures
that threaten the supremacy of constitutional guarantees on due process, a
danger to citizens as well as aliens. A 38-year-old lawyer on the staff of the
Depart ment of Justice, RichardAllen Marshall Jr., recently quit his job her e
because, he said, he could no longer in conscience defend the Gove rnment's
position.

Besides, as Mr. Marshall and many other troubled Floridians point out, however
hard it may be to define the difference between a political refugee and a person
simply seeking a better chance to work and survive, the test isn't being applied
with common fairness. Why is it taken so much for granted, they ask, that
Cubans, Vietnamese, and now Poles meet that measure, but Haitians probably
don't? Does political asylum only apply to people from Communist states but not
to those fleeing equally if not more repressive dictatorships?

An easy conclusion is that discrimination against Haitians represents endemic
racism. That may be a factor, but it clearly isn't the whole story.

For one thing, there is a last-straw element in the hostility to Haitian
migration into Miami. The area has absorbed over 100,000 Cubans who streamed in
from Mariel in a period of three months, putting a tremendous strain on the
community. A sharp rise in the crime rate aggravated tensions, though it is
easing now and in any case it is generally accepted that serious crime here is
almost all drug-related and has little to do with refugees. Resistence to
newcomers, however, is immensely increased, especially at a time of high
unemployment.

Less openly expressed, but obviously important, are the cultural and social
difficulties presented by the Haitians. Older migration waves brought urban
dwellers with some knowledge of at least the rudiments of modern society.
Current arrivals tend to be totally unskilled illiterates, speaking an arcane
language, Creole, that scarcely anyone else knows.

A country big enough and adaptable enough to settle large numbers of Vietnamese
could cope with these people, now estimated at 60,000 in the U.S. But the Miami
area's population of 1.7 million, nearly double that of a generation ago, balks
at being saddled with the whole responsibility.

So the Immigration Service has packed new Haitian migrants into a detention
center where normal standards of justice aren't being applied, and the Coast
Guard is trying to intercept new arrivals at the cost sometimes of their lives.
Every part of the operation has some justification, and every part of it is in a
way disgraceful.

This is a national problem -Miami's only because it is the nearest U.S. city to
Haiti - and it requires a national decision on refugees that can't be evaded by
legalisms about who is and who is not ''political.''

And it is a long-term problem of how to live next door to desperation. We can
try to build cruel and costly barriers, undermining our own standards, but we
can't ignore it.

The unlimited immigration of America's first century and a half is no longer
realistic. Now the U.S. cannot avoid some responsibility for helping people
nearby to make life tolerable in their own homes if we want to avoid the
shameful dilemma Miami is having to face with hapless Haitians.

COUNTRY: HAITI (96%); UNITED STATES (95%); SOUTH-EASTERN ASIA (79%); NORTH
AMERICA (79%);

STATE: FLORIDA, USA (95%);

CITY: MIAMI, FL, USA (93%);

GEOGRAPHIC: ;UNITED STATES; HAITI; MIAMI (FLA); FLORIDA  HAITI (96%); UNITED

AROUND THE WORLD;
5 Irish Nationals Are Arrested by U.S.

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section A; Page 9, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 166 words

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Feb. 8


Immigration officials said today that five Irish nationals were arrested over
the weekend for attempting to enter the United States from Canada to purchase
weapons.

Immigration officials said the five, including three who were landed immigrants
in Canada, were stopped at the Whirlpool Bridge in Lewiston, N.Y., just north of
Niagara Falls, late Saturday night.

Bill Truesdale, assistant immigration director, said, ''At the time they were
arrested they were found to be in po ssession of evidence which reflects their
purpose, to purchase arm s and ammunition to return to Northern Ireland.''

Officials declined to identify the five, but said additional details would be
made available later. The arrests came just over two weeks after two Irish
Republican Army supporters, Owen Carron and Danny Morrison, were arrested as
they attempted to enter the United States illegally from Canada.

3 ARE INVESTIGATED IN THEFT OF EXAMS

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 399 words

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2


The Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service is studying the arres ts of
three pers ons and the seizure of stolen college admissions tests that they bel
ieve are part of a Taiwan-based ring dealing in English-language examinations
used by Taiwanese to get into American schools.

The arrests and subsequent investigation were made by the San Francisco Police,
but Robert Moschorak, an investigator with the immigration service here, said
today that his agency was studying the case because one of those charged might
be an illegal Taiwanese alien.

He also said the service would attempt to determine whether the stolen college
and graduate school test materials had been used to help aliens remain in the
United States on student visas they had obtained by cheating.

The case began last Oct. 17 when proctors at a test center here called the
police after noticing a Taiwanese student cutting pages out of his test booklet
for the Graduate Record Examination, a standard test used to determine
eligibility for admission to graduate school.

Arrests at Testing Center

The student, Che-tang Weng, 26 years old, was arrested as he left the testing
room. Jean Chen, 29, also a Taiwanese student, was arrested and charged with
stealing her test booklet at the same examination. They face charges of grand
theft, possession of stolen property, unlawfully obtaining trade secrets and
conspiracy.

Jean Seto, a native of Taiwan who is a naturalized American citizen, was
arrested later after the police seized eight cartons of testing materials at her
home, where Miss Chen was also living.

The police said the material included copies of the Graduate Record Examination,
the Law School Aptitude Test, and the Test of English as a Foreign Language.
Mrs. Seto was charged with possession of stolen property and with unlawfully
obtaining trade secrets.

Mrs. Seto's attorney, J. Farragher Campbell, acknowledged that his client did
''distribute booklets and exams'' for the Merica Assocation, an organization in
Taipai, Taiwan, that assisted students in studying or seeking to study in the
United States, but he contended that it was ''no different from a bar review
course where you get old test booklets.''

               February 1, 1982, Monday, Late City Final Edition

PERILED ETHIOPIANS CAN STILL STAY HERE

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 408 words


To the Editor:

Anthony Lewis's Jan. 4 column, suggesting that the Reagan Administration was
embarking on a wholesale deportation of Ethiopian refugees (''Hypocrisy Wins
Again''), contains some serious inaccuracies and distortions.

In fact, the recent change in the treatment of Ethiopians by the Immigration and
Naturalization Service only brings their status into line with that of most
other nationalities in the United States. Up until last summer, Ethiopians were
allowed to remain and work in the U.S., even if their visas had expired, under
what is called ''extended voluntary departure status.''

This special status was adopted following the Ethiopian revolution in 1974 -
during the period of Ethiopia's ''Red Terror,'' when large numbers of Ethiopians
were being killed in both Government-sponsored and random violence. At that
time, the State Department recommended to the Immigration and Naturalization
Service that Ethiopians in the United States not be forced to return to Ethiopia
while these conditions persisted.

Such voluntary departure programs have been adopted only rarely.  This policy
provided for humane treatment of thousands of Ethiopians in this country as a
temporary response to conditions in Ethiopia at that time.

Although the human-rights picture in Ethiopia is still very bleak, the level of
chaos and violence in most of the country has declined since the period of the
Red Terror and the other post-revolutionary excesses. It is now possible for
Ethiopians who are not on their Government's ''wanted'' list to return without
fear of falling victim to persecution.

Ethiopians who are bona fide refugees (i.e., those who have been admitted into
the United States as refugees from processing centers overseas) are in no danger
of being asked to leave. Neither are those Ethiopians who do have well-founded
fear of persecution from the Government should they return.

All applications for political asylum are reviewed on a case-bycase basis;
asylum is granted to those applicants who do show a wellfounded fear of
persecution.

Ethiopians who are here for eduction, medical treatment or whatever may also
stay as long as their visas remain valid. Those who are affected by the
suspension of extended voluntary departure status for Ethiopians are those who
no longer have any legitimate reason for remaining in the United States.
CHESTER A. CROCKER, Assistant Secretary of, State Washington, Jan. 21, 1982

U.S. Ends Registration In January for Aliens

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 22, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 181 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 30


Sunday is the first Jan. 31 in more than three decades that has not marked the
deadline for aliens living in the United States to register with the Immigration
and Naturalization Service.

In December, Congress pa ssed and President Reagan signed a bill that eliminated
the annual report. Resident a liens had been required since 1950 to report their
addresses every Ja nuary.

Willful failure to do so was considered a misdemeanor, although the agency said
the law was rarely, if ever, enforced. Under the new law, aliens are still
required to report any change of address within 10 days.

An agency spokesman, Verne Jervis, said the law was changed because the report
was unnecessary.  ''It was simply redundant information,'' he said, ''absolutely
unnecessary'' because aliens are required to inform the service immediately of
any change of address.

Mr. Jervis predicted that the service would save more than $1 million a year by
eliminating the regulation.

EMPLOYERS DEFENDED IN COAST 'SLAVERY' CASE

BYLINE: By JUDITH CUMMINGS, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 27, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 694 words

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 30


Several of the Los Angeles-area residents suspected of using Indonesian aliens
as ''slave'' labor in their homes and businesses are Indonesians themselves, an
attorney representing them said today.

Alvin Michaelson, a lawyer who practices in Beverly Hills, said in an interview
that his clients are a close-knit group of relatives and friends who had no
knowledge of the immigration status of the Indonesians in their employ.

Mr. Michaelson's firm, Michaelson, Withey & Abzug, is representing 12 of the 80
homeowners and business people under Government subpoena to testify in the case.

''Many of these people are Indonesians themselves,'' Mr. Michaelson said. ''Many
of them were born in Indonesia and lived there most of their lives. They simply
wanted good help. You know like they say, 'Good help is hard to get these days'?
That's what it's all about.''

Defense of Employers

Describing the workers as ''like family'' to his clients, Mr.  Michaelson
contended that they were not held against their will.  ''They work in excellent
accommodations,'' he said. ''They begged to come here, and they are absolutely
delighted to be here.'' The Justice Department said Tuesday that it had
discovered an international ''slave'' ring that was providing illegal Indonesian
aliens to work in the homes and businesses of wealthy residents of Los Angeles
and Beverly Hills. Federal invest igators have refused to identify any of the
residents it has called t o testify in the grand jury proceedings, which began
at the end of t he week.

No arrests have been made in the case. Federal officials said the target of the
investigation would be providers of the aliens, who they said were being sold
for $1,500 to $3,000 and forced to work for two years for their ''owners.''

However, officials of the Indonesian Government have expressed do ubts about
whether the workers were held against their will and hassaid they may have been
tourists.

Raids on Homes and Businesses

The 26 Indonesian workers who were seized in raids on homes and businesses
Tuesday are being held in a Federal center in Hollywood as material witnesses.
The case was investigated jointly by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the
Immigration and Naturalization Service.

Gerald Klippness, an immigration agent, was quoted by The Los Angeles Times as
having said the investigation found that the same ring had also sent Indonesians
to families in New York City and Miami.

The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, John S. Martin
Jr., said tonight that he was aware of the investigation on the West Coast but
unaware of any in New York.

''It has not come to my personal attention,'' Mr. Martin said, adding that the
Federal authorities nevertheless ''may very well be investigating'' the matter.

No Comment From Agency

A duty officer at the Immigration and Naturalization Service in New York said
nobody in a position to comment would be available until Monday.

The Justice Department has contended that the Indonesian workers were paid
minimal or no wages and that they were kept against their will, sometimes
through intimidation, threat of bodily harm and confiscation of their passports
and other papers.

Mr. Michaelson said his clients, whom he declined to identify, ''all thought
these people were eligible to be working in this country.''

He said, however, that he did not know whether the workers were paid wages or
''how they worked it.'' Mr. Michaelson called the Government's case ''absurd''
and said his clients had done nothing ''more serious than what happens every day
in L.A. with the hiring of Salvadorans, Guatemalans, everybody'' who may be in
this country illegally. He suggested that the Government had made an issue of
the Indonesians' case to improve the public's perception of the immigration
agency.

               January 31, 1982, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

HAITIANS ATTRACT SYMPATHETIC NOTICE

BYLINE: By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN

SECTION: Section 11; Connecticut; Page 1, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1325 words


CONNECTICUT, a state settled by waves of immigrants, is beginning to fathom the
size, needs and problems of its latest newcomers, the Haitians.

The Haitian population that grew to several thousand in the preceding decade had
attracted little attention other than from the Federal Immigration and
Naturalization Service. But the last month has seen concern for Haitian
immigrants emerge in many other areas, from local social service agencies to
some of the state's highest elected officials.

United States Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Norwich, who returned two
weeks ago from a tour of Haiti and the detainment camps of Haitians in the
southern United States, is advocating more lenient immigration laws. He
specifically proposed allowing individuals other than family members to act as
sponsors of the Haitians already here.

Although Mr. Dodd's remarks related to a national policy, they have clear
implications for Connecticut, where at least one-third of the Haitians are here
illegally, according to an informal survey by a Haitian social worker in
Stamford. Many continue to hide from the Immigration and Naturalization Service,
which last summer arrested more than 25 Haitians in Stamford, Greenwich, Norwalk
and Westport.  To stem the flow of Haitian refugees, Mr. Dodd said, the United
States must work with the Haitian Government to improve the economic conditions
in the island nation, one of the poorest in the world.

''What Americans have to understand,'' said Mr. Dodd, ''is that, yes, these
people are violating our immigration laws. But they don't know what those laws
are when they get on some rickety boat on the north shore of Haiti. They're
following a natural law: survival. I'd backstroke out of Haiti if I had to.''

Most Americans, the Senator continued, let racial animosity and a lack of
knowledge about conditions in Haiti influence their ''misundertanding'' of the
refugees.

United States Representative Stewart B. McKinney, Republican of Fairfield, has
co-sponsored legislation in Congress that would classify Haitians who arrived
between Jan. 1, 1979, and May, 14, 1981, as political refugees. The changed
status would protect those Haitians from deportation. The bill is awaiting
action in the House Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee of Immigration, Refugees
and International Law.

''This is not an immigration problem,'' Mr.  McKinney said recently,''but a
humanitarian problem requiring a huma ne solution.'' Mr. McKinney also has
followed the Haitian issue locally. His Stamford office received a report
detailing t he housing and employment needs of that city's Haitian population,
which may be the largest in the state, from the Committee on Training and E
mployment Inc., a social service agency. Mr. McKinney's Stamford aid es have
helped several Haitians gain entrance to this country for their children, who
had been barred because they had not had the necessary blood tests to prove the
family relationship.

Neither the Immigration Service nor the Bureau of the Census possesses recent
estimates of legal or illegal Haitian immigrants.  The informal survey in
Stamford, conducted by Lehem Felican, a Haitian who is a social worker, counted
2,155 Haitians in that city, 687 of them illegal immigrants. But Mr. Felican
said that he omitted many Haitians who asked not to be counted because they
feared being discovered by immigration agents.

He and other observers estimated that Stamford may have as many as 5,000
Haitians. Myra M. Oliver, the executive director of the International Institute
of Connecticut, a private group that resettles immigrants, said there were also
enclaves of Haitians in Hartford, Bridgeport and New Haven.

But the situation in Stamford, as documented in the report to Mr.  McKinney and
amplified by interviews in the city, may provide indications of the Haitian
experience statewide.

Haitian unemployment stands at 60.8 percent, the report to Mr.  McKinney said,
and underemployment stymies hundreds of Haitians who arrived with skills but
often without fluency in English. Many speak French or a Haitian dialect.

Mickel Roy, who was trained as an accountant and is the elder of a Seventh-day
Adventist congregation in Stamford, works as a machine operator. Another
Haitian, who was a physician in Haiti, earns $3.37 an hour as an assembler in
Norwalk.

Housing is the second major problem for the Haitians, the report said.
Applicants for public housing face a two- to four-year wait - longer than many
Haitians have lived here. Private rents rarely dip below $350 a month for a
one-bedroom apartment.

''It's a desperate situation,'' said Mundy C. Redfern, a housing relocation
officer for the City of Stamford.  It is a situation many Haitians have resolved
by crowding into small apartments. Families of five sometimes share a single
room, Mr. Felican said.

But the Haitians and their supporters are quick to dispel a picture of uniform
squalor and helplessness. Municipal officials in Stamford and in Bridgeport said
the Haitians did not present a particular crime problem or drain civic resources
- two common misperceptions, particularly of illegal immigrants.

''They're not a serious crime problem,'' said Stamford Police Chief John T.
Considine. Richard L. Bisi, an aide to Bridgeport Mayor Leonard S. Paoletta,
said, ''We're not aware of any particular problems in this office.'' Five
Haitians have received welfare from Stamford in the last few years, said Robert
J. Mendela, caseworker supervisor for the city. Only one Haitian has ever stayed
in the emergency housing shelter operated by the Community of St. Luke in
Stamford, said its administrator, Frank P. Marzullo.

But a number of Haitians, Mr. Marzullo added, helped refurbish the shelter. To
him, the action was typical. ''All they want,'' he said, ''is a roof over their
head and an education for their kids.''

While unemployment and poor housing plague Haitians in Stamford, some are
striving for economic gain and assimilation. Dozens of Haitians study English in
Stamford's night school for adults.  Twentysix Haitian families own homes, Mr.
Felican's survey indicated. Two Haitian congregations, Baptist and Seventh-day
Adventist, hold services in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

The issue now for the Haitian supporters is how to extend those possibilities to
more people. The initial steps of organizing have been slow. Mr. Felican
convened a statewide congress of Haitians four weeks ago; it drew 30 people on a
snowy Saturday afternoon. In the first week of January, the Stamford branch of
the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked local
Haitians to come forward on the Jan. 15 birthday celebration of the Rev. Martin
Luther King and demand a better life. Five Haitians contacted Betty Saunders,
president of the N.A.A.C.P. chapter.

No one knew exactly why more Haitians did not answer the calls of either Mr.
Felican or Mrs. Saunders. Weather and communications difficulties may have
played a role. Illegal immigrants may have considered it too risky to attend a
public gathering. But Mr. Roy, the church elder, said he believed the question
simply is how much any outsider can do for the Haitians.

''I look at the Jewish people, the Italian people, what the y have
accomplished,'' he said. ''I think the Haitia ns can do that, too. Butno one can
do it for us. We must find our own leaders.'' b

Around the World;
Two Irish Nationals Are Deported to Canada

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 5, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 130 words

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Jan. 28


Two Irish nationals were deported to Canada today after bail had been posted on
criminal charges that they attempted to enter illegally from Canada on Jan. 21.

The two men, who were turned over to Canadian Immigration officials at the Peace
Bridge here, were Owen Carron, a member of the British Parliament from Northern
Ireland, and Danny Morrison, a spokesman for Sinn Fein, political arm of the
Irish Republican Army.

In a news conference on Wednesday, they said they considered themselves
''political prisoners'' here and contended that criminal charges had been filed
on orders from the State Department to placate Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher
of Britain.

U.S. SAYS COAST RING IMPORTED 30 ALIENS TO WORK IN 'SLAVERY'

BYLINE: By JUDITH CUMMINGS, Speci al to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 867 words

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 27


Federal officials said today they had discovered a ring that illegally brought
30 people to the United States to work for wealthy residents of Los Angeles and
Beverly Hills under arrangements one official described as ''pretty close to
slavery.''

The group, described by the officials as 30 Indonesians, may include four
Spanish-speaking persons. An Indonesian official and an attorney representing
some in the group both cast doubt on the question whether they were held against
their will.
The aliens were questioned today by the Federal Bureau of In vestigation and the
Immigration and Naturalization Service after ag ents found them Tuesday in an
early-morning raid on businesses and ab out six homes.

No arrests have been made. The head of the F.B.I.'s Los Angeles office, Edgar
Best, said information on the case would be turned over to a Federal grand jury
within a week. He characterized the condition of the group at a news conference.


'Close to Slavery'

''A fair reading of it would be, if you're brought into this country, your
documentation is taken away from you, and you're put into a servitude situation,
I'd say that's pretty close to slavery,'' Mr. Best said.

A statement issued by Mr. Best's office said the investigation ''has determined
that the aliens are being allegedly sold for amounts of $1,500 to $3,000 and are
forced to remain with their 'owner' for a period of two years.''

Grand jury subpoenas have been issued to individuals suspected in conncection
with the ring, according to an F.B.I. agent involved in the investigation, but
he did not say how many.

Mr. Best said the 25 men and five women were all in their 20's and 30's.  The
authorities would not identify the residences raided. At one point, Mr. Best
described them as ''typical houses of Beverly Hills.''

The raid was conducted under criminal search warrants obtained after an 11-month
investigation by the two Federal agencies.  Mr. Best said felony charges of
violating the involuntary servitude and conspiracy laws could be lodged against
those responsible for bringing aliens into this country under such conditins.

''It's obvious to us that the people that were involved in this scheme were well
aware of what they were doing,'' he added.  But a representative of the
Indonesian Government said he doubted the Indonesians involved had been
involuntarily held by anyone.  Ngurah Swetja, the vice consul in San Francisco,
said his government was aware of the presence of the group in Los Angeles.
Consul Offers Another View

''I don't think they were held against their will,'' he said in an interview,
''because they came here as tourists.'' He suggested that the Indonesians were
in the homes of ''friends,'' and that there had been a misunderstanding. It was
''common'' in his country, he said, that ''someone visit friends in another
country and live with them as family.

''Sometimes there are problems with friends,'' he continued, ''but we never
received a complaint from our citizens that they were kept as slaves.''

In the news conference, the Federal investigators would not provide details on
the extent of the operation or the number of Americans involved. They suggested
that there might be further raids after the grand jury investigation.

''The targets are the providers, or the people who actually concocted the
scheme,'' Mr. Best said. He indicated that those who owned some of the homes
that were raided might be involved in the smuggling.

4 Said to Have Spanish Names

Manuel Araujo, a public defender representing some in the group, said in an
interview that four were not Indonesian but had Spanish surnames.

Mr. Araujo said he had spoken to them in Spanish, and that they had described a
situation that was not involuntary servitude. They said they were paid $40 to
$45 a day and offered room and board but had turned it down, Mr. Araujo said.

He said his information about the Government case was limited to Justice Depar
tment affidavits. But he said the question of involuntary s ervitude was
muddled. Many of the aliens, he said, ''intended to work here, save money and go
back home.''

Asked why the two Federal agencies would use such strong terms to describe the
situation, he replied, ''Apparently they believe they can prove their case.''

A Federal magistrate, James Penne, is to rule Thursday on a Justice Department
effort to have the aliens declared material witnesses, to be held in custody
without bond. They have been in a locked facility in Pasadena, Calif.

Operation Used Tourist Visas

Only sketchy details were offered on how the aliens were brought here and kept
in the residences and businesses. But part of the operation, it appeared,
involved the use of fraudulently obtained tourist visas.
The deputy director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service of fice here,
Omer G. Sewell, suggested that the visas had been ob tained from an American
consulate.

''The American consul was given false information in order to obtain the tourist
visas,'' he said. ''He was informed, I'm sure, that the people were going to
come only for a brief visit in the U.S.'' He also indicated that false documents
backed up the visa applications.

2 I.R.A. SUPPORTERS ORDERED BY A JUDGE TO GET OUT OF U.S.

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 3, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 275 words

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Jan. 27


Two Irish nationalists, indicted on charges of trying to illegally enter the
United States from Canada, were ordered deported today by a Federal immigration
judge.

Benedict J. Ferro, regional director of the United States Immigration and
Naturalization Service here, said the two, Owen Carron, a Member of the British
Parliament, and Danny Morrison, a spokesman for Sinn Fein, political arm of the
Irish Republican Army, might be deported within 24 hours.

Earlier, both men were denied visas for illegally entering the country.  On
Tuesday, both were indicted on felony charges of presenting false papers to
Immigration Service officials in separate attempts to cross into the United
States from Canada last Thursday.

Two people who were driving the men in separate cars were also indicted for
attempted smuggling. They are Patrick Morrell of Niagara Falls, Ontario, a
naturalized Canadian of Irish birth, and Helen C.  McDonald Quigley, an
Australian living in Hamilton, Ontario.

The Imigration Service also brought civil charges against the four for trying to
enter the country illegally.  The immigration judge ruled tonight that the
Federal Government did not prove that Mr. Morrell knew that his passenger, Mr.
Carron, was trying to enter illegally and dismissed the civil charge. Mr.
Morrell returned to Canada and remains on bail on the criminal charge.
Immigration authorities adjourned the hearing involving Mrs. Quigley. She
returned to her home in Hamilton; she also remains on bail.

DOUBLED QUOTA FROM MEXICO AND CANADA SOUGHT

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section A; Page 10, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 539 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25


The Reagan Administration, eager to improve relations with neighboring
countries, today proposed doubling to 40,000 a year each the number of legal
immigrants to the United States from Canada and Mexico.

The announcement, expected to please and benefit Mexico particularly, was
coupled with warnings by officials of the State and Justice Departments against
imposing rigid Congressional ceilings on immigrants or on political refugees.

Assistant Secretary of State Diego C. Asencio told the Senate Subcommittee on
Immigration and Refugee Policy that the higher figures for Mexico and Canada
were the only changes proposed for United States immigration and refugee quotas.

The current worldwide immigration ceiling is 270,000 a year to the United
States, including 20,000 each from Canada and Mexico. With the doubling of those
two quotas, the total ceiling would rise to 310,000.

Alan Nelson, deputy commissioner of the Justice Department's Immigration and
Naturalization Service, said the net addition of 40,000 would not add
significantly to the 550,000 immigrants and refugees expected to enter the
United States in the current year.

'Special and Unique Ties'

Mr. Asencio said the proposal for Mexico an d Canada ''takes into account the
very special and unique ties - so cial, economic and cultural - which exist
between the United Sta tes and its two contiguous neighbors.''

These increases, he said, ''reflect our close relationships with both while
providing an additional opportunity to reduce or deter illegal immigration by
opening a supplementary channel for legal immigration to the United States.''

As explained by Mr. Asencio, the higher quotas for the two countries would
definitely benefit Mexico because if either of the two countries does not use
all of its 40,000 quota, the unused portion would go automatically to the other
country.

He said that only an estimated 15,000 Canadians were expected to emigrate to the
United States, meaning the remaining 25,000 openings would be available to
Mexicans.

While there is no fixed, permanent numerical limitation on refugee admissions,
there is the annual 140,000-limitation set by the Administration for the fiscal
year 1982 at the urging of Congress.  The Administration proposed a 173,000
limit.

The 1982 limit for refugee admissions is down from 217,000 in 1981 and 231,700
in 1980.

Overall Ceilings Opposed

Mr. Nelson said that, despite the ceilings of 140,000 refugees fleeing political
repression and 310,000 immigrants, the Administration opposed an overall cap on
both categories as ''impractical, not in the interests of the American people,
and restricting Presidential authority to respond to certain foreign policy
crises.''

This was echoed by Mr. Asencio, who also cautioned Congress against ''imposing a
rigid ceiling which could inhibit the President's ability to respond to changing
foreign and domestic circumstances.''

IMMIGRATION AGENCY CURBED IN SEARCH ES FOR ALIENS

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL SHEPPARD Jr., Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 22, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 784 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 23


A Federal district judge here has permanently enjoined the Immigration and
Naturalization Service from surrounding or invading factories and homes and then
forcibly interrogating Hispanic Americans on the status of their citizenship.

But the judge, Prentice Marshall, refused to enjoin the Federal agency from
randomly stopping and interrogating Hispanic Americans on the street, saying the
legality of this practice would have to be resolved at trial. Judge Marshall
said a trial date would be set on Jan. 27.

The judge's actions Wednesday grew out of an eight-year-old lawsuit filed by the
Illinois Migrant Council, a private, nonprofit corporation, and eight defendants
who said they had been harassed, abused and in some instances improperly
arrested by immigration agents looking for illegal aliens.

In 1975 a preliminary injunction was issued prohibiting the service from
entering residences of Mexicans or Spanish-surnamed people without valid
warrants to search or arrest them or without probable cause to enter without
such warrants unless the occupants voluntarily let them in.

Other Provisions of Injunction

The injunction also enjoined the agents from arresting, stopping, detaining or
interrogating Hispanic Americans by force, without valid search or arrest
warrants, or without reasonable suspicion based on specific facts that they were
illegal aliens unlawfully in the United States. The injunction allows the agents
to question Hispanic Americans publicly about their citizenship if they
volunteer to be questioned and are not coerced. The ruling covers the Northern
District of Illinois, which is served by Judge Marshall.

The case has dragged on largely because of appeals by the immigration service.
The permanent injunction binds the service to the same restrictions as the
preliminary injunction with the exception of street searches.  The plaintiffs
and defendants dispute whether the street interrogations are conducted as a
result of voluntary cooperation or detention and coercion.

Judge Marshall said both sides had presented evidence to support their
contentions but that neither had been convincing and therefore the issue must be
resolved at trial.

Edward J. Moran, an Assistant United States Attorney, and Theodore L. Giorgetti,
assistant district director for the immigration service, refused comment on
Judge Marshall's ruling.

Voluntary Cooperation Disputed

In its efforts to justify its ''area control'' sweeps of homes and factories,
the immigration service contended that the operations were conducted only with
the voluntary cooperation of those at the premises and that its agents did not
force anyone to remain on the premises.

Judge Marshall said he found thi s assertion ''inherently incredible'' and
without ''support in the stipulated facts'' in the case.

He said, however, that there existed ''a genuine issue of material fact'' on the
issue of street interrogations. ''Each side has submitted evidence which
supports its view of what the I.N.S. policy and practice actually are; neither
side's evidence is conclusive.  Since the evidence is in conflict, this question
must be resolved at trial.''

The plaintiffs alleged that they and other Hispanic Americans ''have been
subjected to numerous interrogations'' by immigration agents ''on public
streets, in their work places, and in their homes'' and that many of these
incidents ''led to detentions and arrests although they were citizens or
permanent residents of the U.S.''

Two years ago, a Federal judge in California issued an injunction against the
agency similar to the injunction issued in Chicago Tuesday. But the legality of
the agency's policy of random street interrogations of persons who appear to be
of Hispanic descent, which has become a heated issue in Hispanic American
communities around the country, has not been reviewed by a Federal court. The
forthcoming trial on the issue here would provide the first test of what the
agency considers an important tool in identifying illegal aliens.

The immigration agency temporarily halted the street encounters in 1980 at the
request of the Bureau of the Census, whose officials argued that the
interrogations made it even more difficult for census takers to get an accurate
count of Hispanic-Americans. The street interrogations have now resumed.

2 I.R.A. SUPPORTERS RRMAIN IN CUSTODY

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 3, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 630 words

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Jan. 22


Two prominent Irish republican activists remained in c ustody here today after
trying to enter the United States illega lly from Canada in separate cars.

The men, Owen Carron, a Member of the British Parliament, and Danny Morrison,
identified as public relations director of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the
Irish Republican Army, were arrested Thursday night. Mr. Carron was seized at
the Whirlpool Bridge in Niagara Falls, which carries traffic from Niagara Falls,
Ontario; Mr. Morrison, at the Peace Bridge in Buffalo, which carries traffic
from Fort Erie, Ontario.

According to Benedict J. Ferro, district director of the United States
Immigration and Naturalization Service in Buffalo, Mr. Carron and Mr. Morrison
were on their way to a dinner tonight in Astoria, Queens, sponsored by the Irish
Northern Aid Committee.

Both were charged with making false statements to Immigration and Naturalization
Service officials. The charge is punishable by up to five years in prison.

Two Canadians Also Seized

Officials said Mr. Carron had identified himself at the bridge as having
landed-immigrant status in Canada and showed a driver's license that was not
his. Mr. Morrison, officials said, had reportedly showed border authorities a
Canadian citizenship certificate that belonged to someone else.

In addition, two people who were said to have been driving the two activists
across the border were charged with attempted smuggling, according to Roger P.
Williams, interim United States Attorney here.  They could receive as much as
two years in prison if convicted.

They were identified as Patrick Morrell, reported to be an Irish native who is a
naturalized Canadian citizen living in Niagara Falls, Ontario, who was driving
Mr. Carron, and Helen McDonald Quigley, an Australian citizen, who is a resident
of Hamilton, Ontario.

All four were brought before Magistrate Edmund F. Maxwell, who set a preliminary
hearing for 2 P.M. Tuesday and set $10,000 recognizance bond for each of the
four. They were then turned over to the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
No date was set for a civil hearing on their status, according to the
immigration agency.  Normally, this hearing is held after the criminal charges
are disposed of.

2 Claim to Be Political Prisoners

Immigration agency officials declined to say where the four would be held.  Both
Mr. Carron and Mr. Morrison claimed to be political prisoners when they appeared
without lawyers before Magistrate Maxwell.  Mr. Ferro said the immigration
agency was waiting for the two to try to enter the country. He said the American
border authorities had been watching a pattern of Irish republican activists
traveling in Canada during an 18-month investigation.

''This investigation made us aware they would be coming,'' he said, adding that
a special immigration agency squad was waiting at the border crossing when the
attempts were made.

---- 'Publicity Stunt,' Paisley Says

LONDON, Jan. 22 (AP) - The Rev. Ian Paisley, the militant Northern Ireland
Protestant leader, said today that the arrest of two Roman Catholic Irish
nationalists in the United States was ''all a publicity stunt.''

''It doesn't suprise me at all,'' Mr. Paisley said without elaboration.  Mr.
Paisley made the remarks to reporters upon returning from a weeklong visit to
Canada to publicize the Protestant position in Northern Ireland and combat Irish
Republican Army sentiment.

Mr. Paisley said his trip to Canada was an ''outstanding success.'' ''What I had
to say was carried on more than 800 radio and television networks,'' said the
55-year-old Protestant leader, who is a Member of the British and European
Parliaments.

POLICE AIDE ON COAST SAYS SPIES MAY POSE AS JEWISH EMIGR ES

SECTION: Section 1; Page 8, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 192 words

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22


Daryl Gates, the Los Angeles police chief, said today that intelligence reports
indicated the Soviet Union was sending ''dangerous criminals'' to this country,
posing as Jewish emigres and that they might attempt to disrupt the 1984 Summer
Olympic Games here.

In a report distributed to business leaders and news executives, Mr. Gates noted
that the annual quota for immigration of Soviet Jews was recently increased to
50,000 a year and said that investigators had determined that some immigrants
entering this country under the quota were not Jewish.

''Many knowledgeable people,'' he said, ''are of the opinion that the Soviets
are selecting dangerous criminals and sending them to the United States as
refugees via the Jewish immigraion quota. The Soviets realize they can aggravate
our already serious crime problem in this manner. Intelligence agents and spies
are infiltrating in the same way.''

Mr. Gates later said at a news conference that the report was speculation but
that he ''saw nothing in here so out of line it shouldn't have been stated.''

2 I.R.A. LEADERS ARRESTED WHILE TRYING TO ENTER U.S. ILLEGALLY

BYLINE: By LES LEDBETTER

SECTION: Section A; Page 3, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 600 words


Two leaders of the Irish Republican Army - in what appeared to be a coordinated
effort to reach New York City in time for a fundraising dinner tonight - were
arrested in separate incidents last night as each was trying to cross into the
United States illegally from Canada, the Immigration and Naturalization Service
said.

One of the arrested I.R.A. leaders, Owen Carron, is a recently elected member of
the British Parliament who last summer was refused a visa to enter the United
States because of his support for violence in Northern Ireland.

Mr. Carron, an unemployed high school teacher who has been identified as a
hard-line republican, was elected to Parliament in August to replace Robert
Sands, the I.R.A. official who won the seat in April while on a fatal hunger
strike in Maze Prison outside Belfast.

The other I.R.A. official who was arrested was identified by the Immigration
Service as Danny Morrison, the I.R.A.'s director of public relations.

Irish Panel Denounces Arrests

The arrests were denounced early this morning by the Irish Northern Aid
Committee as ''censorship'' by the United States State Department ''at the
request of the British'' to prevent Mr. Carron and Mr. Morrison from speaking at
a testimonial dinner in New York City this evening.

A statement issued by the committee said, ''The State Department has apparently
decided at the request of the British that free speech does not apply to those
who oppose the British presence in the north of Ireland.''

The committee said that while it ''no advance knowledge'' of the attempts at
illegal entry into the United States, ''it is obvious that both m en intended to
speak'' at the dinn er and ''to confront'' a loyalist group currently in this
country.  The spokesman for the group would not elaborate.

Antismuggling experts in the Immigration Service had been aware ofthe presence
of the two I.R.A. officials in Canada, according to officials of the Federal
agency, and it was expected that they would make attempts to reach New York City
before the dinner.

Mr. Carron, believed to be 29 years old, was arrested along with a Canadian man
shortly before 9 P.M. as they tried to cross into the United States at Niagara
Falls, said Benedict Ferro, district director for the Buffalo office of the
Immigration Service.

At about the same time, Mr. Morrison, was arrested along with a Canadian
national as they tried to enter the United States across the Peace Bridge in
Buffalo, Mr. Ferro said.

Mr. Carron falsely told immigration officers in Niagra Falls that he had landed
immigrant status in Canada, permitting him to enter without a visa, according to
Mr. Ferro. Mr. Morrison presented officers in Buffalo with a Canadian
citizenship certificate that was not his, he said.

'We Knew They Would Try'

Alerted by members of the service's antismuggling squad, the border officers
were waiting for the two Irishmen and arrested them and their companions.

''We had the information for days and knew they would try,'' Mr.  Ferro
explained in a telephone interview.  All four men were arrested on criminal and
administrative charges in connection with giving false information and attempted
smuggling, according to Mr. Ferro. He said they would be held in upstate jails
while it was determined whether to try them on the charges or initiate
deportation proceedings.

               January 19, 1982, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

2 EXILE COMMUNITIES PROTEST IN MIAMI

BYLINE: By GREGORY JAYNES, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 1107 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 18


Protest has at times seemed the lifeblood of Miami's Latin community, which now
makes up 58 percent of the city's population, but until this weekend no protest
had been marked by violence, nor, according to participants in a Saturday night
demonstration, had there been such a sense of personal loss.

About 3,000 Cubans turned out to protest the deportation of a Cuban stowaway
last week, the first time in the years of local Cuban gains that the United
States has shipped a Cuban refugee to Havana.  At the same time, another
volatile and growing ethnic presence in Miami, the 20,000-strong Haitian
community, was on the streets because it, too, had suffered a loss: A tiny,
locally launched attempt to overthrow the Haitian Government had failed
miserably, and most of its participants were under Federal arrest.

Failed to Prove His Case

In the Cuban case, the State Department found last week that Andres Rodriguez
Hernandez, a 20-year-old Cuban discovered aboard a Panamanian freighter in
Miami, had failed to prove a ''well-founded fear of persecution,'' the criterion
under which political asylum is granted or denied under present immigration
policy. Mr. Hernandez was deported to Havana Friday. He was the first Cuban sent
back since Fidel Castro took power in 1959.

The deportation had two effects locally. It defused a legal argument by Haitian
advocates that the United States was discriminating against refugees from
nations that are friendly, such as Haiti, while going to great lengths to
accommodate refugees from unfriendly nations, such as Cuba. The other effect was
to put the flame to a fuse in the Cuban community, which saw the decision as
barring friends and relatives who might try to flee here.

About 3,000 demonstrators began the protest on Calle Ocho, or Eighth Street,
Saturday night. At the end, stones, bottles and tear gas canisters were flying,
34 persons were arrested and charges of police brutality were made. At a special
meeting of the five-member Miami City Commission Sunday, the police said the
violence began after the protesters, who did not have a permit for a
demonstration, were told to disperse. Participants said the demonstration had
been peaceful until police officers moved against them with tear gas.

They Vote to Write Reagan

The commission, of which three members are Hispanic, voted to write the White
House condemning the deportation of the Cuban and to ask the Justice Department
to investigate to see whether the police used undue force. The city's only black
commissioner, Miller Dawkins, explained to the protesters that the Federal
Government ''cannot allow the Cubans to stay while it sends all the Haitians
back.'' ''That is why they sent this man back,'' he said.

A local columnist, Roberto Fabricio, observ ed in his weekly column in The Miami
Herald this morning: ''Cubans ha ve grown accustomed to seeing Miami and the
rest of the United State s as the lifeboat they have traditionally climbed
aboard. The deport ation of Rodriguez Hernandez is symbolic of the end of an
era. B itterness bordering on despair is a mild description of the resultin g
feeling.''

Among Haitians, who number 20,000, the feeling was not dissimilar, according to
leaders. A hapless coup attempt ended last week and 25 of the invaders, picked
up from a sinking boat, were brought back to Miami Sunday by the Coast Guard.

He Had Leaflets Dropped

For months, Bernard Sansaricq, a Haitian and an operator of a Shell service
station in Broward County, north of Miami, had been talking about the invasion.
In October, Mr. Sansaricq has acknowledged, he had a plane fly over
Port-au-Prince, the Haitian capital, dropping leaflets denouncing President
Jean-Claude Duvalier and announcing a coming invasion.

Earlier this month rumors flew that t he invasion was imminent, and Mr.
Sansaricq , who came to this country after participating in an abortive atte mpt
to overthrow the Haitian regime in 1963, went to theisland of Sou th Caicos, 90
miles north of Haiti, to prepare for the strike. On Su nday, Jan. 10, the
37-year-old revolutionary left the island in a 3 5-foot boat with 24 followers.
The day before, at least nine other Sa nsaricq followers went by seaplane to the
island of Tortuga, off Haiti's northwest coast, where they were captured.

On Tuesday, Jan. 12, the Haitian Government announced that three of the nine had
''succumbed to their wounds.'' Last Wednesday, the Sansaricq vessel, a sloop
called the Caicos Cloud, was intercepted by the Coast Guard cutter Gallatin,
which had picked up radio distress calls. The vessel was leaking and her engine
was stalled. A Coast Guard spokesman said they had been ''floating around
seasick for a couple of days.''

Two Others Also Charged

Sunday Mr. Sansaricq was brought back to Miami charged with violating the United
States Neutrality Act for leading an expedition against another nation.
Conviction carries a maximum penalty of three years in prison and a $3,000 fine.
Two of his followers were also charged with violating the Neutrality Act, and
the others were being held as material witnesses.

About 200 Haitians demonstrated outside the Coast Guard base here Sunday,
shouting words of praise for Mr. Sansaricq. As he was brought in for an initial
appearance before a magistrate this morning, another throng of Haitian
supporters gathered. Some participants at these and other demonstrations said
many of Miami's Haitians had worked themselves into a state of unrealistic
optimism, to the point that they believed success was at hand.

Mr. Sansaricq was ordered released on a personal bond of $400,000, and Milo
Gousse, a 37-year-old geography instructor in Montreal, and Phillipe Carre, a
32-year-old employee of a security system in Montreal, were ordered released on
$100,000 signature bonds, pending trial.
----

Murder Count Dropped in '80 Riots

MIAMI, Jan. 18 (AP) - The state dropped murder charges today against William
Paul Hembree, the only white accused of killing a black in the race riots here
in May 1980.

Defense attorneys said they convinced the state that it was a case of mistaken
identity. Assistant State Attorney Leonard Glick, who was to prosecute Mr.
Hembree in the killing of 38-year-old Lugene Brown, said, ''We cannot in good
faith proceed to trial.''

Mr. Hembree, 35, remained in the Dade County Jail on charges of parole
violation. He was arrested last August after the police were told that he had
boasted of shooting a black man in Liberty City on May 18, 1980.
