BRIEFING

BYLINE: By Francis X. Clines and Bernard Weinraub

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 925 words


W HEN martial law was declared in Poland, a number of Polish tourists and
professionals visiting in this country became, in effect, frozen in their
tracks, not seeking refugee status but not wanting to return home until they had
a clearer idea of the crisis.

This morning, representatives of the Polish American Congress are to meet with
officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to see whether some
temporary permits might be arranged so that these Poles can earn a living here
while lingering and deciding whether to go back.

''It's a very unusual situation, a very human problem,'' said Zdzislaw
Dziekonski, the Washington representative of the congress, who is careful in
discussing the situation. ''We've already been assured that there'll be no
deportations, but they have to survive while they are stranded here.''

W ITH more than 40 Congressional Democrats and dozens of other party faithful
signed up for the Franklin Delano Roosevelt dinner Feb. 1 in New York, the
Democratic National Committee is considering heading out in F.D.R. style from
the capital - aboard a chartered railroad train full of politicians toward the
$500-a-plate whistle stop at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Roosevelt centennial dinner i s one of the first major projects of the
commit tee's new regional office in New York, and a heavy contingent is booked
from Washing ton, in part, according t o a spokesman, because Democrats are
''angered by Reaganists' blasphemoususe of F.D.R.'s words and resolve to
recapture the memory of the great leader.''

A FTER the niceties were out of the way at an informal encounter with some
reporters the other day, the Director of Central Intelligence bluntly sought
some intelligence.

''Why is the press dumping on me?'' asked William J. Casey, chief of the C.I.A.
A reporter, with a good memory for past encounters between those who are paid to
keep secrets private and those paid to make them public, replied, ''At least
nobody's written that Casey is stupid or crazy, the way one of your predecessors
was described.''

Mr. Casey took this with a genteel harrumph, then said, ''Well, I guess I should
mark that as a plus.''

I F there is a ranking expert on liquor in Washington - and an enormous marathon
of contenders could be readily assembled outside the capital's expense-account
haunts - that expert is one of the most pleasantly sober of men, Milton S.
Kronheim.

He is a 93-year-old liquor wholesaler who for decades has debated public issues
of the day in congenial luncheons at his office with old and new friends in
Government. At one such forum, his own specialty came up with the news that
President Reagan was considering doubling ''sin taxes,'' including the Federal
excise on liquor.

''That would be a mistake,'' Mr. Kronheim told a friend. ''A vicious chain of
events would follow. Doubling the present $10.50-agallon tax would mean a
decline in consumption and revenues and at the same time make it worthwhile for
the illegal people, the bootleggers, to make a comeback, the same as the
cigarette bootleggers have been doing with all the extra cigarette taxes.''

Mr. Kronheim was speaking from an interest in the liquor business that extends
back to 1903, with time away from it, he stressed, in Prohibition. How, he
asked, would a bootlegging threat fit in with the Administration's decision to
disassemble the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms? He did not know whether
the White House was considering this.''I am not a lobbyist,'' he said.

N ORMALLY there seems to be an unbridgeable gulf between the vast, amorphous
budget decisions made in Washington and their everyday effects beyond the banks
of the Potomac. But for a moment during the turmoil that swept the city after
the fatal plane crash last Wednesday, a connection was attempted.

An officer of the National Parks Service involved in the helicopter rescue of
survivors had made a point of saying that the service was down to one copter but
had more before the budget cuts.  The one craft so quickly at the scene
performed heroically, ferrying five survivors to shore, but returning too late
for a sixth. More survivors afloat, the officer implied, would have further
frustrated the rescue.

Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt was furious that evening when this point
was brought up by a reporter who saw him at a cocktail party.

''Jiminy Crickets, I can't believe you're asking that question,'' he said. ''I
saw men risking their lives. That's where your attention should be.''

''Mr. Secretary, I'm asking the question,'' the reporter repeated.  ''Could they
have done more if they had more equipment?'' ''I have no idea,'' Mr. Watt said.
''Maybe there wasn't room for two helicopters.'' Francis X. Clines Bernard
Weinraub

Stowaway's Deportation Is Protested in Miami

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 22, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 160 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Jan. 16


The police broke up a rowdy demonstration at the federal immigration offices
today as about 1,000 chanting Cuban exiles protested the deportation of a
20-year-old Cuban stowaway. At least six people were arrested.

The demonstrators left after 90 minutes of shouting. About 60 officers cordoned
off a one-block area surrounding the Federal Immigration and Naturalization
Service building when demonstrators began running through the streets at 3:30
P.M. Beverly McFarland, a spokesman for the immigration service, said the
demonstrators apparently began running when a woman fell and hurt herself. Some
demonstrators said she had been pushed by the police.

Andres Rodriguez Hernandez was sent back to Cuba Friday, two days after he
arrived in Miami as a stowaway aboard a Panamanianregistered freighter.

EXILED SOUTH AFRICAN ALLOWED TO SEEK ASYLUM

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 2, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 396 words

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 14


Dennis Brutus, the exiled South African poet and scholar who has been ruled
''deportable'' because of an expired visa, received a temporary reprieve today.

A United States immigration judge, Irving Schwartz, gave him 20 days to seek
political asylum in this country. The petition will be submitted to the State
Department for advice, a process that generally takes at least 30 days.

When the State Department advisory opinion is returned to Judge Schwartz, a
hearing will take up whether Professor Brutus will be granted asylum, have his
visa extended, leave the country voluntarily or be deported. In addition,
according to Robert Vinikoor, a lawyer for the United States Immigration and
Naturalization Service, ''It should be stated on record where Brutus should be
sent,'' in the event of deportation.

Professor Brutus's attorney, H. Nasif Mahmoud, had asked that his home be
defined by the court as South Africa. But, Mr. Vinikoor said, ''We do not intend
to designate South Africa, but rather Zimbabwe, the country of his birth, from
which he holds a passport.''

Mr. Mahmoud asserted that his client's life would be in danger in Zimbabwe. He
said that terrorists employed by South Africa are at work there; he cited the
murder of a South African nationalist, Joe Gqabi, in July 1981.

In the meantime, Mr. Brutus, a senior professor of African literature in the
Northwestern University English department, is free to return to Amherst
College, where he is spending a sabbatical year as a visiting writer.

In the 20-minute hearing, much time was spent in argument on the professor's
sojurn at Amherst while claiming residency at Northwestern. Judge Schwartz
repeatedly demanded to know why no mention of the sabbatical had been made at a
hearing in November.

In tones of exasperation, the judge read from the November transcript. But his
expression changed as Mr. Mahmoud said that a passage marked ''unintelligible''
referred to Amherst College. The Judge smiled, and said, ''I take it back.''

Mr. Mahmoud called the hearing ''a victory in that Dennis didn't get thrown out,
but it's a short-lived victory be-

BLACK POET, AN EXILE FOR 10 YEARS, BATTLES U.S. DEPORTATION TO AFRICA

BYLINE: By DUDLEY CLENDINEN, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 20, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 989 words

DATELINE: BOSTON, Jan. 13


For the last 10 years, since arriving in the United States as an exile after
being shot by the secret police and imprisoned in South Africa, the black poet
Dennis Brutus has been a professor of English at Northwestern University in
Evanston, Ill.

This year, by invitation, he is a visiting professor at Amherst College. But at
the moment he is in Chicago because an immigration judge there has ruled that
Professor Brutus is ''deportable,'' and on Thursday morning he must try to
persuade the court not to send him back to Africa.

''Dennis Brutus Defense Committees'' have sprung up in the academic communities
of Amherst, Boston, Minneapolis and Chicago, where they contend in leaflets that
''if deported, Dennis Brutus will become a target of assassination for the South
African secret police, because of the lifelong battle he has waged against
racism and apartheid.''

While of that danger may be impossible to assess, Professor Brutus a nd his
frien ds cite a book about the South African secret police recently publ ished
in Britain. Called ''Inside BOSS,'' the acronym for the Bureau of State
Security, the book is written by a former agent named Gordon Winters, who
describes the black poet i n one chapter as a man considered by the Government
of South Afr ica to be one of its most dangerous opponents.

Imprisoned in South Africa

Professor Brutus, a man of precise and gentle speech, does not wholly agree with
the way he is characterized in the book. But he notes that last July 31, Joe
Gqabi, a former nationalist guerrilla leader in South Africa with whom he had
been imprisoned, was machinegunned to death in his driveway in a suburb of
Salisbury, Zimbabwe. The Prime Minister of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, has accused
South Africa of the assassination.

As the country of his birth when it was Rhodesia, during a short period when his
parents were missionary teachers there, Zimbabwe is one place to which Professor
Brutus could be deported. His international reputation as a poet and opponent of
apartheid, the system of racial separation, and the possibility that he could be
deported to the region of South Africa, have led to written expressions of
concern and support from the Black Congressional Caucus, the president of
Amherst College and from other Congressmen in Chicago and Massachusetts,
including United States Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts.

But at a hearing in Chicago in November, a United States Immigration Judge,
Irving Schwartz, upheld the district director's decision that Professor Brutus
was in violation of immigration law and thus ''deportable,'' and adjourned the
hearing until Thursday to allow the poet's attorney to study arguments for
discretionary relief.

'Never Did Anything Wrong'

''The most tragic and moving issue here is the fact that Professor Brutus never
did anything wrong,'' his Chicago attorney, Nasif Mahmoud, said. The Immigration
and Naturalization Service has formally agreed that Professor Brutus originally
fell into violation through no fault of his own. But once ensnared in the
complexities of immigration law, his case has grown more complicated.

As a native citizen of Rhodesia, he carried a British passport, which he used to
make periodic application for the extension of the temporary visa that allowed
him to work as a university professor in this country. But when Rhodesia became
Zimbabwe in the spring of 1980, Britain canceled his passport, and by the time
Zimbabwe issued him a new one, he was late in applying for the extension. Then,
for a period of almost six months, the immigration district office in Chicago,
pleading the confusion of a change in Administrations, said that it could not
find his file.

Meanwhile, he continued to teach African literature under contract at
Northwestern, which threw him into further violation since an alien is not
supposed to work if his visa has expired. Once in that state of illegality, his
only remedy under immigration law was to leave the country and reapply. He could
not do it from within.

''It could have been resolved if he had chosen to leave the country,'' said O.
John Brahos, the chief legal officer for the Chicago district.

Problem on Returning

''My response was that I am willing to do that if I have a reasonable assurance
that I will be allowed to return,'' Professor Brutus said in an interview here
before leaving for Chicago. ''But this the prosecuting attorney has not been
willing to give me.''

The difficulty is that, should he leave the United States, another long and
complicated set of immigration standards, the McCarran-Walter Act, comes into
play.

The act, passed in the McCarthy era in 1952, makes it possible for the United
States to bar anyone who can be considered a Communist or Communist sympathizer.
And Professor Brutus, who was originally arrested in 1963 for challenging the
participation of segregated South African teams in the Olympics, was formally
''banned,'' or put under house arrest there in 1965 under a law called the
''Supression of Communism Act.''

That is now the unknown factor that lurks in the United States Government's
consideration of his case.  Mr. Mahmoud sees in the Government's prosecution of
the case a signal of friendship that the Reagan Administration can send to South
Africa, and Professor Brutus fears that the immigration service has material
from the South African police in its files.

Mr. Brahos, the chief Government lawyer, denies that he has had any expressions
of interest from Washington in the matter.

Briefing

BYLINE: By Francis X. Clines and Bernard Weinraub

SECTION: Section B; Page 8, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 905 words


T HE wrenching plight of children of the Orient fathered by American servicemen
is scheduled to reach Congress in the next few weeks, and Representative Stewart
B. McKinney, who has been championing their cause, is faintly optimistic that
the House will finally approve his bill.

Mr. McKinney, Republican of Connecticut, is sponsoring a measure that would
change the ''not-preferential'' status of the children and allow them to apply
to enter the United States under the Immigration and Nationality Act's ''first
preference'' status for unmarried children of American citizens.  The change
would also require the applicants to have American sponsors, but that would not
be very difficult since a range of groups, such as The Pearl S. Buck Foundation
and Save the Children, are actively involved.

''These children will not be coming here to find fathers,'' said Mr. McKinney,
whose earlier bill concerning the children died in the House. ''Many of these
kids are abandoned.''

The Congressman said that both the Carter and Reagan Administrations had been
chilly to his proposal to assist the children, of whom there may be as many as
80,000 in Vietnam, Korea, Thailand, Laos and the Philippines. Officials of the
Reagan Administration have expressed worry about fraud and abuse, Mr.  McKinney
said, and have proposed that any immigration effort should wait until each child
received a blood test, a notion he called ''ludicrous.''

Mr. McKinney said that the measure would not open the doors to mass immigration,
but ''would simply place the Amerasian in his or her proper reference
classification, based on their legitimate claim as a child of a U.S. citizen.''

With 155 co-sponsors in the House, and with a Senate bill supported by such
Republican conservatives as Jeremiah Denton of Alabama and Paul Laxalt of
Nevada, Mr. McKinney is hopeful that his measure will triumph.

''I don't think you can see the pictures and hear the stories of these kids and
not become involved,'' he said.

I N this day of tight Federal budgets and a war on waste in the Pentagon, the
Defense Department's chief spokesman, Henry E. Catto Jr., was asked the other
morning to justify an annual subsidy to the National Rifle Association to
promote target practice. Caught unaware, Mr. Catto asked how much was involved.
Told it was $440,000, he said, almost with a straight face: ''You can't call tha
t a cheap shot, can you?''

A S if the State Department didn't have enough worries, along comes The Crisis
in the American Embassy in Bangkok.  For the last few years, the former American
Ambassador, Morton I.  Abramowitz, maintained a somewhat informal diplomatic
atmosphere.  Most of the senior staff called the Ambassador ''Mort.'' His door
was inevitably open to anyone who wanted to chat. Unlike most ambassadors, Mr.
Abramowitz would dial the telephone himself and invite American journalists over
for a movie or a quick lunch. Around the embassy, many of the men wore
short-sleeved shirts, open at the neck, because of the pulsing heat.

Mr. Abramowitz departed last year; he is now scheduled to take over the American
Embassy in Indonesia. His replacement, John Gunther Dean, promptly made it plain
that the informal days were over.

Mr. Dean, a former Ambassador to Cambodia, Denmark and Lebanon, prefers to be
called ''Sir,'' or ''Mr. Ambassador.'' An embassy officer who showed up
Saturday, his day off, to clean up his desk, was admonished by Mr. Dean because
of his casual appearance.

Mr. Dean even has a young political aide pouring tea now, whenever the
Ambassador has a guest in his office. Mr. Dean prefers his tea hot.

J O-ANN GASPER, a self-described ''pro-family leader'' who edited a publication
called, ''The Right Woman,'' and who opposes Federal assistance to battered
wives and abused children, has just been appointed Deputy Assistant Secretary
for Social Services Policy at the Department of Health and Human Services.

''People for the American Way,'' a Washington-based organization seeking to
counter the influence of Moral Majority, takes note in its current bulletin of a
column that Mrs. Gasper wrote in the March, 1980, issue of the Conservative

In the column titled, ''Beating Up on the Family,'' Mrs. Gasper wrote that the
concept of domestic violence was so vague that it can mean ''any form of
'belittling' or 'teasing' or 'failure to provide warmth' (whatever that may be -
I guess if you don't set the electric blanket high enough in the winter).''

VISA DISPUTE IMPERILS U.S. MEXICO TIES

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 3, Column 4; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 767 words

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 10


A decision by the Reagan Administration to cancel the temporary immigrant visas
of tens of thousands of Mexicans living in the United States has provoked loud
protests in Mexico and is threatening the first storm in relations since
President Reagan took office.

The Government has recalled its Ambassador to Washington, Hugo B.  Mar gain, who
will brief President Jose Lopez Portillo and Foreign Minister Jorg e Castaneda
de la Rosa on the controversy this week.  Mexican labor groups have also
asserted that the Immigration and Naturalizatio n Service is planning ''mass
deportations'' of Mexicans in the United States.

So far, however, both the Reagan and Lopez Portillo administrations have been
careful not to let the problem grow into a major crisis.  ''The issue, as
presented publicly, has been blown out of all proportion to the real facts,''
the American Ambassador, John Gavin, insisted last week. The Mexican Government
said it had been assured there would not be ''massive deportations or
roundups.''

Court Decision Is Root

Yet despite the evident political good will existing between the two
administrations, Washington's freedom to be flexible is limited by legal
constraints. If the law is applied strictly, relations will unavoidably be
strained.

The issue has its roots in a decision by a United States district court in
Chicago accepting the argument of a Mexican national, Refugio Silva, who
maintained that the United States Government's practice of deducting the number
of immigrant visas granted to Cuban refugees from the Western Hemisph ere quota
di scriminated against applicants from other countries.

The court ordered that a similar number of visas - 144,999 - be issued to
citizens of the Americas in addition to the 120,000-person annual quota and the
single country limit of 20,000 a year. This was to take place between Nov. 9,
1979, and Nov. 9, 1981.

Around 200,000 Mexicans were eligible to apply for the new visas and, once they
had become ''Silva class applicants,'' they were allowed to stay and work in the
United States and receive welfare benefits. Of these, however, only 115,271
Mexicans eventually received permanent resident status.
Judge Ends Injunction

On Dec. 24, a district court judge took note that the required number of
additional visas had been issued and he lifted the injunction imposed on the
Immigration and Naturalization Service, which effectively protected the ''Silva
class applicants'' against arrest and deportation.

Soon afterwards, letters started being mailed to those applicants who had not
benefited from the Silva program asking them to go to the offices of the
Immigration Service to discuss their status.  Immediately, protests began to be
heard from Hispanic leaders in the United States and labor groups in Mexico

Until Ambassador Margain was received by a State Department official last
Wednesday, however, the Mexican Government had received no information from the
United States on the subject. ''This is an internal matter of the United States,
but we would have expected to have been warned as a courtesy,'' a Mexican
Foreign Ministry official noted.

Estimates of the number of Mexicans affected vary from 70,000 to 100,000 and,
according to the Mexican Foreign Ministry, Ambassador Margain was told that as
many as 50 percent of those may still be granted immigrant visas through
ordinary channels as a result of having wives, children or other close relatives
who are now United States citizens. ''As for the other 50 percent, each case
will be studied individually,'' the ministry statement said.

Confrontations 'Can Be Avoided'

Faced by a wave of alarmist reports in the Mexican press suggesting an imminent
offensive against ''Silva class applicants'' and other illegal immigrants,
Ambassador Gavin issued a statement last Thursday stressing that ''they are not
being rounded up an herded to the border.''

''Unfortunately, many people speak out on this sensitive and emotional issue
before they know the facts,'' Mr. Gavin said.  ''Others, some of them in the
United States, frequently take advantage of confusion to inflame passions for
their own purposes. If we speak to each other calmly, based on a knowledge of
the facts, these confrontations can be avoided.''

Israel Immigration Unit Curtails Vienna Efforts

BYLINE: Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 6, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 298 words

DATELINE: TEL AVIV, Jan. 6


The official Israeli agency that handles the immigration of Soviet Jews to
Israel said today that it was curtailing its activities in Vienna because of a
dispute with the Austrian authorities.

The organization, the Jewish Agency, accused the Austrian Government of
violating a longstanding agreement giving the agency exclusive access to Soviet
Jews arriving in Vienna. It said that because the Austrians allowed other
organizations to get in touch with the Soviet emigrants, who had been traveling
with visas to Israel, many had been persuaded to go to countries other than
Israel.

The Jewish Agency said it was dropping its use of hostels in Vienna provided by
the Austrian authorities and moving the occupants to hotels. The agency's
representative in Vienna, Baruch Minkowitz, said the Ministry of Interior hung
signs in the hostel Tuesday referring Soviet emigrants wishing to go to
countries other than Israel to a room in the hostel to meet a representative of
the Austrian Red Cross.

The signs, in Russian, gave the addresses and telephone numbers of six
organizations that might help them. The groups included Rav Tov, a Hasidic
anti-Zionist organization in the United States; the World Council of Churches,
and the Tolstoy Foundation of anti-C@ommunist Russians.

In a statement issued in Jerusalem this afternoon, Aryeh Dulzin, chairman of the
Jewish Agency and the World Zionist Organization, said the Austrians had leased
the premises exclusively to the Jewish Agency.

The Austrian move appeared to be a response to Israeli actions to reduce the
rate, estimated to be as high as 85 percent, of emigrants who go to countries
other than Israel.

IT'S TIME FOR IMMIGRATION LAW REFORM--OR IS IT?

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1540 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Despite the sporadic, intense focus on specific groups of foreigners who seek
the American dream - Hungarians, Mexicans, ''boat people,'' and now Haitians -
the historical record suggests that only once in a generation does Congress deal
comprehensively with the issue of immigration. The last sweeping revision, the
McCarran-Walter Act, was passed in 1952 and many of its provisions are still on
the books. The Reagan Administration thus had every reason to hope for the best
when it proposed ''omnibus'' legislation designed to control the flow of aliens
across the nation's borders.

But immigration is one of those issues, like criminal code revision and welfare
reform, that are so complex that they tax the institutional capabilities of
Congress. Typically, by the time a subcommittee has mastered the subject, it is
usually too late in the session to pass comprehensive legislation.

President Ford had a Domestic Council Committee on Illegal Aliens which examined
the problems of illegal immigration. After a similar Cabinet-level study,
President Carter sent Capitol Hill a comprehensive set of immigration proposals
in August 1977, but they did not go far. In 1978, Congress established the
Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy, which included eight
members of Congress and four members of Mr. Carter's Cabinet. By the time the
panel completed its work, Ronald Reagan was President, and he appointed an
interagency Task Force on Immigration and Refugee Policy to study the issue yet
again.

The studies agree on the problem - the United States has lost control of its
borders. The proposed solutions are permutations of several components: improved
enforcement of existing laws; penalties against employers hiring illegal aliens;
some type of amnesty for illegal aliens already in the country; an improved
method of identification for job applicants.

The urgency of the problem became apparent again last week when Haitians at a
detention camp in Miami staged a hunger strike.  Authorities said that 100
Haitians escaped from the camp last Sunday when 300 members of Miami's Haitian
exile community stormed the facility, throwing stones and bottles at security
guards. More than 2,100 Haitians are still being detained at various places,
including 588 at the camp in Miami.

Attorney Ge neral William French Smith outlined the Reagan Administratio n's
policy last July. Detailed legislative proposals were not offe red until late
October. Subcommittees in both houses of Congress, und er Senator Alan K.
Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, and Representativ e Romano L. Mazzoli, Democrat
of Kentucky, have completed exh austive reviews of the subject. Senator Simpson
and his staff have be gun drafting legislation, with some indications that
Mr.Mazzoli will introduce a similar proposal in the House.

Emergency Powers?

Optimists at the Justice Department, like David D. Hiller, a special assistant
to the Attorney General, see a consensus emerging in Congress in support of
proposals very similar to Mr. Reagan's.  But Mr. Mazzoli, in an interview,
sounded uncertain about the contents of any legislation and his strategy for
gaining its approval. ''My own personal feelings are pretty amorphous,'' he
said. ''I'm trying my best to halfway understand the subject matter.''

The comments of Mr. Simpson, Mr. Mazzoli and their aides suggest that President
Reagan's proposals, if enacted at all, will be substantially modified. Senator
Simpson appears to favor more severe employer sanctions than were recommended by
the President and freemarket economists on the White House staff. The penalty
suggested by the President - a $500 fine for each illegal alien employee on the
first offense, $1,000 per alien for subsequent violations - is seen on Capitol
Hill as just a tax, and not a very high one. Testimony at Congressional hearings
strongly suggested that the President's proposed procedure for legalizing the
status of illegal aliens would be cumbersome to administer and unattractive to
the intended beneficiaries. After coming forward to identify themselves, the
illegal aliens would have to live here continuously for 10 years before becoming
eligible for permanent resident status, which carries most of the rights of
citizenship. During that decade, the aliens could accept emp loyment but could
not bring t heir spouses and children. Congress is looking for a simpler,
shorter method of legalization.

Many members of Congress share the President's conviction that the Government
needs additional authority to deal with an ''immigration emergency'' such as the
boatlift that brought 125,000 Cubans to Florida in 1980. But some influential
members say they would grant only a small portion of the vast powers requested
by the Administration.

The President wants to be able to restrict travel and shut down harbors,
airports and roads when he determines that the country is threatened with a
massive, unauthorized influx of aliens. Without waiting for Congress to act, the
Administration has already curtailed the flow of Haitians by deploying Coast
Guard vessels to intercept Haitian boats in international waters.

There is likewise support for the Reagan Administration's effort to streamline
the convoluted sequence of administrative and judicial appeals available to an
alien ordered out of the country. But members of Congress who have studied the
issue would not go so far as the President wants to go in curtailing the courts'
power to review decisions on an alien's admissibility.

With the unemployment rate at its highest point in six years, Congressional
aides say it would be exceedingly difficult for the Administration to win
approval of its proposal to admit Mexicans as temporary guest workers. Under the
Reagan proposal, Mexicans would go only into states and industries where state
officials had certified a need. But labor unions contend that such needs often
exist because employers are unwilling to pay high wages.

Continued high unemployment may, however, stimulate support for those parts of
the Reagan program that seek to control and restrict immigration. If members of
Congress clamp down on illegal aliens and illegal immigration next year, they
can tell their constituents that they have taken steps to preserve jobs for
Americans. But even if it passed restrictive new laws, Congress probably could
not find the money to insure aggressive enforcement at a time when fiscal
austerity limits the operations of existing law-enforcement agencies.

President Reagan has asked Congress to enact a package of immigration
legislation including these elements: Emergency Interdiction Act. The President
could order the Coast Guard to intercept foreign vessels bringing illegal aliens
to the United States. Refugees would be eligible for asylum, but other aliens
would be returned to their homeland. Unauthorized Entry and Transportation Act.

Anyone who transported illegal aliens into the United States would be subject to
a fine of $10,000 and a prison sentence of up to five years. Immigration
Emergency Act. After declaring an emergency, the President could close harbors,
airports and roads that might be used by aliens to enter the United States.
Appeal, Asylum and Exclusion Act. The Government would expedite proceedings for
aliens who want to enter the United States, while curtailing rights that they
have under current law. Temporary Resident Status for Illegal Aliens.  Illegal
ali ens who were in this country before Jan. 1, 1980, could apply for new status
as ''temporary residents'' and could become permanent res idents after living
here continuously for 10 years.  Such temporar y residents could take jobs, but
they could not bring their familie s and would not be eligible for welfare or
food stamps. Cuban-Haitian Temporary Resident Act.

Cubans and Haitians who arrived before Jan. 1, 1981, could become permanent
residents after living in the United States for five years. Employer Sanctions
(Unlawful Employment of Aliens Act). An employer who knowingly hired illegal
aliens could be fined $500 for the first offense and $1,000 for each subsequent
violation. The Reagan Administration opposes creation of a national identity
card recommended by some studies. Instead, job applicants are supposed to
''attest'' that they are citizens or legal aliens.  Temporary Mexican Workers
Act. The

United States would admit 50,000 Mexican citizens each year as ''guest workers''
in an experimental program scheduled to last two years. Each state would
determine its need for Mexican labor. Mexican workers would not be permitted to
bring their families.

3 Poles Defect in Canada

DATELINE: PORT CARTIER, Quebec, Dec. 31


The first mate of a Polish freighter, his wife and child applied for political
asylum in Canada today in this port on the St. Lawrence River. Pawel Urbanska,
3O years old, his wife, Lydia, also 3O, and 3-year-old Mickal ''will probably be
granted asylum,'' an immigration official said.

                January 1, 1982, Friday, Late City Final Edition

FLASH FIRES OF RUMOR KEEP HAITIAN CAMP ON EDGE

BYLINE: By GREGORY JAYNES, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 7, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1118 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 31


A snake, sometimes merely a searing bite from a deer fly, can spark a stampede
in a cattle holding pen. Something unfamiliar brought into a henhouse - a pipe
elbow or a hank of rope are enough to do the trick - will spook chickens into
riot. The flashpoint is even lower at a detention facility for illegal aliens
here: a rumor is enough to drive people wild.

The Krome Avenue Detention Facility, named for the nearest thoroughfare, which
years and years ago was named for a nearby farmer, has no more amenities than a
place for cows or domestic fowl. Its administrators, the United States
Immigration and Naturalization Service, are not proud of it. Seeking shelter as
well as a place for processing the waves of Cubans that hit here in 1980, the
Federal authorities settled on Krome, a closed missile base on the eastern edge
of the Everglades. It was to be a temporary expedient.

It is still in use. The Cuban crush diminished, but the flood of Haitian
refugees continued well into this year. Krome, a hangar an d atent holding camp
with an ''emergency'' capacity of 859 people, by midsummer was housing 1,500. To
relieve the overcrowding, the service was ' 'sponsoring out'' 50 Haitians a day
to relatives or volunteer org anizations. Miami, inundated by 125,000 Cubans the
year before, seein g approaching Haitian boats on the seascape every day,
screamed to t he Federal Government for relief.
'In a Detention Posture'

The resulting threat of Coast Guard interdiction on the high seas, the threat of
a permanent detention facility somewhere in the coldest part of this country and
the end of ''sponsoring out'' have stopped the tide of Haitians. As the year
ends, the naturalization service is in what it calls a ''detention posture.''
And a Haitian named Milus, the father of 10 children, is in his seventh month at
Krome.

''We get up and we eat,'' he said through a translator the other day. ''Then
they put us in the yard. The sun boils us. At midday they send us to eat again.
Then after we eat they send us inside. Then we lay on our beds. I have a Bible
but I cannot read. Some words I understand.''

Milus continued: ''I hold it and I look at it and sometimes I find a little word
that I understand and it stops me from going mad. There is a policeman at the
door and you cannot go out. You have no freedom. Later you can go out and if you
can find some water you can bathe. When I was in Haiti I thought I could work
much more here and support my children. Everywhere in Haiti they speak of
Miami.''

'I Will Carry Your Garbage'

Finally: ''If they would release me, even if there is no work outside, I will
find work. In Haiti you put your head upset down trying to find ways to get
money for your family. Can I clean your car? I will carry your garbage.
Anything.''

Milus (the naturalization service will not permit the use of the detainees' full
names) is one of 650 men still being held at Krome while civil liberties groups'
suits for Haitian rights inch their way through the courts. There are 50 Haitian
women now at the camp. Some detainees have been there as long as 10 months. One
of these, Lucian, believes that rumors drive the people madder than the long
days without a thing to do.

''All the time there are rumors in the yard,'' Lucian said. ''All the time. I
warn the people they talk too much. They listen to stupidities. They have crazy
things they say. People are losing their minds. Prison does that. It makes them
think and say crazy things. It is so crazy you cannot remember. You cannot hold
on to crazy things said to you.''

Start of Hunger Strike

False word of the death of a detainee can burn through the camp like a dynamite
fuse. It happened Nov. 6, putting Krome on edge for days. When someone falls ill
the suspicion is nearly always that he was poisoned. Anyone transferred is
always transferred to a hell much worse than Krome. On Christmas Eve, according
to the detainees, the message with no known origin was, ''Don't eat and they'll
let you out.''

A hunger strike began. On Sunday, 300 demonstrators f rom Miami's Haitian
community, having heard the detainees were fainting from hunger -and this, too,
a rumor - stormed the gate at Krome. Stones and bottles were thrown at guards.
The guards retaliated with tear gas. The demonstrators set small fires in the
sawgrass outside the camp. In the bald yard inside, 150 Haitian me n made a
break. Lucian says it was because the people in the yard sa w the smoke, heard
the commotion and bolted.

They scaled the 10-foot chain link fence at the back of the yard, grabbing the
strands of barbed wire on top and leaving behind little shreds of flesh.

Milus said the guards rushed back to stop the escapes with tear gas. ''A lot of
them were afraid because they had never been gassed before,'' he said, adding
that he had been through disturbances and tear gas at Krome before. ''The gas is
terrible because our eyes burn and our mouths burn and we can't breathe.''

''They don't have gas on La Gonave,'' he said, referring to the island in the
bay of Port-au-Prince from whence he came.
He Believes They Are in Montana

Milus said the gas stopped him from making it over the fence. A hundred men made
it. Milus does not know that. He and the others in the yard think they were
caught outside and taken to a prison in Montana, where they are freezing today.
(For a time, the service considered establishing a detention facility in
Glasgow, Montana, but the idea was abandoned.)

The Haitian said everyone was locked inside Sunday night. He said that on Monday
the immigration officials told them to stop the hunger strike and there would
not be any trouble. So they started eating, he said, giving an esentially
accurate account.

Now they are all back standing in the bright sun. A man named Escanej is telli
ng the latest story. He borrowed $800 from a money lender named Samson in
Port-au-Prince to pay for having himself smuggled to M iami on a plane. He was
supposed to pay it back at $300 a month for a year, such was the interest. But
he was picked up immediately, and has not made a single payment to his cousin,
who wassupposed to t urn the payments over to Samson. His cousin, the father of
six childr en, has since been found beaten to death in a cemetery. Tongues cluck
, and the story flies across the monotonous morning.
